  • Specifies that an unofficial canvass of election results may occur for a regular city or school election, and a primary election, in addition to the already established general election.
  • Requires the commissioner to provide an explanation in writing to the State Commissioner of Elections if in a canvass all precincts will not be reported before leaving the office.
  • Removes a provision allowing the county board of supervisors to meet on Monday after the election to canvass the vote, requiring them to meet on the Tuesday after the election, with certain exceptions for holidays.
  • Removes a provision allowing the controlling commission for a city election, or school board election, to meet on the second Monday after the election to canvass the vote, requiring them to meet on the second Tuesday after the election.
  • Requires that a recount be conducted in all counties, rather than specified counties, and modifies the request deadline to the second day after the county canvass in question, rather than the third day.
  • Specifies that a written request for a recount must indicate whether only automatic tabulating equipment will be used or if it should be followed by a hand recount, and provides that the request is by county.
  • Requires a notification of a request for recount to be sent to the state commissioner by electronic mail and changes the deadline for the commissioner to attempt to contact the winner by phone from four days to three days, before contacting the party chairperson.
  • Provides that a civil penalty of $100 against the candidate will be assessed for each office requested to be recounted, if a hand recount is not assessed, and will be deducted from the bond filed by the candidate.
  • Outlines notification procedures and timelines for the conduct of a hand recount and outlines the membership of a recount board based upon county population size.
  • Direct that the commissioner will convene the recount board by 9am on the sixth day following the canvass.
  • Outlines procedures for the recount board to complete the recount, including for a hand recount and directs that a written report of findings be submitted to the commissioner with specified instructions.
  • Directs the commissioner to correct a canvass, based on the recount results, as required by election code, if required.
  • Adds a deadline for the county board to reconvene if a recount report states that the county board's canvass was incorrect, and specifies deadlines for completing a recount and filing a report, by office.
  • Outlines procedures for a recount for any public measure including petition, timelines, type and scope of recount, petition signature requirements, notification and verification requirements, recount board membership and selection, and deadlines.
  • Provides that a commissioner may request an administrative audit in certain circumstances and that each party may appoint up to five observers to witness the audit, specifying how observers should be appointed.
  • Specifies procedures for what should be included when sending a voter an absentee ballot, including printing or stamping deadline notices and tracking options, and makes conforming changes.
  • Requires an absentee voter to sign the affidavit envelope and to mark the voter verification number and makes conforming changes.
  • Furnishes requirements for including a serial number on absentee ballot envelopes.
  • Includes primary elections with general elections in rules regarding preparation of a separate absentee ballot style for special precincts whose results will be reported separately.
  • Changes the number of members from seven to five from the both house and senate for a contest court for a contested gubernatorial election and adds the majority and minority leaders of each chamber.
  • Modifies the clerk of court for a contest for presidential electors or congresspeople, to be the clerk of the supreme court rather than the secretary of state, requiring the secretary of state to serve if the clerk of the supreme court is unable to act, and provides that the auditor of state will act if the secretary of state is unable.
  • Requires the senate to act as soon as possible when an impeachment is presented.
  • Provides that a special election for a Congressional vacancy will be convened when Congress is in session or will convene prior to the next general election.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: A bill for an act relating to the conduct of elections, including provisions related to absentee ballots, recounts, and contested gubernatorial elections and impeachments, making penalties applicable, and including effective date and applicability provisions.(Formerly HSB 719.)
most_recent_action: House Committee on Education Executive Session (16:00:00 16:00:00 House Committee on Education)
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Administrative deadlines,Audits,Transparency,Ballot access for candidates,Ballot design,Recalls,Counting and canvassing procedures,Certification,Recounts,Legislative authority
summary:
• Requires nomination papers be signed by eligible electors.
  • Allows one person who is a precinct election official, selected by the chief judge, to attend a primary election recount.
  • Changes deadlines for withdrawal of a candidate.
  • Establishes notification guidelines for a caucus and elections.
  • Establishes legal funding sources for elections. 
  • Requires the commissioner to make public notifications related to the election 30 days in advance, and including information about the post-election audit.
  • Allows the commissioner to use an electronic election register under certain conditions.
  • Requires public announcement of canvass results at a precinct when the canvass is done and someone at the precinct requests it.
  • Applies rules and timelines governing unofficial canvas of election results to all levels of election, and requires the commissioner to provide explanation in writing to the state commissioner if all precincts are not reported. 
  • Changes days appropriate officials meet to canvass the vote and conduct a second canvas.
  • Specifies requirements for ordering a recount and requirements for conducting it and reporting it.
  • Outlines requirements for appointment to observe an audit.
  • Provides relevant definitions.
  • Specifies requirements for processing absentee ballot applications, and what should be included, including tracking by the commissioner.
  • Specifies voter duties in filling out absentee ballots and envelopes and affidavits.
  • Outlines absentee ballot, envelope, and affidavit handling requirements and deadlines, including what to do when requirements are not met or a voter is deceased.
  • Specifies which elections require the commissioner to prepare a separate absentee ballot style for each precinct.
  • Outlines procedures for contested gubernatorial and lieutenant governor elections.
  • Specifies roles in the case of the clerk's absence.
  • Changes the timeline for an impeachment.
  • Outlines timelines for special elections to fill vacancies based on whether Congress is in session.

name: A bill for an act relating to the conduct of elections, including the counting and recounting of ballots and the certification of results.
most_recent_action: Introduced, referred to State Government. H.J. 236
summary:
• Removes the statement that a ballot will be rejected if the voter uses a mark to identify a voter's ballot.
  • Requires the board to certify an election canvas summary report no later than one week after convening. 
  • Requires the secretary of state to present to the board of state canvassers abstracts of votes cast at the election no later than 34 days after the election date.
  • Allows the county board of canvassers to order a recount of votes cast in each election precinct where a vote was cast for an office.
  • Requires the commissioner to send a copy of a request for recount to each commissioner of a county where elections were held immediately upon receipt of the request, requiring the commissioners in the county to conduct a recount.
  • Establishes a candidates for statewide office only be required to pay one bond for a recount.
  • Outlines the number of designees to attend a recount, based upon the number of ballots cast.
  • Requires recounts be conducted by hand. 
  • Clarifies that any mark in a "voting target" is a vote for a candidate, unless the board finds the voter made the mark by accident or attempted to erase the mark.
  • Establishes that at least two-thirds of members of the recount board must sign the written report of findings.

name: A bill for an act relating to the conduct of elections, including the recounting of ballots, the mailing of absentee ballots, and in-person absentee voting.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Administrative deadlines,Recounts
summary:
• Establishes the makeup of a recount board, based upon county population size.
  • Authorizes the recount board to oversee the recount.
  • Allows the recount board to conduct the recount, or allows them to direct the county commissioner and staff to conduct the recount, and amends related legislation.
  • Allows the recount board to re-tabulate ballots using the automatic tabulating equipment on a per precinct basis, and requires the board to examine each ballot the equipment identifies as containing an undervote, overvote, or write-in.
  • Requires two-thirds of the recount board to sign the written report.
  • Requires the commissioner to mail absentee ballots up to 45 days before an election, or the next day that is not a holiday.
  • Requires the commissioner to facilitate absentee in-person voting and satellite absentee voting up to 45 days before an election.

name: A bill for an act relating to the conduct of elections.
most_recent_action: Introduced, referred to State Government. H.J. 452.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Drop-box availability,In-person voter ID,Early voting administration,Early voting duration,Voter participation deadlines,In-person voting and polling places,Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Absentee/mail-in voter assistance
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Strikes a provision canceling a voter registration if the person does not vote in two election cycles.
  • Modifies the closing of polling places from 8:00pm to 9:00pm.
  • Adds a list of documents a voter may use at the polling place as identification.
  • Modifies the timeline for mailing an absentee ballot from no more than 20 days before an election to no more than 40 days.
  • Creates a requirement that a voter must require someone collecting and delivering their absentee ballot to complete a receipt upon picking up the ballot.
  • Modifies the timeline for the provision of facilities for completing an absentee ballot in person from 20 days before an election to 40 days, and requires they be established at the direction of the commissioner, without requiring a petition.
  • Requires the commissioner to establish a satellite Saturday absentee voting location, with specified requirements.
  • Furnishes that someone delivering an absentee ballot for a voter must mail it no later than the day before the election or with time enough to have the barcode traced to the day before the election, whichever is earlier.
  • Directs the commissioner to have at least one ballot dropbox for every 25,000 people in a county.
  • Requires absentee ballots be received by noon on the Monday after the election.
  • Modifies who may serve as a delivery agent, prohibiting only a candidate, and strikes language regarding reasons someone may need to use a delivery agent, thus not requiring an excuse.
  • Strikes provisions relating to a limit on the number of absentee ballots a delivery agent may deliver and the requirement that they be delivered in person.
  • Requires the Governor to immediately establish the right to vote and hold office to anyone who completed their sentence (confinement, parole, probation or supervised release) for an infamous crime, with exceptions.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: A bill for an act relating to the conduct of elections, including challenges to voter registrations by persons in other counties and the preparation of lists of registered voters, and making penalties applicable.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Establishes that the registration of a registered voter may be challenged by another registered voter of a county in which the challenged voter does not live, with certain requirements.
  • Specifies what must be included with a challenge.
  • Requires the state registrar of voters to create a form to allow a registered voter to challenge the registration of a registered voter in another county.
  • Provides that a challenger is not required to attend a hearing regarding a filed challenge.
  • Prohibits the registrar from imposing any requirements other than those required by code in preparation of a list of registered voters, and requires the registrar to immediately prepare a list of registered voters in certain situations.
  • Defines "bona fide political research."
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: A bill for an act relating to the conduct of elections, including the casting of provisional ballots by persons registering to vote on election day or when casting an in-person absentee ballot, and the use of automatic tabulating equipment and optical scan voting systems.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Removes the possibility for a person who registers on election day to vote a regular ballot, and instead requires the person to vote by provisional ballot.
  • Allows the commissioner to determine whether ballots will be counted by hand or electronically for all related elections.
  • Makes an optical scanning system optional rather than required.

name: A bill for an act relating to the conduct of elections, including provisions related to absentee ballots, recounts, and contested gubernatorial elections and impeachments, making penalties applicable, and including effective date provisions.(See HF 470.)
most_recent_action: Committee report approving bill, renumbered as HF 470.
categories: Election dates,Administrative deadlines,Audits,Transparency,Ballot access for candidates,Vacancy procedures,Counting and canvassing procedures,Certification,Recounts,Reporting,Voter participation deadlines,Ballot access deadlines,Provisional ballots,Challenges
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that a third board member selected by the chief judge in which a canvass occurs will convene with the board.
  • Changes a deadline for to withdraw from a nomination to fill a ballot vacancy from 64 days before the election to 67 days before the date of the election.
  • Provides that a political party may publish a notice on its website in lieu of a newspaper, specifies what information should be included, and specifies minimum requirements for the website.
  • Requires a challenger to post a bond at the time of filing a challenge and specifies related administrative procedures.
  • Changes the deadline for publishing notice of an election from 4-20 days before the election to 4-30 days before the election, and requires notification of the date the election will be audited, along with related information.
  • Requires public announcement of the total number of votes received by each candidate upon request of someone at the precinct when the canvass is complete.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Requires the commissioner to provide an explanation in writing if all precincts will bot be reported explaining why they will not be reported.
  • Modifies the day the county board of supervisors meet for the canvass from Monday and Tuesday after the day of each election, to just Tuesday after the election.
  • Furnishes that a county board of canvassers will order a recount all election precincts (rather than just specified precincts) if the request is made by the second day (rather than third day) following the canvass.
  • Requires the written request for the recount to specify whether the recount will be conducted using automatic tabulating equipment of by hand.
  • Specifies that a candidate requesting a hand recount in one county will also request hand recount in each county where the candidate requests a recount.
  • Adds the state commissioner to who must receive a copy of a request for recount and changes the deadline for contacting the apparent winner from within four days to within three days before next steps are taken.
  • Specifies what must be included in the report after the recount,and the deadlines by office.
  • Changes the term "administrative recount" to "administrative audit" in existing code.
  • Provides that each specified party may appoint up to five observers to witness an audit, and specifies procedures.
  • Provides that an absentee ballot will be enclosed in an unsealed affidavit envelope, and further procedures for envelope placement for delivery of a ballot, and specifies how to affidavit is to be signed and verified on the envelope.
  • Clarifies further requirements for the absentee ballot return envelopes related to providing deadlines and tracking.
  • Requires the commissioners to review the affidavit envelope for completeness and voter verification number.
  • Outlines procedures for if the voter verification number does not match the one associated with the voter's registration.
  • Removes secrecy folders and leaves only secrecy envelopes for provisional ballots.
  • Requires the majority and minority leaders to serve on the contest court, along with five (rather than seven) members each.
  • Supplies that the clerk of the supreme court will be the clerk of court, rather than the secretary of state, unless the clerk is unable or absent.
  • Specifies that a special election to fill a vacancy in congress will be held when congress is in session or will convene prior to the next general election.

name: A bill for an act relating to the administration of elections.
most_recent_action: Subcommittee reassigned: Salmon, Boulton, and Schultz.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Removes an exception about when a commissioner's office will close for registration if deadline falls on the day after Thanksgiving.
  • Requires the state commissioner to adopt rules to implement instruction for precinct election officials, and removes the requirement that at least two precinct election officials be present.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Requires a commissioner to provide an explanation in writing if all precinct results are not reported.
  • Specifies data to be included in the written report by commissioners at the conclusion of a recount.

name: A bill for an act relating to the conduct of elections, including the recounting of ballots, the mailing of absentee ballots, and in-person absentee voting.
most_recent_action: Subcommittee: Schultz, Bousselot, and Jochum. S.J. 323.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Counting and canvassing procedures,Recounts
summary:
As introduced, this bill: 

  • Requires recount boards for counties with less than 25,000 people to have 2 designees for the requesting candidate, 2 designees for the current highest vote receiving candidate, and an individual chosen by the other 4 designees. 
  • Requires recount boards for counties will less than 90,000 but more than 25,000 to have 3 designees for the requesting candidate, 3 designees for the current highest vote receiving candidate, and an individual chosen by the other 6 designees. 
  • Requires recount boards for counties will more than 90,000 to have 3 designees for the requesting candidate, 3 designees for the current highest vote receiving candidate, and 3 individuals chosen by the other 6 designees. 
  • Allows recount boards to either complete the recount or have the county commissioner complete the recount. If the county commissioner is charged with the recount, the recount board will still oversee it. 
  • Allows the recount board to request a retabulation via automatic tabulating equipment per precinct, if they do, each undervote, overvote, or write-in ballot will be reviewed by the board. 
  • Requires the report from the board be signed by at least 2/3 of the board’s members. 
  • Changes the mailing of absentee ballots and absentee in person voting time frame from 20 days before the election or less to 45 days or less.

summary:
• Outlines absentee ballot submission guidelines for Address Confidentiality Program participants.
  • Lays out appointment limitations for conference board appointees. 
  • Adds actions to the list of behaviors leading to election misconduct in the first, second, third degree.
  • Adds actions to the list of behaviors leading to technical infractions.
  • Requires the state commissioner to immediately notify the attorney general and county attorney of election law violations or misconduct.
  • Requires the attorney general or county attorney to investigate reported election misconduct and implementation of certain actions based on the outcome of the investigation.
  • Precludes nomination papers being filed on behalf of a candidate if papers were already filed on behalf of the candidate for the same office and the same year.
  • Outlines signature requirements for nomination papers.
  • Outlines requirements for nonparty political organizations to nominate a candidate through convention or caucus, including minimum numbers of eligible electors required.
  • Outlines nominating petition signature requirements for statewide and federal office holders.
  • Allows the state commissioner of elections to issue guidance clarifying election law.
  • Stipulates that the county commissioner of elections does not possess home rule powers related to conduct of elections.
  • Requires the state registrar to quarterly conduct voter verification in the statewide voter registration file, with specific guidelines and timelines
  • Requires the state registrar to use information from the Electronic Registration Information Center and the department of transportation to update voter registrations.
  • Requires the voter identification card to include the times during which polling places are open on election days.
  • Provides timelines for verifying or rejecting a change of address notification.
  • Requires the commissioner to participate in the US Postal Service national change of address program and verify voter registration through a specific related process.
  • Changes deadlines related to voter change of address verification.
  • Requires a cancellation of voter registration if a voter's registration record has been inactive for two successive general elections.
  • Outlines reporting and publication requirements for the commissioner of registration.
  • Requires the state registrar of voters to conduct audits of voter registration maintenance in certain timelines and outlines related actions.
  • Outlines oversight guidelines by the state commissioner of the county commissioner and defines "oversee."
  • Requires a person on the precinct election board who changes political party within 30 days of the election be immediately removed from the board.
  • Outlines notification requirements for change of precinct polling place.
  • Requires public notification of polling place hours on a website by November 7, 2024.
  • Prohibits someone running for office from assisting a voter in the voting booth.
  • Prohibits precinct election officials or county commissioners from interfering with someone who is voting and outlines penalties.
  • Entitles voters two consecutive hours of time off from work to vote.
  • Allows members of local law enforcement and state patrol to take "reasonable actions" to prevent election violations.
  • Sets a timeline for a commissioner to send an absentee ballot application and requires certain actions in a public health disaster.
  • Prohibits prefilling absentee ballot applications, except for ballot type and date of the election, and prohibits sending absentee ballot applications without a submitted request.
  • Outlines timeline requirements for sending absentee ballots based on receipt date of the application.
  • Outlines reporting requirements for absentee ballots.
  • Requires the commissioner to enclose information with an absentee ballot about return by a person not prohibited to collect and deliver the ballot, including outlining who may drop off an absentee ballot.
  • Requires absentee voting in-person and satellite absentee voting 20 days before the election.

summary:
• Allows special elections to be additionally held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November.
  • Requires the proposed Constitutional amendment be considered a public measure.
  • Allows election officials to hold a second elected office if 30 days or less remain in the term of the first office.
  • Authorizes a political party or nonparty political organization to intervene in certain proceedings or court actions to challenge an election provision, including petitioning the court and the authority to appeal.
  • Allows nomination papers on behalf of a candidate to be filed 92-74 days before the election, with the withdrawal deadline no later than 69 days before the election.
  • Requires new deadlines in case of candidate withdrawal or death before an election.
  • Sustains objections when incorrect or incomplete information is submitted for nominating petitions or certificates.
  • Sets new deadlines related to filing objections for nomination petitions or certificates, and withdrawal of candidacy.
  • Requires a likeness of the county seal to appear on ballots, and requires counties to have only one official seal.
  • Amends quantities of required signatures for nomination of candidates to county offices.
  • Forbids a commissioner from sending change of address and return cards to voters who will be under 18 years of age on the date of the general election.
  • Requires the commissioner to accept notification of death from the federal social security administration.
  • Allows the state registrar of voters to set the audit schedule within certain parameters.
  • Sets deadlines for the commissioner drawing lots for ballot position. 
  • Requires certain notifications be placed on ballots for presidential elections.
  • Requires the commissioner to summarize constitutional amendments and other public measures. 
  • Sets specific election notification requirements and publication of ballot requirements.
  • Specifies the oath for board members before opening the polls.
  • Requires proof of identity by voters before signing an oath or casting a provisional ballot.
  • Sets a new timeline for certification of sample ballots.
  • Allows election officials to deliver election results in person at the request of the commissioner conducting the election, and specifies certain required procedures. 
  • Requires write-in candidates receiving fewer than ten votes and not winning the election to be reporting collectively under the heading "scattering."
  • Requires the state commissioner to order an audit before every election.
  • Requires voters to date their absentee ballot request form.
  • Outlines circumstances in which a satellite absentee voting station may be rejected, and exceptions.
  • Requires the state commissioner to create an application where a voter can track his or her absentee ballot and absentee ballot request form by February 26, 2024, and requires specific information be included.
  • Specifies rules related to the lawful and unlawful return of an absentee ballot. 
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Specifies compensation for presidential electors.
  • Requires new deadlines for hospital trustees.

name: A bill for an act relating to the conduct of elections, including absentee ballots and voter list maintenance activities, making penalties applicable, and including effective date provisions.(Formerly HSB 213.)
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Administrative deadlines,Transparency,States of emergency,Ballot access for parties,Nonpartisan elections,Counting and canvassing procedures,Enforcement against officials,Election officials,Legal causes of action,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance,Ballot collection,Physical security
summary:
This bill adds ways election officials can fail in their duties including disregarding or hindering the law and inadequate voter list maintenance. This bill prohibits election officials serving as a member of the challenging committee while also serving as a precinct official at the polls, making it a third degree misconduct charge. This bill also makes interfering with a person permitted at a polling place a third degree misconduct charge. This bill classifies the following as election misconduct: return of an absentee ballot to a drop box by a person prohibited from collecting and delivering completed absentee ballots, and making a false statement reporting that an absentee ballot was returned to a drop box by a person prohibited from delivering ballots. This bill required that a state commissioner impose a fine of $10,000 or less upon a technical infraction by a county commissioner and outlines the process of paying the fine and possible suspension. This bill requires the state commissioner to immediately inform the attorney general and relevant county attorney if a technical infraction may constitute election misconduct. This bill requires the attorney general to investigate allegations of election misconduct reported to him or her, or to the county attorney and requires certain related actions. This bill requires nomination papers in partisan nominations be signed by eligible electors. 

This bill requires nonparty political organizations to have a minimum of 500 eligible electors at its convention or caucus to nominate candidates for statewide office, 200 eligible electors for US representative, 20 eligible electors for county or city office, 25 eligible electors for representative in the general assembly, and 50 eligible electors for a state senatorial district. This bill also states a candidate who has been nominated under a political party is not eligible for a nonparty nomination for the same office in the same election year. This bill requires nomination petitions for candidates for US Senator, President, Vice President, Governor, and Lieutenant Governor be signed by at least 3,500 eligible voters with at least 100 of the voters coming from at least 19 counties. This bill also states that nomination petitions for other statewide offices must be signed by at least 2,500 eligible voters including at least 77 from at least 18 counties. This bill requires nomination petitions for US House of Representatives be signed by at least 1,726 eligible voters with at least 47 voters from at least one-half of the counties in the district. This bill further makes changes to the number of signatories on nomination petitions for county-wide office, county supervisor, city offices, and special charter city offices. 

This bill allows the state commissioner of elections to issue guidance to clarify election laws. This bill clarifies that the county commissioner of elections doe not have home rule powers related to the conduct of elections. This bill outlines quarterly voter verification, reporting, and report publication requirements for the state registrar and allows the registrar to pursue related third party vendor contracts. This bill also requires the state registrar to use information from the Electronic Registration Information Center to update voter information. This bill requires each commissioner to update registration information using specific guidelines, and follow specific reporting requirements. This bill allows for a voter registration to be canceled if the voters registration record has been inactive for two successive general elections. This bill outlines certain procedures and rules for the state registrar to conduct an audit. This bill allows the state commissioner or their designee to oversee activities of county election commissioners under certain circumstances, defining "oversee." This bill specifies a person serving on a precinct election board who changes political party within 30 days of an election will be immediately removed from the board. This bill specifies that a voter may choose anyone to assist them in voting, except someone whose name is on the ballot. This bill prohibits an election official or county commissioner from obstructing or interfering with a person's role or duty and specifies penalties. This bill allows members of law enforcement to take "all reasonable actions" to prevent election violations. This bill allows voters to apply for absentee ballots no more than 70 days before the election and specifies when a commissioner may not sent an absentee ballot. This bill specifies that absentee ballot applications may not have prefilled fields, except type and date of election. This bill specifies requirements for commissioners in handling absentee ballot applications arriving at certain times, and specifies reporting requirements for absentee ballots. This bill specifies that absentee ballots must include a statement that they may be returned to certain drop boxes under certain conditions. This bill prohibits election officials from mailing an absentee ballot to anyone not submitting an application. This bill requires a commissioner to provide absentee in-person voting no more than 18 days before an election, and to create satellite absentee voting stations when receiving a petition meeting certain requirements. This bill removes the postmark requirement for return absentee envelopes and relies on a postal service barcode. This bill outlines requirements for handling return absentee envelopes including drop box requirements, deadlines, security, accessibility, retrieval of ballots, and processing. This bill defines relevant terms. This bill specifies processes for voter affidavits lacking specific requirements and outlines requirements. This bill specifies information required for record keeping of absentee ballots by the commissioner. This bill specifies requirements for if a voter is hospitalized after the deadline for a written application for an absentee ballot and how to return the ballot. This bill specifies requirements for handling, recording, and reporting on signed affidavits and reconciling them with the number of ballots counted. This bill specifies who may return a completed absentee ballot. This bill specifies that an appointed or elective officer may be removed by impeachment for failure to pay a fine. This bill requires vacancy appointments by the board of supervisors be until the next general elections and requires if a petition is circulated and filed within 14 days of the publication only to be valid of the signature is dated prior to the date the appointment was made. This bill removes the provision that a special election not be held on the same day as a school election. This bill provides for the county attorney bringing actions for failure to pay fines.

name: A bill for an act relating to the conduct of elections, including absentee ballots and voter list maintenance activities, making penalties applicable, and including effective date provisions.(See SF 413.)
most_recent_action: Committee report approving bill, renumbered as SF 413.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Administrative deadlines,Transparency,States of emergency,Ballot access for parties,Nonpartisan elections,Counting and canvassing procedures,Enforcement against officials,Election officials,Legal causes of action,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance,Ballot collection,Physical security
summary:
This bill adds ways election officials can fail in their duties including disregarding or hindering the law and inadequate voter list maintenance. This bill prohibits election officials serving as a member of the challenging committee while also serving as a precinct official at the polls, making it a third degree misconduct charge. This bill also makes interfering with a person permitted at a polling place a third degree misconduct charge. This bill classifies the following as election misconduct: return of an absentee ballot to a drop box by a person prohibited from collecting and delivering completed absentee ballots, and making a false statement reporting that an absentee ballot was returned to a drop box by a person prohibited from delivering ballots. This bill required that a state commissioner impose a fine of $10,000 or less upon a technical infraction by a county commissioner and outlines the process of paying the fine and possible suspension. This bill requires the state commissioner to immediately inform the attorney general and relevant county attorney if a technical infraction may constitute election misconduct. This bill requires the attorney general to investigate allegations of election misconduct reported to him or her, or to the county attorney and requires certain related actions. This bill requires nomination papers in partisan nominations be signed by eligible electors. 

This bill requires nonparty political organizations to have a minimum of 500 eligible electors at its convention or caucus to nominate candidates for statewide office, 200 eligible electors for US representative, 20 eligible electors for county or city office, 25 eligible electors for representative in the general assembly, and 50 eligible electors for a state senatorial district. This bill also states a candidate who has been nominated under a political party is not eligible for a nonparty nomination for the same office in the same election year. This bill requires nomination petitions for candidates for US Senator, President, Vice President, Governor, and Lieutenant Governor be signed by at least 3,500 eligible voters with at least 100 of the voters coming from at least 19 counties. This bill also states that nomination petitions for other statewide offices must be signed by at least 2,500 eligible voters including at least 77 from at least 18 counties. This bill requires nomination petitions for US House of Representatives be signed by at least 1,726 eligible voters with at least 47 voters from at least one-half of the counties in the district. This bill further makes changes to the number of signatories on nomination petitions for county-wide office, county supervisor, city offices, and special charter city offices. 

This bill allows the state commissioner of elections to issue guidance to clarify election laws. This bill clarifies that the county commissioner of elections doe not have home rule powers related to the conduct of elections. This bill outlines quarterly voter verification, reporting, and report publication requirements for the state registrar and allows the registrar to pursue related third party vendor contracts. This bill also requires the state registrar to use information from the Electronic Registration Information Center to update voter information. This bill requires each commissioner to update registration information using specific guidelines, and follow specific reporting requirements. This bill allows for a voter registration to be canceled if the voters registration record has been inactive for two successive general elections. This bill provides for electronic records to include a status code designating whether records are active and specifies actions to be taken for inactive records. This bill outlines certain procedures and rules for the state registrar to conduct an audit. This bill allows the state commissioner or their designee to oversee activities of county election commissioners under certain circumstances, defining "oversee." This bill specifies a person serving on a precinct election board who changes political party within 30 days of an election will be immediately removed from the board. This bill specifies that a voter may choose anyone to assist them in voting, except someone whose name is on the ballot. This bill prohibits an election official or county commissioner from obstructing or interfering with a person's role or duty and specifies penalties. This bill allows members of law enforcement to take "all reasonable actions" to prevent election violations. This bill allows voters to apply for absentee ballots no more than 70 days before the election and specifies when a commissioner may not sent an absentee ballot. This bill specifies that absentee ballot applications may not have prefilled fields, except type and date of election. This bill specifies requirements for commissioners in handling absentee ballot applications arriving at certain times, and specifies reporting requirements for absentee ballots. This bill specifies that absentee ballots must include a statement that they may be returned to certain drop boxes under certain conditions. This bill prohibits election officials from mailing an absentee ballot to anyone not submitting an application. This bill requires a commissioner to provide absentee in-person voting no more than 18 days before an election, and to create satellite absentee voting stations when receiving a petition meeting certain requirements. This bill removes the postmark requirement for return absentee envelopes and relies on a postal service barcode. This bill outlines requirements for handling return absentee envelopes including drop box requirements, deadlines, security, accessibility, retrieval of ballots, and processing. This bill defines relevant terms. This bill specifies processes for voter affidavits lacking specific requirements and outlines requirements. This bill specifies information required for record keeping of absentee ballots by the commissioner. This bill specifies requirements for if a voter is hospitalized after the deadline for a written application for an absentee ballot and how to return the ballot. This bill specifies requirements for handling, recording, and reporting on signed affidavits and reconciling them with the number of ballots counted. This bill specifies who may return a completed absentee ballot. This bill specifies that an appointed or elective officer may be removed by impeachment for failure to pay a fine. This bill requires vacancy appointments by the board of supervisors be until the next general elections and requires if a petition is circulated and filed within 14 days of the publication only to be valid of the signature is dated prior to the date the appointment was made. This bill removes the provision that a special election not be held on the same day as a school election. This bill provides for the county attorney bringing action for failure to pay fines.

name: Amends existing law to revise provisions regarding voter identification and proof of residence.
most_recent_action: Delivered to Governor at 10:35 a.m. on March 30, 2023
categories: Voter ID for registration,Voter ID for low-income voters,Voter registration,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Directs the secretary of state to provide a registration application form, lists information required for the oath, and requires a signature.
  • Requires those registering to vote to provide proof of identity and residence and lists acceptable proofs.
  • Prohibits the use of a post office box address document for proof of residency.
  • Requires the registration application to include a warning regarding use of false information specifying that it is perjury.
  • Directs the county clerk to upload valid registration applications to the statewide voter registration database and specifies that they are confidential.
  • Furnishes that the statewide voter registration database maintained by the secretary of state is the official register of voters.
  • Specifies that Election Day registration may occur at an absent voter's polling place or early voting station.
  • Directs the department to issue a no-fee, four-year ID card to eligible voters, with certain specifications and requirements, and allows for one free replacement and for renewals.

name: Amends existing law to revise provisions regarding voter registration and voter identification.
most_recent_action: Take bill off General Orders; referred to State Affairs
categories: Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,Voter ID for registration
summary: As introduced, this bill requires proof of identity and residence to register to vote including in-person at an early voting or polling station or by mail. The bill sets forth what types of documents constitute proof of identity or residence.

name: Adds to existing law to prohibit the use of ranked choice voting in Idaho.
most_recent_action: Reported Signed by Governor on March 24, 2023 Session Law Chapter 135 Effective: 07/01/2023
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Prohibits ranked choice voting or instant runoff voting for any election or candidate nomination in the state.
  • Defines "local government," "ranked choice voting," "instant runoff voting."
  • Provides that any local ordinance in conflict with this legislation is void.

name: Amends and repeals existing law to consolidate presidential primaries with the primary election.
most_recent_action: Delivered to Governor at 9 a.m. on March 28, 2023
summary: As introduced, this bill eliminates the presidential primary date and combines it with the general primary date on the third Thursday in May.

name: Amends existing law to revise provisions regarding the deadline to change political party affiliation or unaffiliated designation.
summary: • Removes provisions for affiliating with a party as an unaffiliated elector.

name: Various election law matters.
most_recent_action: Third reading: passed; Roll Call 255: yeas 49, nays 1
summary: • Allows stored ballots to be unsealed by order of Secretary of State or the county clerk when there is a challenge by a candidate or organization affiliated with a ballot measure, or for a recount.

name: Amends existing law to provide for the filling of certain school board trustee vacancies.
summary:
• Directs that the term of incumbent trustees elected as of July 1, 2018 will expire January 1 following the November election.
  • Requires the election date for the recall of a school district trustee follow Idaho Code.
  • Outlines procedures, including timelines, for filling a vacancy or vacancies on the school board of trustees, including possibly appointing temporary trustees.

name: Adds to and amends existing law to allow the Secretary of State or a county clerk to petition for judicial review of an election when it appears that an error occurred in the administration of the election and the error might be sufficient to change the outcome of the election.
most_recent_action: Senator Rogers added as second sponsor
summary:
• Outlines a procedure for judicial review of election results, including timetable and notifications.
  • Outlines district court roles and powers in the case of juridical review of an election.

name: Amends existing law to revise provisions regarding accepted voter identification at the polls.
most_recent_action: Reported Signed by Governor on March 15, 2023 Session Law Chapter 27 Effective: 01/01/2024
summary: As introduced, this bill removes student IDs as acceptable proof of identity for voting purposes at polling places.

name: Amends and adds to existing law to provide for State Board of Education member elections.
most_recent_action: Filed in Office of the Chief Clerk
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Establishes that starting in 2024, seven state board of education members will be elected and outlines their terms of office, election zones, and other candidacy requirements.
  • Implements that state board of education members will be elected by voters in the zone they seek to represent and that those receiving the plurality of votes will win the election.
  • Furnishes procedures, fees, and requirements for filing for candidacy.
  • Provides that for state board of education office, a petition with 500 signatures from the proper zone can be submitted rather than paying a filing fee.
  • Provides that state board of education members will be paid $12,000 per year and outlines a policy for reimbursement of expenses and per diem.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Directs that the state superintendent will serve as the chair of the state board of education.
  • Outlines vacancy procedures.

name: Amends existing law to provide for State Board of Education member elections.
most_recent_action: Reported Printed and Referred to Education

name: Amends and adds to existing law to provide for the registration and training of signature gatherers for initiative and referendum petitions.
most_recent_action: Reported Printed and Referred to State Affairs

name: Amends and adds to existing law to provide for a voters' guide with candidate information to be prepared by the Secretary of State.
most_recent_action: Read First Time, Referred to State Affairs
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the secretary of state to prepare and distribute a voters' guide before each primary and general election with information on issues, measure, and candidates. The content form and distribution of the guide are explained.

name: Amends existing law to provide that, effective in 2024, school board trustees will be elected to two-year terms at general elections.
most_recent_action: House State Affairs Committee (09:00:00 09:00:00 Room EW40)
categories: Election dates,Alignment of elections,Ballot access for candidates
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Specifies that the term of school district trustees is two years (from four years) starting at the general election on November 5, 2024.
  • Provides that trustees elected prior to November 5, 2024 will serve out the remainder of their term, and if required, a vacancy election will be held at the end of the term.
  • Changes the day of school district trustee elections from the Tuesday following the first Monday in November in odd-numbered years, to the day of the general election.
  • Requires school trustee candidates to declare a political party, or unaffiliated status when filing candidacy.

name: Amends existing law to provide an exemption from postelection audits for selected ballots.
most_recent_action: Read First Time, Referred to State Affairs
summary: As introduced, this bill exempts any precinct reporting election results meeting the free recount threshold from postelection audits.

name: Amends existing law to provide requirements for postelection audits ordered by the Secretary of State.
most_recent_action: Reported Signed by Governor on February 21, 2023 Session Law Chapter 2 Effective: 07/01/2023
summary:
• Requires ballots to be returned to the custody of the county clerk after an audit.
  • Requires ballots to be returned to the custody of the county sheriff in the case of a recount.
  • Lists minimum requirements for a postelection audit.

name: Amends existing law to move city elections to even-numbered years.
most_recent_action: Reported Printed; referred to State Affairs
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the election date for city elections to be held in even-numbered years.

name: Amends existing law to provide for automatic voter registration through the Division of Motor Vehicles.
most_recent_action: Reported Printed and Referred to Ways & Means
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 27, 2023, creates a process to automatically register individuals (unless they opt-out) to vote when they apply for a new, renewal, or change to a state driver’s license at the division of motor-vehicles.

name: Adds to existing law to require notification of boundary changes for election zones, districts, and subdistricts.
most_recent_action: Reported Signed by Governor on March 25, 2022 Session Law Chapter 257 Effective: 07/01/2022
summary: • Requires a city or district with governing members elected by separate zones, districts, or subdistricts to notify the county clerk within 30 days of approved changes to district boundaries.

name: Adds to existing law to authorize either or both houses of the Legislature to intervene in certain actions regarding constitutionality of an Idaho statute.
summary: • Allows the legislature to intervene when a party challenges the constitutionality of an Idaho statute by serving a motion upon the parties.

name: Amends and adds to existing law to provide that a person's residence for voting purposes shall be the homestead for which the person claims a certain tax exemption and to provide for an investigation into candidate qualifications.
most_recent_action: Reported Signed by Governor on March 21, 2022 Session Law Chapter 81 Effective: 03/21/2022
summary:
• Specifies procedures for if a voter claims a homestead exemption.
  • Provides provisions for investigating a candidates qualification for office.
  • Requires a declaration of candidacy include a sworn verification that the candidate satisfies legal qualifications for office, including disclosure of the homestead exemption.
  • Requires the state tax commission to disclose information about an improper claim for homestead exemption to the county clerk and secretary of state, who are to use it to determine a person's voting residence. 
  • Requires the state tax commission to establish a searchable database of active homestead exemptions accessible to relevant officials.

name: Amends, repeals, and adds to existing law to revise provisions regarding voter identification.
most_recent_action: Introduced, read first time; referred to: State Affairs
categories: In-person voter ID,Voter ID for registration,Voter registration,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
• Outlines acceptable forms of identification for registering to vote, including for proof of identity and proof of citizenship.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create and maintain a voter registration website.
  • Specifies requirements for verification of online and mailed registration in certain circumstances.
  • Specifies individuals using the federal voter registration form, not providing identification required by Idaho law, will only be eligible to vote for federal office.
  • Specifies required information for a voter registration oath or affirmation.
  • Creates and funds an election integrity fund.
  • Specifies that certain code must be followed regarding acceptable personal identification at the polls.
  • Specifies all records to be retained for five years after an election.
  • Requires voter registration through the department of motor vehicles include proof of citizenship.
  • Requires drivers licenses or identification cards of US citizens have a notation "USA" included on the license.
  • Requires the motor vehicle department to keep records of the proof relied upon to determine citizenship status of an applicant.
  • Requires the motor vehicles department to issue a free identification card under certain circumstances and requires the applicant to submit proof of citizenship, identity, and date of birth.

name: Amends and adds to existing law to provide for postelection audits of selected paper ballots in certain elections by the Secretary of State.

• Specifies that stored ballots may be unsealed and resealed as part of a post election audit.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to identify and order a post election audit of certain paper ballots cast in any election, with notification requirements.
  • Specifies procedures related to the post election audit.
  • Specifies which elections may be audited and how precincts may be chosen for audit. 
  • Allows the Secretary of State to select certain ballots from early and absentee ballot voting for an audit.
  • Allows the Secretary of State to conduct the audit and requires the county clerk to facilitate it.
  • Specifies procedures for the audit, including who may attend it, the timetable, notifications, observers, reporting, costs and payment, and follow up.

  • Requires those registering electronically, or by mail, to vote in-person at least once before being able to vote absentee, with certain exceptions.
  • Outlines required identification for mail-in registration and registration applications.
  • Removes provisions related to unaffiliated party affiliation.
  • Outlines certain requirements for absentee ballot applications.
  • Removes the possibility of electronic transmission of completed absentee ballots.
  • Outlines content requirements for the absentee ballot return envelope.
  • Requires the absentee ballot be returned by mail or delivered personally by hand.
  • Aligns rules regarding voter identification at the polls.
  • Requires a voter without proper identification to complete an affidavit on a secure envelope, place his or her ballot in the envelope, and return to the polling place within two business days with proper identification. 
  • Provides instructions to the clerk in the case of a provisional ballot.



  • Removes provisions related to voter registration including where a registration may be delivered and provisions related to unaffiliated voter registration and voting.
  •  and includes a list of acceptable forms of identification when registering.
  • Provides that a first time voter registrant using the federal application form who did not provide voter identification required by Idaho law will only be eligible to vote in federal races.
  • Includes all information required under oath for voter registration.
  • Provides for a provisional ballot when a voter lacks proper identification and outlines administrative actions to be taken with the provisional ballot.
  • Removes student identification cards as acceptable identification at the polls. 
  • Requires certain county records be maintain for five years, adding provisional ballot envelopes to the list.
  • Removes election day registration from early absentee voting rules.

name: Amends, adds to, and repeals existing law to provide for nonpartisan primary elections and ranked-choice voting in general elections.
most_recent_action: Reported Printed; referred to State Affairs
summary:
• Defines terms including "nonpartisan primary election," "precinct captain election," "presidential primary," "ranked choice voting."
  • Outlines the method to be used for ranked choice voting and rules for counting ballots using the method.
  • Removes provisions for unaffiliated voters in primary elections by mail.
  • Requires unaffiliated voters to declare which precinct captain or presidential primary election ballot they wish to vote and aligns relevant rules.
  • Establishes that for nonpartisan primaries, every voter will receive the same ballot.
  • Specifies an elector may change political party affiliation for precinct caption and presidential primary elections within certain guidelines. 
  • Removes certain requirements for write in candidates in nonpartisan primaries.
  • Clarifies that nonpartisan primary elections determine four candidates to appear on the general election ballot, not based upon party.
  • Clarifies that candidates for judicial office will be nominated at the judicial nominating election.

  • Specifies with which office each level of candidate needs to file candidacy.
  • Specifies the procedure for notifying parties of declared candidates affiliated with the party.
  • Amends certification of candidate procedures by the Secretary of State. 
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide a sample form for presidential primaries, nonpartisan primary elections, and precinct captain races to each county clerk.
  • Requires the county clerk to prepare a sample primary and precinct captain ballot for upcoming elections, including names of all candidates.
  • Specifies procedures and timelines for filling vacancies in nonpartisan primary races and precinct captain elections.
  • Specifies procedures for filling vacancies for nonpartisan judicial races.
  • Amends administrative procedures for withdrawal of candidacy.
  • Requires presidential primary elections to be conducted by laws governing elections for federal office in a general election.
  • Allows candidates for precinct captain to seek one additional office in a nonpartisan primary election.
  • Outlines requirements for primary nonpartisan election ballots and precinct captain election ballots.
  • Adds precinct captain elections to rules for eligibility to vote in presidential primary elections, and rules for absentee ballot applications and issuance of absentee ballots.
  • Outlines rules for what must be printed on ballots for the general election.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create and disseminate widely voter education materials for nonpartisan primary elections, and general elections at least 60 days before the election.
  • Removes certain requirements on absentee ballot applications related to unaffiliated voters.   
  • Outlines rules and procedures for certificate of nomination for nonpartisan primary elections and precinct captain elections.
