summary:
• Requires incumbent trustees elected after July 1, 2018 terms to expire January 1 after the November election.
  • Requires the election date of a recall election for school board trustee to be determined by Idaho Code.
  • Outlines provisions for filling a vacancy in the case of a recall or resignation of a board of trustees member(s), including the timeline and temporary appointments.

name: ELEC CODE-INCARCERATED BAN
most_recent_action: Added Co-Sponsor Rep. Kevin John Olickal
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:
• Removes a clause that excludes those prohibited from voting in the definition of the term "population."
  • Deletes a prohibition on voting by those who are imprisoned.

name: GENERAL ELECTION DAY
summary: As introduced, this bill designated general election day as a state holiday and is considered a legal school holiday. Closed schools can be used as polling places.

name: ELECTIONS-SERVICE OF NOTICE
summary: As introduced, this bill permits election authorities to authorize service of objections to candidate nominations through e-mail if the election authority requires candidates and objectors to provide an e-mail address and publishes notice on its website of its decision to authorize service of objections to candidate nominations through e-mail.

name: ELECT CODE-ELECTION JUDGES
summary: As introduced, this bill allows an election authority to reduce the number of election judges in each precinct from 5 to 3 for any election with certain exceptions and requires the board of commissions to choose no less than 3 persons as election judges for each precinct in certain cities, villages, and incorporated towns.

name: DIRECT RECORDING ELEC VOTING
most_recent_action: Senate Committee Amendment No. 1 Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments
summary: This bill will require voting machines to be approved by the State Board of Elections and repeals Direct Recording Electronic Voting Systems Article.

name: ELECTIONS-REMOTE ACCESS VOTE
most_recent_action: Senate Committee Amendment No. 1 Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the State Board of Elections to provide a certified remote accessible vote by mail system to voters with a print disability which allows them to receive a vote by mail ballot delivered through electronic transmission, ensures they are able to complete all aspects of the vote by mail, and electronically authenticate a vote by mail ballot without assistance.

name: ELECTION CD-OBJECTION NOTICE
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot measures (initiative and referendum),Challenges
summary: As introduced, this bill requires, as it relates to the receipt of a certificate of nomination, nomination papers, or proposed ballot question and an objector's petition, the chair of the electoral board to send a call notice by registered or certified mail to the election authority where the ballot is certified and the appropriate county clerk.

name: ELECTIONS-JUDGE COMPENSATION
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the State Board of Elections to reimburse a county up to $50 for an amount paid to an election judge that is in excess of $100 per day.

name: ELECTION-INCAPACITATED ELECTOR
summary: As introduced, this bill allows a physically incapacitated person to vote by mail rather than only on specified facilities.

name: ELECTIONS-PETITION/FILING DATE
ELECTIONS-VOTE BY MAIL NOTICE
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election authority to notify all qualified voters of the option for permanent vote by mail status using the authority’s notice and vote by mail application, except voters who have applied for permanent vote by mail status or voters who have requested to be excluded from the permanent vote by mail status.

name: ELECTION CD-VOTE CENTERS
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election authority establishing one polling location in the largest municipality where all voters in the jurisdiction are allowed to vote to identify the location and health precautions 40 days before an election and to certify the location.

name: ELEC CD-ELECTORAL COLLEGE
summary:
• Requires that one elector for US President and Vice President come from each congressional district.
  • Allows the State Convention or State central committee of a party to choose two electors at-large.
  • Makes complying changes to Election Code.
  • Requires each congressional district elector to cast his or her ballot for the candidate who received the highest number of votes in the congressional district.
  • Requires each at-large elector to cast his or her ballot for the candidate who received the highest number of votes in the state.

name: ELEC CD-PRE-REGISTRATION
summary:
As introduced, this bill: 

  • Allows the State Board of Elections to receive voter registration information provided by applicants using an electronic voter registration portal.
  • Allows a person who is prequalified to vote may preregister on their 16th birthday with the registration held in abeyance until that individual attains the required age to vote. Preregistration must be completed using the online voter registration system or an electronic voter registration portal.
  • Allows a prequalified person who is 17 years old and will be 18 years on the date of the next general or consolidated election is deemed eligible to circulate a nominating petition or a petition proposing a public question.

name: Election Law - Ballot Processing and Reporting Procedures and 2024 Primary Date
summary: • This bill makes non substantive changes to the election code.

name: Voter registration provisions modified; absentee voting provisions modified; voting instructions and sample ballot required to be multilingual and interpreters required to be provided; intimidation, deceptive practices, and interference with registration and voting regulated; campaign finance provisions modified; express advocacy definition expanded; penalties provided; reports required; and money appropriated.
summary: • This bill makes non substantive change to the election code.

name: ELEC CD-DECEASED VOTERS
summary: As introduced, this bill makes it a requirement for the county clerk of the county to issue a certification of death records when someone is deceased and to cancel the registration of any person who died in the preceding month.

name: ELEC CD-VOTING MACHINES
summary: • Prohibits any voting machine from being connected to the internet while being used to cast votes.

name: Senate Substitute for HB 2053 by Committee on Federal and State Affairs - Providing for a presidential preference primary election on March 19, 2024, and establishing voter registration and voting procedures for such election.
most_recent_action: Senate Committee Report recommending substitute bill be passed by Committee on Federal and State Affairs
summary:
• Requires a vote by mail ballot to be postmarked no later than three days before election day to be counted, rather than election day.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: ST BD EDUC-ELECT MEMBERS
most_recent_action: Read second time; filed for Third Reading
summary:
• Requires five members of the State Board of Education be elected in a nonpartisan election at the general election in 2024 and every four years after.
  • Allows the State Board of Elections to hear and pass upon objections to nominations of candidates for State Board of Education.
  • Requires election authorities to open the returns and make abstracts of the votes for State Board of Education.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to proceed with a canvass after the election for elected members of the State Board of Election.
  • Provides that the State Board of Education should consist of five elected and eight appointed members.
  • Requires one election member from the State Board of Education come from each judicial district for a four year term.  
  • Outlines the petition for nomination process for State Board of Education candidates.
  • Provides vacancy procedures for appointed and elected members.
  • Outlines qualification requirements for candidates for State Board of Education.
  • Defines what constitutes quorum for the Board and what is needed for a vote to pass.

name: AN ACT relating to elections.
summary:
• Changes the name of the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Chicago to the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago.
  • Requires in the 2022 primary that members of the Board of Trustees of the City Colleges of Chicago and the Illinois Community College District 508 be elected in a non partisan election for a term of five years, with successors being elected for a term of four years.
  • Requires that members of the Board of Trustees of the City Colleges of Chicago and Illinois Community College District 508 be elected at each consolidated election starting in April 2023 to succeed incumbent members whose term ends after the consolidated election.
  • Outlines board appointments, elections, membership, size, and vacancy procedures for community college districts.
  • Establishes language for nomination petitions, as well as instructions for content, processing, and timelines, in the City of Chicago.
  • Outlines rules for ballots and petitions related to community college district elections.
  • Requires the City of Chicago to create 20 trustee districts by January 1, 2022 and requires they be reapportioned the year after the decennial census.

name: ELEC CODE-DECEASED VOTER
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Makes it a requirement for the county clerk of the county to issue certifications of death records and to cancel deceased individuals voter registration each month.
  • Requires certain individuals responsible for certification of death to transmit records to the county clerk within seven days after someone's death.
  • Requires the county clerk and coroner to report quarterly to certify full compliance regarding the accuracy of voter rolls.
  • Furnishes that anyone may request a copy of the report, and that the report must be provided within five business days, or 48 hours if it is 30 days before an election, and provides enforcement guidelines.
  • Authorizes the circuit court to order certain records and compliance, and authorizes the court to award reasonable attorney's fees and costs if someone prevails, with certain requirements.
  • Authorizes the circuit court to impose a fine on the public body if it determines that the public body willfully failed to comply, with certain specifications, including imposing additional penalties for further noncompliance.

name: ELEC CD-BALLOT TRACKING
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary:
• Defines "change in status," "voter registration database," and "trackable ballot."
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to develop and maintain a system to track ballots, including updates of changes.
  • Requires the ballot tracking system to update a voter electronically about any changes.
  • Provides language for consenting to receive notifications.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to update a voter's information in the statewide voter registration database.

name: GOVT ETHICS-ECONOMIC INTERESTS
summary:
• Defines "asset," "creditor," "debt," "diversified funds," "economic relationship," "family," "filer," "income," "investment real estate," "lobbying," "lobbyist," "personal residence," "sector funds," "spouse," "affected office," and "candidate political committee." 
  • Prohibits legislators from engaging in promoting or opposing the passage of any legislative matter affecting the interests of any individual, association, or corporation, in distinction from the interests of the people of the state as a whole.
  • Prohibits legislators from engaging in compensated lobbying of any government body on behalf of any lobbying entity registered in the state of Illinois or any Illinois county, municipality, or township.
  • Prohibits any appointed person from serving as an officer or becoming a candidate of a candidate political committee.
  • Requires that an appointed person within 30 days of their appointment implement certain measures related to their affiliation with a candidate political committee.
  • Requires the General Assembly to be in compliance with this legislation within 30 days of its effective date.
  • Requires that the interest of a spouse or any other party is considered the same as the interest of the person making the statement of economic interest.
  • Provides that campaign receipts are not to be included in the statement of economic interests.
  • Lists the interests that are required to file, including certain assets, income, debt, employers within the government, lobbying.
  • Provides that every five years the Secretary of State will adjust disclosure amounts based on inflation.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to develop guidance for filing the statement of economic interests and make it available on their website.
  • Removes conflicting guidance.
  • Provides the instructions for the statement of economic interests and provides that it may be filed with a county clerk, in addition to the Secretary of State.
  • Allows that a filers statement should be made with reasonable, good faith guidance from the Secretary of State and should not constitute a willful false or incomplete statement for classification of misdemeanor offenses.
  • Adds Supreme Court Justices, appellate court judges, circuit court judges, and judicial retention to the list of those who should not use the internet to file their statement.
  • Clarifies that candidates, officials, and officers may not hold a virtual fundraising event in Sangamon County on certain days related to when the legislature is in session if the person is not in Sangamon County.
  • Prohibits a former officer of the executive or legislative branch from engaging in activities that require registration under the Lobbyist Registration Act for a period of six months after leaving office.
  • Adds fiscal administration of state contracts as a reason to work with certain state agencies or entities on issues dealing with procurement and the prohibition of a revolving door.
  • Requires the Legislative Inspector General to be a full time employee of the state, outlines compensation requirements, and requires him or her to post office hours in Springfield.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Prohibits a limited activity committee from accepting contributions, except in specific circumstances and under certain guidelines.
  • Provides that a limited activity committee may only make certain expenditures.
  • Requires that starting January 1, 2022 compensation paid to members of the General Assembly be paid bi-monthly and prorates payment to members who resign and those completing a vacancy term.
  • Provides that state regulations regarding lobbying supercede local rules.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • Non-substantive change to the election code.

name: LOCAL OFFICER ELIGIBILITY ACT
ELEC CD-AUDIT OF BALLOTS
summary: This bill will require the State Board of Elections to create a process for auditing the affidavit signatures on ballots. This will include random sampling 1 percent of the ballots in each election authority.

name: ELECTIONS-NOTICE MAILING
summary: As introduced, this bill requires election authorities to notify qualified voters of the option to vote-by-mail between 90 and 45 days before an election unnless the voter has already opted in to a permanent vote-by-mail list, or has opted out of receiving elections related notifications.

name: ELECTION CODE-DECEASED VOTERS
summary: This bill will require individuals responsible for certification of death to transfer the records to county clerks within seven days of a death to update voter rolls. Monthly, the county clerk with request from the United State Postal Service records of address changes and subsequently update registrations and change jurisdiction.

name: ELEC CODE-DECEASED VOTER
summary: This bill, as introduced, requires the person issuing death certificates to notify the county clerk within 7 days of any death and give a quarterly report. Then the county clerk will cancel the voting registration of the deceased. It also allows people to request a copy of the quarterly report.

name: ELEC CODE-REGISTRATION
categories: Voter ID for registration,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a grace period registrant to present identification that identifies the registrant's date of birth.

name: ELECTION CODE-EARLY VOTING
summary: As introduced, this bill designates the in-person early voting period runs from the 40th day preceding a general primary, consolidated primary, consolidated or general election through the end of the day of the Friday immediately preceding election day.

name: ELECTIONS VOTER PHOTO ID
summary: This bill will require photo identification to vote. Approved identification includes state driver’s license or identification car, state disabled person identification card, firearm owners identification card, US passport with current address, or other government issued id with name, photo, and address. The Secretary of State will be required to issue a Voter Identification Card to every registered voter without a photo identification card. The card will meet the identification card requirement and it will be valid as long as the individual stays registered at that address. There will be application available for this card. Voters who have religious objections to photographs or fee concerns can vote with a provisional ballot and affidavit. When voting, a voter must present one of the acceptable photo identification options.

name: ELEC CD-BALLOT TRACKING
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration
summary: This bill will require the State Board of Elections to create a system for voters to track their ballots by providing a status for each mail-in ballot. The system will, upon the voter opting in, notify the voter via text and email.

name: HIGHR ED-ELECTION JUDGE CREDIT
most_recent_action: Placed on Calendar Order of 3rd Reading - Short Debate
summary: As introduced, this bill directs each Illinois public institution of higher education to adopt a policy regarding its awarding of academic credit for election judges. The policy shall apply to any individual who has been an election judge while enrolled in the public educational institute.

name: ELECT CODE-DEEP FAKE VIDEO
most_recent_action: (H) Missed Deadline for General Bill Transmittal
summary:
• Defines deep fake videos.
  • Provides that a person is committing a Class A misdemeanor if the person creates, publishes, and distributes a deep fake video with the intent to injure a candidate or influence the results of an election within 30 days of the election.

name: ELECTIONS-PUBLICATION/LOCAL
summary: As introduced, this bill requires local election authorities to post requirements and qualifications for running for local offices and petition filing deadlines on the local election authority website.

name: GENERAL ELECTION DAY
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Time off for voting
summary: As introduced, this bill designated general election day as a state holiday and is considered a legal school holiday. Closed schools can be used as polling places.

name: ELECT CODE-DEEP FAKE VIDEO
summary: As introduced, this bill furnishes that it is a misdemeanor for anyone to create, publish or distribute a deep fake video within 30 days of an election and defines "deep fake video."

name: ELEC CODE-DECEASED VOTER
summary:
As introduced, this bill:
  • Makes it a requirement for the county clerk of the county to issue certifications of death records and to cancel deceased individuals voter registration each month.
  • Requires certain individuals responsible for certification of death to transmit records to the county clerk within seven days after someone's death.
  • Requires the county clerk and coroner to report quarterly to certify full compliance regarding the accuracy of voter rolls.
  • Furnishes that anyone may request a copy of the report, and that the report must be provided within five business days, or 48 hours if it is 30 days before an election, and provides enforcement guidelines.
  • Authorizes the circuit court to order certain records and compliance, and authorizes the court to award reasonable attorney's fees and costs if someone prevails, with certain requirements.
  • Authorizes the circuit court to impose a fine on the public body if it determines that the public body willfully failed to comply, with certain specifications, including imposing additional penalties for further noncompliance.

name: ELECT CODE-ELECTION JUDGES
summary: As introduced, this bill allows an election authority to reduce the number of election judges in each precinct from 5 to 3 for any election with certain exceptions and requires the board of commissions to choose no less than 3 persons as election judges for each precinct in certain cities, villages, and incorporated towns.

name: ELEC CODE-DECEASED VOTER
ELEC CD-RISK-LIMITING AUDIT
summary: As introduced, this bill allows an election authority to conduct a risk-limiting audit before the certification of the results of an election or after the results of an election have been certified and the period for filing an election contest has expired.

name: ELECTION CODE-PETITIONS
summary: • Outlines guidelines and requirements for completing the nominating petition forms and changes the minimum age from 18 to 17.

name: ELEC CD-REPORTING TO ISBE
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election authority it include the methods of voting used in its unit-by-unit vote totals to the State Board of Elections.

name: ELECTIONS-VOTE CENTERS
summary: As introduced, this bill provides that election authorities may (rather than requiring them to) establish at least one location in the largest municipality within its jurisdiction where all voters in the jurisdiction are allowed to vote on election day regardless of the precinct they are registered.

name: ELEC CD-VOTE BY MAIL TRACKER
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the State Board of Elections to create a free and secure system available to voters that allows each vote by mail voter to confirm delivery and receipt of their ballot, view status of whether or not the ballot was accepted, and the reason for a denial. The system should be available to voters from the first day that vote by mail ballots are accepted until 30 days after completion of the official deadline.

name: ELEC CD-PHOTOGRAPHING BALLOTS
summary: This bill will allow individuals to take photos of their own ballot when voting, but makes it a felony for a person to give, promise to, or get or give money for sharing or viewing photos of ballots.

name: ELEC CD-VOTER REG APPLICATIONS
summary: This bill, as introduced, creates a dual-purpose voter registration application for individuals when applying for a driver’s license, state ID card, or change of address/renewal of one. Applicants can deny registration. Amends joint application process with other state agencies to single affirmation.

name: ELEC CD-BALLOT PRINTING
summary: As introduced, this bill requires that all lettering on ballots be printed in both upper and lower case letters and makes other minor changes to the design of physical ballots.

name: ELECT-MUNI ELECT COMM
summary: As introduced, this bill authorizes county board or boards of county commissioners in counties with a population of less than 100,000 to dissolve a municipal board of election commissioners and transfer its functions to the county clerk.

name: ELEC CD-CONTRIBUTION MATCHING
ELECTIONS-PREREGISTRATION
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Allows qualified individuals to preregister to vote online on or after their 16th birthday.
  • Provides that an individual who is 17, and will be 18 by the next election may circulate a nominating petition or petition proposing a public question.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: ELEC CD-RANKED CHOICE VOTING
summary: As introduced, this bill requires state legislative and certain executive offices use the ranked-choice voting method for elections and describes voting procedures.

name: ELEC CD-USE OF PUBLIC BUILDING
summary: As introduced, this bill provides that a public building may be used as a permanent or temporary polling place if the unit or local government determines that it will neither interfere with normal operations nor incur additional costs.

name: ELECTIONS-VACANCY APPOINTMENT
ELECTIONS-VOTER REGISTRATION
most_recent_action: House Committee Amendment No. 1 Rule 19(c) / Re-referred to Rules Committee
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Authorized qualified voters to register to vote at certain drivers services facilities or mobile events, when they are not applying for a driver's license or ID card.
  • Authorizes qualified individuals who have certain valid state issued ID to register to vote electronically on the state website.
  • Clarifies that a voter registration application transmitted electronically must contain the same information as other voter registration applications.
  • Specifies that a person registering to vote on the state's website online must swear an affirmation as to their identity, truthfulness of information provided, and authorizing the secretary of state to transmit the information, including signature, and provides the language and requirements for the affirmation.
  • Directs that voter registration information, applications, and collection of completed applications must be available at US citizenship naturalization ceremonies in the state, under the supervision of the secretary of state and coordination of the state board of elections.

name: ELEC CD-VOTER IDENTIFICATION
ELECTIONS-RIGHTS OF VOTERS
ELECTIONS VOTER PHOTO ID
categories: Voter ID for registration,Voter ID for low-income voters,Provisional ballots
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Lists all forms of acceptable photo identification for voting.
  • Requires the secretary of state to issue a voter identification card to registered voters who do not have an acceptable photo ID and specifies information to be included on the card.
  • Specifies how long the card is valid and for which purpose it may be used.
  • Requires the secretary of state to make an application form available for a voter ID card within three months of the passage of the bill and specifies acceptable information for identity and address verification purposes.
  • Allows indigent voters unable to obtain an a voter ID card and voters who have a religious objection to being photographed to vote via provisional ballot.
  • Prohibits a fee being charged to specified indigent voters.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Specifies that provisional voters have 10 days to provide the election authority with acceptable identification.

name: ELEC CD-USE OF PUBLIC BUILDING
summary: As introduced, this bill directs local units of government to make available public buildings to election authority districts for early voting purposes if it does not interfere with operations or incur additional costs.

name: ELECTIONS-INACTIVE VOTERS
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election authority to cancel the voter registration card of an inactive voter who has not voted in 2 consecutive general elections.

name: ELEC CD-VOTER REGISTRATION
categories: Voter registration,Voter list maintenance,Automatic voter registration
summary: This bill will require the jury administrator or commissioner to send a list of changed addresses from jury summons to the local election authority at least once every 3 months. When receiving this list, the county clerk will notify any person via mail if they do not appear to be a qualified voter. The individual can then attend a hearing to prove their valid registration. Otherwise, their voter registration will be canceled. If there has been a change of address from the National Change of Address Linkage System, the election authorities have 90 days to automatically register the voter in the new Illinois jurisdiction. The county clerk will complete a voter registration verification after consolidated elections in odd-numbered years but before the day where petitions start for candidacy in the next even-numbered year election.

name: ELECTIONS-ACCESSIBLE POLLING
summary: As introduced, this bill requires that all polling places comply with the federal Voting Accessibility for the Elderly and Handicapped Act of 1984, that disabled voters shall be notified of the nearest accessible vote center, and that all polling locations shall be accessible to voters with disabilities and elderly voters and include at least one voting booth that is wheelchair accessible.

name: ELECTIONS-SERVICE OF NOTICE
summary: As introduced, this bill permits election authorities to authorize service of objections to candidate nominations through e-mail if the election authority requires candidates and objectors to provide an e-mail address and publishes notice on its website of its decision to authorize service of objections tocandidate nominations through e-mail.

name: ELECTIONS-NOMINATION FILINGS
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the deadline for filing nominating petitions for candidates from 134-141 days before an election to 106-113 days before the election and for filing a petition for the office of multi-township assessor from 106-113 days before an election to 92-99 days before the election.

name: ELEC AUTHORITY-PRIVATE FUNDING
summary: As introduced, the bill directs the State Board of Elections to regulate and maintain oversight of all private, nongovernmental funds that are given to an election authority to use. An election authority may not apply for any private, nongovernmental funding from any source. Only the Board may seek and apply for private, nongovernmental grants and donations to distribute to election authorities for carrying out its duties for official operations and administering elections.

name: ELEC CD-DECEASED VOTERS
most_recent_action: House Committee Amendment No. 1 Rule 19(c) / Re-referred to Rules Committee

name: ELEC CD-VOTER REG APPLICATIONS
most_recent_action: Senate Committee Amendment No. 1 Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments
categories: Signature matching,Language accommodations,Noncitizen voting,Automatic voter registration
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Allows for automatic voter registration if the applicant demonstrates they are a US citizen and is of age to vote, or if the applicant is currently registered to vote in Illinois.
  • Authorizes a dual purpose applicant to decline voter registration.
  • Requires a single affirmation for dual purpose applicants that includes the affirmation required for the driver's license or state ID, and the applicants eligibility to register to vote.
  • Provides procedures for if a person's dual purpose application does not demonstrate that the person is a citizen or is not a citizen.
  • Authorizes the secretary of state to provide additional voter registration instructions.
  • Furnishes that an applicant demonstrating they are not a US citizen is therefore not a dual applicant.
  • Prohibits address information being forwarded to the state board of elections if the address is a substitute mailing address related to the Confidentiality for Victims of Domestic Violence, Sexual Assault, Human Trafficking or Stalking Act.
  • Provides for options for a voter registration applicant to provide a choice of language.
  • Provides that the Department of Heathcare and Family Services will implement an automatic voter registration system by July 1, 2025.
  • Provides that agencies collecting or cross referencing reliable personal information including citizenship status, may be considered an an applicant for the dual purpose application.
  • Changes signature verification options for voters applying for voter registration under a dual application.
  • Specifies automatic voter registration administrative procedures. 
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: JUDICIAL ELECTION/RETENTION
summary: This bill will require sitting judges to file for retention for their declaration of candidacy if they want to stay in that office. It prohibits a judge from resigning and then seeking election to that office, unless two years has passed since they resigned.

name: POLLING PLACE ASSISTANCE
summary: This bill will allow for in-vehicle assisted voting by requiring election authorities to setup a phone number for individuals with disabilities, with infants, or older than 80 years old to call and request to vote in-vehicle at a polling location. 2 judges from different political parties will be assigned to each vehicle in this instance and provide a voting affidavit and ballot.

name: ELEC CD-FOREIGN NATIONALS
summary: As introduced, this bill provides foreign nationals may not make contributions to ballot initiative or independent expenditure committees for influencing ballot initiatives to be considered by voters. Additionally, ballot initiative or independent expenditure committees may not knowingly solicit contributions from foreign nationals for ballot initiative purposes.

name: ELECTION CD-VOTE CENTERS
summary: As introduced, this bill removes a repeal date of July 1, 2023 for vote center provisions and establishes a recurring date of 40 days before an election for an election authority to comply with identification requirements for vote centers.

name: ELECTION CD-PUBLIC QUESTIONS
ELECTIONS-EMPLOY RESTRICTION
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits an election authority official, employee, spouse, or immediate family member from accepting employment or compensation for 1 year after leaving from persons or entities who had contracts of more than $25,000 with the election authority if the election authority official or employee had a substantial role in those contract procurements.

name: ELECTIONS-VOTE BY MAIL NOTICE
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election authority to notify all qualified voters 45-90 days before a general election of the option for permanent vote by mail status except for those who have applied for permanent vote by mail status or voters who submit a written request to be excluded from the permanent vote by mail status.

name: ELEC CD-VOTE BY MAIL BALLOTS
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the state board of elections to create a statewide reporting system for election authorities to record the receipt of vote by mail ballots before election day, on election day, and after election day, as well as based on their postmark.

name: ELECTIONS-CON AMENDMENT BALLOT
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Amends the state Constitution to require proposals for a constitutional amendment or calling for a constitutional convention to be included on the same official ballot containing names of candidates for office, and to precede the names of candidates for state and other office.
  • Specifies the paper to be used for the ballot (white instead of blue) and the format of the page.
  • Clarifies that the proposal must be included with the ballot and should include a printed notice with the words "CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT."
  • Requires additional digital publication of the proposed amendment, when publishing it in the newspaper based upon established code, at least two months before the election.

name: ELECTION CODE-VARIOUS
most_recent_action: Senate Committee Amendment No. 1 Rule 3-9(a) / Re-referred to Assignments
categories: Audits,Counting and canvassing procedures,Election officials,Voter list maintenance
summary:
As introduced, this bill: 

  • Requires the election judge affidavits to posted online with 48 hours of polls closing. 
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to create training and guidelines for election judges. 
  • Election judge training will include voter verification duties, campaign-free zone notices, details on electioneering, the vote by mail process, provisional ballots, and how to process ballots. 
  • Adds a timeline for election authority registration of voters who moved jurisdictions, so that they are completing it within 90 days of notice from the National Change of Address database. 
  • Requires verification of voter registrations by the county clerk and board of election commissioners start in odd-numbered years after an election and be completed by the first day of candidate filings for primary elections in the next even-numbered year. 
  • Requires election judges to submit an affidavit explaining tally sheet delivery delays (more than 5 hours past close of polls).  
  • Requires election authority to publish online vote by mail processing procedures 120 days before an election. 
  • Requires an audit by the State Board of Elections of vote by mail ballots received after election day.

name: ELEC CD-PRE-REGISTRATION
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Clarifies that the Board may receive voter registration information through the electronic voter registration portals, rather than the State Board of Elections website.
  • Allows individuals to preregister to vote who are 16 or 17 years old using the online voter registration system or an electronic voter registration portal.
  • Authorizes those qualified individuals who are 17 years old, but who will be 18 by the date of the next election, to circulate a nominating petition or a petition proposing a public question.
  • Authorizes those who are 16 or older to execute and attest to any voter registration forms.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: ELECTIONS-PETITIONS
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures
summary:
As introduced, this bill: 

  • Requires the State Board of Elections create a process for petition signatures to be obtained over the internet.
  • Requires statement of candidacy to include fields for telephone and email address of candidate. 
  • Requires candidates running for countywide offices in Cook County to collect between 5,000 and 10,000 signatures. 
  • Allows otherwise qualified voters to sign a petition for more than one candidate for the same office. 
  • Requires that between 5,000 and 10,000 signatures be submitted for mayor, city clerk, and city treasurer.

name: ELECTION CD-OBJECTION NOTICE
summary: This bill, as introduced, requires the chair of the electoral board to notify the election authority and county clerk within 24 hours of receiving nomination papers, proposed ballot questions, and objector’s petitions.

name: ELECTIONS-POST CONVICTION VOTE
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Grants a person convicted of a felony, sentenced in a correctional institution, or anyone under state supervision to have their right to vote restored.
  • Requires election authorities to collaborate with correctional institutions to facilitate a voting by mail program for those incarcerated. 
  • Requires compliance with federal voting rights law including language access and disabilities to these provisions.
  • Requires correctional institutes to make current election resources available to those in custody.
  • Allows a person who has left a correctional institute and not established a new residence to use their address prior to confinement for voter registration purposes.

name: ELECTIONS-PETITION/FILING DATE
summary: This bill, as introduced, changes the candidate filing time frame to between 141 days and 134 days before the general election (was 113 to 106).

name: ELEC CD-VOTE BY MAIL NOTICE
summary: As introduced, this bill requires election officials to notify voters between 90 and 45 days before a general election of the option to vote by mail, unless the voters has otherwise enrolled in a permament vote-by-mail list or opted out of receiving notices.

name: ELEC CD-VOTE BY MAIL
summary: This bill, as introduced, requires election authorities to appoint vote by mail election judge panels composed of three individuals nominated by county central, township, or war committees. This panel will compare the voter’s signature on the certification envelope to that of the signature on file. It also allows voters to provide a statement affirming the signature if it was rejected or cast another vote if the ballot was rejected because it was open when received.

name: ELECTIONS-JUDGE COMPENSATION
summary: As introduced, this board requires the State Board of Elections to reimburse any local jurisdiction up to $50 for an amount paid to an election judge greater than $100.

name: ELEC CD-BALLOT SECURITY
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Establishes that recordings of collection sites for vote by mail ballots are public records, subject to inspection and copying by the public.
  • Stipulates that collection sites must be established only on the grounds of a public building in which a unit of local government conducts ordinary business, where there are no residential dwellings.
  • Requires all collection sites to be recorded by security cameras, and for those recordings to be retained for 90 days after the election, and be made available for inspection and copying for that period.
  • Tasks the state's attorney to confirm that security cameras are working at least once per week until election day, beginning when the first vote by mail ballots are mailed.

name: ELECTION CD-VOTE CENTERS
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election authority establishing one polling location in the largest municipality where all voters in the jurisdiction are allowed to vote to identify the location and health precautions 40 days before an election and certify the location.

name: ELECTION-INCAPACITATED ELECTOR
summary: As introduced, this bill allows a physically incapacitated person to vote by mail rather than only on specified facilities.

name: ELECTIONS-CON AMENDMENT BALLOT
ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • This bill makes non substantive changes to the election code.

name: ELEC CD-COUNTY CONVENTION DATE
most_recent_action: Ethics & Elections Hearing (14:00:00 14:00:00 Room 413 Stratton Building)
summary: This bill will change precinct committee terms from two years to the time between the county convention after the election and the day before the next county convention. It will also change the convention dates for county central committees to no earlier than 29 days and no later than 50 days after the primary in which committeepersons are elected.

name: ELEC CODE-DECEASED VOTER
most_recent_action: Senate Referred to Committee on Federal and State Affairs
summary:
• Requires appropriate officials to transmit a death certificate to the county clerk within seven days of the death.
  • Requires the county clerk and coroner to report quarterly to certify full compliance.
  • Allows for any person to request a copy of the report and outlines penalties for not providing the report, including the role of a circuit court judge in compliance and penalties.

name: ELECTIONS VOTER PHOTO ID
ELEC CD-POST-CONVICTION VOTING
most_recent_action: Added Chief Co-Sponsor Rep. Mark L. Walker
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: This bill will restore voting rights to convicted felons within 14 days of their conviction. Local election authorities must work with correctional facilities to provide for voting by mail for registered voters incarcerated. Temporary polling locations will be set up in county jail for counties with populations of 3 million or more. The institution is responsible for providing access to election resource materials and will report on voting within by December 31 of each year. This bill will create the Post-Conviction Task Force to oversee and improve this process.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • Non substantive change to the electoral code.

name: ELEC CD-MAIL BALLOT/DISABILITY
most_recent_action: Senate Final Action - Not passed;  Yea: 16 Nay: 24
summary:
• Defines "electronic transmission" and "voter with a disability."
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to establish a procedure to sent vote by mail ballots electronically to persons with disability so that they can privately mark their ballot using assistive technology.
  • Requires the election authority to transmit a vote by mail ballot for a voter with disability within two business days if the application arrives after the election authority begins transmitting ballots.
  • Requires ballots received and marked to be printed by the voter and returned to the election authority.
  • Allows election authorities to deliver an official ballot electronically in certain instances.
  • Requires election authorities to provide voters with electronically transmitted ballots to provide the same instructions, certifications, and balloting materials as for other voters, to the extent possible.

name: ELEC CD-ELECTORAL COLLEGE
most_recent_action: House Stricken from Calendar by Rule 1507
summary:
• Requires one elector from each congressional district for the purpose of election a US President and Vice President.
  • Allows the State Convention or State central committee to choose two at-large electors.
  • Applies this rule to existing procedures.
  • Requires that each congressional district elector cast his or her ballot for the person who won in their congressional district.
  • Requires that each at-large elector cast his or her ballot for the person who won the statewide race.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: • This bill makes non substantive change to the election code.

name: ELEC CODE-VOTE BY MAIL
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Authorizes a resident of the voter's address of registration to endorse a vote by mail envelope verifying the voter's identity and residency.
  • Provides that a resident of the voter's precinct may endorse a vote by mail envelope if no other person residing at the voter's address is available, or the voter may provide a utility bill or least verifying their identity with the ballot.

name: ELECTION CODE-BALLOT FORMAT
summary: As introduced, this bill requires all ballots contain an "Illinois State Board of Elections" watermark and to be numbered consecutively. No link between the ballot number to a voter’s identity may exist.

name: ELEC CODE-VOTE BY MAIL
summary: As introduced, this bill modifies the timeline for a voter to order a vote by mail ballot electronically, by mail, or in person from 5-90 days before an election, to 60-90 days before the election.

name: ELEC CD-OVERSEAS CITIZEN
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary: • Allows a US citizen who has never lived in the US, but whose parent or legal guardian is a qualified voter, eligibility to register and vote in federal elections where his or her parent or guardian lives.

name: ELECT CODE-REFERENDA
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to design an alternative signature verification method for petition signatures from state advisory referendums.
  • Removes the requirement that a proponent in a statewide advisory referendum file a copy of the petition with each proper election authority.
  • Allows registered proponents and opponents of proposed amendments to certain articles of the state Constitution to observe the sample signature verification process, and to participate in proceedings related to sample signature verification.
  • Allows political parties and civic organizations to participate in the proceedings related to sample signature verification for proposed amendments to certain articles of the state Constitution.

name: ELECTION CD-DIGITAL SIGNATURES
ELEC CD-ELECTORAL COLLEGE
most_recent_action: House Hearing: Thursday, February 16, 2023, 3:30 PM Room 218-N - CANCELED
summary:
• Requires one elector from each congressional district for the purpose of election a US President and Vice President.
  • Allows the State Convention or State central committee to choose two at-large electors.
  • Applies this rule to existing procedures.
  • Requires that each congressional district elector cast his or her ballot for the person who won in their congressional district.
  • Requires that each at-large elector cast his or her ballot for the person who won the statewide race.

name: ELEC CD-VOTE BY MAIL BALLOTS
most_recent_action: House Hearing: Thursday, February 16, 2023, 3:30 PM Room 218-N - CANCELED
summary:
• Requires the State Board of Elections to create a reporting system for election authorities to record returned mail in ballots.
  • Requires election authorities to record the number of mail in ballots received before and after election day, and on election day, and ballots received postmarked after election day.

name: ST BD EDUCATION-ELECT MEMBERS
most_recent_action: Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Terri Bryant
summary: As introduced, this bill makes the State Board of Education an elected office to be voted on by the qualified voters of the state beginning in 2024 and every four years thereafter.

name: ELEC CD-EQUIPMENT/AUDITS
summary:
As introduced, this bill: 

  • Creates the Illinois Election Integrity Act and the Election Integrity Fund. 
  • Requires election authorities to perform an audit on 10% of the votes and independent audits of “post-election parallel tabulations.” 
  • Creates rules for optical scan and direct recording electronic voting systems based on testing standards. 
  • Allows residents to donate to the Election Integrity Fund and requires individual tax forms to set up form fields to do so. 
  • Requires direct recording electronic voting system for early voting so that voters can choose paper ballots if they want.

name: ELEC CD-CONTRIBUTION MATCHING
ST BD EDUC-ELECT MEMBERS
most_recent_action: Added as Chief Co-Sponsor Sen. Tom Bennett
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that five members of the State Board of Education will be elected on a nonpartisan basis at the general election in 2024 and every four years after, and the Board will also have eight appointed members and a chairperson.
  • Provides that one member will be elected for each judicial district.
  • Requires a petition for nomination to be signed by .5% of the total number of voters in the judicial district.
  • Provides that each term is four years, along with starting dates.
  • Provides vacancy procedures.
  • Provides qualifications and disqualifications for candidates.
  • Prohibits anyone serving more than two consecutive terms.
  • Provides quorum and voting procedures.

name: ELECT-MUNI ELECT COMM
categories: Oversight and accountability,Conflicts between levels of government
summary: As introduced, this bill allows a county board or board of county commissioners within a county of less than 100,000 dissolve a municipal board of election commissioners within that county and transfer its functions to the county clerk.

name: ELECTION-INCAPACITATED ELECTOR
summary: • Allows eligible incapacitated voters to vote by mail or onsite, rather than onsite only.

name: ELEC CD-AUDIT FOR CAUSE
most_recent_action: Senate Hearing continuation: Tuesday, February 14, 2023, 1:30 PM Room 548-S
summary:
• Requires the treasurer of a political committee to preserve all records and accounts for two years before January 1, 2022, and seven years after that date.
  • Adds cause for the Board to order an audit of a political committee, including: sworn testimony in a guilty plea of a candidate or officer, conviction related to misuse of political committee funds, filing a statement of organization with a same officer or candidate who was in a political committee that was administratively terminated in the last 24 months.
  • Creates an audit period of seven years.

name: JUDICIAL CAMPAIGN REFORM
ELEC CD-PRIMARY/RANKED CHOICE
MUNI CD-ELECTED POLICE CHIEF
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that each municipal police chief will be elected at the general election in 2024 and at each general election every four years after.
  • Lists eligibility requirements for being a candidate for police chief.
  • Provides that a fire chief may be appointed from among the members of the fire department and excludes the possibility of appointment from the members of the police department.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: ELEC-POLITICAL COMMITTEE FUNDS
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits a political committee from making payments to immediate family members of a public official or candidate and defines "immediate family member" and "payments."

name: ELEC-PROHIBITED USE OF FUNDS
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits political committees from using their funds for payment to attorneys except in the case of expert witnesses, investigators, or for purposes of criminal defense.

name: ELECTIONS-NOMINATIONS
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Enforcement against non-officials
summary: This bill, as introduced, requires the objector of an objector’s petition certify that the petition comes from reasonable objections to nomination based on law. Otherwise, it allows the electoral board to impose sanctions for false certification. Prohibits candidate from appearing on the ballot if they were involved in fraud related to nominating papers.

name: ELEC CD-VARIOUS
most_recent_action: Added Chief Co-Sponsor Rep. Paul Jacobs
categories: Audits,Oversight and accountability,Transparency,Ballot access for candidates,Legal causes of action,Voter list maintenance
summary:
• Requires the posting of uncounted ballot information on a website to also include election judge affidavits.
  • Requires the State Board of Elections to establish training materials and guidelines for judges of elections.
  • Requires the county clerk and the Board of Election Commissioners to incorporate guidelines and training materials from the State Board of Elections, including outlining minimum guidelines.
  • Requires election authorities to automatically register a voter whose information is received through the National Change of Address database within 90 days.
  • Requires the county clerk to conduct a verification of voter registrations after elections in odd-numbered years, but before the first day of candidate filing for the following primary election in an even-numbered year.
  • Allows the county clerk to conduct investigations and conduct canvasses of registered voters after elections in odd-numbered years, but before the first day of candidate filing for the following primary election in an even-numbered year.
  • Provides for the county clerk and the Board of Election Commissioners to certify the verification of information to the State Board of Elections.
  • Allows the Board of Election Commissioners to conduct investigations and make canvasses of registered voters after elections in odd-numbered years, but before the first day of candidate filing for the following primary election in an even-numbered year.
  • Requires that if there is a delay of more than five hours in getting tally sheets to the county clerk, that the two designated judges, one from each major political party, create a written affidavit explaining the delay.
  • Requires the affidavit be delivered to the county clerk and be made available to the general public on a website.
  • Requires vote by mail processing procedures be published on a website at least 120 days before an election.
  • Subjects vote by mail ballots arriving after election day to an audit and outlines the procedures, timeline, and scope of the audit.

name: ELEC CD-EQUIPMENT/AUDITS
summary:
• Requires each early voting polling place to have sufficient paper ballots for voters who request them.
  • Requires a 10% election day audit of all votes cast for each statewide, countywide, federal, municipal, or other race or proposition on election day, where there is more than 50,000 registered eligible voters.
  • Requires audits to take place as soon as possible after the close of polls at the location where votes are counted, but not interfere with the reporting of election results.
  • Requires the audit be conducted by election judges with staffing requirements laid out in the legislation.
  • Provides for a method for the random selection of ballots and for recording the results of the random selection.
  • Provides a system for examining and recording ballots for the audit.
  • Requires election authorities to create and print an audit summary form before election day listing the races and propositions to be audited, with spaces for recording the results of the audit, and certain other requirements.
  • Outlines requirements for completion of the audit summary form and distribution and publicity of copies of the form. 
  • Requires election authorities to collect all precinct audit reports and create a consolidated report to be published within 24 hours of the polls closing, and requires authorities to certify the election day audit results.
  • Outlines storage and public availability requirements for the audit.
  • Provides that the reports are admissible as evidence as required.
  • Requires a parallel, independent audit be conducted for each race or proposition in each election.
  • Outlines staffing, timeline, and committee composition rules for the audit.
  • Outlines rules for the parallel election tabulation and audit, including request for proposals, timeline, awarding the contracting, funding, contractor qualifications, licensing and bonding requirements, and requires the contractor have access to all records of the election.
  • Outlines requirements for the report submitted by the contractor in the parallel audit including timeline, procedures, certification or non-certification criteria, what should be examined, questions to be answered, and information required. 
  • Clarifies that the parallel election tabulation and audit reports are public property, in the public domain, available under FOIA, and may be posted on a website.
  • Requires the parallel election tabulation and audit reports be admissible as evidence as required.
  • Creates the Illinois Election Integrity Fund as a special fund in the State treasury and clarifies funding mechanisms.
  • Defines "approved independent testing authority."
  • Requires precinct tabulation optical scan technology voting systems to fulfill voluntary provisions and mandatory requirements from proper authorities and to fulfill testing requirements by approved testing authorities.

name: ELEC CD-ELECTORAL COLLEGE
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes that each political party shall choose one elector for Vice-President and President per congressional district in the state, as well as two at-large electors for the state. This bill requires electors to cast their electoral college ballot for the candidates that received the most votes in their corresponding congressional district, or the highest statewide vote-getter for at-large electors.

name: ELECTION CODE-EARLY VOTING
summary: • Amends the early voting period to end on the Friday immediately before the election, and requires the early voting polling place to stay open until then.

name: ELECTIONS-SENATE VACANCY-PARTY
summary: As introduced, this bill directs a person who is appointed to fill in a U.S. Senate vacancy must be from the same political party as the person vacating the seat. The appointee’s political party affiliations can be demonstrated with prior primary voting records or party affiliation while holding office.

name: ELEC CODE-DECEASED VOTER
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the county clerk of where a deceased person last resided must issue a death certificate and remove the person’s name from the voter registration system. The county clerk must produce a quarterly report of death records submitted and accuracy of the voting rolls which can be viewed publicly, or the public can take action against the clerk if this section is not met properly with associated penalties laid out.

name: ELECTIONS VOTER PHOTO ID
summary: As introduced, this bill provides for the issuance of a voter ID for people who cannot obtain another form of government-issued photo ID. This bill requires an acceptable ID to vote. A provisional ballot may be cast if an acceptable photo ID cannot be shown at a polling place and will be accepted once an acceptable photo ID is shown within 10 days.

name: ELECTIONS-TECH
summary: As introduced, this bill makes nonsubstantive changes to existing code.

name: NOTARY PUB-NOMINATING PAPERS
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 31, 2023 makes it a violation of election code and Class A misdemeanor to notarize candidate nomination papers if you are not an authorized notary public.

name: ELECTION CD-JUDGE'S INITIAL
summary: • Removes the requirement that judges initial ballots of those who ordered a vote by mail ballot, but came to the polls in person.

name: ELECTION DAY HOLIDAY
summary: This bill will replace Columbus Day with General Election Day as a state holiday. It will be the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November.

name: ELEC CD-FAILURE TO DISCLOSE
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 25, 2023, changes the civil penalty language from “intentional willful, or material failure” to “intentional failure to disclose” election materials for registration.

name: Elections; ordering of candidates for partisan offices on state general election ballot requirements modified.
summary: • This bill makes non substantive changes to election code.

name: ELEC CD-QUARANTINE
most_recent_action: House Referred to Committee on Elections
summary: • Adds voters in quarentine to those entitled to a hand delivered vote by mail ballot.

summary: This bill makes non-substantive changes to the election code.

summary: • This bill makes non-substantive changes to the election code.
