name: School board candidate filing deadline.
most_recent_action: Senate concurred in House amendments; Roll Call 320: yeas 48, nays 0
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures
summary: This bill, as amended, changes the deadline for petition and declaration filings for school board candidates. Petition filings are due between the day voter registration begins after the primary election and 30 days from the first day declaration of intent filings can be submitted. Declaration of intent filings can be submitted between 90 days and 74 days before the general election. Candidate withdrawal deadline is July 15th. Adds the same new filing deadlines to statements submitted questioning a candidates petition or nomination.

name: Absentee voting.
most_recent_action: Returned to the House with amendments
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Cure provisions
summary:
As introduced on January 12, 2023, this bill: 

  • Requires county election boards to have a process for voters to resolve issues with their absentee ballot applications. 
  • Prohibits the government from sending an absentee ballot application to an individual who has not requested it. 
  • Requires absentee ballot applications ask for either the voter’s driver’s license number, identification card number, or voter registration number and the last 4 of their Social Security Number. For an online application, only 1 of the former 4 numbers is require. 
  • Requires a voter voting by mail due to location absence (from county, precinct, confinement, home care for dependent, work, or religious obligations) to have that issue during the time they could vote absentee before the board in addition to on election day.

name: Local powers concerning elections.
most_recent_action: Signed by the President of the Senate
summary:
As introduced, this bill clarifies a jurisdiction does not have the power to adopt an ordinance, a resolution, or an order concerning elections unless the power to do so is expressly granted by statute. This bill also voids an ordinance, a resolution, or an order concerning an election before January 1,

2023 unless the jurisdiction was explicitly granted by statute.

name: Various election law matters.
most_recent_action: Returned to the House with amendments
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 17, 2023, removes election scheduling for past election cycles and adds new election years information for future precinct committeemen, presidential electors, senators, statewide office, judicial, municipal, and political party primary elections.

name: Various election law matters.
most_recent_action: Senator Rogers added as second sponsor
categories: Administrative deadlines,Audits,Ballot access for candidates,Signature matching,Ballot design,Voting materials,Counting and canvassing procedures,Voter list maintenance
summary:
As introduced on January 17, 2023, this bill: 

  • Prohibits signatures under IC 26-2-8-106 from being sent by fax or email but allows electronic signatures for candidate and campaign finance committee chairman or treasurer on campaign finance filings.  
  • Makes election forms obsolete if they become part of the voter registration system. 
  • Allows the secretary of state to provide voting history to law enforcement for an investigation. 
  • Allows notification to absentee voters regarding additional documentation to be used without forms management approval. 
  • Requires the statewide voter registration system to identify nonresidential addresses that have been used on registration applications. 
  • Changes the petition count needed for candidate nominations for election districts with only 1 precinct, only 5 voters in that district are require to sign the petition. 
  • Prohibits an elected official from receiving the office’s salary if they failed to submit the proper candidate filings, filing the documents will remedy the situation. 
  • Adds failing to file campaign finance reports to the list of violations that rise to the level of civil penalty. 
  • Requires electronically filed reports be filed by noon 7 days after report’s date. 
  • Removes the requirement for county election board to make duplicate of election returns for candidates. 
  • Allows counties to not create additional precincts if a precinct would have less than 2,000 voters or 2,300 in the case of vote center counties. 
  • Requires absentee ballots to use security paper that allows for authentication. 
  • Adds the ballot secrecy waiver to the absentee ballot envelope as an option for comparing voter signatures. 
  • Starts the absentee ballot vote counting after 6:00 AM on the day of the election, as long as the electronic poll books have been updated to include all absentee ballots. 
  • Requires the election board to notify the voter of an “absentee ballot signature mismatch” within 2 days of the ballot being assessed.  
  • Requires an audit after the election be ordered by the secretary of state by the last Friday in June after a primary or December 20th after a general election. 
  • Allows a personal representative of a treasurer or candidate to shut down the political committee.

name: Various elections matters.
most_recent_action: Committee report: amend do pass adopted; reassigned to Committee on Tax and Fiscal Policy
categories: Ballot design,Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Redistricting process
summary:
As introduced on January 10, 2023, this bill: 

  • Requires municipalities who have not redistricted by January 1, 2023 to pass and certify a redistricting ordinance by May 15, 2023. 
  • Allows an individual to petition to hold a public hearing for a municipality that has failed the deadline above. After the public hearing, the secretary of state will issue an adoption of a redistricting plan. 
  • Removes the right to vote for anyone convicted of a felony under IC 3-14-2 for 10 years. 
  • Allows electronic devices, except electronic poll books, to display sample ballots. If used, there must be public notice and it must be accessible on election day. 
  • Requires the county election board to provide either enough sample ballots or electronic form of the sample ballot.

name: Various elections matters.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
categories: Election dates,Ballot measures (initiative and referendum),Special election procedures,Election workers/volunteers,Election officials
summary:
As introduced on January 10, 2023, this bill:

  • Defines election worker and gives per diem to circuit court clerks serving as voter registration officer. 
  • Makes it a Level 6 felony to influence, interfere, or injure an election worker. 
  • Requires public questions and delegate elections to only be on the general election ballot, or a municipal election if the public question is only for a municipality. 
  • Requires the county election board to provide an electronic sample ballot the inspector if the county allows electronic displays of the sample ballot. 
  • Makes what a voter selected on a ballot confidential. 
  • Excludes electronic devices that show or can print sample ballots from being part of a voting system. 
  • Allows a referendum on school corporation taxes imposed before January 1, 2024 and expiring after December 31, 2023. The referendum can be held at a primary, general, or municipal election as long as the question is certified 74 days before the primary or by August 1st for the general. If there is not an election scheduled during the year, there can be a special election for the public question held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in May or November.

name: Processing, counting, and tabulating ballots.
most_recent_action: House Elections and Apportionment Hearing (08:30:00 08:30:00 Room 404)
summary:
As introduced on January 10, 2023, this bill: 

  • Requires ballots that can be retracted to have a unique code for retraction. 
  • Allows the voter to place their ballot into the scanning machine. 
  • Prohibits absentee ballots from being counted before 6:00 PM on election day.

name: School board elections.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Nonpartisan elections,Vacancy procedures
summary:
As introduced on January 17, 2023, this bill: 

  • Sets up school board office candidates to be nominated via a political primary, repealing the existing nonpartisan election process for school board candidates. 
  • Creates a process for handling a tie vote for school board elections, where the incumbent (if running for reelection) remains in office while the governing body (minus any member who is a candidate for this seat) will vote to appoint one of the tied candidates by December 31st of that year 
  • Requires vacancies in the school board to filled by caucus if the seat was held by a major political party office holder or by an alternative process if the seat was held by an independent or minor party office holder.

name: Driving privilege cards.
most_recent_action: Senator Walker K added as coauthor
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 11, 2023, creates a process for driving privilege card but does not add them to the process for automatic voter registration. Prohibits voter registration cards from being used as “bona fide evidence of majority or identity.” It also allows for voter registration information to be given to law enforcement.

name: Audit of election systems.
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 11, 2023, requires an election system components audit for the 2023 municipal and 2024 general election to be ordered by the secretary of state by July 1, 2023. The entity contracted for the audit must not be located in Indiana and perform the audit in 10 random counties. The report from the audit is due by January 1, 2026.

name: Elections matters.
most_recent_action: Representative Payne Z added as coauthor
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Audits,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots
summary:
As introduced on January 17, 2023, this bill: 

  • Prohibits any expansion to voting by mail or absentee voting by mail. 
  • Prohibits the commission from changing the time, location, or way the election is held. 
  • Prohibits absentee ballot applications from containing prefilled out driver’s license, identification card, voter registration, or social security number. 
  • Requires an absentee ballot to include either a voters driver’s license or state identification number and a photocopy of the card. 
  • Prohibits contracts for voting system from denying access to the source code of a voting system.
  • Requires an electronic voting system audit, arranged by the secretary of state by July 1, 2023 in pilot counties. After December 31, 2023 the secretary of state will get a contract for future audits after every general election. 
  • Prohibits the governor from using an executive order to change the timing, date, or way an election is held.

name: Local elected officials roster.
most_recent_action: Representatives Boy and Pressel added as coauthors
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 9, 2023, requires election divisions to create a local elected official roster by January 1, 2025 and continue to maintain it, adding new information by January 1 after each election. The roster will include names, elected information, office terms, and more.

name: Reorganization of municipality and township.
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 9, 2023, creates a voting process for cities and towns reorganizing into a single political subdivisions. The question will be put to voters at the next general election and requires a majority of the votes to be approved.

name: Township assessors.
summary: This bill, as introduced, requires counties with township assessor to add a ballot question on the 2024 general election on whether to get rid of the office. If a majority of voters vote yes, the office will be abolished in 2026.

name: School board elections.
most_recent_action: Representatives Morris and Teshka J added as coauthors
summary:
As introduced on January 9, 2023, this bill: 

  • Repeals nonpartisan school board elections. 
  • Adds political party to the candidate petition nomination for school board. 
  • Requires the certification of the county chairman if the candidate claims a majority political party but has not voted in that parties primary in the last 2 elections. 
  • Allows individuals to challenge a candidate’s petition political party affiliation to a major party.

name: Candidate, office holder, and voter residence.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 19, 2023, removes residency eligibility with regards to election if an individual registers to vote in another state. It also requires an individual to do more than intend to reside when determining residency but have supporting evidence and defines family residences for a variety of situations.

name: School board elections.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Nonpartisan elections,Vacancy procedures
summary:
As introduced on January 19, 2023, this bill: 

  • Sets up school board office candidates to be nominated via a political primary, repealing the existing nonpartisan election process for school board candidates. 
  • Creates a process for handling a tie vote for school board elections, where the incumbent (if running for reelection) remains in office while the governing body (minus any member who is a candidate for this seat) will vote to appoint one of the tied candidates by December 31st of that year 
  • Requires vacancies in the school board to filled by caucus if the seat was held by a major political party office holder or by an alternative process if the seat was held by an independent or minor party office holder.

name: Ballot access for major and minor parties.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 19, 2023, changes nominating procedures for political parties. Those who received at least 2,500 but less than 25% of the total votes for secretary of state in the last election will nominate candidates by state or county convention. For minor political parties or independents, petition process is allowed and must be signed by at least 250 voters in district.

name: Electronic voting systems.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections
summary:
As introduced on January 17, 2023, this bill: 

  • Changes electronic voting system definition to include an audit trail printer. 
  • Retires electronic voting systems, after June 30, 2023 counties may not purchase new electronic voting systems except for to provide voting process for disabled individuals or if the secretary of state approves it and after December 21, 2027 electronic voting systems cannot be used except for voting for disabled individuals. 
  • Requires the secretary of state to create a plan to switch from electronic voting system by July 1, 2026.

name: Same day voter registration.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
categories: Voter ID for registration,Provisional ballots,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Allows a voter to register or transfer registration on election day, and then vote a provisional ballot.
  • Lists election day voter registration requirements, including administrative requirements, as well as required forms and voter ID.
  • Outlines procedures for a provisional ballot if the individual does not have proper ID.
  • Requires the county election board to provide each precinct with a sufficient number of registration forms and other documentation required for voter registration.
  • Specifies procedures for the precinct election board and the county voter registration office, related to administration of same-day voter registration.
  • Requires that a person be removed from registration rolls if his or her mailed notice is returned as undeliverable.
  • Provides that someone returning to the polls to present appropriate documentation to register to vote is entitled to re-enter the polls to file the documentation so that their provisional ballot will be counted.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Student ID card.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Education
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Adds approved post-secondary educational institutions ID cards to the list of acceptable IDs for voter registration.
  • Defines "student ID card."
  • Requires post-secondary institutions to issue an ID card without charge to qualified students, and to issue new cards upon expiration of original cards if the person is still a student.
  • Lists required content of student ID cards.

name: Documents and procedures concerning elections.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,In-person voter ID,Voter ID for registration,Noncitizen voting,Voter list maintenance
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that if a candidate withdraws a candidacy, that withdrawal will be used to update their voter registration address.
  • Adds a required item, that is an electronic form of the sample ballot and provisional ballot, to the list of items for the county election board to deliver to each inspector.
  • Provides that an electronic device may be used at a poll center to display a sample ballot or provisional ballot, if its only function is to display the ballots.
  • Prohibits anyone from providing an individual with more than one absentee ballot application.
  • Requires each county election board to provide each precinct an adequate number of sample ballots.
  • Lists items that may be used to show proof of a current address, allowing them to be submitted in portable document format (PDF), and requires proof be shown when issuing or renewing a driver's license.
  • Requires a certain marking for a drivers license or permit if a voter is not a US citizen.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Poll hours.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
categories: Administrative deadlines,Counting and canvassing procedures,In-person voting and polling places
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Defines "close of polls."
  • Modifies the beginning time for counting absentee ballots from 6am to 7am on election day.
  • Strikes 6pm as the closing time of polling stations in existing legislation and instead replaces it with "the close of polls."

name: Threats against election workers.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Courts and Criminal Code
summary: As introduced, this bill defines who is included in the term "election worker." This bill also adds election workers to list of individuals whom threatening is a level 5 felony.

name: Same day voter registration.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
categories: Voter ID for registration,Provisional ballots,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Allows a voter to register or transfer registration on election day, and then vote a provisional ballot.
  • Lists election day voter registration requirements, including administrative requirements, as well as required forms and voter ID.
  • Outlines procedures for a provisional ballot if the individual does not have proper ID.
  • Requires the county election board to provide each precinct with a sufficient number of registration forms and other documentation required for voter registration.
  • Specifies procedures for the precinct election board and the county voter registration office, related to administration of same-day voter registration.
  • Requires that a person be removed from registration rolls if his or her mailed notice is returned as undeliverable.
  • Provides that someone returning to the polls to present appropriate documentation to register to vote is entitled to re-enter the polls to file the documentation so that their provisional ballot will be counted.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: School board elections.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot design,Nonpartisan elections,Vacancy procedures
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 9th, 2023, would require that candidates for school board, including candidates for an elected school advisory board, be nominated in the same manner as all other elected offices are nominated under state law. The bill would also eliminate the requirement that school board members be elected on a nonpartisan basis, modify how school board candidates are listed on primary and general election ballots, annd provides for a new method of filling vacancies as well as resolving tied votes for school board members that first gives preference to any incumbent in a tied vote, and thereafter defers to the remaining members of the board to resolve the tie.

name: Automatic voter registration.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 11, 2023, creates a process for automatic voter registration via application for driver’s licenses at the bureau of moto vehicles. The bureau shares the information with county registration office, unless the individual requests otherwise, and then the office determines if the individual is eligible to vote and will then register them.

name: Straight ticket voting.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 10, 2023, prohibits “straight ticket voting,” the ability to vote for all candidates of a political party at one time, and repeals any measures that allowed that option on the ballot.

name: Candidate vacancies.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Ballot access deadlines
summary:
As introduced on January 10, 2023, this bill: 

  • Requires candidates to give notice by noon on March 1st to the political party chair and the election division. 
  • Changes candidate filing deadlines for petitions to March 1st from June 30th and county office certification deadline to March 15th from July 15th. 
  • Prohibits a political party from filing a candidate vacancy (from having no primary candidates) for the general election.

name: School board candidate filing deadlines.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access deadlines
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 10, 2023, changes the window for submitting school board nomination petitions from between 104 to 74 days to between 118 to 88 days before the first Tuesday after the first Monday in May of an election year. Declarations of intent would now have to be filed no earlier than 118 day, instead of 90, days before and no later than July 3rd (used to 74 days before). Write-in candidates must file by July 15th.

name: Declaration of candidacy.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 10, 2023, removes the requirement that a candidate have voted with the party in the last 2 primary elections or have a certification by the county chairman to filing nominating papers with that party.

name: Election security.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Drop-box availability,Election workers/volunteers,Drop-box security
summary:
As introduced on January 10, 2023, this bill: 

  • Creates an interim study committee on making absentee ballot voting by mail “as secure as in-person voting.” 
  • Defines election worker as individual who works or volunteers for a list of municipal, county, and state government election offices and boards. 
  • Allows county election boards to provide training in a variety of formats, including online, in person, via video, and any combination. 
  • Defines representatives of inspectors as an authorized member of the precinct election board. 
  • Prohibits individuals from altering absentee ballot applications by marking the ballot with any instrument in order to confuse voters filling out the application. 
  • Prohibits the use of drop boxes for absentee ballots. 
  • Makes casting two ballots in the same election a Level 6 felony.

name: Deceased voters.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections
summary: This bill will require absentee ballots submitted to be counted even if the voter dies after submitting but before the election.

name: Ballot and initiative referendum.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 10, 2023, enables Indiana voters to propose statutes and constitutional amendments to be voted on for approval or rejection by other voters in the state. To get on the ballot, initiatives must have a petition count equaling 2% of the vote count for Secretary of State in the last election and must be approved by a majority to pass.

name: Redistricting commission.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
summary:
As introduced on January 10, 2023, this bill: 

  • Establishes the Redistricting Commission Nominating Committee made up of appointees from state educational institutions to nominate individuals to the Redistricting Commission.
  • Establishes the Redistricting Commission to investigate, hold hearings, and take public comment to draw new districts for congress and the state legislature. 
  • Creates a deadline of January 1st of a redistricting year for the Commission to publish a publicly accessible redistricting portal for residents and a deadline of March 15th for scheduling hearings and meetings. 
  • Generates a report for the general assembly by August 1st with recommendations for redistricting. 
  • Includes other requirements for redistricting, including number of districts, population dispersion, and more. 
  • Requires the general assembly to pass redistricting bill(s) by October 1st.

name: Election of Lake County superior court judges.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 9, 2023, creates an election process for Lake County superior court judges. Terms of office will be 6 years and they will be elected in the general election. Eligibility for candidacy includes county residency and eligible to practice law in Indiana. Candidacy will follow the nomination process of other elected judges in IC 3-8.

name: Prohibition of firearms at polling places.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 9, 2023, prohibits non-on duty law enforcement individuals from carrying firearms within 50 feet of polling locations, to do so will be a Class C or A misdemeanor.

name: Redistricting local election districts.
summary:
• Requires redistricting after the decennial census to occur in certain years for certain bodies: for a county or school corporation, in the first year after the census; for municipalities it depends on the year it conducts its elections.
  • Outlines certain deadlines for redistricting after a decennial census.
  • Outlines other timelines for conducting redistricting and prohibits redistricting at other times.
  • Clarifies when an area is required to redistrict.
  • Clarifies what to do if conflicts exist or if a territory is not included.
  • Changes population sizes for areas not subject to the standard redistricting rules.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Elections.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Audits,Oversight and accountability,Enforcement against non-officials,Absentee/mail-in voter assistance
summary:
• Allows the election division to call a meeting under certain circumstances.
  • Requires the director, assistant director, or co-director of the board of elections to attend these meetings if they are called.
  • Provides that a member of a county election board may attend the meeting.
  • Outlines provisions for meetings held by the election division in a primary election year, including per diem and other reimbursements.
  • Allows county election officials to perform post-election audits.
  • Allows voters with print disabilities to vote by electronic mail or fax.
  • Establishes that a voter voting more than one ballot, except in certain circumstances, is commiting a felony.

name: Electronic voting machines.
categories: Voting equipment,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Audits,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,Early voting administration,Provisional ballots
summary:
• Provides that this bill applies only if the costs can be paid from federal government funds or appropriated by the general assembly.
  • Requires certain information be used on the envelope for an absentee ballot application, including font size.
  • Requires the electronic poll book must have the capacity for each voter to transmit information if the voter cast a provisional ballot, through a private server to the statewide voter registration system.
  • Requires this function not be disabled.
  • Removes the provision that the circuit court clerk must provide notice to a voter who casts a provisional ballot.
  • Makes changes aligning current election code with new requirements.
  • Defines "early voting" to mean voting before an absentee voter board.
  • Enumerates circumstances in which a county election board will not use a direct record electronic voting system in an election after July 1, 2022.
  • Allows a county election board to use a module of the computerized list to comply with requirements for provisional voters.
  • Lists required elements in a county's list related to provisional ballots.
  • Defines "post election audit" and replaces the term "risk limiting audit" in related legislation.

name: Election of school board members.
summary:
• Defines "school board" to mean the governing body of a school corporation and includes elected school advisory boards in the definition.
  • Provides that the following rules apply only for nonpartisan school board elections.
  • Provides that nominees may withdraw by noon on July 15 under if nominations followed certain codes.
  • Removes candidates for precinct committeeman, state convention delegate, and school board from the requirement that names on ballot be arranged in alphabetical order.
  • Aligns relevant election code.
  • Removes school board elections from the list of elections where a candidate may receive the greatest number of votes to win.
  • Puts school board candidates on the ballot behind the town council candidates with certain provisions.
  • Outlines the process for resolving tie votes in school board elections.
  • Clarifies to whom a circuit court clerk should provide written notification in the case of a tie in a local or school board election.
  • Removes conflicting code regarding vacancies and makes clarifying changes.
  • Clarifies rules governing nomination to be a candidate of a governing body.
  • Provides that these rules do not apply to school corporations with an elected school advisory board.
  • Amends the population size requirements of cities in adoption of certain membership increases of the governing body of the school corporation.

name: Description of political subdivisions.
summary:
• Names political subdivisions described by certain population parameters and other identifying features.
  • Changes formulas used to determine distribution of funds.
  • Removes provisions regarding the timeline for certain political subdivisions to take effect, as they relate to the decennial census.

name: Various elections matters.
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Audits,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,Early voting administration,Provisional ballots
summary:
• Provides that this bill applies only if the costs can be paid from federal government funds or appropriated funds from the general assembly.
  • Extends the term of the threat intelligence code to expire January 1, 2028, from January 1, 2023.
  • Requires certain information and format on the envelope for an absentee ballot application.
  • Allows that someone can register on election day if they meet certain requirements.
  • Removes the provision that the circuit court clerk must provide notice to a voter who casts a provisional ballot.
  • Lists reasons a voter would be permitted to vote by mail.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Clarifies that voting before an absentee voter board is "early voting."
  • Defines "post election audit" and replaces the term "risk limiting audit" with "post election audit" in related code.
  • Requires those accessing absentee ballot applications to provide certain identification.

name: Poll hours; same day registration.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections and Apportionment
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
• Defines relevant terms.
  • Allows an individual to register or transfer registration on election day.
  • Makes changes to align new rules to current election code.
  • Enumerates requirements for registering on election day, including the responsibilities of relevant officials.
  • Establishes that an individual can register to vote until the close of polls on election day.

name: Various election law matters.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Education
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Audits,States of emergency,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots
summary:
• Prohibits the election commission from instituting, increasing, or expanding vote by mail or absentee ballot voting.
  • Prohibits the election commission from changing the time, manner, or place of holding an election.
  • Allows additionally a ten digit Indiana drivers license number or last four digits of the Social Security number for absentee ballot application identification.
  • Requires the county election board to deny an absentee ballot application if it does not include either the driver's license number or last four digits of the social security number, or if the numbers given do not match the election board's file.
  • Repeals the abilities of the secretary of state to designate counties as risk limiting pilot counties.
  • Requires the county election board to conduct a risk limiting audit before results are certified.
  • Specifies that the governor does not have the power to create an executive order changing the time, manner, or place of elections.
  • Specifies that the governor does not have the authority to institute or increase absentee voting or voting by mail.

name: Various election law matters.
most_recent_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Elections
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Audits,States of emergency,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots
summary:

categories: Voting equipment,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Administrative deadlines,Permanent lists,Audits,Poll observers,Oversight and accountability,Transparency,Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Cure provisions,Primary systems,Special election procedures,Counting and canvassing procedures,Recounts,Reporting,Ballot access deadlines,In-person voting and polling places,Provisional ballots,Election workers/volunteers,Election officials,Legal causes of action,Challenges,Physical security,Cybersecurity
summary:
• Provides that the secretary of state will oversee the conduct of statewide elections.
  • Provides that each county election officer will be responsible for planning and conducting elections in the county.
  • Prohibits anyone convicted of certain crimes from becoming a county election officer.
  • Prohibits election officials from creating or disclosing an image of the hard drive of a voting system or other voting equipment.
  • Changes the timeline for an election to sell a public utility from 40 to 60 days after passage of an ordinance and requires notice of an election to be posted on a county's website 21 days prior to the election.
  • Provides that in a vacancy for county clerk, anyone who is qualified may be appointed, not just county residents.
  • Provides that an elected sheriff must be a resident of the county.
  • Clarifies population certification procedures.
  • Changes the deadline for publishing notification of a general election from 15 to 30 days before the election and changes the deadline for knowing the names on the ballot from 25 to 50 days before the election.
  • Requires election officials to verify party affiliation of precinct committee candidates.
  • Requires election officials to mail certain officials a list of those appearing on the ballot 50 days before a primary (instead of two weeks before) and allows those officials to make certain changes up to 45 days before the primary (instead of 11 days before).
  • Outline guidelines for the secretary of state to determine the validity of independent nominating petitions.
  • Provides that write-in candidates for national or state office must file no later than noon on the 4th Monday before the elections.
  • Outlines guidelines for county election officials to contact anyone submitting a mail ballot where there is a signature deficiency.
  • Changes the number of elections from four to two in which, if a permanent advance voter fails to vote, they will receive a notice.
  • Requires an application to mail a ballot to a voter.
  • Changes the deadline for a candidate to file a declaration of intention from June 10 to June 1.
  • Clarifies that school board write in candidates must live in the district.
  • Requires county election officials to publish notification of registration dates.
  • Makes exceptions for counties not using optical scanners to count votes.
  • Clarifies how votes in a partisan primary by an unaffiliated voter should be counted.
  • Redefines "authorized poll agent."
  • Adds constitutional amendment questions to audits and to other existing electoral code.
  • Provides that certain officials may select a designee to serve on the state board of canvassers.
  • Requires parties to notify the secretary of state before each partisan primary whether unaffiliated voters are allowed to vote in the party's primary.
  • Adds certain actions to the list of voter fraud felonies.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

categories: Oversight and accountability,Transparency,Municipal election procedures,Special election procedures,Enforcement against officials,Enforcement against non-officials
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Specifies the definition and criminal classification of interference with an election official and failure to comply with statewide voter registration database requirements. The definition of intimidation of voter is also modified.
  • Modifies the definition of general election and primary election to allow for a definition of special election. A special election cannot be held within 45 days of either a general or primary election, but one can be held on the same day.
  • Directs a candidate for a city office elected to file with the county election officer of the county where the city is located or the county where the greater population of the city is located if the city is in more than one count. 
  • Directs no portion of the voter registration database to be made available for public inspection unless each individual's social security number, driver's license card number, ID card number and email address have been fully redacted. No records concerning a voter's provisional ballot shall be made available for public inspection or copying except the voter who cast the ballot.
