name: Fostering voter opportunities, trust, equity and security
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor, Chapter 92 of the Acts of 2022
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Early voting eligibility,Early voting administration,Early voting duration,Voter participation deadlines,Voter registration
summary:
This bill makes a number of changes to the state's election laws, including, but not limited to, the following:

  • Allowing all voters to cast absentee/mail-in ballots;  
  • Establishing in-person early voting for two weeks before state general elections and one week before presidential and state primary elections; and
  • Moving the voter registration deadline from 20 days before Election Day to 10 days before Election Day.

name: Election Law - Ballot Processing and Reporting Procedures and 2024 Primary Date
most_recent_action: Favorable with Amendments Report by Ways and Means
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary: As introduced, this bill directs local boards of election to begin processing and counting absentee ballots eight days before the first day of early voting. This bill also creates a requirement that local boards notify a voter within three days of determining their absentee ballot was not signed and afford the voter an opportunity to correct the missing signature.

name: Election Law - Ballots - Issuance, Processing, and Reporting Procedures
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary: As introduced, this bill directs local boards of election to begin processing and counting absentee ballots eight days before the first day of early voting. This bill also creates a requirement that local boards notify a voter within three days of determining their absentee ballot was not signed and afford the voter an opportunity to correct the missing signature.

name: Election Law – Party and Elected Public Offices – Prohibition
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary: As introduced, this bill creates exceptions to a law prohibiting a person from simultaneously being a candidate for more than one public office or more than one political party office, stipulating that the prohibitions do not apply to a person holding an elected public office who is on the national presidential nominating convention ballot or who is a convention delegate. The bill also prohibits a person from simultaneously being a candidate for a party office and an elected public office and from simultaneously holding a party office and an elected public office.

name: Orphans’ Court Judges – Election
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures
summary: This bill, as introduced, adds judge of the orphan’s court to list of elected offices that does not require party affiliation for candidacy. Adds this office to election law for other elected judicial offices.

name: Election Law – Ascertainment of Results – Process
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the governor to ascertain and enumerate the electors for US President and Vice President, and issue a certificate of ascertainment of electors.

name: Election Law - Campaign Finance - Draft Committees and Exploratory Committees
summary: This bill, as introduced, adds draft and exploratory committees to election law regarding political committees. Requires that individuals can only create a draft committee if the creator is not a candidate and it is not done with coordination. Prohibits candidates from creating either type of committee and limits the committees expenditures to paying for polling, direct mail and donor outreach, staff, and website.

name: Election Reform Act of 2023
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Election officials
summary:
As introduced, this bill: 

  • Requires the local board of elections to hold public meetings on changing locations of polling places before voting to change them. 
  • Add force, fraud, threat, menace, intimidation, bribery, and rewards to the list of ways you cannot influence another voters decision. 
  • Allows board of election custodians to deny inspections temporarily in the 90 days before the election and through the certification or would hurt their ability to prepare for an election.
  • Requires the custodian to petition the court for approval of denial within 5 days of the initial inspection request.

name: Howard County - Board of Education - Terms
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Prohibits anyone from inducing an election official to violate or not comply to his or her duties.
  • Prohibits anyone from threatening, coercing, or intimidating an election official with certain intent.
  • Provides that anyone violating these laws is guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to fines and/or imprisonment.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Prohibits anyone making personal information about an election official or his or her immediate family available on the internet, if the information may pose an imminent or serious threat to their safety.
  • Provides that anyone violating these laws is guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to fines and/or imprisonment.
  • Furnishes that an election worker may submit a request to remove personal information from the database made available on the internet if its inclusion poses a threat to the worker or his or her family.
  • Lists what should be included in the request.
  • Outlines what the department must do upon receipt of the request.
  • Provides that the worker may wirhdraw the request by submitting a signed request for withdrawal with the deparment.

name: Election Law - Foreign Manufacture of Election Systems - Notification and Termination of Contract
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary: This bill, as introduced, prohibits the State Board of Elections from contracting with companies unless the company would be required to report if any part or material change for the election system was made or took place outside of the United States. It also allows the State Administrator to terminate contract.

name: Election Law - Postelection Tabulation Audits - Risk-Limiting Audits
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires the state board, in collaboration with local boards, to audit the accuracy of the voting system's tabulation of votes by completing a risk limiting audit.
  • Lists elections to be included in the audit.
  • Outlines what must be done in a risk limiting audit and procedures to be followed.
  • Provides that the audit must be completed before the election can be certified.
  • Outlines procedures for if it is determined that the count is incorrect.
  • Implements reporting and notification guidelines. 
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Election Law – Recounts – Procedures
summary: This bill, as introduced, allows those requesting a recount to determine if the count takes place with the same tabulating equipment, alternative tabulating equipment, or manual recount. Requires local boards to keep voter-verifiable paper records with the duplicate ballot.

name: State Administrator of Elections - Removal From Office
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the requirements for the State Administrator of Elections to be removed and that the Administrator serve until a successor is appointed.

name: Elections - Election Judges - Minimum Compensation
most_recent_action: Referred Education, Energy, and the Environment
summary: As introduced, this bill requires that an election judge be compensated at least $250 per each election day and early voting day that the judge works, and be compensated at least $50 for each completed course of instruction.

name: Voting Rights Act of 2023 - Counties and Municipalities
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
categories: Language accommodations,Reporting,State appropriations,Enforcement against officials,Legal causes of action,Legislative authority,Redistricting criteria/requirements,Redistricting process
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Enacts a Voting Rights Act for counties and municipalities.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Provides that rules and statutes should be construed in favor of protecting the right to cast a ballot, ensuring that eligible voters are not impaired in voting processes, and ensuring that protected class voters have equitable access.
  • Outlines protections offered to protected class members, and lists violations.
  • Lists voting and methods that constitute a violation against protected class members.
  • Outlines related actions that may be filed and court actions that may be taken.
  • Lists what local government proposals may be subject to this legislation and how actions should be handled.
  • Requires the state board to designate languages other than English for which there is need for language related assistance at the local level and includes guidelines to do so, and required support for non English speakers, and outlines procedures for actions to be filed, should they be necessary.
  • Outlines provisions for preclearance, what is included in preclearance, and outlines guidelines for preclearance, and defines relevant terms.
  • Implements an Information Office in the State Board and a statewide election database.
  • Outlines guidelines and responsibilities for the creation and administration of the Information Office.
  • Outlines required information for the statewide election database.
  • Outlines what constitutes voter intimidation and obstruction, who may file allegations, and court actions.
  • Clarifies who pays litigation costs and when the state or local government is responsible.

name: Elections - Election Judges - Minimum Compensation
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes a minimum compensation for elections judges and establishes a monetary incentive for election judges to complete certain eligible training programs.

name: Election Law - Citizens Who Live Overseas - Right to Vote
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary: As introduced, this bill allows a person living overseas to register to vote and vote in the county they last lived before leaving the U.S. if they were eligible to register or otherwise eligible to vote before leaving the U.S. The election director may not remove a voter from a voter registration list unless the voter confirms in writing that the voter has changed residence in another state or territory.

name: Elections - In-Person Voting - Proof of Identity
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a voter to present a current government-issued ID and proof of residence to establish the voter’s identity. If a voter cannot meet these requirements, they will be given a provisional ballot. This bill also criminalizes attempting to vote with a false ID.

name: Election Law - Voting - Proof of Identity
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a voter to present a current government-issued ID with signature and provide a signature to an election judge to establish the voter’s identity. If a voter cannot provide an ID, they will be given a provisional ballot. This bill also criminalizes attempting to vote with a false ID.

name: Election Law - Electronic Ballot Return System - Study and Request for Proposals
most_recent_action: Referred to interim study by Ways and Means
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires the Department of Legislative Services, in consultation with certain experts, to complete a study about the creation of an electronic ballot return system.
  • Lists items to be included in the study, such as the impact on voters with disabilities and absent overseas uniformed voters, best practices for accessibility and security for returning ballots, integration into existing infrastructure, voter eligibility in other states, mechanisms for opting in to electronic returns, and changes necessary to existing election law.
  • Requires a report be submitted by December 1, 2023.
  • Requires the State Board to issue a request for proposals for an electronic ballot return system by January 1, 2024.

name: Election Law – Voting Systems – Sourced, Manufactured, and Assembled in the United States
summary: As introduced, this bill directs that voting systems, including all parts and components, be sourced, manufactured, and assembled entirely in the United States.

name: State Administrator of Elections - Term, Vacancy in Office, and Removal From Office
most_recent_action: Referred Education, Energy, and the Environment
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that the state administrator is subject to removal by affirmative vote of four out of give members of the fully constituted state board for incompetence, misconduct, or other "good cause."
  • Requires that prior to removal, the state board will set forth written charges and offer the state administrator notice and "ample opportunity" to be heard.
  • Provides that after an affirmative vote, the state administrator is authorized to continue to work until a successor is confirmed by the Senate.

name: Election Law – Voting – Proof of Identity
categories: In-person voter ID,Provisional ballots,Enforcement against non-officials
summary: As introduced, this bill allows an election judge to request certain ID (state or federally issued photo ID), plus provide a signature in the presence of the judge to match to the signature on the ID card, when a voter's name cannot be found on the list or on the inactive list. This bill also requires the judge to refer the voter for a provisional ballot if the voter is unable to provide identification and it prohibits anyone attempting to vote with a false ID.

name: Election Law - Voter Registration List - Right to Opt Out of the Sale of Personally Identifiable Information
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the state board to establish a process for an individual to opt out of the sale of certain voter information to anyone other than an employee or vendor of the board.

categories: Language accommodations,Reporting,State appropriations,Enforcement against officials,Legal causes of action,Legislative authority,Redistricting criteria/requirements,Redistricting process

  • Outlines possible remedies and related procedures.

name: Election Law – Early Voting – Number of Days
summary: As introduced, this bill provides that early voting will begin on the second Monday (instead of Thursday) before a primary or general election.

name: Election Law – Voter Registration List – Absentee Voters (Absentee Ballot Transparency Act of 2023)
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes that a candidate may request, and a board must furnish, a list of registered voters who have requested an absentee ballot for the upcoming election, including email and telephone number of voters where available.

name: Election Law - Candidate Truthfulness - Oath
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires a certificate of candidacy be accompanied by a signed oath or statement.
  • Furnishes the text and format of the candidate oath.
  • Provides an alternative statement and format for a candidate who declines to sign the oath.

name: Election Law - Polling Places - Establishing Voter Identity (Voter Privacy Act of 2023)
summary: As introduced, this bill allows an election judge to request certain ID (voter registration card, driver's license, any state or federally issued photo ID) when a voter's name cannot be found on the list or on the inactive list.

name: Election Law - Registered Voter List and Petitions (Ballot Petition Modernization Act)
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Signature matching,Ballot access deadlines
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Adds electronic signature options to petitions and requires requirements for signature verification, and accessibility for people with disabilities, be developed by the state board.
  • Requires clearly labeling optional information on the petition as optional.
  • Provides that a signature will be validated if the identity of the person can be reasonably determined from the required information section, and the signature cannot be invalidated because the individual signed the petition using a derivative of their given name.
  • Direct that if an individuals surname on a petition does not exactly match the surname on their voter registration record, the election authority should invalidate the signature.
  • Outlines procedures for if an individual signs a petition more than once.
  • Lists whose electronic signatures may be on a petition.
  • Outlines procedures and rules for electronic signatures on a petition, including witness requirements.
  • Outlines procedures and timelines for if there is a deficiency in a petition.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Election Law – Election Officials and Workers – Prohibitions Against Interference and Disclosure of Personal Information
Election Law - 2024 Primary Date - Alteration
summary: As introduced, this bill sets the statewide primary election and the primary election for municipal offices in Baltimore City to be held on the third Tuesday in April.

name: Election Reform Act of 2023
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )

name: Election Law - Electronic Ballot Return System - Study and Request for Proposals
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the department of legislative services to conduct a study on the creation of an electronic ballot return system.

name: Election Law – 2024 Primary Date – Alteration
most_recent_action: First Reading House Rules and Executive Nominations
summary: As introduced, this bill sets the statewide primary election and the primary election for municipal offices in Baltimore City to be held on the third Tuesday in April.

name: Orphans’ Court Judges – Election
most_recent_action: First Reading House Rules and Executive Nominations
summary: As introduced, this bill requires orphan court judge candidates to appear on the ballot without party designation and provides for qualifications to appear on the ballot and election procedures.

name: St. Mary's County - County Commissioners Election Method - Straw Ballot
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that the St. Mary's County Board of Elections, in consultation with the State Board, will prepare a ballot question asking whether voters favor changing the method of selection of four out of five members of the St. Mary's County Board of County Commissioners from at-large election to a district method of elections.
  • Requires the question be placed on the November 2024 ballot.
  • Clarifies that the vote will be an advisory vote.

name: State Board of Elections - Procurement Oversight
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires the state administrator to disclose a request for proposals (RFP), or invitation for bids (IFB), or a procurement contract to the state board.
  • Directs the state board to vote on RFPs or IFBs expected to exceed $200,000 before they are issued by the state administrator.
  • Directs the state board to vote on proposed procurement contracts with a value greater than $200,000 before the state administrator submits them for approval.
  • Makes certain exceptions.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Election Law – Polling Sites – Firearms Prohibitions
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Substitutes the word "firearm" for the word "gun" in existing voting law related to firearm prohibitions.
  • Defines the word "firearm."
  • Provides prohibitions of carrying or displaying a firearm through the voting process and provides exceptions.
  • Provides penalties.

name: Election Law - Insufficient Number of Candidates for a Primary Election
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Primary systems,Vacancy procedures,Ballot access deadlines
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires the state board to extend the filing deadline for a primary election for certain offices for seven days if in the 48 hours before the filing deadline an unopposed candidate dies, is disqualified or withdraws.
  • Requires the state board to extend the filing deadline for a primary election for certain offices for seven days if in the 48 hours before the filing deadline there are not enough political party candidates for the number of political party seats available.
  • Requires the state board to extend the filing deadline for a primary election for governor and lieutenant governor for seven days if in the 48 hours before the filing deadline an unopposed candidate dies, is disqualified or withdraws; or no candidate for the political party has filed candidacy for either of the offices.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Provides that if after the extended filing deadline there is still no candidate for either governor or lieutenant governor for a primary election, the state central committee if the political party will select a candidate to fill each of the vacancy, with certain restrictions and requirements.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Election Law – Early Voting – Number of Days
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the required early voting center opening date to be from the second Thursday to the second Sunday before a primary or general election.

name: Election Law – Recounts – Procedures
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Authorizes the petitioner to select the method for conducting a recount and lists possible methods.
  • Requires the local board to preserve and store the paper record for each duplicate ballot created with the corresponding paper record.
  • Requires the local board to count only the paper record in a manual recount.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: General Assembly Vacancy - Political Party Central Committees - Procedures
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Establishes that the application period to fill a vacancy is seven days.
  • Outlines what the advertised vacancy notice should include.
  • Requires the notice to be translated to certain languages, per the Voting Rights Act.
  • Outlines posting requirements and timelines of applications to fill the vacancy.
  • Requires the central committee to hold a public meeting to interview candidates and a public meeting to vote on filling the vacancy, with certain requirements.
  • Outlines procedures for the vote.
  • Clarifies recusal requirements.

name: Election Law - Polling Places at Continuing Care Retirement Communities
most_recent_action: First Reading House Rules and Executive Nominations
summary: As introduced, this bill requires local boards of election to establish voting precincts for continuing care retirement facilities, defined as elder care facilities with more than 200 residents, and, if the facility so requests, to establish a polling location on the premises for eligible elections.

name: State's Attorney, Clerk of the Circuit Court, Register of Wills, Sheriff, and Judge of the Orphans' Court - Nonpartisan Elections
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures,Nonpartisan elections
summary: This bill, as introduced, removes the party affiliation requirement and makes state’s attorney, clerk of the circuit court, register of will, sheriff, or judge of the orphan’s court elections nonpartisan. It creates a certification process for candidacy without party affiliation designation and the candidates (twice the number of offices to be filled) with the highest number of votes will move onto the general election from the primary.

name: Ballot Access - Affiliating With a Party - Unaffiliated Voters
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary: This bill, as introduced, allows a voter to choose a political party up to 5:00 PM on the day before early voting and the local board must process their request effective on the first date of early voting.

name: Elections - Ballot Questions - Publication of Proposed Laws
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary: This bill, as introduced, requires the board of elections to post ballot questions in full for at least 65 days before the general election in way that is easy for the public to access.

name: Election Law - Casting General Election Ballot in Multiple States - Prohibition
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary: This bill, as introduced, prohibits voters from voting in two or more states in an election year.

name: General Assembly Vacancy - Political Party Central Committees - Procedures
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
summary: This bill, as introduced, creates a process for filling vacancies in the General Assembly. Applications for the vacancy will be open for no less than 7 days and be advertised by the political party of the vacant office. Applications will be publicly available and stay up for at least 30 days after the party votes on filling the seat. There will beat least one public hearing on the matter prior to the political party committee voting to elect an applicant to the seat.

name: Election Law - Insufficient Number of Candidates for a Primary Election
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 )
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Primary systems,Ballot access deadlines
summary: This bill, as introduced, requires the State Board to extend filing deadlines for 7 days for primary elections if, within 48 hours of the deadline, unopposed candidate dies, disqualifies, or withdraws or the number filed is less than the number allowed. If the only candidate for governor or lieutenant governor dies, disqualifies, or withdraws or there is no candidate, then the deadline for that office is also extended by 7 days. If, after the extension, there is no candidate for governor or lieutenant governor for a primary election the state party will nominate a candidate to the vacancies.

name: Election Law - Citizens Who Live Overseas - Right to Vote
summary:
As introduced, this bill: 

  • Defines residency for voting as: 
  • An individual born outside of the US with parent who is registered to vote in this state. 
  • Resided in the state prior to living overseas, without living or being registered in another state. 
  • Requires overseas individuals to register using the federal post card application. 
  • Prohibits these individuals from registering to vote in person during early voting.

name: Election Law - Campaign Finance - Draft Committees and Exploratory Committees
summary: This bill, as introduced, adds draft and exploratory committees to election law regarding political committees. Requires that individuals can only create a draft committee if the creator is not a candidate and it is not done with coordination. Prohibits candidates from creating either type of committee and limits the committees expenditures to paying for polling, direct mail and donor outreach, staff, and website.

name: Election Law - Automatic Voter Registration - Alterations
Voting Systems - Ranked Choice Voting and Inclusion of City of Takoma Park Municipal Elections on the State Ballot MC 7-23
categories: Municipal election procedures,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary: This bill, as introduced, requires that voting systems approved by the State Board of Elections be able to be used for ranked choice voting elections. In the event that the City of Takoma Park uses ranked choice voting, this bill require the Board to get additional voting and tabulating machines.

name: Election Law - Local Public Campaign Financing - Boards of Education
summary: This bill, as introduced, allows counties to create their own public campaign finance process for county board of education after an election cycle with public campaign financing for executive and legislative county offices. Prohibits this system from being used in student member school board elections.

name: Montgomery County – Voting Methods MC 03–23
summary: This bill, as introduced, allows Montgomery county to use ranked choice voting for select offices (county executive, member of the county council, circuit court judge, state’s attorney, register of wills, sheriff, and board of education).

name: State Board of Elections - Contracts and Invoices - Requirements
summary:
• Establishes that the State Board is to review and vote on each contract with a value of $50,000 or more.
  • Establishes that the State Board will ensure the cost effective use of government resources in administering elections.
  • Requires the State Administrator to report each proposed contract, renewal, and change to the State Board, with guidance for submitting a report.
  • Requires the State Board to vote on approval before contracts are finalized.
  • Lists requirements for a State Board report to the Board of Public Works.
  • Requires counties to reimburse the State Board for 50% of the state's cost of elections, and electronic voting systems, that are mandated by the State Board, with non-mandated costs being paid out of county funds.
  • Directs that costs should be calculated based on the size of the voting age population in each county.
  • Outlines procurement allowances and contract allowances for the State Board.

name: Elections - Ballot Questions - Publication of Proposed Laws
summary: This bill, as introduced, requires the board of elections to post ballot questions in full for at least 65 days before the general election in way that is easy for the public to access.

name: Election Law - Curbside Voting - Establishment
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes curbside voting on election day and during early voting.

name: Elections - In-Person Voting - Proof of Identity
categories: In-person voter ID,In-person voting and polling places,Provisional ballots
summary: This bill, as introduced, requires the election judge to determine a voters identity prior to them voting. If their identity cannot confirmed by using the election register and inactive voter list, the election judge will require the individual present a photo identification or document (such as utility, bank statement, paycheck, etc) that has the name and address. If the individual cannot present evidence of identity, then they can vote using a provisional ballot.

name: Local Public Campaign Financing - Expansion to Additional Offices
summary: This bill, as introduced, allows counties to create their own public campaign finance process for local offices (state’s attorney, sheriff, register of wills, circuit court and orphan’s court judges, circuit court clerks, and school board) after an election cycle with public campaign financing for executive and legislative county offices.

name: Election Law - Absentee Ballots - Signature Requirements and Verification
summary: As introduced, this bill requires that absentee ballots and return envelopes be signed by the voter and a witness to be eligible.

name: Ballot Access - Affiliating With a Party - Unaffiliated Voters
summary: This bill, as introduced, allows a voter to choose a political party up to 5:00 PM on the day before early voting and the local board must process their request effective on the first date of early voting.

name: Election Judges - Training and Signs - Accommodations for Voters in Need of Assistance
categories: Voting materials,In-person voting and polling places,Election workers/volunteers,Election officials,In-person voter assistance
summary:
As introduced, this bill: 

  • Requires election judge training to include both oral and written instructions on how to assist elderly and disabled voters. 
  • Requires the instructions be specific to each polling location. 
  • Requires the state board to create signs for polling locations that list ways elderly and disabled voters can be assisted, these signs must be displayed clearly in an easy to see places near the entrance, outside, and at the check-in desks.

name: Election Law - Contested Elections
most_recent_action: Enacted under Article II, Section 17(c) of the Maryland Constitution - Chapter 624
summary:
• Adds a definition to the terms "contribution" and "expenditure" stating that it is a payment made to a campaign finance entity that may be used to pay expenses associated with an election.
  • Requires there to be less than a 5% difference for a candidate or voter to be able to petition for a recount.
  • Establishes rules for candidates accepting public campaign financing, including the requirement that the candidate establish a contested election committee, meeting all specified requirements.
  • Lists the roles and requirements of a contested election committee.
  • Prohibits certain donations, loans, and actions by the contested election committee.
  • Requires the treasurer of the contested election committee to keep detailed records of specified items, and to retain them for specified periods.
  • Establishes reporting requirements for the treasurer of the contested election committee, including in cases of a recount petition.
  • Requires the State Board to establish reporting periods for the required reports of the contested election committee.
  • Codifies procedures if a treasurer of a contested election committee fails to provide required reports, including notifications, fees, timelines, and prosecution and penalties.
  • Establishes guidelines for receiving an overdue report.
  • Establishes that a candidate with a contested election committee that failed to file required reports cannot be elected, take the oath, or receive salary, and includes related rules.
  • Clarifies related possible civil penalties and with which funds they may be paid.
  • Clarifies what to do when there are insufficient funds to pay civil penalties.
  • Outlines guidelines for repaying public contributions, paying outstanding debts, disposing of remaining assets, and reporting when applicable.
  • Provides that a publicly financed candidate may transfer funds from the candidate's campaign finance entity to the contested election committee.
  • Defines relevant terms. 
  • Makes conforming changes.
