name: Election Law - Ballots - Processing and Reporting Procedures
summary:
• Removes the provision that unofficial returns do not include absentee and provisional ballot counts.
  • Requires the local board to review ballot return envelopes for the omission of a voter signature on the oath during the canvas.
  • Requires a local board to wait until 8am, 8 business days before the first day of early voting to accept, reject, open, or process absentee ballot envelopes.
  • Prohibits a local board releasing tabulations of absentee ballot results before the polls close on election day.
  • Allows a voter to correct a ballot return envelope signature before 10am, 10 days after the election.
  • Requires the state board to develop regulations requiring the local board to allow voters to correct signature errors on ballot return envelopes with certain guidelines.
  • Allows a voter to supply a digital signature to fix the envelope signature error with certain requirements and options.
  • Requires the local board to count the first ballot with a properly signed envelope when receiving more than one ballot from an individual.
  • Requires the local board to release a report of unofficial election results each day beginning after the polls close on election day, including early, absentee, and provisional ballots.
  • Outlines guidelines for accepting or rejecting an absentee or provisional ballots received from the same individual.
  • Requires the board of canvassers to prepare a report by precinct including early, absentee, and provisional votes.

name: Election Law - Ballot Canvassing - Multiple Ballots Cast by an Individual
summary:
• Removes audits from the definition of what a canvas includes.
  • Changes the definition of "board of canvassers" from canvassing "after" an election to canvas "for" an election.
  • Clarifies that unofficial returns do not include provisional ballot counts, but do include absentee ballot counts.
  • Requires a local board to review an absentee ballot envelope for omission of voters signature on the oath promptly upon receipt.
  • Prohibits a local board from processing a ballot before 8am, eight business days before the first day of early voting.
  • Prohibits a local board from tabulating absentee ballots until the polls close on election day.
  • Requires the local board to reject a ballot if the voter fails to sign the oath on the ballot envelope and fails to correct the omission by 8am, ten days after the election.
  • Requires the State Board to adopt regulations requiring local boards to implement systems to rectify omission of signature on absentee ballot envelopes, with specific timelines, and guidance on counting the ballots. 
  • Allows a signature to be a digital image sent by email or phone beginning June 1, 2023.
  • Allows a voter to choose the method by which they would like to communicate with the local board to correct a signature omission, including text message and an online portal by June 1, 2023.
  • Requires the local board to release a report of unofficial returns of absentee ballots after polls close on election day. 
  • Outlines procedures for if the board receives more than one ballot from the same individual.
  • Requires the board of canvassers to report the early, absentee, and provisional vote separately, but not by precinct.
  • No longer requires the local board to print copies of election results and make them available to the public.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Elections - Polling Place Location Restrictions - Repeal
summary:
• Requires the State Board to adopt rules governing the use of a building that holds an alcoholic beverage license as a polling place.
  • Requires the local board to prioritize putting polling places in buildings that do not have an alcoholic beverage license.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Elections - Polling Place Location Restrictions - Repeal
categories: Early voting administration,In-person voting and polling places
summary:
• Repeals the rule that an election may not be in a building used by an establishment that holds an alcohol license.
  • Requires the State Board to adopt rules governing the use of buildings with an establishment that holds an alcohol license.
  • Requires local boards to prioritize polling location placement in buildings without an establishment with an alcohol license.

name: Congressional Districting Plan
summary: This bill sets forth a redistricting plan for congressional districts in the State of Maryland.

name: Election Law - Foreign Manufacture of Election Systems - Notification and Termination of Contract
most_recent_action: Senate Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs Hearing (13:00 3/23/2022 )
summary:
• Forbids the State Board from approving a contract with an election service provider, unless the provider includes a contract clause that requires the provider to report if any manufacturing or change to an election system occurred outside the US.
  • Lists report requirements.
  • Requires the state administrator to forward a copy of the report to appropriate people within five days of receiving it.
  • Allows the state administrator to terminate the contract if he or she determines that there is a possibility of election misconduct.
  • Requires the state administrator to notify appropriate people of the termination within seven days.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Election Law - Deadline for Selection of Lieutenant Governor
most_recent_action: Referred Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs
summary:
• Requires a candidate for governor to designate a candidate for lieutenant governor by 21 days after the primary election.
  • Requires a candidate for governor not running in a primary election to designate a candidate for lieutenant governor at the time of filing a nomination.
  • Requires governor and lieutenant governor candidates to provide consent in writing at the time of their candidacy filing or declaration of intent.
  • Requires candidates for lieutenant governor and governor be listed jointly on the general election ballot.
  • Requires the name of the gubernatorial candidate to be listed on the primary ballot.
  • Requires the candidate for lieutenant governor to file a certificate of candidacy when he or she is designated by the candidate for governor.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Election Law - Postelection Tabulation Audits - Risk-Limiting Audits
most_recent_action: Referred Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs
summary:
• Defines automated software audit and electronic count.
  • Changes the name of manual audit to manual count and makes conforming changes.
  • Defines risk limit and risk limiting audit.
  • Requires the State Board and local boards to audit the accuracy of the voting system's tabulation of votes with a risk limiting audit after each statewide election.
  • Lists which races must be included in the audit.
  • Allows the State Board to choose specific races to conduct the audit, with certain limitations.
  • Includes the requirements of a risk limiting audit.
  • Outlines actions if a risk limiting audit finds certain outcomes.
  • Requires the State Board to publish audit results within certain timelines and with certain requirements.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Election Law – Curbside Voting – Establishment
most_recent_action: Taken off notice for cal in s/c Higher Education Subcommittee of Education Administration
categories: In-person voting and polling places,In-person voter assistance
summary:
• Defines curbside voting.
  • Establishes that a voting system must accommodate curbside voting.
  • Lists reasons a voter may be eligible for curbside voting, including qualifying under the Americans with Disabilities Act.
  • Requires local boards to establish a location for curbside voting at each early voting center and on election day at all voting locations, during voting hours.
  • Establishes certain guidelines for implementation of curbside voting.
  • Requires curbside voting to be able to be completed without assistance, unless the voter requests it, and to maintain the secrecy of the ballot.
  • Outlines signage requirements at voting locations for curbside voting.
  • Requires that an area be provided for a voter to obtain information from campaigners.
  • Requires a system by which the voter may announce they have arrived for curbside voting.
  • Requires the voter be promptly acknowledged, and that the same information be provided to curbside voters.
  • Requires two election judges representing different political parties to observe curbside voting, with some exceptions.
  • Outlines the process for requesting a ballot and voting curbside.
  • Requires election judges to maintain a record of each curbside vote at each location.
  • Requires the State Board to designate each curbside voting location at least six months before a primary election and to adopt regulations to carry out the rules outlined for curbside voting.

name: Election Law - Ballots - Processing and Reporting Procedures
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Cure provisions,Counting and canvassing procedures,Provisional ballots
summary:
• Requires a local board, at the start of the absentee ballot canvas, to review the ballot envelope or ballot return envelope for any omission by the voter.
  • Requires the local board to wait until 8am, eight business days before the first day of early voting to being processing absentee ballot envelopes.
  • Forbids a local board from canvasing absentee ballots during the early voting period.
  • Outlines the process for absentee voters who failed to correct an omission on the absentee ballot envelope by 10am, ten days after the election.
  • Requires the State Board to adopt rules requiring a local board to adopt a process for rectifying the absentee ballot envelope problems and specifies what must be included.
  • Requires the local board to release a report of unofficial results beginning after the polls close on election day and at the end of each canvasing day.
  • Outlines a procedure for counting ballots when an absentee ballot and a provisional ballot is received from the same person.

name: Election Law - Ballots - Processing and Reporting Procedures
categories: Cure provisions,Counting and canvassing procedures,Provisional ballots
summary:
• Requires a local board, at the start of the absentee ballot canvas, to review the ballot envelope or ballot return envelope for any omission by the voter.
  • Requires the local board to wait until 8am, eight business days before the first day of early voting to being processing absentee ballot envelopes.
  • Forbids a local board from canvasing absentee ballots during the early voting period.
  • Outlines the process for voters whose ballots do not meet the guidelines.
  • Requires the State Board to adopt rules requiring a local board to adopt a process for rectifying the absentee ballot envelope problems and specifies what must be included.
  • Requires the local board to count only the first legally sufficient ballot it receives from a voter.
  • Requires the local board to release a report of unofficial results beginning after the polls close on election day and at the end of each canvasing day.
  • Outlines a procedure for counting ballots when an absentee ballot and a provisional ballot is received from the same person.

name: Election Law - Absentee Ballot Envelopes - Party Affiliation
summary: • Prohibits absentee ballot envelopes from visibly identifying the party affiliation of the voter.

name: Allows canvassing of early votes and mail-in ballots before election day under certain conditions.
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Voter registration
summary:
• Defines voter registration drive.
  • Establishes events that may constitute a voter registration drive.
  • Requires that each local board conduct a voter registration drive in each public high school in their county at least once per year.
  • Requires the high school to provide a space for free in an appropriate building.

name: Election Law – Voter Registration Drive – High Schools
summary:
• Establishes that a voter registration drive may include an event on school property where: completed registration applications are accepted by election officials or where election officials visit classrooms in a school and distribute and collect voter registration forms.
  • Requires that each local board conduct a voter registration drive at each public high school at least once per year.
  • Requires that the public high school provide a space free of charge for the voter registration drive.
  • Defines voter registration drive.

name: Election Law - Municipal Corporations - Voter Qualifications
summary: • Forbids people who are not US citizens from voting in an election for any municipal corporation.

name: Election Law – Early Voting Centers – Bus Stops
summary:
• Defines a fixed bus route and excludes certain routes.
  • Establishes that if an early voting center is located within one-half of a mile from a fixed bus route, buses should allow passengers to embark and disembark at the entrance of the early voting center during its hours of operation.

name: Permits county board of elections to begin counting mail-in ballots up to 14 days prior to election day.
most_recent_action: Unfavorable Report by Ways and Means
summary:
• Exempts recall elections from requirements for standard election dates.
  • Lists which offices are subject to recall election.
  • Describes the process of filing a petition for recall including timing, signatures, and holding the recall election.
  • Outlines what should be on the ballot for a special recall election.

name: Requires electronic voting system vendors disclose financial ties prior to electronic voting system approval by Secretary of State.
summary:
• Removes the prohibition on legislative districts with more than two counties that they may not have more than one delegate living in the district. 
  • Removes certain requirements related to the content of ballots for election of candidates to the House of Delegates who are required to live in a certain county.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Election Law - Signature Verification of Absentee Ballots and Absentee Ballot Applications and Ballot Canvassing
most_recent_action: Unfavorable Report by Ways and Means
categories: Signature matching,Counting and canvassing procedures,Provisional ballots,Election workers/volunteers
summary:
• Requires the absentee ballot application include an option for voters to indicate their preferred method to receive communication.
  • Requires the election director to verify the signature of an absentee ballot application.
  • Requires the State Board to provide each local board with machines that electronically verify signatures.
  • Outlines the process for if a signature cannot be verified.
  • Requires the voter to provide the local board a copy of any required forms of identification for the absentee ballot application and the absentee ballot return envelope.
  • Requires an election board to verify the signature on a return identification absentee ballot envelope.
  • Outlines the process for if a voter is unable to provide a signature that matches the record.
  • Outlines the process for the local board to verify the signature and the process if they are unable to verify it, including voter notifications.
  • Requires the State Board to adopt appropriate regulations to carry out these rules.
  • Authorizes the local board to reject an absentee ballot if it is established that the voter voted in person in the same election.
  • Establishes that if a voter's absentee ballot was rejected, the voter's provisional ballot may bot be rejected because the voter cast more than one ballot in the same election.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Election Law – Absentee Ballots – Signature Verification and Verification Statements and Unsigned Ballot Statements
categories: Voting equipment,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Oversight and accountability,Signature matching,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary:
• Requires the state board to establish guidelines for verification of signatures on absentee ballot envelopes.
  • Requires absentee ballot envelopes to be signed and signature verified to be counted.
  • Requires a local board to verify the signature by comparing it to the signature with the voter's registration record, which may be done electronically.
  • Requires the state board to provide voter signature verification machines to local boards requesting them.
  • Provides steps if the board is unable to verify a signature.
  • Outlines what should be included in the instructions with the absentee ballot.
  • Allows voters to return a signature verification statement two days after they receive it.
  • Outlines the required contents of a signature verification form.
  • Outlines guidelines for the local board in verifying a signature.
  • Requires each local board to provide certain related information on their website.
  • Requires prepaid postage for the envelope.
  • Requires a voter to return the unsigned ballot statement by the second Sunday after the election to be counted.
  • Outlines the contents of the unsigned ballot statement.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Orphans’ Court Judges – Election and Restriction on Practicing Law
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Nonpartisan elections
summary: This bill prohibits a candidate for judge of the orphans' court from appearing on the ballot in a primary election or being nominated by a political party or by petition. This bill also prohibits judges of the orphans' court from acting as an attorney during their term of office in any matter that is within the jurisdiction of the court and related to the administration of an estate or guardianship of a minor.

name: Requires that election infrastructure vendors disclose financial ties for approval as vendor by Secretary of State; requires report of known or suspected security incidents involving election systems to Division of Elections.
most_recent_action: Introduced in the Senate, Referred to Senate State Government, Wagering, Tourism & Historic Preservation Committee
summary:
• Requires that the method for electing the county or municipality governing body may not impair the ability of members of a protected class to elect candidates of their choice or influence the outcome of the election.
  • Establishes a list of violations, including listing factors that may establish a violation.
  • Includes a list of items a court should consider to determine whether polarized voting has occurred.
  • Outlines further legal exclusions and requirements when considering voting rights violations.
  • Allows the Attorney General to bring action to enforce voting rights violations and offers means of relief.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Provides for vacancy in county surrogate, clerk, register of deeds and mortgages, and sheriff offices occurring 70 days before general election to be filled at second succeeding general election.
summary:
• Defines care giving services as direct care, protection, and supervision of a child or individual with a disability or medical condition for whom a candidate has direct caregiving responsibilities.
  • Excludes private school tuition, tutoring, or nursing home care.
  • Establishes that expenditure includes reasonable expenses for caregiving services that the candidate incurs as a direct result of his or her campaign.

name: Elections – Absentee Ballots – Mailing of Unrequested Ballots
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Municipal election procedures
summary: • Prohibits the state and local board, and municipalities, from mailing absentee ballots to voters who did not request them.

name: Requires ballot privacy sleeves at polling place; makes various changes to early and mail-in voting procedures; creates online form to update name and residence on existing voter registration record.
summary: • Allows county governing bodies to establish a public campaign financing system for any of a list of offices, after establishing it for one complete election cycle under current rules.

name: County Boards of Education - Student Membership - Alterations
summary:
• Directs that the student member on the Board of School Commissioners in certain counties will be an elected position (it was appointed previously). 
  • Requires the student position to be elected by high school students in the jurisdiction.
  • Prohibits the student member from attending executive or special sessions of the board in certain circumstances, unless invited to attend by a majority of the board through a vote.
  • Allows the majority of board members to determine on a case by case basis whether a matter is covered by the exclusionary provision.
  • Establishes that the student member has the same rights and privileges, and voting rights, as other board members with certain exceptions.
  • Provides that the nomination and election process for the student member will be determined by the county board and should include procedures in the case of a vacancy.
  • Establishes certain grade level requirements in certain jurisdictions.

name: Election Law - Casting General Election Ballot in Multiple States - Prohibition
summary: This bill prohibits anyone from casting a ballot in more than one state in the same year.

name: Election Law – Polling Places – Proof of Identity
summary:
• Requires an election judge to establish a voter's identity and verify their address when an individual seeks to vote.
  • Outlines procedures for finding the individual on lists, or establishing the person's identity in another way if they are not on the list.
  • Directs the election judge to authorize a person to vote a regular ballot after establishing their identity.
  • Establishes guidelines for when to refer an individual to a provisional ballot.
  • Forbids anyone from voting or attempting to vote under false identification.

name: Election Law – Postelection Tabulation Audits – Risk–Limiting Audits
summary:
• Requires the State Board in collaboration with local board to audit the accuracy of the voting system tabulation of votes with a risk limiting audit after each statewide election.
  • Lists the races that should be included.
  • Allows the State Board to select specific races to be audited, with certain limitations.
  • Requires the risk limiting audit to examine randomly chosen paper records until a certain quantifiable point in the count.
  • Requires the audit be completed before certification of the election results and be observable to the maximum extent possible.
  • Outlines procedures for an audit outcome determining the electronic count is incorrect.
  • Requires reporting on the state website within 10 days of the conclusion of the audit.
  • Allows the state board to conduct an automated software audit after a statewide election that includes no more than 25% of the ballot styles used in the election.
  • Outlines procedures for pilot risk limiting audits in the November 2022 elections.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Secure Elections Act of 2022
most_recent_action: Referred to Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee
summary:
• Defines an audit threshold as 0.5% of the audit total.
  • Defines an audit total as 3% of absentee ballots cast in the county in the previous comparable election.
  • Defines previous comparable elections.
  • Requires the State Board to conduct an audit of absentee ballots in each statewide election.
  • Requires each local board to canvas absentee ballots in equal number batches, with the State Board determining the number in each batch.
  • Describes the process of choosing absentee ballots to audit.
  • Requires each voter's signature to be verified in the audit.
  • Outlines which personnel should be included in the audit.
  • Describes the process when a signature cannot be verified.
  • Clarifies the process if the total number of signatures that cannot be verified exceed the audit threshold in the county.
  • Establishes reporting and publication requirements for the audit.
  • Requires the State Board to adopt appropriate policies to carry out the audits.

name: Allows county boards of elections to begin canvassing early votes and mail-in ballots before election day under certain conditions.
most_recent_action: Introduced, Referred to Assembly State and Local Government Committee
summary: This bill sets forth a redistricting plan for congressional districts in the State of Maryland.

name: Requires public bodies to publish detailed agenda prior to public meeting.
most_recent_action: Introduced, Referred to Assembly State and Local Government Committee
summary:
• Requires the State Administrator to make arrangements with crematories, morticians, and funeral directors to receive reports of Maryland residents, at least 16 years of age who died in the past 30 days.
  • Requires the State Administrator to transmit this information to the appropriate local board. 
  • Requires the election director to remove the name of the deceased voter when receiving this information.

name: Permits county board of elections to begin counting mail-in ballots up to 14 days prior to election day.
most_recent_action: Introduced in the Senate, Referred to Senate State Government, Wagering, Tourism & Historic Preservation Committee
summary:
• Defines "firearm" and includes examples.
  • Forbids anyone carrying a firearm to a polling site, or within 100 feet of one, during an election, including the parking lot, with certain exceptions.

name: Election Law - Congressional Representatives - Residence Requirement
summary: This bill requires, beginning on November 1, 2024, that a congressional House candidate be a resident, by the day of election, of the congressional district in which the candidate is running to represent.

name: Provides primary and school election sample ballots may be sent to registered voter by electronic mail if so requested.
most_recent_action: Introduced in the Senate, Referred to Senate State Government, Wagering, Tourism & Historic Preservation Committee
summary:
• Allows candidates for state senator or state house to accept certain eligible private contributions under the Public Financing Act.
  • Expands public financing rules to candidates for state senator and state house.
  • Establishes that a candidate for state senator must collect at least 250 eligible private donations worth $15,000 to qualify for Public Financing.
  • Establishes that a candidate for state house must collect at least 150 eligible contributions worth $7,500 to qualify for Public Financing.
  • Establishes that state senate candidates will receive $6 for each dollar of eligible private contributions received for the first $50 of contributions, and $2 for each eligible contribution for the next $100, and no additional funds for other donations.
  • Establishes that state house candidates will receive $6 for each dollar of eligible private contributions received for the first $50 of contributions, and $2 for each eligible contribution for the next $100, and no additional funds for other donations.
  • Establishes maximum limits for public contributions for candidates for governor, state senator, and state house.

name: Election Law - Political Clubs
summary: This bill requires that a political club be established as a political committee and file a statement of organization. This bill also mandates that political clubs file campaign finance reports and prohibits them from paying a person other than a campaign finance entity to defray the costs of a campaign finance entity.

name: Election Law - Polling Places and Early Voting Centers - Electronic Devices
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Enforcement against non-officials
summary:
• Defines electronic device.
  • Allows authorized individuals and voters to use an electronic device at the polling place for specific actions.
  • Outlines when an individual may not use an electronic device at a polling place.
  • Lists which authorized individuals may use an electronic device.
  • Establishes penalties for violating this section.

name: Election Law - Petitions - Signatures
summary:
• Requires petition signatures be in ink.
  • Requires a signature to be validated and counted if the identity of the person can be "reasonably determined" using the required information.
  • Prohibits the election authority from invalidating a signature because someone used a derivative of their given name.
  • Requires the election authority to invalidate a ballot where someone's last name does not match their last name as it appears on the voter registration record.
  • Requires the election authority to validate the first signature of an individual who signed the same petition more than once and makes subsequent signatures invalid.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Election Judges - Training and Signs - Accommodations for Voters in Need of Assistance
summary:
• Requires training materials created by the State Board to include oral and written instruction on the methods a judge may use to assist an elderly or disabled voter at the polling site, including individualized accommodations.
  • Requires the state to develop a sign that states the various methods an election judge may use to accommodate elderly or disabled voters and specifies the size of the sign, and where the sign should be posted.

name: Election Law - Polling Places at Continuing Care Retirement Communities
summary:
• Defines "continuing care retirement community."
  • Requires a local board to establish a separate precinct in a retirement community to serve at least the residents of the facility, if the facility requests a voting location.
  • Requires the continuing care retirement community to provide a free of charge facility for the polling place, and to provide assistance in recruiting election judges from among the residents.

name: Orphans' Court Judges - Election and Restriction on Practicing Law
categories: Ballot access for parties,Nonpartisan elections,Primary systems
summary: This bill prohibits a candidate for judge of the orphans' court from appearing on the ballot in a primary election or being nominated by a political party or by petition. This bill also prohibits judges of the orphans' court from acting as an attorney during their term of office in any matter that is within the jurisdiction of the court and related to the administration of an estate or guardianship of a minor.

name: Permits county board of elections to open inner envelopes containing mail-in ballots up to five days prior to election day.
most_recent_action: Introduced in the Senate, Referred to Senate State Government, Wagering, Tourism & Historic Preservation Committee
summary: This bill makes it a crime to willfully and maliciously destroy, injure, or deface campaign signs. This bill also criminalizes willfully and knowingly obtaining or exerting unauthorized control over campaign signs under certain circumstances.

name: Harford County - County Superintendent - Election and Recall Procedures and Compensation
summary:
• Requires that the superintendent of Hartford County Public Schools will be elected beginning in 2024 to a four year term.
  • Establishes qualification criteria for superintendent candidates.
  • Requires the term to begin December 1 after the election.
  • Prohibits a superintendent from running for more than three consecutive terms.
  • Requires the elected superintendent to choose an assistant superintendent within 60 days of the election, with the approval of the county board.
  • Establishes qualification criteria for candidates for assistant superintendent.
  • Establishes guidelines for filling a vacancy for superintendent or assistant superintendent.
  • Establishes removal and recall guidelines for the two positions.
  • Provides that a registered voter from the county may initiate a recall and outlines the requirements, including petition requirements.
  • Outlines requirements for a candidate seeking to succeed the county superintendent, including ballot placement and wording.
  • Provides for procedures related to the vote for or against recall.
  • Provides procedures for if a superintendent resigns.
  • Requires that the compensation for the superintendent set by the county board be at least equal to the current compensation of the county executive, but not greater by more than 20%.
  • Details what to do in case of a tie in the election.
  • Establishes that in the general election for the superintendent voters may only vote for one candidate and the nominee with the most votes wins the election.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Election Law - Circuit Court Judges - Nonpartisan General Elections
categories: Ballot access for parties,Nonpartisan elections,Primary systems
summary:
• Requires a candidate for circuit court judge to file a certificate of candidacy by 5pm on the first Monday in August in the year of the election.
  • Requires circuit court judges be elected in nonpartisan elections.
  • Describes the process for circuit court judges to file candidacy.
  • Prohibits circuit court judge candidates to be on the ballot in the primary election.
  • Outlines the process for filling a vacancy of a circuit court judge.
  • Specifies that voters may only vote for the number of candidates as there are vacant positions, and the candidate with the largest number of votes wins the election.
  • Describes the process for if there is a tie.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Voters' Rights Protection Act of 2022
summary: • Requires each early voting center to be open beginning the second Thursday before an election through the Sunday before the election, 7am-8pm each day.

name: General Assembly - Residency Requirement - Enforcement - Factors
summary:
• Outlines requirements for candidates seeking to be members of the General Assembly, and members of the General Assembly.
  • Establishes that in determining whether a candidate or member is a resident of a district, the state board or court will consider 13 factors.
  • Establishes that the residency of a candidate or member on active duty may not be considered eligible or ineligible based solely on where the member is stationed.
  • Requires the General Assembly Counsel to annually review the compliance of each member with residency requirements.

name: Elections - Election Judges - Minimum Compensation
summary:
• Provides that compensation for election day and each early voting day may not be less than $200 per day for each election judge.
  • Removes compensation requirements for Allegany County and Calvert County.
  • Allows chief election judges in Washington County to receive a mileage allowance in addition to their pay.

name: Montgomery County - Voting Methods MC 13-22
summary:
• Defines approval voting and ranked choice voting.
  • Allows the Montgomery County Council to adopt ranked choice voting of approval voting for elections for any of a list of offices.
  • Requires the local law to include guidance for ballot format, tabulating procedures, and other provisions.
  • Requires the local law include an education campaign about the method.
  • Allows the Montgomery County Council to choose the format of the ballots for either method.

name: General Assembly – Residency Requirement – Enforcement – Factors
summary:
• Outlines requirements for candidates seeking to be members of the General Assembly, and members of the General Assembly.
  • Establishes that in determining whether a candidate or member is a resident of a district, the state board or court will consider 13 factors.
  • Establishes that the residency of a candidate or member on active duty may not be considered eligible or ineligible based solely on where the member is stationed.
  • Requires the General Assembly Counsel to annually review the compliance of each member with residency requirements.

name: Election Law - Deadline for Selection of Lieutenant Governor
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access deadlines
summary:
• Requires a candidate seeking nomination for governor in a primary to designate a candidate for lieutenant governor within 21 days after the primary election.
  • Requires a candidate for governor to identify a candidate for lieutenant governor when filing a declaration of intent to seek nomination.
  • Establishes that the two candidates will be considered for nomination jointly.
  • Requires a candidate to provide consent in writing.
  • Requires the governor and lieutenant governor candidates to be listed together on the ballot in a primary election.
  • Requires a candidate for lieutenant governor to file a certificate of candidacy at the time the candidate is designated by the candidate for governor.

name: Election Law - False Ballot Drop Boxes - Criminal Penalty
summary:
• Prohibits anyone from collecting absentee ballots in a container that is not an official ballot drop box, or that is not labeled or designated to be an official or unofficial dropbox.
  • Provides felony level penalties including fines and imprisonment.

name: Requires use of paper ballots during conduct of election; requires use of open source voting technology; makes appropriation.
most_recent_action: Introduced in the Senate, Referred to Senate State Government, Wagering, Tourism & Historic Preservation Committee
summary: This bill sets forth a redistricting plan for congressional districts in the State of Maryland.

name: Prohibits voter registration of standard driver's license or identification card applicants.
most_recent_action: Introduced, Referred to Assembly State and Local Government Committee
summary:
• Requires the State Board to adopt requirements for the secure storage and use of voter data.
  • Requires the State Board to adopt regulations regarding the collection of electronic signatures.
  • Specifies the requirements for accepting an electronic signature.
  • Specifies that an electronic signature must reflect an affirmative action of the signer, or add the signer's name to a petition.
  • Requires the State Board to create forms for electronic signature.
  • Requires the circulator of a petition to witness (in person) and attest to a person signing electronically.

name: Establishes pilot program to provide for same-day voter registration on election day in certain years.
most_recent_action: Introduced, Referred to Assembly State and Local Government Committee
summary:
• Requires an audit and a manual audit after each primary and general election.
  • Requires 3% of precincts statewide (up from 2%) be manually audited.
  • Requires the manual audit to begin the same day the final ballots are canvassed.
  • Requires official results to be altered if the manual audit finds that the results from the electronic canvas are incorrect.
  • Provides for an automated software audit.
  • Establishes procedures for various election officials to follow before opening the polls during early voting and on election day.
  • Establishes procedures for after all ballots have been canvased.
  • Outlines procedures when auditing the ballot scanner machine.
  • Lists who may observe election officials while they are performing their auditing duties.

name: Provides for agreement between Secretary of State and AOC to match information in Statewide voter registration system with certain jury records in order to identify and remove ineligible non-citizen voter registrants from system.
most_recent_action: Introduced, Referred to Assembly State and Local Government Committee
summary:
• Defines push poll.
  • Lists characteristics of a push poll.
  • Clarifies that a push poll does not include a survey supporting one candidate that fails to reference another candidate other than in a preference question.
  • Clarifies that this section does not apply to a push poll or political phone solicitation where individuals knew each other before the call.
  • Lists legitimate election practices excluded from push poll prohibitions.
  • Lists requirements that must occur during each call of a push poll.
  • Establishes that it is not a violation if the respondent voluntarily ends a call or asks to be called back after all disclosures are made, with certain exceptions.
  • Prohibits a person giving a fictitious name or phone number.
  • Requires disclosures be made in a clear manner and repeated if necessary.
  • Provides certain exclusions.
  • Requires the push poll to have a designated agent to serve the process, notice, and demand before the poll starts and for at least 180 days after the completion of activities in the state.
  • Outlines certain requirements for the designated agent.
  • Requires the State Board to create and maintain forms for the designation of agents and lists information to be included.
  • Includes these provisions in the civil penalties for violation.

name: Authorizes State constitutional convention to reform system of property taxation; makes appropriation.
most_recent_action: Introduced, Referred to Assembly State and Local Government Committee
summary: This bill requires the State Board of Elections and each local board of elections post aerial photos on their websites showing the location of the electioneering boundary for polling places and early voting centers.

name: Requires Secretary of State to establish voter list maintenance and crosscheck program and to include certain voter registration data in annual report to Governor and Legislature.
most_recent_action: Introduced in the Senate, Referred to Senate State Government, Wagering, Tourism & Historic Preservation Committee
summary:
• Provides that the State Board will review and vote on each contract with more than $50,000 value related to elections.
  • Provides that the State Board must ensure the cost effective use of government resources in administering elections.
  • Requires the state administrator to report each proposed contract or renewal to the Board, including reporting certain information.
  • Requires the state administrator to have Board approval before finalizing a contract.
  • Outlines requirements for a State Board report to the Board of Public Works related to proposed contracts.
  • Provides that counties will reimburse the State Board for 50% of the state's cost of all election related goods and services mandated by the State Board.
  • Allows the State Board to procure other goods that are not mandated, with processing requirements. 
  • Requires each county to pay 50% of the cost for voting systems, absentee voting, and all associated equipment and support costs. 
  • Establishes that county cost will be based on population.

name: County Boards of Education - Elected Members - Recall Procedures
summary:
• Defines "elected member," "local board," "petition."
  • Establishes that an elected member is subject to recall by voters.
  • Lists reasons an elected member may not be recalled.
  • Describes the process a registered voter must use to initiate a recall.
  • Requires the elected member to respond within 14 days of the Notice of Intention being filed and describes requirements.
  • Requires a recall petition to be signed by at least 30% of registered voters in the county.
  • Lists requirements for the recall petition.
  • Lists required steps for the candidate seeking to succeed the elected member.
  • Outlines what should be on the ballot for a special recall election, the process of administering the election, and provides voting instructions.
  • Forbids an elected member subject to recall to be on the ballot to succeed himself.
  • Outlines procedures if an elected member resigns before a recall election.
  • Establishes that a majority of votes is needed for the recall to succeed, and that they candidate for replacement with the highest number of votes wins the election.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Requires public bodies upon request to provide American Sign Language interpreter at public meetings.
most_recent_action: Introduced, Referred to Assembly State and Local Government Committee
summary: • Forbids the absentee ballot form and envelope to include information that identifies a voter's party affiliation.

name: Election Law – Absentee Ballots – Signature Requirements and Verification
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Signature matching,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary:
• Requires the State Board to establish guidelines for verification of signatures on absentee ballot envelopes.
  • Prohibits a local board from removing an absentee ballot from the envelope or counting the ballot unless the ballot is 1) signed by the voter and witness, with certain exceptions, 2) the signature is verified.
  • Makes exceptions for the witness signature requirement with ballots returned by an active duty service member who is overseas, or his or her spouse or dependent also living overseas.
  • Requires a local board to verify the signature on the return envelope by comparing it to the voter registration signature on record.

name: Election Law – Polling Sites – Firearms Prohibitions
summary:
• Replaces the term "gun" with "firearm."
  • Defines the term "firearm" and includes examples.
  • Forbids anyone carrying a firearm to a polling site, or within 100 feet of one, during an election, including the parking lot, with certain exceptions.

name: Election Law – Party and Elected Public Offices – Prohibition
summary:
• Prohibits a person simultaneously holding a party office and an elected public office, excluding those who hold an elected public office and are on the national presidential nominating convention ballot or who hold the office of delegate at a presidential nominating convention.
  • Prohibits an individual from being a candidate for more than one elected office.

name: An Act To Amend the Laws Governing Elections
most_recent_action: PASSED TO BE ENACTED, in concurrence.
categories: Drop-box availability,Ranked-choice voting,Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Cure provisions,Voter ID for registration,Signature matching,Ballot design,Counting and canvassing procedures,Ballot access deadlines,Automatic voter registration
summary:
• Clarifies which elections may be included in ranked choice voting.
  • Allows voters who have an alternative registration signature statement on file to authorize any other Maine registered voter to sign direct initiative of legislation petitions and people's veto petitions, along with other items previously listed.
  • Clarifies that this method of signing satisfies existing requirements.
  • Requires that if someone applies for, renews, or updates a drivers license or state issued ID card, the bureau will record the documentation that provides proof of voter eligibility, unless the individual opts out.
  • Updates the number of nomination petition signatures required for statewide and national office seekers.
  • Changes the deadline to October 1 for a state committee to certify whether is a contest among candidates for several offices.
  • Requires that petitions be delivered to the registrar or Secretary of State for certification by certain deadlines.
  • Allows 16 year olds who are conditionally registered to serve as election clerks.
  • Allows the order on the ballot to be modified for ranked choice contests with certain provisions.
  • Clarifies requirements for counting ballots using ranked choice voting.
  • Allows a municipality to obtain and install secured drop boxes for absentee ballots that meet specified criteria related to location, security, quantity, design, accessibility, monitoring, labeling, with certain exceptions.
  • Outlines how absentee ballots in the dropbox must be removed and processed.
  • Requires an electronic absentee ballot application to be accepted if it contains a voter's name, date of birth, and certain address(es).
  • Clarifies that a voter applying for an absentee ballot may be asked for their phone number and email address, which will remain confidential.
  • Requires a clerk to issue absentee ballots when the official ballots become available. 
  • Prohibits a clerk from issuing an absentee ballot to any third person who has been issued five absentee ballots for voters in the municipality until the person has returned one of those ballots.
  • Adds "incapacity or illness" where a voter is unable to leave home as an approved reason for requesting an absentee ballot after the deadline.
  • Prohibits the clerk from issuing a ballot to a candidate other than the candidate's own ballot.
  • Requires the clerk to note whether a cured absentee ballot was accepted or accepted but challenged, including requiring certain specific information. 
  • Requires a clerk verify a voters address and year of birth before issuing a ballot.
  • Outlines procedures for the clerk to examine signatures and affidavits and outlines what to do in specific situations.
  • Provides procedures for curing defects on an absentee ballot envelope.
  • Provides procedures for wardens verifying signatures on absentee ballot return envelopes.
  • Requires the clerk to note on the absentee ballot envelope if the ballot was rejected. 
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create and maintain an online service for voters to request and track absentee ballots.
  • Requires that upon determination of electors for President, the Governor must send each elector's name and number of votes each candidate for President received statewide and by Congressional district.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: An Act Regarding 2021 Municipal Elections and Town Meetings
most_recent_action: PASSED TO BE ENACTED - Emergency - 2/3 Elected Required, in concurrence.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Administrative deadlines,States of emergency,Voting materials,Municipal election procedures
summary:
• Allows a municipal budget approved in the previous year to be considered approved if the meeting is delayed because of public health concerns related to COVID-19.
  • Allows assessors to commit property taxes based on the approved budget.
  • Allows the municipal treasurer to disburse funds based on a warrant created for that purpose and signed by a majority of municipal officers during a governor-declared state of emergency related to COVID-19, and for 30 days after the emergency ends.
  • Allows municipal officers to postpone a scheduled election at least two days before the election. 
  • Outlines guidelines for notification and rescheduling the election.
  • Outlines guidelines for notification when the new election is scheduled and ready to be held.
  • Outlines guidelines for absentee ballots and establishes that the same rules apply for municipal ballot referendums.
  • Allows a referendum vote hearing to be carried out remotely following certain guidelines.
  • Outlines guidelines for municipal officers terms of office during a state of emergency due to COVID19 and when to conduct secret ballot elections during the state of emergency.
  • Requires municipal officers file the wording for a referendum question by 30 days before the referendum.
  • Suspends the requirement for a written ballot to change the property tax levy at an open town hall meeting during a state of emergency, and allows instead for a show of hands or voice vote.
  • Retroactivly applies this bill to January 15, 2021 and repeals it as of June 30, 2022.

name: An Act To Promote Civic Engagement and Voter Participation for Young People by Lowering the Voting Age for Municipal Elections to 16 Years of Age
summary: This bill lowers the voting age for municipal elections to 16 years of age.

name: An Act To Adopt the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact
most_recent_action: Pursuant to Joint Rule 310.3 Placed in Legislative Files (DEAD)
summary: This bill repeals ranked-choice voting in general elections for President of the United States and proposes to adopt an interstate compact to elect the President of the United States by national popular vote. Under the compact, all of a state's electoral votes would be awarded to the presidential candidate who receives the most popular votes in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. The bill would take effect only if enacted by states possessing a majority of the electoral votes, which is at least 270 of 538.

name: An Act To Join the National Popular Vote Compact
most_recent_action: Pursuant to Joint Rule 310.3 Placed in Legislative Files (DEAD)
summary: This bill repeals ranked-choice voting in general elections for President of the United States and proposes to adopt an interstate compact to elect the President of the United States by national popular vote. Under the compact, all of a state's electoral votes would be awarded to the presidential candidate who receives the most popular votes in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. The bill would take effect only if enacted by states possessing a majority of the electoral votes, which is at least 270 of 538.

name: Elections: voting equipment; electronic voting systems being incapable of being connected to or operated on the internet; require. Amends sec. 795 of 1954 PA 116 (MCL 168.795).

summary:

name: Elections: election officials; objective signature verification process; require secretary of state to create, clarify and expand the rights of election challengers, and require election inspectors to wear a name badge. Amends secs. 31 & 733 of 1954 PA 116 (MCL 168.31 & 168.733) & adds sec. 672a.
most_recent_action: Assembly Legislative Operations and Elections Hearing (16:00:00 16:00:00 Room 4100)
summary:
• Establishes requirements for the curriculum and training of election officials, including multiple penalties and violations, and signature validation requirements.

  • Requires all appointed election inspectors to wear a badge while acting as election inspector, with certain requirements regarding the content of the badge and its distribution.
  • Establishes that failing to comply is punishable as a misdemeanor offense with possible imprisonment and/or a fine.
  • Allows a challenger to be located behind the processing table.
  • Allows a challenger to observe the election process at a "reasonable distance" and defines the term.
  • Allows a challenger to challenge the manner the duties of an election inspector are being performed.
  • Establishes that a challenger may observe but not interfere with voters.
  • Defines "good reason to believe."
  • Establishes that a challenger may obtain the voting results generated after polls close.
  • Establishes that a challenger may use an electronic device as long as it does not impede with a voter's right to vote a secret ballot.
  • Clarifies that an expelled challenger may demand and be provided a written explanation for the expulsion, and the entity that appointed the challenger may appoint a replacement.
  • Outlines reporting requirements if someone infringes on the rights of a challenger.
  • Makes clarifying changes.

name: Elections: voters; definition of identification for election purposes; expand to include current concealed pistol license. Amends sec. 2 of 1954 PA 116 (MCL 168.2).

Elections: petitions; process for counting duplicate petition signatures; provide for, and eliminate penalties. Amends secs. 482, 590h, 685, 957 & 958 of 1954 PA 116 (MCL 168.482 et seq.); adds secs. 482f & 547 & repeals sec. 547a of 1954 PA 116 (MCL 168.547a).
summary:
• Removes knowingly signing a petition more than once as a violation of Michigan election law.
  • Provides that only the first signature of a voter who signs a petition more than once will be counted.

name: Elections: election officials; certification procedures for boards of county canvassers; modify, and extend the ballot retention period. Amends secs. 201, 581, 811, 822, 842 & 847 of 1954 PA 116 (MCL 168.201 et seq.) & adds sec. 841a.
summary:
• Provides clarifying edits.
  • Changes the timeframe for the board of county canvassers to deliver a certificate of returns from 14 days to 21 days after the election to the county clerk.
  • Changes the timeframe for each county clerk to deliver to the Secretary of State a certified statement of how many votes each candidate received from 14 days to 21 days after the election.
  • Changes the timeframe for the Secretary of State to call a meeting of the board of state canvassers from 20 days after the election to 22 days.
  • Changes when primary election ballots may be destroyed from 30 days after the election to 180 days after the election.
  • Changes the timeframe for the board of county canvassers to complete a canvass and certify election results from 14 days to 21 days after an election.
  • Provides procedures for if a member of the county board of county canvassers signs an affidavit saying that their vote on certification was made under duress.
  • Changes the deadline for the board of state canvassers to meet with the Secretary of State for determining the results of an election from 20 days to 22 days after the election.
  • Changes the deadline by which the Secretary of State may ask for certification of returns for electors for President and Vice President, during an expedited canvass, from 14 days after the election to 21 days after the election.
  • Changes the deadline for the Secretary of State to require the receipt of returns after an expedited canvass from 20 days to 22 days after an election.

name: Elections: absent voters; electronic return of absent voter ballots by uniformed services voters and overseas voters; allow, and codify tabulating certain absent voter ballots received up to 6 days after the election. Amends secs. 759a & 764a of 1954 PA 116 (MCL 168.759a & 168.764a) & repeals sec. 18a of 1954 PA 116 (MCL 168.18a).

Elections: qualified voter file; most recent digitized photographic image of an elector to be contained in the qualified vote file; require, and require election officials to compare the digitized photographic image of an elector to that elector before voting. categories: In-person voter ID,Voter ID for registration,Signature matching,Voter list maintenance,Automatic voter registration
summary:

  • Makes clarifying edits.

Elections: voting equipment; use of electronic voting systems that contain certain parts or equipment; prohibit. Amends secs. 795 & 795a of 1954 PA 116 (MCL 168.795 & 168.795a).

name: Elections: offenses; intimidating an election inspector or preventing an election inspector from performing his or her duties; prohibit. Amends 1954 PA 116 (MCL 168.1 - 168.992) by adding sec. 931b.

name: Townships: other; disincorporation of a township; provide for. Amends title of 1851 PA 156 (MCL 46.1 - 46.32) & adds secs. 16m, 16n, 16o, 16p, 16q, 16r, 16s, 16t, 16u, 16v, 16w, 16x, 16y & 16z.
most_recent_action: Referred To Committee On Local Government And Municipal Finance
categories: Ballot measures (initiative and referendum),Municipal election procedures,Special election procedures,Election workers/volunteers
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides for the disincorporation of a township into a county, requiring a petition signed by at least 15% of registered voters of the township to initiate the process.
  • Requires the petition to designate the county into which the township would be disincorporated.
  • Outlines procedures for the township clerk to declare a sufficient petition.
  • Directs that if the petition is sufficient, a question about the disincorporation must appear on the ballot of the next election and provides the format for the question.
  • Requires the county election commission of the involved county to provide ballots and for the clerk and election officials of the associated cities and townships to conduct the election.
  • Requires the associated board of county canvassers to conduct the related canvass.
  • Specifies that a majority vote by both the township, and the county, excluding votes cast by the township, is needed to pass.
  • Outlines procedures upon approval of the question, including directing the county board of commissioners to pass a related resolution at their next regular annual meeting.
  • Outlines procedures related to vacating the incorporation of the township, including as they relate to taxes and debt and creation, membership, and rules for a disincorporation commission.
  • Outlines the duties and procedures of the disincorporation commission.
  • Outlines language for a ballot measure asking voters whether they approve the disincorporation of the township by using the plan adopted by the disincorporation commission.
  • Specifies that the question should be included in specified general, primary, or special elections, and specifies rules for special elections.
  • Requires a majority vote by both the township, and the county, excluding votes cast by the township, to pass.
  • Outlines procedures for if the proposal is not adopted.

name: Elections: scheduling; May regular election and August regular election; eliminate, and replace with March regular election and June regular election.
