summary: As introduced, this bill repeals the use of drop boxes for mail-in ballots.

name: Complaint process for election law violations established.
most_recent_action: Introduction and first reading, referred to Elections Finance and Policy
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the secretary of state to establish a procedure for the review of complaints and provide a complaint form that requires the signature of the complainant and any supporting documentation.

Right to vote restored to individuals convicted of a felony upon completion of any term of incarceration imposed and executed by a court for the offense, and money appropriated.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: As introduced, this bill restores voting rights to individuals charged or convicted of a felony that are not currently incarcerated.

name: Grant appropriation to improve access to polling places
categories: In-person voting and polling places,State appropriations
summary: As introduced, this bill appropriates $500,000 from the state general fund to counties and municipalities to improve access to polling places for individuals with disabilities.

name: Early voting provision
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Municipal election procedures,Early voting eligibility,Early voting administration,Early voting duration
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires the statewide voter registration system to provide reports with the information needed to conduct early voting.
  • Establishes that eligible voters may vote early in federal, state, and county elections, and that early voting must run from 30 days before the election through 5pm on the third day before the election. 
  • Specifies that early voting must be available from 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. on weekdays and 10:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. on Saturdays. Early voting must be available from 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. on at least one weekday. 
  • Requires at least one voting station to be made available at each polling place, as well as at least one ballot marking device for disabled voters.
  • Provides that city elections not held in conjunction with other regular elections may offer early voting upon resolution of the governing body. Outlines requirements.
  • Specifies that voters must be notified about early voting at least 14 days in advance and specifies the locations of the notification.
  • Outlines early voting procedures and specifies that ballots must be counted by the ballot board.
  • Requires the computer program for any election to be delivered at least 40 days before the election.
  • Specifies that absentee ballots must be accepted from 8 a.m. to 12 p.m. on the day before an election subject to early voting.

name: Elections; voting instructions and sample ballots required to be printed in languages other than English for designated precincts, multilingual election judges required in precincts, and voting instructions in languages other than English required for use in in-person absentee voting.
Authorization repeal of absentee ballot drop boxes
summary: As introduced, this bill repeals the use of absentee ballot drop boxes.

name: Complaint process establishment for certain election law violations
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the secretary of state to establish a procedure for the review of complaints currently in statute and to provide a public complaint form that requires the signature of the complainant and supporting documentation.

name: Data classification in the statewide voter registration system
summary: As introduced, this bill makes certain data in the statewide voter registration system private including some personally identifying information, information maintained on the presidential nomination primary political party list (except the secretary of state must provide the list to the chair of each major political party), and persons who have petitioned and been granted to keep their information confidential. Any person requesting public data from the database must state in writing that any information obtained will not be used for purposes unrelated to elections, political activities, or law enforcement.

name: Requirement modification related to the ordering of candidates for partisan offices on the state general election ballot
summary: This bill, as introduced, changes the ordering of candidate names on ballots. For those party orders determined by average vote, it defines average vote as dividing the total number of voters for office by the number of votes for that party’s candidate. It adds that partisan and nonpartisan offices will have rotating names.

name: Counties, municipalities, and school districts prohibited from accepting contributions for election expenses.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits a county, municipality, or school district from accepting funds from a for-profit business or a nonprofit organization for the purpose of paying expenses associated with conducting an election.

name: Elections; judicial offices provisions modified, requirement that term incumbent be printed next to incumbent candidate's name on ballot repealed.
summary: As introduced, this bill repeals the requirement that a chief justice, associate justice, or other incumbent judge candidate be designated as an incumbent on the ballot.

name: Photo ID required to register to vote and to vote, voter identification card created, provisional ballots established, reports required, and money appropriated.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Oversight and accountability,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,In-person voter ID,Voter ID for registration,Voter ID for low-income voters,Witness or notary requirements,Counting and canvassing procedures,Reporting,In-person voting and polling places,Provisional ballots,State appropriations,Legislative authority,Military/UOCAVA voting,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Prohibits a fee or surcharge for a certified vital record if the applicant attests the record is needed for voter identification, and requires an annual report regarding the number of records so requested.
  • Clarifies a fund calculation and transfer system to pay for the cost of the fee or surcharge, and establishes a voter ID card account in the special revenue fund.
  • Outlines what information requirements must be included in an application for a voter identification card and supplies that submitted information is private data.
  • Establishes that a voter ID card must be issued to qualified voters and specifies the format of the card, and its purpose.
  • Specifies that a voter ID card issued to an active military service member, or their spouse, does not have a renewal requirement until one year after the service member's discharge, or the cardholders birthday four years after the card was issued.
  • Specifies that if a voter ID card holder changes address, they must apply for a duplicate card with certain address requirements.
  • Outlines reasons for a card cancellation and requires the commissioner to cancel a card meeting those reasons and notify the person.
  • Lists documents that provide sufficient proof of identity.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Specifies that a person registering on election day must provide proof of identity, along with (already existing) proof of residence, and that those who cannot do so must vote a provisional ballot.
  • Requires certain application processing procedures by the election judge.
  • Applies an exception for listing an address of someone participating in the Safe at Home program on the polling place roster.
  • Requires the county auditor or municipal clerk to verify a submitted ID number in an application for an absentee ballot.
  • Changes the absentee ballot envelope used to establish a certificate of eligibility from the "return" envelope to the "signature" envelope and specifies that the certificate must contain an oath, and specifies requirements for showing a witness proof of identity and residence, as well as for the witness administering an oath.
  • Submits identity requirements for a witness.
  • Outlines affidavit requirements for a voter unable to secure proof of identity and residence, as well as provisional ballot procedures.
  • Outlines procedures for the county auditor or municipal clerk to accept or reject a provisional ballot.
  • Outlines procedures and timelines for reconciling and counting provision ballots.
  • Changes the day of the county canvassing board meeting from the second or third day after the election to the eighth day and requires the canvass to be completed on that day.
  • Changes the day for the state canvassing board to meet from the seventh day after the election to the fourteenth day after.
  • Changes the day for the county canvassing board to meet at the auditor's office from between the 3-10 day to between the 8-14 day.
  • Specifies a new deadline for the election return report for a general election to be received by the secretary of state from ten days after the election to 15 days.
  • Provides that a vendor may be contracted to produce and implement a statewide public education campaign related to voter identification requirements.
  • Requires the secretary of state to report to certain legislative committees on proposed legislation related to this bill.
  • Requires training for driver's license agents on the process of issuing voter ID cards.
  • Appropriates funds for voter ID.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Retention elections requirement for persons appointed to certain county offices
most_recent_action: Referred to State and Local Government and Veterans
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires an county to hold a retention election for an office becoming an appointed office at the first general election after appointment, to determine whether to retain the appointed person.
  • Provides that if the appointee is not retained, he or she must stay in the position until January 1 immediately following the election.
  • Requires the county board of commissioners to appoint another person to the position following January 1.
  • Requires the county to hold a retention election at the general election every four years while the office is appointed.
  • Details the wording of the ballot question.

name: Designation and election of presidential electors provided.
most_recent_action: Introduction and first reading, referred to Elections Finance and Policy
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires each major political party to nominate one presidential elector for each congressional district and two electors at large.
  • Directs that the party must specify which electors are representing which specific districts.
  • Requires the state canvassing board to clarify in its canvass statement the number of votes cast for presidential electors statewide and within each congressional district.
  • Furnishes that statewide vote totals must be used to determine those elected at large, and congressional district totals must be used to determine those elected to represent a district.

name: Political subdivisions prohibited from establishing or enforcing ranked-choice voting.
categories: Ranked-choice voting,Conflicts between levels of government
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits political subdivisions from adopting or enforcing ranked-choice voting as a voting method.

name: Trainee election judges service until reaching the age of 18 authorization
Trainee election judges permitted to serve until reaching the age of 18.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows trainee election judges to continue to serve in their role until they turn 18 years of age.

name: Requirements provided related to mailings containing an absentee ballot application or sample ballot sent by or on behalf of a committee or other private organization.

Photo ID required to register to vote and to vote; voter identification card created; provisional ballots established; compensation methods related to absentee voting prohibited; identification of individuals acting as agent for absentee voter required; identification of individuals providing assistance to voter in polling place required; voter registration and absentee voting activities prohibited; counties, municipalities, and school districts prohibited from accepting contributions for electi
categories: Voter ID for registration,Counting and canvassing procedures,Reporting,Provisional ballots,Private funding,Voter registration,Absentee/mail-in voter assistance
summary:
As introduced, this bill: 

  • Requires photo identification from driver’s license, state or voter identification card, US military ID, or identification card from Bureau of Indian Affairs for in-person and mail in voting. Other combination of documents and IDs can be accepted per statute to provide proof of address and photo ID. 
  • Requires identification for individuals assisting other voters at a polling location.
  •  Allows voters who cannot prove identification through the above means to vote using a provisional ballot, after which they will have 7 days to prove their identity.  
  • Prohibits the state from charging for state voter identification cards or for providing records required to obtain a state voter identification card. 
  • Requires voter identification card applications to collect name, DOB, sex, address and proof of address, and SSN or proof of not being assigned one. 
  • Requires voter identification cards to have identifying personal and physical information about the individual, like a driver’s license has, be colored, have a unique number, and be labeled with “valid identification only for voting.”  
  • Allows any individual who does not have other approved photo identification and is an eligible to vote to apply for a voter identification card. 
  • Requires in-person absentee voting locations to be open during the entire absentee voting period and maintain the same operating hours as the office of the county auditor. 
  • Allows the commissioner to cancel voter identification cards under specific circumstances. 
  • Changes the county canvassing board meetings to the 8th day after the primary and the state canvassing board to 14 days after the primary. 
  • Requires the secretary of state to report to legislative election committee chairs and ranking members on or before January 15, 2024 with proposed amendments for administrative changes to enact this bill. 
  • Prohibits counties or municipalities from taking contributions from any private entity to pay for election administration.

name: Voter registration provisions modification
Prohibitions clarification on soliciting at or near a polling place
summary: As introduced, this bill modifies certain prohibitions around electioneering and soliciting votes at polling locations and strengthens certain languages around these prohibitions.

name: Automatic voter registration system provided.
categories: Reporting,Voter participation deadlines,Noncitizen voting,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance,Automatic voter registration,Testing and certification
summary:
As introduced on January 26, 2023, this bill:

  • Defines "ineligible voter data."
  • Provides that qualified individuals will be automatically registered to vote if they file certain applications, unless they choose to decline the registration.
  • Outlines the requirements for developing a process for the person to decline to be registered to vote.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Requires the Department of Public Safety commissioner, the Department of Human Services commissioner, and other agencies and units of government, to monthly submit data to the secretary of state identifying the number of qualified individuals completing transactions and the number transferred to registration.
  • Requires the secretary to publish a monthly report with the data.
  • Stipulates that those qualifying must be US citizens.
  • Provides requirements for accuracy of data and system testing.
  • Defines "driver's license."
  • Requires the secretary of state to submit registration data to the county auditor of the voter's county and outlines what the county auditor must do with the registration information.
  • Provides instructions on how and when to inactivate a voter's record.
  • Provides that the effective date of the registration is 20 days after the date of the application and allows anyone registered 20 days before an election to vote in the election.

name: Voting eligibility requirements for federal, state, and local elections modification prohibited by local ordinance or charter provision unless authorized by Constitution.
summary: As introduced, this bill prevents local governments from changing voter eligibility requirements in any election.

name: Right to vote restoration to individuals convicted of a felony upon completion of any term of incarceration imposed and executed by a court for the offense
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:
• Provides that an individual incarcerated due to a felony has their right to vote restored when they are no longer incarcerated.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create a publication on the voting rights of people charged with a  crime and make it electronically available to certain groups.
  • Outlines how the chief executive officer of each correctional facility must implement a program informing people of their restoration of their right to vote and how to register to vote, including an application.

name: Virginia Retirement System; investments, environmental, social, and governance investing restricted.
summary:
• Requires the attorney general to assist in enforcement of a series of laws related to business, commerce, and trade, as well as laws related to voter intimidation, interference, and deceptive practices in elections.
  • Lists specific potential infractions in voting related practices and elections and their penalties.
  • Provides for and defines vicarious liability related to elections.
  • Establishes the extent and limits of remedies.
  • Lists specific voter intimidation and deceptive practices included in the code, and establishes penalties. 
  • Defines related terms. 
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Provisional balloting procedure establishment
summary: As introduced, this bill creates a procedure for the use of provisional ballots in certain circumstances.

name: State Canvassing Board declaration of the candidates duly elected who received the highest number of votes for each federal and state offices requirement
summary: • Provides that the winner of a federal and state election is the candidate who won the most votes.

name: Amendment to the Minnesota Constitution authorizing individuals under the age of 18 to vote at a primary election if the individual will be 18 by the general election
most_recent_action: Referred to Judiciary and Public Safety
summary: As introduced, this bill would amend the Minnesota constitution to allow citizens under the age of 18 who are otherwise qualified to vote to vote in primary elections when they will be 18 years old by the date of the general election. The bill submits the amendment to Minnesota voters as a ballot question in the 2024 general election.

name: Persons allowed to be absent from work to vote in person before election day.
categories: Early voting administration,Time off for voting
summary: As introduced, this bill expands the right to be absent from work to vote to include the early voting period.

name: Absence from work to vote in person before election day authorization
summary: • Adds the early voting period to existing Code allowing a person to be absent from work to vote.

name: Retention elections for persons appointed to county offices required.
most_recent_action: Introduction and first reading, referred to Elections Finance and Policy
summary: As introduced, this bill requires, for any county office made an appointed office, the county must hold an election on whether to retain the person appointed.

name: Voter electronic signatures allowed for purposes of electronic rosters.
summary: This bill, as introduced, allows electronic signatures for voters on online voter registration applications. The electronic roster must label the signature as electronic.

name: Procedure for the chair of either of the state's two largest major political parties to request a forensic audit of a state primary or state general election establishment
summary:
As introduced on January 27, 2023, this bill:

  • Provides that a request for a forensic audit must be made by 5pm on the second day after the canvas for a state election.
  • Provides that the chair of either of the two largest major parties may file a request for a forensic audit.
  • Lists what must be included in a forensic audit and who may conduct the audit.
  • Requires costs of the requested audit be covered by the requesting party and outlines related procedures.

name: Voter registration provisions modified; absentee voting provisions modified; voting instructions, sample ballots, and election judges required to be multilingual in certain situations; intimidation, deceptive practices, and interference with voter registration and voting regulated; campaign finance provisions modified; Democracy Dollar coupon program established; political contribution refund program repealed; definition of express advocacy expanded; penalties provided; and reports required.
most_recent_action: Introduction and first reading, referred to Elections Finance and Policy
categories: Permanent lists,Oversight and accountability,Transparency,Language accommodations,Enforcement against non-officials,Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Youth voting,Noncitizen voting,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance,Automatic voter registration,Testing and certification
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Establishes that someone convicted of a felony will have their right to vote restored after incarceration, or upon sentencing when not incarcerated, clarifying that the right to vote is lost only during incarceration.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Establishes that someone who is at least 16 may submit a voter registration application pursuant to existing law regarding preregistration, and makes conforming changes.
  • Requires the voter registration form to include an option to join the permanent absentee voter list.
  • Establishes that registered voter information is not public until the voter is registered or has a voting history.
  • Lists ways in which a qualified voter may be automatically registered with proof of citizenship.
  • Provides that a qualified voter may decline automatic registration and specifies procedures and timelines.
  • Specifies that the commissioner of public safety must consult with the secretary of state when making changes to instruction permits and requires all forms to provide for documentation of citizenship, and makes conforming changes.
  • Requires voter registration related information from the department of safety to be transmitted daily.
  • Directs the commissioner to monthly submit data to the secretary of state data regarding registrations, and outlines citizenship verification requirements.
  • Outlines certification and testing requirements for transmission of data, including deadlines, and defines "driver's license."
  • Instructs that the commissioner of human services in consultation with the secretary of state must ensure certain applications also serve as voter registration applications and specifies requirements and information transmitting guidelines and deadlines.
  • Outlines certification and testing requirements for transmission of data, including deadlines.
  • Authorizes the governor to make a decision whether to implement automatic voter registration with other agencies and includes requirements.
  • Instructs the secretary of state to determine whether submitted voter registration applications are already in the database and specifies procedures if they are or are not in the database.
  • Outlines procedures, including notification procedures and prosecution specifications, for ineligible applicants whose data is removed.
  • Provides an effective date for declining registration of 20 days after the date of the qualifying application.
  • Directs the secretary of state to develop information in a single publication regarding voting rights for those convicted of a crime.
  • Specifies procedures for delivery of absentee ballots to voters on the permanent absentee list.
  • Outlines notification requirements and responsibilities to provide information to those whose right to vote is restored after incarceration, including providing language for the notification.
  • Directs that beginning with the effective date of this act, election officials may not print voter registration applications that do not meet this act's requirements.
  • Establishes that voting instructions and sample ballots will be created in languages other than English and outlines related requirements and procedures, including the requirement that the materials be made available when voting occurs.
  • Outlines procedures for establishment of language minority districts and specifies translation requirements and procedures.
  • Prohibits someone threatening, coercing, violence, restraint and more as it relates to voting and provides for civil action and penalties.
  • Prohibits and defines deceptive practices and prohibits interference in registration or voting.
  • Establishes that someone may be held vicariously liable for damages resulting from listed violations.
  • Establishes criminal and civil penalties and remedies.
  • Defines "expressly advocating."
  • Establishes a Democracy Dollars campaign finance program and makes conforming changes.

name: Minnesota Elections Integrity Act
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,In-person voter ID,Counting and canvassing procedures,Reporting,In-person voting and polling places,Private funding,In-person voter assistance
summary:
As introduced, this bill: 

  • Requires photo identification from driver’s license, state or voter identification card, US military ID, or identification card from Bureau of Indian Affairs for in-person and mail in voting. Other combination of documents and IDs can be accepted per statute to provide proof of address and photo ID. 
  • Requires identification for individuals assisting other voters at a polling location. 
  • Allows voters who cannot prove identification through the above means to vote using a provisional ballot, after which they will have 7 days to prove their identity.
  • Prohibits the state from charging for state voter identification cards or for providing records required to obtain a state voter identification card.
  • Requires voter identification card applications to collect name, DOB, sex, address and proof of address, and SSN or proof of not being assigned one.
  • Requires voter identification cards to have identifying personal and physical information about the individual, like a driver’s license has, be colored, have a unique number, and be labeled with “valid identification only for voting.”
  • Allows any individual who does not have other approved photo identification and is an eligible to vote to apply for a voter identification card.
  • Requires in-person absentee voting locations to be open during the entire absentee voting period and maintain the same operating hours as the office of the county auditor.
  • Allows the commissioner to cancel voter identification cards under specific circumstances.
  • Changes the county canvassing board meetings to the 8th day after the primary and the state canvassing board to 14 days after the primary.
  • Requires the secretary of state to report to legislative election committee chairs and ranking members on or before January 15, 2024 with proposed amendments for administrative changes to enact this bill.
  • Prohibits counties or municipalities from taking contributions from any private entity to pay for election administration.

name: Requirement that the term incumbent be printed next to the incumbent candidate's name on the ballot repeal
summary: As introduced on January 27, 2023, this bill repeals the requirement that the designation incumbent must be included by an incumbent candidate's name on a ballot.

categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals

name: Designation and election of presidential electors establishment
summary:
As introduced on January 27, 2023, this bill:

  • Provides that each major party will nominate one presidential elector for each congressional district, and two at large electors.
  • Requires the chair to indicate those nominated for districts (and the district number) and those nominated at large.
  • Requires that when canvassing, winners for at large seats are determined using statewide vote totals, and congressional winners be determined using district vote totals.

name: Free, fair, and equal elections provided, and constitutional amendment proposed.
summary:
• Proposes a Minnesota Constitutional Amendment which prohibits civil or military power to interfere with the free exercise of the right to vote.
  • Specifies the form of the proposed amendment on the 2024 general election ballot.
  • Specifies an implementation timeline.

name: Right to vote restored to individuals convicted of a felony upon completion of term of incarceration imposed and executed by court for the offense.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: As introduced, this bill restores the right to vote to any citizen charged or convicted of a felony who is not currently incarcerated.

name: Voters who register on election day required to cast provisional ballots, and conforming changes made.

summary: As introduced, this bill requires any voter who registers to vote on election day and votes in that same election to cast their vote on a provisional ballot.

name: Voters allowed to join permanent absentee voter list, and absentee ballots required to automatically be sent before election to voters on permanent absentee voter list.
summary: This bill, as introduced, updates voter registration applications to include option for applicant to sign up for permanent absentee voter list. Voters who opt-in will automatically receive a ballot 46 or more days before the next election, unless it is a town general election and then it will be 30 days or more before.

name: Amendment to the Minnesota Constitution, providing for free, fair and equal elections

summary: This bill, as introduced, amends the constitution to add language affirming that elections will be “free, fair, and equal” and prohibits the use of civil or military power to infringe on that. The bill would put this amendment on the next 2024 general election ballot for the people to approve or reject.

name: Provisional balloting procedure established.

summary: As established, this bill creates a procedure by which some voters vote with provisional ballots.

name: State Canvassing Board required to declare candidates duly elected who received highest number of votes for each federal and state office.
summary: As introduced, this bill stipulates that the State Canvassing Board shall declare as duly elected each candidate who receives the ihghest number of votes for each state and federal office.

  • Allows the commissioner to cancel voter identification cards under specific circumstances.

name: Voters who register on election day casting of provisional ballot requirement
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Administrative deadlines,Voter ID for registration,Counting and canvassing procedures,Ballot access deadlines,Provisional ballots,Voter registration,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Removes the requirement for an oath for an election day registration.
  • Entitles an election day voter registrant to cast a provisional ballot with certain required procedures.
  • Requires election day voter registration applications to be entered no later than three days after the election.
  • Requires the secretary of state to provide same day voter registration reports for six days following an election.
  • Specifies procedures, processing, and requirements for voter registration that is included with an absentee ballot.
  • Modifies methods a voter may use to rectify an incomplete voter registration mail application by removing the option to provide proof of residence.
  • Prohibits someone who is not registered from casting an absentee ballot using alternative procedure.
  • Specifies a list of options for meeting residence requirements.
  • Outlines procedures for casting a provisional ballot, as well as procedures and timelines for accepting or rejecting, and counting, the ballots.
  • Changes the deadline for the county canvass board to meet and complete the count from the 2nd or 3rd day to the 10th day following the primary.
  • Changes the deadline for the State Canvassing Board to meet from seven days after the election to 14 days.
  • Changes the timespan for the county canvass board to meet from 3-10 days after the election to 10-17 days after.
  • Modifies the deadline for the county canvass report to 17 days (from 10) after a primary election, or 24 days after a general election.
  • Requires the school board certification to occur on the 10th day after the primary.
  • Requires a school board canvass of returns between the 10-17 days after the election, instead of 3-10 days after.
  • Requires the secretary of state to conduct a public awareness campaign with certain timelines and requirements.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Voter electronic signatures permission for purposes of electronic rosters
summary: As introduced, this bill permits voters to complete and sign an electronic form for certain registration purposes.

name: Statewide voter registration system data classification establishment
summary: This bill, as introduced, defines and details privacy requirements on information stored in the statewide voter registration system.

name: Ballot reconciliation and postelection review duties required to be completed before canvassing board may certify its report on results of an election.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits canvassing boards from anounncing election results until all duties related to ballot reconciliation are completed as required by law.

name: Local optional revenue information required on referendum ballot.
most_recent_action: Introduction and first reading, referred to Education Finance
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a referendum ballot state a district's existing amounts of referendum revenue authority and local optional revenue per pupil. A notice of the pending referendum ballot proposal sent to each taxpayer before an election must contain the same information.

name: Photo ID requirement to register to vote establishment
categories: Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,In-person voter ID,Counting and canvassing procedures,Reporting
summary:
As introduced, this bill: 

  • Requires photo identification from driver’s license, state or voter identification card, US military ID, or identification card from Bureau of Indian Affairs for in-person and mail in voting. Other combination of documents and IDs can be accepted per statute to provide proof of address and photo ID. 
  • Allows voters who cannot prove identification through the above means to vote using a provisional ballot, after which they will have 7 days to prove their identity.  
  • Prohibits the state from charging for state voter identification cards or for providing records required to obtain a state voter identification card. 
  • Requires voter identification card applications to collect name, DOB, sex, address and proof of address, and SSN or proof of not being assigned one. 
  • Requires voter identification cards to have identifying personal and physical information about the individual, like a driver’s license has, be colored, have a unique number, and be labeled with “valid identification only for voting.”  
  • Allows any individual who does not have other approved photo identification and is an eligible to vote to apply for a voter identification card. 
  • Allows the commissioner to cancel voter identification cards under specific circumstances. 
  • Changes the county canvassing board meetings to the 8th day after the primary and the state canvassing board to 14 days after the primary. 
  • Requires the secretary of state to report to legislative election committee chairs and ranking members on or before January 15, 2024 with proposed amendments for administrative changes to enact this bill.

name: Ranked-choice voting establishment and enforcement prohibition
summary: This bill, as introduced, prohibits cities and towns from holding elections using ranked-choice voting.

name: Elections; ordering of candidates for partisan offices on state general election ballot requirements modified.

For those party orders determined by average vote, it defines average vote as dividing the total number of voters for office by the number of votes for that party’s candidate. summary: This bill, as introduced, allows people under 18 but over 16 to complete a voter registration application for preregistration.

name: Minnesota Constitutional amendment proposal to place limits on the terms of office of legislators and executive officers
most_recent_action: Referred to State and Local Government and Veterans
summary: As introduced, this bill proposes a Constitutional amendment to be submitted to voters that would impose term limits on state legislative and executive officeholders.

name: Certain duties related to ballot reconciliation and post election review requirement to be completed before a canvassing board may certify its report on the results of an election
summary: This bill, as introduced, prohibits the canvassing board certifying results until all ballot reconciliation and the postelection review are completed.

name: Resolution memorializing Congress to overturn the United States Supreme Court decision Citizens United v. FEC; requesting Congress to clarify rights protected under Constitution are rights of natural persons and not rights of artificial entities and spending money to influence elections is not speech under First Amendment; asking Congress to propose constitutional amendment
summary: This resolution asks that Congress overturn the United States Supreme Court decision, Citizens United v. FEC, and requests that Congress clarify that the rights protected under the Constitution are the rights of natural persons and not the rights of entities. This resolution asks Congress to clarify that spending money on elections is not speech under the First Amendment and asks that Congress propose a constitutional amendment to provide such clarification.

name: Election judges lists with party affiliation submission to secretary of state requirement
summary:
• Requires submission to the Secretary of State a list of election judges by 14 days after the election.
  • Specifies certain information that must be included in the list.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide the chair of each relevant political party with a list of politically affiliated judges 14-21 days after an election.

name: Early voting establishment and appropriation
categories: Early voting eligibility,Early voting administration,Early voting duration
summary:
• Includes early voting in existing electoral code, including related to reporting, and procedures, including absentee ballot procedures.
  • Defines early voting.
  • Establishes that voters may not vote absentee in-person during the early voting period.
  • Establishes opening hours for county offices collecting absentee ballots and applications.
  • Outlines ballot board duties related to early voting.
  • Includes early voting in rules related to recording a vote and storage and counting of ballots.
  • Changes the day when absentee ballot envelopes may be opened to the day prior to the beginning of early voting, from the 7th day before the election.
  • Establishes that any eligible voter may vote early, and outlines procedures for applying this at the local and state level.
  • Outlines a the timeline for early voting, locations for early voting, notification of voters, procedures for early voting.
  • Requires the county auditor to prepare and make available election materials for early voting one day before the beginning of the early voting period.
  • Provides that the computer program for an election must be completed and delivered at least 40 days before an election.
  • Requires a voting system be tested at least 37 days before an election (changed from 14 days before).
  • Appropriates related funds.

name: Resolution applying to Congress for a limited convention to propose an amendment to the United States Constitution to restore balance and integrity to elections
summary:
• Proposes a resolution calling on Congress to call a Constitutional Convention to restore free and fair elections.
  • Specifies individuals who should receive a copy of the resolution.

name: Ranked choice voting implementation in federal and state elective offices establishment
summary:
• Defines terms relevant to ranked choice voting.
  • Provides that the ranked choice voting method must be used for federal, state, and legislative offices at every primary and regular election.
  • Authorizes local adoption of ranked choice voting for all general elections and primaries.
  • Clarifies that a primary election must not be held for nonpartisan races. 
  • Outlines timelines for adopting ranked choice voting.
  • Outlines guidelines for how to repeal ranked choice voting.
  • Specifies ballot format for ranked choice voting.
  • Outlines requirements for tabulation of ranked choice voting including location and procedures.
  • Codifies procedures for reporting results.
  • Outlines procedures for a recount.
  • Gives the Secretary of State implementation authority.
  • Requires outreach, notification, and training before use of ranked choice voting in an election.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to create ballot format rules for ranked choice voting, with certain requirements.
  • Specifies procedures for use of an approved electronic voting system with an unapproved tabulating system.
  • Outlines procedures for purchasing and testing a new electronic voting system.
  • Specifies requirements related to ranked choice voting in the post election review.
  • Requires that ranked choice voting be used for presidential nominating elections.

name: Postsecondary student voter registration provisions modifications

• Requires postsecondary institutions to prepare a list of students residing on campus or within 10 miles of campus, with certain exceptions.
  • Allows certain proofs of residence for eligible student voters.

summary: This constitutional amendment allows a person under the age of 18 to vote in a primary election if the person meets all other voter eligibility requirements and will be 18 years of age or older on the date of the general election. The amendment goes into effect if approved by voters at the 2022 general election.

summary:

  • Outlines procedures for a vacancy and a special election in the Metropolitan Council office.

  • Outlines transition requirements for the Metropolitan Council members.
  • Applies the Act to certain counties.

  • Makes complying changes.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Strengthening Attorney General Oversight of Voting and Election (SAVE) Act established.
most_recent_action: Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections
summary:

  • Clarifies that the jurisdiction is concurrent with the local prosecuting authority.
  • Requires an investigating Attorney General to notify appropriate local authorities.

name: Elections; procedure established for two largest major political parties to request forensic audit of primary and general state elections.
most_recent_action: Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections
summary:
• Outlines the requirements and timeline for a forensic audit.
  • Provides for payment for a forensic audit.
  • Outlines the expenses for which the requesting party is responsible.

name: Certain duties related to ballot reconciliation and postelection review requirement to be completed before canvassing board may certify its report on the results of an election
categories: Oversight and accountability,Counting and canvassing procedures,Certification
summary: • Establishes a canvassing board may not certify its results report until all required ballot reconciliation and post election review is complete.

name: Elections; various provisions modified including voter ID card, provisional ballots, absentee voting, and election expenses; criminal penalties increased; report required; and money appropriated.

summary:
• Prohibits a fee to be charged when someone certifies they need a certain document to register to vote, or a voter identification card, and outlines related reporting requirements.
  • Provides for appropriations related to this service, including specifying certain amounts.
  • Adds a voter identification card to the list of identifications whose format must be approved by the department.
  • Provides that no fee may be charged for a voter identification card.
  • Stipulates what must be included on the application for a voter identification card.
  • Outlines criteria and requirements for issuing a voter identification card.
  • Outlines required content of a voter identification card.
  • Establishes rules governing voter identification cards for military voters and their spouses.
  • Stipulates that voter identification cards must have the voter's current address and procedures to update a card and issue a duplicate card.
  • Specifies procedures for canceling a voter identification card.
  • Lists what is considered sufficient proof of identity and residence for Election Day voter registration.
  • Establishes a voter identification card account for reimbursement in for multiple specified expenses.
  • Specifies that the polling place roster address must be the voter's most current address, and includes certain exceptions, and outlines verification procedures when a voter is checking in to vote.
  • Outlines certain provisions for absentee ballot signature envelopes, particularly for the witness.
  • Includes the voter identification number as an acceptable identification for an application for absentee ballot.
  • Requires the appropriate official to verify identification numbers provided for absentee ballot applications.
  • Allows the voter identification card as an acceptable ID for the absentee ballot signature envelope. 
  • Provides that a judge must require a voter to sign the polling place roster and outlines procedures for voters who do not have proper identification.
  • Prohibits a government entity from accepting contributions in any form from an outside entity to pay for election related expenses.
  • Outlines procedures for distributing, casting, and counting provisional ballots.
  • Provides that the canvas board, or other canvas group, will meet on the 8th day (rather than the second or third day) after the election and complete the canvas. 
  • Provides timelines for the canvas board, or other canvas group, to meet at the auditor's office, and the state capitol, to canvas the vote.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to receive the canvas report 10 days following a primary and 15 days following a general election.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to contract with a vendor regarding a voter information campaign about voter identification requirements, with specific requirements.
  • Requires the Secretary of State by January 15, 2023 to report on proposed changes to administrative rules governing elections, with certain requirements.
  • Requires training for drivers license agents on issuing voter identification cards.
  • Requires any other designated polling place be open for in person absentee voting during the entire absentee voting period during the same days and hours as the office of the county auditor. 
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Provides effective dates.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Absentee voting compensation methods prohibited, identification of individuals acting as absentee voter agent required, identification of individuals assisting a voter in a polling place required, voter registration and absentee voting activities prohibited, and criminal penalties increased.

  • Requires those assisting a voter to provide certain information and establishes that assisting a voter in an unauthorized manner is a felony.
  • Established that a person may not unduly influence a person to register or vote absentee, and violations are a felony.

name: Ballot reconciliation and postelection review duties required to be completed prior to canvassing board certification of election result report.
most_recent_action: Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections

summary:

name: Right to vote restored to individual convicted of a felony upon completion of any term of incarceration imposed and executed by a court for the offense.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: This bill mandates that an individual convicted of a felony has his or her civil right to vote restored when the individual is no longer incarcerated for the offense, or upon sentencing if no incarceration is imposed. If the individual is later incarcerated for the same offense, the individual's civil right to vote is lost only during the period of incarceration. This bill requires a notice of restoration of the civil right to vote and a voter registration application be provided to formerly incarcerated individuals and those leaving incarceration.

name: Right to vote restoration for persons with felony convictions upon execution completion of incarceration term
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: This bill mandates that an individual convicted of a felony has his or her civil right to vote restored when the individual is no longer incarcerated for the offense, or upon sentencing if no incarceration is imposed. If the individual is later incarcerated for the same offense, the individual's civil right to vote is lost only during the period of incarceration. This bill requires a notice of restoration of the civil right to vote and a voter registration application be provided to formerly incarcerated individuals and those leaving incarceration.

name: Resolution memorializing Congress to overturn the United States Supreme Court decision Citizens United v. FEC; requesting that Congress clarify that the rights protected under the Constitution are the rights of natural persons and not the rights of artificial entities and that spending money to influence elections is not speech under the First Amendment asking that Congress propose a constitutional amendment to provide such clarification
summary: This resolution asks that Congress overturn the United States Supreme Court decision, Citizens United v. FEC, and requests that Congress clarify that the rights protected under the Constitution are the rights of natural persons and not the rights of entities. This resolution asks Congress to clarify that spending money on elections is not speech under the First Amendment and asks that Congress propose a constitutional amendment to provide such clarification.

summary: This bill authorizes mail balloting in any town or city with fewer than 400 registered voters.

  • Specifies filing official duties.
  • Establishes that city or school district may assume legal costs (in addition to a county) incurred by an elected local official and pay the costs of a hearing.
  • Clarifies that an elected local official may be removed by majority vote at a special election held for that purpose.
  • Provides an effective date and requirements.
  • Makes clarifying changes.

most_recent_action: Referred to State Government Finance and Policy and Elections

summary:
• Changes options for a voter submitting an incomplete voter registration application by mail to require the voter to complete the application more than 20 days before the election, but not requiring any additional items.
  • Allows a voter to register to vote on Election Day by filing out a voter registration application.
  • Clarifies that a voter registration application must be printed on or attached to a provisional ballot envelope and contain certain information.
  • Requires voter registration applications submitted on Election Day to be added into the statewide system within three days of the election (from 42 days).
  • Requires the Secretary of State to provide a daily report for six days after an election about voter registration applications received.
  • Clarifies that a voter registration application may be placed in a return envelope with an absentee ballot.
  • Outlines procedures for opening absentee ballot return envelopes and handing voter registration applications.

  • Changes the name of absentee return envelopes to signature envelopes.
  • Lists forms of acceptable identification for a challenger.
  • Outlines procedures for casting, administering, and counting provisional ballots.
  • Changes a series of deadlines for canvassing primaries, canvassing county elections, reporting on county elections, reporting results for municipal primaries, canvassing returns and certifying elections, canvassing school district primaries.
  • Requires the Secretary of State to conduct a public awareness campaign encouraging people to register to vote. 
  • Provides conforming changes.
  • Provides clarifying language.

name: School use as polling places limitation authorization
most_recent_action: Referred to State Government Finance and Policy and Elections
summary:
• Directs that a school may be designated as a polling place only when no other location is reasonably available.
  • Directs election staff to establish an environment where contact between students and voters is minimized.
  • Defines "school."

Redistricting principles established, district numbering requirements provided, and census data use specified.
summary:
• Requires legislative districts to be numbered in a specific way outlined in the provision.
  • Establishes a list of principles of redistricting.
  • Establishes the components of the redistricting process.

name: Incumbent candidate separate filing period provided, and supplemental filing period established in the event of a candidate withdrawal.
most_recent_action: Introduction and first reading, referred to State Government Finance and Elections
summary:
• Splits deadlines for nonincumbent and incumbent candidates in general elections.
  • Requires nonincumbent candidates to file 70-84 days before the primary.
  • Requires incumbent candidates to file 75-84 days before the primary.
  • Outlines guidelines and deadlines for when an incumbent withdrawal is filed on the last day of the filing period or during the withdrawal period.

name: Modifies provisions relating to elections
most_recent_action: HCS Reported Do Pass (H) - AYES: 13 NOES: 1 PRESENT: 0
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,Ballot access deadlines,Electioneering,Voter registration
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that if the closing date for filing a candidate declaration falls on a holiday, the deadline will be 5pm on the day after the holiday.
  • Exempts a government entity from having to register to solicit voter registration applications.
  • Requires the confidentiality of absentee ballot application lists for people with permanent disabilities. 
  • Allows a person without a proper voter ID who is requesting an absentee ballot in person or who claims to be properly registered in the jurisdiction can be given provisional ballot. 
  • Increases the distance for prohibited electioneering activities near polling places from 25 to 100 ft. 
  • Criminalizes the action of tampering with an elected official.

name: Moves school board elections to the November general election
most_recent_action: Formal Calendar S Bills for Perfection
categories: Election dates,Alignment of elections,Municipal election procedures
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Allows a candidate for school board to file for and hold any other office for which he or she is qualified.
  • Establishes that all school board elections will be held on the first Tuesday following the first Monday in November of even-numbered years.
  • Establishes that the term of all school board candidates will be four years, with some exceptions.
  • Outlines procedures for transitioning to the new election dates and terms.
  • Specifies that the candidate in each election earning the highest number of votes will be elected.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Modifies the date that a president, vice president, secretary, and treasurer will be chosen for a school board from July 15 of each year to January 15 of odd-numbered years.

name: Modifies constitutional provisions about election and voting
most_recent_action: Special Committee on Public Policy Executive Session (16:30:00 16:30:00 House Hearing Room 7)
categories: Primary systems,Counting and canvassing procedures,Legislative authority,Testing and certification
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Modifies existing legislation to require all ballots to be paper ballots.
  • Requires voters to have only the number of votes for an office or issue as there are available seats or issues.
  • Directs that the winner of a primary election is the person receiving the greatest number of votes, and that that candidate's name should be placed on the general election ballot, with certain exceptions.
  • Directs that the winner of the general election is the person receiving the greatest number of votes.
  • Requires voting machines used for counting to be tested and certified in accordance with federal standards.
  • Specifies that voting machines are not required for tabulating votes.
  • Empowers the general assembly to require or prohibit the use of voting machines.

name: Requires all elections for local tax increases to be held at a general or primary election
categories: Election dates,Alignment of elections,Ballot measures (initiative and referendum)
summary: As introduced, this bill requires all proposals levying a new tax, license, or fee, or renewing or increasing a current tax, license, or fee, to be submitted to voters at general or primary elections. The bill would apply to proposals submitted after January 1, 2024.

name: Reinstates the presidential preference primary

  • Provides that if the closing date for filing a candidate declaration falls on a holiday, the deadline will be 5pm on the day after the holiday.
  • Exempts a government entity from having to register to solicit voter registration applications.

name: Requires all elections for local tax increases to be held at a general or primary election
most_recent_action: Second Read and Referred S Local Government and Elections Committee
summary: As introduced, this bill requires all elections for a new, increase, or renewal of taxes to be submitted to the voters on a general or primary election day.

name: Modifies provisions relating to elections
most_recent_action: Hearing Conducted S Local Government and Elections Committee

name: Modifies constitutional provisions relating to elections
most_recent_action: SCS Voted Do Pass S Local Government and Elections Committee (0915S.05C)
categories: Audits,Ballot access for candidates,Voting materials,Noncitizen voting,Testing and certification,Digital/electronic voting,Physical security
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Introduces a constitutional amendment providing that all voters must be US citizens, "over" the age of 18, and residents of Missouri, and the county where they are registering, to be able to vote.
  • Specifies that ballots may be paper or mechanical.
  • Specifies that voters are entitled to one vote for each office.
  • Requires that a candidate receiving the greatest number of votes in a party primary election will be the only candidate for that party at the general election.
  • Requires that every voting machine in an election be tested and certified, to federal standards, before the election.
  • Requires each voting machine to create a paper record of votes, available for inspection and verification by the voter.
  • Requires the paper record to be retained for audit.

name: Requires closed primary elections
most_recent_action: Second Read and Referred S Local Government and Elections Committee

name: Modifies provisions for election-related mailings
summary: As introduced, the bill changes the requirements that an election authority send notifications through first class mail rather than a voter ID card.

name: Creates new provisions of law relating to elections
most_recent_action: Second Read and Referred S Local Government and Elections Committee
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Authorizes the legislature to regulate both voter qualifications and the time, place, and manner for state and local elections and clarifies compliance with federal elections laws.
  • Requires any state agency or official who communicates with the U.S. Department of Justice or any other federal agency related to voting or election laws to notify the governor or legislature within five business days. 
  • Requires all federal election guidance to be approved by the legislature, and all election administration officials or agencies must give notice to the legislature 30 days before implementation of guidance. 
  • Requires all federal election funds to be approved by the legislature before dispersal, and all election administration officials or agencies must give notice to the legislature 30 days before dispersal to explain intent.

name: Requires closed primary elections
most_recent_action: Second Read and Referred S Local Government and Elections Committee
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Permits voters to only vote in the primary of the political party with which they are affiliated.
  • Allows voters to change political party affiliation. Changes must be made less than 23 weeks before the primary election or the change will not take effect until after the election. This bill establishes the procedure and deadlines for people who have not registered to vote in a primary election.
  • Requires a registered person (as of the effective date of this bill) to vote in the 2024 primary or they will become unaffiliated.
  • Requires any candidate must be affiliated with a party 23 weeks prior to the opening of the candidate filing before a primary election.

name: Requires election authorities to make available at least one electronic voting machine per polling location for blind or visually impaired voters at an election in order to comply with federal law
categories: In-person voting and polling places,In-person voter assistance
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires an election authority with 350,000 residents or more to provide one voting machine per polling location for those who are blind or visually impaired.
  • Requires an election authority with 350,000 residents or less to provide one voting machine for those who are blind or visually impaired.
  • Clarifies that each election authority is presumed to possess an accessible voting machine for compliance with the Help America Vote Act, and clarifies that the state will pay any additional costs for maintenance and use of the machines for statewide and general assembly elections.
  • Provides that any qualified voter may use the accessible voting machine without confirmation of blindness or visual impairement, and that the provision does not require those who are blind or visually impaired to use the machine.
  • Specifies that voters who are blind or visually impaired may continue to vote absentee.

name: Establishes voting procedures for persons confined in jails who are otherwise eligible to vote
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Allows defendants who are in jail the opportunity to vote absentee if they are eligible.
  • Clarifies that the person's address is his or her last residential address previous to confinement.
  • Requires jails housing defendants who are eligible to vote to provide absentee ballot applications and to assist in the mailing of the application, including covering the cost of the mailing.
  • Specifies that local election authorities receiving these applications should very the voter's eligibility in the same manner as other applications are verified, and that they should ,ail the appropriate ballot, including postage paid return, to the voter.
  • Codifies that a defendant is allowed to exercise his or her right to vote upon receipt of the ballot.

name: Removes requirements for party affiliation
summary: As introduced, this bill repeals the requirement that voters register a party affiliation when registering to vote or be marked unaffiliated, exempts a government entity from having to register to solicit voter registration applications, and criminalizes distributing personal information of an election official with the intent to harass or influence them.

name: Creates provisions for automatic voter registration

summary:

  • Requires the department of revenue and the motor vehicle division to provide the secretary of state's office information the secretary specifies to conduct automatic voter registration.
  • Provides that when someone is nonconditionally discharged from probation, parole, or incarceration, the department of corrections must submit certain information to the secretary of state, and that the secretary of state must forward the information to the local election authority for inclusion in voter registration lists.
  • Requires the secretary of state to provide a list of recommendations for inclusion on voter registration lists to local authorities and for local authorities to include the recommendations, subject to existing procedures, and furnishes that local election authorities retain full jurisdiction to recline to register individuals who are not verified to be eligible and to remove those who become ineligible from the list.
  • Outlines timelines and procedures for notifying an individual of an automatic voter registration, including how an individual may decline the registration.
  • Empowers the secretary of state to create rules necessary for administration of automatic voter registration.

name: Modifies requirements for voter qualifications following release for prison or jail
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: As introduced, this bill strikes a provision prohibiting someone on parole or probation for a felony from voting.

name: Creates provisions for ranked-choice voting
Creates provisions for ranked-choice voting
summary: As introduced, this bill requires all primary and general elections to use ranked- choice ballots and instant runoff voting, explains the procedures for ranked-choice ballots and instant runoff voting, and ensures voting equipment is compatible with ranked-choice ballots.

name: Creates provisions for automatic voter registration
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires the secretary of state to establish a system for automatic voter registration.
  • Lists which actions would result in an individual being automatically registered.
  • Requires relevant agencies and departments to periodically provide voter information to the secretary of state related to automatic voter registration.
  • Requires the secretary of state to periodically provide local election authorities with lists of recommendations for their voter registration lists and specifies that if the recommendation meets the criteria, the local authority must send notice of potential automatic registration to the prospective voter.

name: Modifies constitutional provisions for voter eligibility and voting procedures
most_recent_action: Second read and referred: Local Government and Elections(S)
summary: HJR131 is a proposed constitutional amendment. Upon voter approval, HJR131 would provide that only citizens of the United States are eligible to vote. It would require that voters cast a single vote for each office or issue (thereby prohibiting the use of ranked-choice voting and similar electoral systems). It would require that the plurality winner of any political party primary election be the only candidate for that political party on the general election ballot. It would also require the use of paper ballots and voting records, which would be preserved for use in any election audit.

name: Requires the vote-counting process to be recorded and livestreamed
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the vote-counting process for every election in the state to be live-streamed and recorded and for the recordings to be public records available to the public.

summary: This bill would allow the secretary of state to audit the registered voter list and perform cyber security reviews of local election authorities. The state or any other political body under the state may not receive private money for the election, except for limited forms of in-kind donations. Exception: in any even-numbered year where the state funds for counties are less than the previously distributed amounts, private money can be received and used to make the difference. Board of election employees and election judges do not have to be registered in the jurisdiction. Anyone who solicits 10 or more voter registration forms is required to register. Starting in 2023, voter applications will include an option to affiliate with a political party. Voters registered prior to 2023, may choose a party affiliation at the polling location. Absentee ballots can be cast in person at designated locations if the individual meets 1 of the absentee reasons in statute. Starting in 2023, the official ballot will be paper ballots “hand marked by the voter,” except for ballots cast with accessibility options. name: Modifies provisions relating to voter registration
summary: This bill would change registration timing to allow for voter registration any time on or before election day. Individuals would be able to register at the election authority office in their jurisdiction. They would have till the close of polls to register.

name: Creates provisions for automatic voter registration
summary: This bill would require the secretary of state to establish a process for automatic voter registration from the state’s driver’s license database. The secretary of state, after receiving information from the department of revenue and the motor vehicle, will make recommendations for new registered voters to local election authorities. Local election authorities will determine eligibility for registration, and within 2 months will notify individuals determined eligible to vote so that they can decline registration. Individuals will have 1 month to decline registration, if they do not, they will become registered voters. If a decline is sent in after 1 month, at that time the individual will be removed from the voter registration list.

name: Creates provisions for automatic voter registration
summary: This bill would require the secretary of state to establish a process for automatic voter registration from the state’s driver’s license database. The secretary of state, after receiving information from the department of revenue and the motor vehicle, will make recommendations for new registered voters to local election authorities. name: Creates provisions for early voting
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Early voting eligibility,Early voting administration,Early voting duration
summary: This bill would enable early voting in-person or by mail, for any voter without needing an excuse. Early voting in-person and by mail would start the 6th Tuesday before the election and last till the Monday before the election. Early voting will be during regular business hours, but starting 21 days before the election will include Saturday and Sunday voting hours from 11:00 AM to 5:00 PM. The hours increase to 8:00 AM to 7:00 PM for all days starting the Tuesday before the election. Early voting locations are determined by local election authorities, with 1, central location for every 3 precincts. Election authorities will appoint 1 or more election judges from each “major” political party to be at the central and any satellite early voting locations.

summary: This bill would require election authorities to add voter history to the registration system “by the time required for election certification.” Touchscreen, direct-recording, voting machines when ready for replacement will be replaced with paper ballot marking devices. Starting in 2023 no machines of that kind can be used except for by voters with disabilities. Election authorities are to be added as members to Center for Internet Security and will allow cyber security reviews of offices. If in violation, the secretary of state can withhold non-federal funds. The bill establishes a Federal Election Fund in the state treasury which will house all appropriated, federal money designated for elections. Federal laws regarding elections would be subject to review by the joint committee on administrative rules prior to be implemented in the state. Starting in 2023, the official ballot will be paper ballots “hand marked by the voter,” except for ballots cast by voters needing assistance due to disability. Antifraud countermeasures, including paper type, watermarks, bank security, and numbering, will be required for all printed ballots. Applications for absentee ballot would now require the voter identification number be provided. In person absentee voting at authorized locations and voters at a polling location will require a photo identification to vote. Mail-in ballots (different than absentee ballots) are only to be used when authorized by executive or administrative order. Any individual seeking to vote with a provisional ballot must first provide an affidavit on the ballot’s envelope. Official ballots must be stored for at least 1 year after the election’s certification.

name: Changes the law regarding primary elections
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Primary systems,Voter registration
summary: This bill would require a voter to be affiliated with a political party prior to voting in that party’s primary election. They would have to designate the party selection on their voter registration by the 23rd Tuesday before a primary election (including presidential preference primary). If a voter wants to change their affiliation after the 23rd Tuesday before a primary election, the change will apply after the election takes place. Notice of change must be done via a signed, written notice following the same process as a voter’s change of address notice. If an individual is unregistered to vote but registers before 5:00 PM on the 4th Wednesday before the primary election, they may choose a party affiliation and vote in the primary election. Those voting via absentee will only receive a primary ballot with the affiliated political party or the unaffiliated ballot. 19 weeks or sooner before a primary election date the secretary of state will distribute a list of registered voters eligible to vote in each political party’s primary election. This “closed primary” system will take effect starting in 2025. Political parties established under section 115.315 are allowed to be exempt from this system and hold a caucus or other election. New voter registration application with political party affiliation question will be available starting in 2023. During the 2024 primary and presidential preference primary, voters who registered prior to 2023 will be registered going forward for whichever political party primary they choose to vote in that election. Voters who registered prior to 2023 who also did not vote in the primary elections will have the opportunity to choose a party affiliation at the general election.

They will be allowed to watch the election process, including certification of voting system, testing of tabulating equipment, absentee in-person voting, canvassing, voter appeals, vote tabulation, ballot transport, audits, and recounts. Watchers must have a badge with their name and political party or ballot measure affiliation but cannot wear any campaign material.
