summary: As introduced, this bill limits what qualifies as a accepted voter identification for in-person and absentee voting, removes requirements that voters be provided notice of the need to provide identification in certain circumstances, and requires voters voting on provisional ballots present acceptable voter identification.

name: Permanent Absentee Voter List
summary: As introduced, this bill creates a permanent absentee voter list and directs county clerks to automatically send a mailed ballot to voters on the list.

name: Elections; canvassing of returns; providing for continuous tabulation; effective date.
categories: Voting equipment,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Administrative deadlines,Audits,Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Voting materials,Primary systems,Counting and canvassing procedures,Election workers/volunteers,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance
summary:
• Clarifies when the Inspection of Public Records Act should apply to public records relating to elections. 
  • Adds definitions related to real-time synchronization of data from voting locations to the office of the county clerk.
  • Creates an election security program within the office of the Secretary of State (SOS) to advise on voting system and cybersecurity requirements, conduct assessments, inspections, and incident response related to elections-critical infrastructure, and monitor functionality of voting systems. 
  • Requires an election-related organization to register with SOS in advance of elections to fill a vacancy in the U.S. House of Representatives. 
  • Limits the use of forms to include only those forms issued and authorized by the SOS and requires service of process on the SOS for election-related litigation.
  • Requires that election board appointments be eligible to vote. 
  • Changes how the county clerk may appoint teams of election judges and provides that each team shall have two election judges that shall not belong to the same political party and provides that an election judge cannot have changed party registration in the previous two years if that change makes the judge ineligible to serve on the team. 
  • Specifies that identification shown to register to vote must be issued by not just “a” government but a state or federal government and tribal government and removes references to identification issued by an education institution as an acceptable form of identification. 
  • Provides that, to register to vote, the name of the qualified elector must reasonably match the name provided on the certificate of registration.
  • Requires that the convening of the absent election board shall take place no earlier than 13 days prior to Election Day.
  • Notes that, relating to transmission of ballots, the ballot must be sealed either with a numbered seal or locking device before being transmitted. 
  • Gives appropriative authority to the board of county commissioners from the county general fund all funds necessary for the administration of elections. 
  • Clarifies that for mayor-appointment of officers, the mayor must submit names for confirmation and the governing body must confirm that persons are appointive officials of the municipality, no longer to include employees.
  • Adds to the definition of obstructing a polling place to include unlawful possession of alcoholic liquors by election board members while performing their duties on Election Day, which the bill notes would be a petty misdemeanor if committed.
  • Revises election board and messenger compensation to be no less than twice the minimum hourly wage set by federal or state law and provides for board and messenger payment for training and per diem/mileage, to be paid by the SOS either through grant/reimbursement or direct payment process.
  • Requires training for challengers, watchers, and election observers to be provided by the county clerk and clarifies limitations for appointment or service. 
  • Provides additional prohibited activities for poll watchers, challengers, and observers, including photographing ballots or protected information.
  • Requires creation of voter convenience centers and removes language regarding prerequisites for consolidation of the centers. 
  • Requires that elected members in political subdivisions with 16 thousand or more residents be a resident of the district, whereas members for subdivisions with fewer than 16 thousand residents may reside at any location in the political subdivision and be elected at large. 
  • Requires the SOS to develop a program to maintain clean voter rolls and reconcile voter registration lists, effective July 2022.
  • Creates provisions related to same day registration, to be provided during early and Election Day voting at all statewide and special elections. 
  • Clarifies the documentation that may be used as identification when a voter registers prior to voting.
  • Changes when county clerks may begin processing voter registrations after an election from 35 days after Election Day to the Monday following an election.
  • Clarifies that a full Social Security number (SSN) is required for registration, sets all county boards of registration to five members, and requires the Motor Vehicle Department to transmit all signature images to the SOS.
  • Requires county clerks verify the last four digits of the registrants’ SSN and signature prior to turning mailed ballot envelopes to the absentee election board and requires county clerks to update absentee voter identification requirements to include both the last four digits of the voter’s SSN as well as a signature.
  • Prohibits absentee applications provided by third parties, establishes that applications must be received 14 days prior to election day.
  • Requires a notice to be sent to a voter’s registration address if a ballot is mailed to another address.
  • Requires a notice to be sent if a ballot is rejected. 
  • Requires that an informational notice be sent with all mailed ballots.
  • Provides for a violation under the election code for establishing a fax drop box.
  • Updates the definition of “immediate family” authorized to return an absentee ballot and clarifies replacement ballot provisions.
  • Provides that if the election board must convene after election day, law enforcement supervision is to be provided for uncounted ballots.
  • Sets working hours for the board if counting is not complete on election night and provides that absentee application from a federal overseas voter is allowed up to three days prior to Election Day if requesting secure electronic delivery of a ballot.
  • Updates the definition of voter-participant to include qualified residents and provides procedures for which a voter-participants may request a replacement ballot.
  • Removes references to public regulation commissioners as elected officials.
  • Clarifies the form requirements and timing for filling a vacancy on a primary and general election ballot.
  • Adjusts the nominating petition requirements for minor party candidates so that if there are fewer registered voters affiliated with the minor party than signatures required then the signature count is to be the same as for independent candidates.
  • Removes the ability to nominate candidates via a state preprimary convention. 
  • Removes references in election law to public regulation commissioners. 
  • Changes the authority to amend the proclamation to be the SOS rather than the governor and removes the option for county candidates from submitting a pauper’s statement in lieu of paying a $50 filing fee and instead requires the candidate to gather nominating petitions.
  • Reduces the nomination requirement in the following ways: 1% of the total vote of the candidate’s party in the district for the public education commission, 2% for judicial candidates, and 3% for all other primary candidates.
  • Amends the primary write-in candidate provisions to require nominating petitions containing the same number of signatures required for major party candidates and establishes the same qualification and challenge process for write-in candidates as is provided for non-write-in candidates.
  • Reduces the amount of time before Election Day that the county clerk is required to certify in writing the ballot for each precinct or county, from 60 days to 56 days.
  • Clarifies that the order of candidates for the same office must be determined in a randomized way. 
  • Requires the Secretary of State to notify voters of an election 42 days prior to each election.
  • Opens the process of preparing, inspecting, certifying and sealing electronic voting machines to observation by the public and requires reporting of serial numbers and product specifications of ballot tabulators to the county chairs of each political party on a ballot.
  • Changes the local election assessment fund to the state election fund and provides for deposit into the fund of any federal revenues, grants, and capital outlay funding intended for state executive elections. 
  • Gives SOS budget adjustment request authority to use money in the state election fund for purposes of conducting elections beyond a 5 percent variance from the approved elections budget that fiscal year.
  • Creates the county election fund within the county treasury, subject to appropriation by the legislature, and provides for reporting requirements. 
  • Provides that fund expenditures are determined by the county clerk and used for administration of elections and remaining balances do not revert to the county general fund.
  • Provides the contents of a county canvass report and requires that all ballots be tallied by an election board, including absentee ballots received after the board has adjourned. 
  • Requires that, if a ballot box is required to be opened at any time during the county or state canvass process, a presiding judge and two election judges or a deputy clerk shall be present. 
  • Provides that ballot impoundment costs are determined by the state canvassing board and inspection of such ballots shall occur in the presence of the county clerk or the clerk’s agent. 
  • Expands post-election voting system audits to occur after each general election and after every statewide election, including special, local, primary, and general elections. 
  • Requires an automatic recount provision to require recounts in cases where there are five or fewer votes between the candidates. 
  • Expands the time for SOS to determine the sufficiency of a referendum petition from 15 to 30 days.
  • Amends the Campaign Reporting Act (CRA) to expand the legislative session prohibited period to include incumbents or candidates for a proscribed office, which includes the state Legislature, governor, lieutenant governor, SOS, attorney general, state auditor, and state treasurer.
  • Prohibits these and campaign committees or legislative caucus committees from accepting contributions except under defined circumstances. 
  • Amends the Lobbyist Regulation Act to conform with language related to the proposed amendment to the above CRA prohibited period.
  • Clarifies the penalties section of the Election Code, making the possession of keys of a secured container by an unauthorized person, unauthorized establishment of a drop box, or unauthorized entering or altering of an absentee register a fourth-degree felony and clarifies “authorized individuals” who are allowed to be within 50 feet of a polling place.
  • Amends sections of the Local Elections Act to change the time for when the regular local election proclamation is issued and the deadline by which it can be amended. 
  • Requires that write-in candidates have the same filing requirements as named candidates and the deadline to file candidate challenges is extended by a week.
  • Allows the Secretary of State to establish by rule the qualification necessary for issuance of each grade of clerk’s certificate, in keeping with standards of accredited educational programs. 
  • Establishes additional compensation for county clerks based on certification level as follows: Clerk 1 to receive an additional $500 per year, Clerk 2 to receive an additional $1,000 per year, Clerk 3 to receive an additional $1,000 per year, and Clerk 4 to receive an additional $1,000 per year.
  • Provides for additional compensation for deputy clerks as follows: Clerk 1 to receive an additional $500 per year, Clerk 2 to receive an additional $1,500 per year, Clerk 3 to receive an additional $2,500 per year, and Clerk 4 to receive an additional $3,000 per year.
  • Clarifies when a ballot should not be automatically mailed, including when a voter notification is returned undeliverable and the voter has not communicated an error or updated their registration address or if the voter is a confidential address program participant.
  • Adds the SOS to the Tax Code authorizing the Taxation and Revenue Department to share taxpayer information for voter registration purposes.
  • Removes the oath of office filing fee and limits the SOS from collecting fees for oath of office or notice of appointment to a vacancy in office.
  • Amends the Confidential Substitute Address Act to include members of an applicant’s household and adds language that removes a participant from the confidential address program if the person does not comply with the provisions of the Intimate Partner Violence Survivor Suffrage Act.
  • Provides a temporary provision creating a voter education and elections task force to study and provide recommendations on best practices to educate voters on electoral procedures, voter registration, and election safeguards. 
  • Provides for reports from the task force be submitted to the Governor and Legislature by December 31, 2023.

name: Elections; prohibiting the contribution, donation, or anything of value for purposes of conducting an election; penalties; effective date.
summary:
• Creates the "voter education and elections task force" to study and provide recommendations on best practices to educate the voters of New Mexico on electoral procedures, voter registration and election safeguards. 
  • Tasks the voter education and elections task force with evaluating opportunities for improvements to the electoral process to maximize voter accessibility and accurate voter rolls while continuing to maintain efficient and secure elections. 
  • Provides that the task force function from the date of its appointment until December 31, 2022. 
  • Provides that staff and administrative support for the task force be jointly coordinated and provided by the Secretary of State and the Legislative Council Service. 
  • Establishes that the members of the voter education and elections task force be composed of 6 members who are legislators, with the two political parties with the most members in the state being represented in equal numbers.
  • The membership must include 3 members of the House of Representatives appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives; 3 members of the Senate appointed by the Senate Committees' Committee or, if the legislature is not in session at the time of appointment, appointed by the President Pro Tempore of the Senate in consultation with and agreement of a majority of the members who served on the Senate Committees' Committee during the second session of the fifty-fifth legislature; the Secretary of State or the Secretary's designee; the Secretary of Taxation and Revenue, or a designee of the Secretary who has oversight or knowledge of data collection and system operations within the Taxation and Revenue Department; 4 public members, with the two political parties with the most members in the state being represented in equal numbers, who have expertise in elections, campaigns and private sector organizational structure and operations and who reflect the ethnic, cultural and geographic diversity of the state, two appointed by the Speaker of the House and two appointed by the President Pro Tempore of the Senate; and 4 county clerks, with the two political parties with the most members in the state being represented in equal numbers, appointed by the county clerks affiliate of the New Mexico association of counties; 1 representative each from the state Registrar and the Administrative Office of the Courts and 1 representative of the county assessors, appointed by the Director of the Property Tax Division of the Taxation and Revenue Department, to serve as advisory members.
  • Requires the task force to invite the United States Postal Service in New Mexico to appoint a representative to participate as an advisory member of the task force.
  • Provides that public members of the voter education and elections task force are entitled to receive per diem and mileage pursuant to the Per Diem and Mileage Act but shall receive no other compensation, perquisite or allowance.
  • Requires the task force be co-chaired by the Secretary of State, or the Secretary's designee, and one of the legislator-appointed members from the minority political party, elected by the membership of the task force to serve as co-chair. 
  • Provides that the task force must meet at the call of a co-chair or at the request of one-third of its membership, and as necessary to carry out its duties, but no less than once and no more than twice a month. 
  • Requires that the first meeting of the task force shall be held no later than May 1, 2022, and the first meeting of the task force be an organizational meeting for the task force to develop a work plan to carry out the task force's duties.  
  • Provides that if a vacancy on the task force occurs it must be filled by the original appointing authority. 
  • Maintains that a member who misses three meetings be removed from the task force, and upon the request of the co-chairs, the appointing authority shall replace the member who has failed to attend three meetings. 
  • Provides that a majority of the task force members constitutes a quorum for the transaction of business, while the support of a majority of the members is required for adoption of any action provided that the final report of the task force, including its recommendations and proposed legislation, shall have, at minimum, the support of a majority of the legislative members. 
  • Allows the voter education and elections task force to create subcommittees by a majority vote of the members. 
  • Provides that a subcommittee shall be composed of at least 1 member from the senate and one member from the House of Representatives, including at least 1 member of a minority political party that is represented in either the Senate or House of Representatives.  
  • Provides that meetings of the voter education and elections task force shall be subject to the Open Meetings Act, and the task force shall actively solicit public input.  
  • Requires the voter education and elections task force develop policy recommendations and proposed legislation to educate voters on electoral procedures, voter registration and election safeguards. The task force shall also consider improvements to the Election Code to make electoral processes more efficient and accessible to all voters while continuing to maintain election integrity.

This bill also makes conforming changes.

summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires the secretary of state to prescribe the content and instructions for completing a voter registration form, or to update voter registration information.
  • Requires the secretary of state to prescribe the content and instructions for a form to cancel voter registration and requires that it be provided to certain property agencies in the state to distribute to those who purchase or sell real estate or enter into a lease at the time they enter into the agreements.
  • Specifies what must be included in the voter registration form and that it must allow a voter to register, update information, or to cancel registration.
  • Specifies that the form must be in paper form to be returned by mail and accepted by each county clerk.
  • Requires the form to include certain specified information about voter registration.

  • Removes a requirement that an Indian reservation or Indian colony request the establishment of a polling place or ballot drop box, and instead requires the county clerk to establish a polling place or drop box in locations approved by the Indian tribe, even if the tribe is located in whole or in part within a county.
  • Provides that an Indian tribe may elect not to have a polling place or drop box established within the boundaries of the reservation or colony and outlines notification procedures.
  • Makes conforming changes.

Revises provisions relating to elections. (BDR 24-836)
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires the secretary of state to establish the form of all envelopes in which mail ballots are sent to voters, as well as return envelopes.
  • Furnishes that return envelopes for mail ballots must be a unique color for each county and city, and unique colors must be request by city and county clerks with approval by the secretary of state.
  • Requires the clerk for each early voting city and county to post at least one sign specifying that the sign is the distance marker from which no electioneering is allowed to the polling place, and specifies the size of the sign, placement, and visibility requirements.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Revises provisions relating to elections. (BDR 24-105)
categories: Oversight and accountability,Reporting,Legal causes of action
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Defines "election irregularity" and "unit."
  • Creates the Unit for the Investigation and Prosecution of Election Crimes within the Office of the Attorney General.
  • Stipulates that it will be composed of an Inspector General appointed by the Attorney General and investigators and staff deemed necessary by the Attorney General.
  • Tasks the Unit with establishing a 24-hour, toll free statewide complaint system for reporting election irregularities, and a form allowing complaints in writing.
  • Requires the Unit to review complaints, referrals, and reports regarding allegations of election irregularities, and investigate and prosecute the alleged irregularity, if applicable.
  • Mandates the Unit to submit a report to the Governor and Director of the Legislative Counsel Bureau by January 15 in odd-numbered years, and specifies the contents of the report.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Revises provisions relating to elections. (BDR 24-690)
Revises provisions relating to mechanical voting machines and mechanical recording devices. (BDR 24-363)
most_recent_action: Senate Legislative Operations and Elections Hearing (15:30:00 15:30:00 Room 2149)

name: Requires proof of identity to vote in an election. (BDR 24-33)
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,In-person voter ID
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires that a voter provide proof of identity in order to vote in person.
  • Defines proof of identity to include a driver’s license or an ID issued by the Department of Motor Vehicles or a federally recognized tribe.
  • Requires the Department of Motor Vehicle to issue an ID at no charge to a registered voter with a financial hardship. A person who seeks to obtain an ID must attest to financial hardship, but no proof of financial hardship is needed.
  • Provides that a mail-in ballot return envelope must have a place for a voter’s signature and identifying information. A voter who uses mail-in ballots must write the last 4 digits of their social security number and their driver’s license or ID number on the envelope. A voter can include a copy of their proof of identity if they do not possess either a license or ID. The county or city clerk must verify the numbers on the envelope match the voter’s records.  
  • Clarifies that voting using the mail-in ballot of another person is a criminal felony.

name: Requires certain proof of identity to vote in an election. (BDR 24-175)
categories: Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,In-person voter ID
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires an acceptable ID to vote. 
  • Directs the Department of Motor Vehicles to issue a voter ID to qualified voters who have no other acceptable ID and attest to financial hardship.
  • Requires a mail-in ballot voter to include the last 4 digits of their social security or ID number on the envelope flap. If the voter does not possess those numbers, they can sign an affidavit attesting to their identity.
  • Provides that a person applying to vote whose identity has been challenged must furnish proof of identity.
  • Requires a person who fails to provide acceptable ID when voting in person to cast a provisional ballot.

name: Revises provisions concerning the confidentiality of certain personal information of certain persons. (BDR 20-408)
summary: As introduced, this bill adds employees of the office of secretary of state charged with duties related to elections to a list of people who may request that personal information and records be kept confidential.

name: Revises provisions relating to elections. (BDR 24-409)
most_recent_action: Senate Legislative Operations and Elections Hearing (15:30:00 15:30:00 )
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires the secretary of state to prepare and publish an election procedures manual every two years, with approval of the final draft by the attorney general.
  • Outlines what must be included in the manual.
  • Requires the secretary of state to train county and city clerks included in the manual, with specific requirements and timelines.
  • Provides for cost allocation and reimbursement for training.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Revises the deadline for returning mail ballots by mail. (BDR 24-736)
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Modifies the postmark deadline for receipt of a mailed ballot from election day, to the last day of early voting. 
  • Stipulates that the ballot must be received by the clerk before the time set for closing of the polls on election day (instead of 5pm on the fourth day following the election).
  • Specifies that personal delivery of a mail ballot must occur before the end of the third day after the day of receipt of the ballot, if the person delivering the ballot receives it four or more days before the election. If the person receives the ballot three or fewer days before the election, the ballot must be delivered before the time set for closing of the polls on election day.

name: Revises provisions relating to elections. (BDR 24-412)
most_recent_action: Senate Legislative Operations and Elections Hearing (15:30:00 15:30:00 )
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Counting and canvassing procedures,Military/UOCAVA voting,Cybersecurity
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides the oath for an independent candidate running for partisan office.
  • Allows filing fees to be paid by credit card.
  • Clarifies that for nonpartisan primary elections where voters could select more than one candidate, for counting purposes, each valid choice will be counted as one vote for that candidate.
  • Changes the deadline for counting mail ballots from seven days after the election to nine days after the election.
  • Requires the secretary of state to adopt a cyber incident response plan for elections, and requires counties and cities to comply with it.
  • Changes the effective withdrawal deadline for candidates for city office from two days before the filing deadline to seven days before the filing deadline.
  • Adds the Space Force to the list of agencies who are included in "uniformed service voters."
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Revises provisions relating to elections. (BDR 24-411)
most_recent_action: Senate Legislative Operations and Elections Hearing (15:30:00 15:30:00 )
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the timeline for a party to file a list of candidates with the secretary of state from starting on the first Monday in March and running until the second Friday following the first Monday in March, and changes it to the first Monday in February and running until the second Friday following the first Monday in February, and it makes conforming changes.

name: Revises provisions relating to presidential electors. (BDR 24-539)
most_recent_action: Senate Legislative Operations and Elections Hearing (15:30:00 15:30:00 )
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes creating or serving in a false slate of presidential electors as a felony and prohibits individuals convicted of these acts from holding public office or voting after parole or discharge.

name: Revises provisions relating to elections. (BDR 24-173)
summary: As introduced this bill makes clarifying edits and changes to conform to exisiting state election code.

name: Provides for the establishment of polling places in county and city jails. (BDR 24-812)
categories: Poll observers,Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires coordination to establish one in-person polling place in each county and city jail for prisoners who are registered to vote in the county for voting in primary and general elections.
  • Specifies procedures for if a prisoner is detained in a jail in a different county.
  • Defines relevant terms as they apply to this legislation.
  • Prohibits voting by those convicted persons who have not had their right to vote restored.
  • Authorizes the secretary of state to adopt related regulations.
  • Prohibits members of the public from observing voting at a polling place in a prison without certain approvals.
  • Authorizes same day voter registration in prison.

name: Revises the deadline for returning mail ballots by mail. (BDR 24-529)
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration
summary:
As introduced, this bill:


  • Requires absentee ballots be postmarked on or before the last day of early voting and received by the fourth day after the conclusion of early voting
  • Requires absentee ballots be returned by mail within three days of receipt by the voter if the voter receives the ballot four or more days before the end of early voting, or before the deadline established by the USPS on the last day of early voting if the voter receives the ballot three or fewer days before the end of early voting
  • Requires absentee ballots returned by personal delivery be received within three days of receipt by the voter if the voter receives the ballot four or more days before the date of the election, or before the polls close on the day of the election if the voter receives their ballot within three days of the election

name: Proposes to amend the Nevada Constitution to revise provisions relating to elections involving incumbent justices or judges who are unopposed. (BDR C-515)
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that if an incumbent justice runs unopposed in an election, the ballot should offer the voter two choices: "retain" or "not retain."
  • Requires that if the number of votes for "not retain" is greater than "retain," no one will be declared elected, and the office must be filled as if a vacancy occurred before the expiration of the term of office.

name: Requires the election of a registrar of voters. (BDR 24-513)
summary:
• Provides that the registrar of voters is an elected position.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to obtaining written acceptance from candidates for certain county committees; requires written acceptance, duly acknowledged, from such candidates to be so designated to be filed within ten days of designating petitions for certain county committee candidates.
Provides for conditional registration of voters during early voting.
Relates to the rejection by voting machines of ballots that contain a vote for a candidate who previously withdrew from an election.
Relates to absentee voting in nursing homes and senior citizen residences; requires board of inspectors to deliver and help complete applications for absentee ballots to residents of such facilities.
Relates to ballots submitted in envelopes that are sealed with tape, paste or any other binding agent or device and have no indication of tampering.

Provides that if a school building is designated as a polling place, the board or body which controls such building shall provide a space that is not easily accessible to areas of the building where instructional activities are taking place, and if such a space cannot be provided that meets such criteria, the board or agency which controls such building shall cancel in-person instructional activities during the operating hours of such poll site.
Requires bi-monthly reporting on deceased voters and certain persons subject to forfeiture of the right to vote in order to accurately maintain the statewide voter registration list.

Requires a current and valid government issued identification card to vote; establishes voter identification cards which shall contain, and prominently display, a registered voters name, address, political party affiliation, voter status, and voter signature which has been filed with the state board of elections; makes related provisions.
Establishes a notarial recordkeeping and reporting exemption for acts relating to the designation and nomination of candidates.
Ensures that boards of elections provide adequate notice to each voter before and after a board cancels the voter's registration or places such voter in inactive status.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that when a board of elections places a voter's registration on inactive status, the board must notify the voter immediately using one of a list of methods.
  • Requires that the notice explain the reason the voter was placed on inactive status.
  • Requires the state board of elections to create uniform notices for such purposes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Lists methods of notifying and confirming with voters a change of address notification.
  • Provides methods for sending a second notice if the first notice is returned as undeliverable.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Amends election law to accurately reflect proper cross reference relating to the operational failure of a voting machine.
summary: As introduced, this bill makes technical changes to statute numbers to update references to voting machines.

name: Enacts the voter registration integrity act; requires a birth certificate, passport, certificate of naturalization or citizenship, evidence of New York state residency, or any other documentation that the board of elections determines establishes United States citizenship.
summary: As introduced, this bill lists items requires of those registering to vote for the first time in the state.

name: Enacts the "voting integrity and verification act of New York (VIVA NY)"; provides that each voter is entitled to the use of an individual, voter verifiable paper ballot of the voter's vote and the opportunity to mark it privately and independently.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires all paper ballots of the same kind for the same election district to be identical. Each voter is entitled to a paper ballot that can be privately marked in the polling place, made available for personal inspection, verified by the voter before the vote is cast and counted, and can be changed or corrected for any errors before the ballot is cast and counted.

name: Permits the state board of elections to join certain multistate voter list maintenance organizations and provide such organizations with certain voter information.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Authorizes the state board of elections to join a multi-state voter list maintenance organization, including the Electronic Registration Information Center, and authorized the agency to spend funds for the purpose.
  • Requires the state board of elections to designate a member as a representative to the organization.
  • Authorizes the board to share registration records and department of motor vehicles information, and lists what information may be shared.

name: Enacts the "voting integrity and verification act of New York (VIVA NY)"; provides that each voter is entitled to the use of an individual, durable, voter verifiable paper ballot of the voter's vote that shall be privately and independently marked in the polling place and made available for private and independent inspection and verification by the voter before the voter's vote is cast and counted.
Relates to the dates to file a designating petition; provides for the repeal of such provisions.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a designating petition be filed no earlier than the Wednesday before and no later than the Monday before the primary election.

name: Requires a government photo identification card to be presented when casting a ballot; provides for a method to receive a government photo identification card at no charge; provides that notaries are not permitted to collect a fee for collecting the documents required.
Provides that an attorney licensed to practice in the state may serve as a poll watcher in any city or county in the state.
summary: As introduced, this bill authorizes an attorney who is licensed in New York, who is a New York resident, to visit a polling place as a poll watcher on election day while the polls are open.

name: Amends election law to accurately reflect proper cross reference relating to the operational failure of a voting machine.
summary: As introduced, this bill makes nonsubstantive changes.

name: Prohibits conflicts of interest among board of elections employees; prevents a board of elections employee with the exception of district leaders from remaining on the board of elections payroll while also a candidate for an office who has an election overseen by the board at which they are employed; allows for a member to remain on the board until 90 days before the general election if there is no primary for such office.
summary:
• Prohibits board of elections employees from maintaining a financial interest in companies providing election-related services and provides a list of types of companies and vendors.
  • Prohibits board of elections employees being employed while also running for office in the same jurisdiction.
  • Provides guidelines on handing a situation in which a board of elections employee runs for office.

name: Relates to the dates to file a designating petition; provides for the repeal of such provisions.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes that in 2023, petitions must be filed between the 12th and 13th Monday before a primary election. It also prohibits counting signatures given earlier than 41 days before the 13th Monday.

name: Requires at-large electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidate who received the highest number of votes in the state; requires congressional electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidates who received the highest number of votes in each congressional district; removes and replaces electors who fail to vote in such manner.
most_recent_action: House Local Government Committee Hearing (13:30:00 13:30:00 House Hearing Room I)
summary: This bill provides that Electoral College votes be designated proportionally to the presidential and vice presidential candidate who obtain the greatest number of votes in each congressional district. The bill also creates a pledge that electors must attest to ensuring that their vote is representative of the vote of the district that they represent as an elector and outlines the cause for removal of an elector should they violate the pledge to remain faithful to the voters of the district they represent.

name: Permits all qualified voters to vote as absentee voters during a state disaster emergency; provides for the automatic mailing of absentee ballots to all qualified voters during a state disaster emergency.
most_recent_action: House Corrections Subcommittee Hearing (10:30:00 10:30:00 House Hearing Room II)
summary: This bill permits all qualified voters to vote as absentee voters during a state disaster emergency and provides for the automatic mailing of absentee ballots during a state disaster emergency.

name: Prohibits level two or three sex offenders from voting at a school or facility for children.
most_recent_action: House Corrections Subcommittee Hearing (10:30:00 10:30:00 House Hearing Room II)
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:
• Provides criminal penalties for a person for unlawfully entering or remaining in a school for the purpose of voting, if they are a sex offender.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Requires the board of elections, 60 days before each election, to compile a list of registered sex offenders entitled to receive a ballot and send an absentee ballot to each person.
  • Provides that no poll worker will be liable for refusing admittance to a sex offender when they are acting in good faith.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to authorizing registration records of victims of sexual violence to be kept confidential in certain cases.
most_recent_action: House Local Government Committee Hearing (13:30:00 13:30:00 House Hearing Room I)
summary: • Adds victims of crimes of sexual violence to existing Election Code about victims of domestic violence being able to keep their registration record confidential.

name: Provides voters an opportunity to cure deficiencies regarding affidavit ballots.
summary:
• Provides instructions and timelines for when a board of elections determines an affidavit ballot envelope is incomplete or defective.
  • Provides for how the voter may cure the defect.
  • Provides instruction for what the board may do with the cured envelope, including what to do in the case of an invalidation.

name: Ensures that voting systems testing requirements do not make it impractical to provide each polling place for early voting all of the election district ballots.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 27, 2023 S.J. 495
categories: Counting and canvassing procedures,In-person voting and polling places
summary:
• Requires the state board of elections to ensure that rules for testing voting systems are not impracticle for early voting sites.
  • Removes a provision stating early voting sites in a county are not required to be greater than ten.

name: Relates to the number of state senators and inclusion of incarcerated persons in the federal census for population determination for redistricting purposes and to the functioning of the independent redistricting commission in the determination of district lines for congressional and state legislative offices.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 27, 2023 H.J. 547
categories: Redistricting,Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:
• Requires incarcerated people to be included in census numbers for determining districts.
  • Moves the timeframe for submission of a redistricting plan earlier from January 1-15 in a year ending in two, to November 1-15 in a year ending in one.
  • Changes the deadline for notification of disapproval of apply from February 28 to January 1.
  • Changes deadlines for submission for the year 2022 only.
  • Specifies incarcerated people should be included in their address of last residence.
  • Changes the number of state senators from 50 to 63.
  • Requires the ratio for apportioning senators be divided by 63 rather than 50.
  • Changes procedures for approving redistricting plans.
  • Removes language excluding aliens in redistricting census counts.
  • Provides clarifying edits.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Relates to the representation of newly formed political parties; relates to the placement of candidates of newly formed political parties on ballots, the representation of such parties within the state and the transmission of the official canvass of votes cast for presidential electors.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary:
• Allows the option of using the highest number of votes for president in the last election, in addition to the option of using the highest number of votes for governor, when determining the order of candidates on a ballot.
  • Provides rules regarding number of delegates at a judicial district convention for newly formed political parties.
  • Provides rules regarding selecting election district delegates by county committee for newly formed political parties.
  • Adds the office of US President to the list of offices where a nominated candidate my appear multiple times on the ballot.
  • Provides rules for newly formed political parties regarding casting votes at the state committee for presidential electors.
  • Adds presidential electors to the list of offices the board of elections needs to transmit to the state board after a canvass.

name: Establishes portable polling locations for early voting; provides that a county board of elections may establish one or more portable polling locations.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 27, 2023 H.J. 547
summary:
• Establishes that a county board of elections may establish portable polling locations for early voting, based on numbers established by the state board of elections.
  • Outlines guidelines for the number and location of stations.
  • Prohibits replacement of existing early voting locations with portable locations.

name: Relates to voting rights expansion, voter registration on election day, expansion of the use of and requirements for absentee voting, creation of a real-time state wide voter registration database, special ballots for election employees, and voter affidavits.
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Voting equipment,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Enforcement against non-officials,Voter list maintenance,Same-day/Election Day registration,Cybersecurity
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides for same day registration at the polling place and defines "election day."
  • Authorizes someone registering on election day to be able to vote after a qualifying registration.
  • Clarifies that if a person is standing in line to register to vote and the polls close, the person will be able to register and to vote.
  • Provides that any voter may choose to vote absentee and defines "board of elections."
  • Requires the board of elections for all counties and cities to mail an absentee ballot to every qualified voter by 30 days before an election, and specifies procedures for a primary election.
  • Provides a witnessed oath in place of a signature on an absentee ballot if a person is unable to sign their name.
  • Requires the board to keep records of all mailed absentee ballots and to make them available to specified groups and individuals.
  • Provides procedures for a voter to have an absentee ballot mailed to a different address than the one at which they are registered, and specifies how application forms may be made available.
  • Lists what information must be included in an absentee ballot application, and furnishes language for the form, as well as penalty for false statements.
  • Provides rules for what constitutes a valid absentee ballot request form.
  • Furnishes that a standard application will be provided by the board of elections and specifies how and where the forms should be made available.
  • Outlines procedures for a board of elections to receive an application and to mail the absentee voter ballots, including to specified facilities.
  • Requires the state board of elections to implement a computerized statewide voter registration list within one year of this bill, and provides requirements.
  • Requires each county board of elections to maintain voter registration information by using the computerized statewide voter registration database within two years of the effective date of this bill, with certain requirements.
  • Specifies that the state board of elections is responsible for the cost of the computer system, training, and rule making regarding ownership of the hardware, and requires that the system be made available to counties at no charge within four years of this bill.
  • Requires the department of state to make the master list of registered voters available at no charge on the internet to county boards of elections as soon as possible.

name: Revise residency requirements for the purposes of voter registration.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 27, 2023 S.J. 495
summary:
• Requires an early voting polling place in cities and towns with a population of 100,000-1,000,000.
  • Requires one polling place per 50,000 residents.
  • Sets element as a maximum number of required polling places.
  • Provides that polling places should be located on public transportation routes when possible.

name: Relates to donate life registrations; changes the effectiveness to one year after it shall have become a law.
summary:
• Edits the list of forms where a person can choose to be an organ donor.
  • Changes the effective date.

name: Relates to the appointment of election inspectors and poll clerks; provides that each board of elections submit a report detailing assignments of election inspectors and poll clerks; provides that each board of elections be required to fill vacancies by appointing individuals that appear on the additional inspector list.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 27, 2023 H.J. 547
summary:
• Requires those appointing election coordinators to prepare a report detailing assignments and specifying polling sites where inspectors or clerks have not yet been assigned.
  • Requires each board of elections to appoint election inspectors, poll clerks, and election coordinators from the additional inspector list for each vacancy at least 20 days before the election.
  • Specifies additional procedures for filling vacancies.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Amends procedures for change of party enrollment to require postmark 25 days prior to a primary, general or special election.
most_recent_action: Referred to Ways and Means by order of the President.
summary: This bill requires a change of party enrollment be postmarked 25 days prior to a primary, general, or special election.

name: Authorizes party designations and nominations for elections to be made via video teleconference or web conference upon notice to the members of the respective committee and allows certificates of designation or nomination to be executed in separate acts by the signatories.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 27, 2023 S.J. 495
summary:
• Provides that party designations and nominations, except for a primary election, may be made via audio or web conference with certain notification of members.
  • Outlines guidelines for the notification process and its certification.

name: Prohibits sex offenders who are on parole and in civil confinement from voting in certain elections.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 27, 2023 S.J. 495
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: • Provides that a convicted, imprisoned person who is committed to civil imprisonment in a hospital or institution is prohibited from voting during the time of his or her confinement.

name: Relates to the number of signatures needed for designating petitions in counties with a population of two hundred fifty thousand or fewer.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 27, 2023 S.J. 495
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures
summary: This bill stipulates that the signature requirement for petitions in counties with a population of two hundred fifty thousand or fewer is to be reduced by one-quarter, rounded down to the nearest whole number. For designating petitions for political subdivisions in counties with a population of two hundred fifty thousand or fewer, except for the position of member of the ward, town, city or county committee, such petitions must be signed by not less than three and three-quarters per 100 residents, as determined by the preceding enrollment, of the then enrolled voters of the party residing within the political unit in which the office or position is to be voted for, excluding voters in inactive status.

name: Enables constitutionally-qualified electors to register to vote and to cast a ballot on the same day at a polling location.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 27, 2023 S.J. 495
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Voter registration
summary:
• Defines "conditional voter registration."
  • Provides the a qualified individual may complete a conditional voter registration and cast an affidavit ballot at an early voting location.
  • Provides procedures for carrying out conditional voter registration, verifying the registration. and counting the ballot.

name: Relates to the number and location of early voting poll sites in certain counties.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 27, 2023 H.J. 547
summary: • Adds a provision that counties with a population of 1,250,000 are required to have at least one polling place in each town and city in the county, outside cities with a population of one million or more.

name: Relates to certain deadlines for voter registration; changes the amount of time required with respect to certain deadlines for voter registration procedures.
categories: Counting and canvassing procedures,Voter participation deadlines,Voter registration,Automatic voter registration
summary:
• Changes the deadline for a registered voter changing their address from 20 days before an election to 15 days before an election.
  • Clarifies that a board of elections receiving an application for someone in another district must forward the application electronically, the same day it was received.
  • Changes the deadline for the county board of elections to receive registration forms from 25 days to 10 days before the election, and the deadline for mailing to 15 days before the applicant can vote.
  • Changes the deadline for the board to notify a registrant of a rejected application from 10 days before an election to seven days before the election and makes associated changes.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Provides that a voter may correct their enrollment in the nine day period before an election (instead of 25 day period).
  • Changes the deadline for publishing the list of registered voters from six days before the election to five days before the election.
  • Edits personal pronouns to be gender neutral throughout.

name: Authorizes any registered voter to vote by absentee ballot and to elect to permanently vote by absentee ballot.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits registered voter to vote by absentee ballot and to elect to permanently vote by absentee ballot. A registered voter may not vote in person if the voter filed an application to vote by absentee ballot.

name: Provides for conditional registration of voters during early voting.
Relates to the definition of the term party.
summary: • Defines "party" for all elections on and after January 1, 2022.

name: Requires the election of fire district commissioners to take place on the same date and at the same location as elections of school board members.
categories: Election dates,Alignment of elections,Municipal election procedures
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the election of fire board commissioners to take place on the same date and at the same location as elections of school board members in the same municipality.

name: Requires the state board of elections to conduct a background check on all candidates which appear on a ballot.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a background check to be performed on each candidate who will appear on a ballot no later than thirty days prior to the election.

name: Authorizes the state board of elections to reject the use of voting machines or systems on the grounds that such machines or systems are not proper, safe, or secure.
summary: • Provides that a board and a state board may reject the use of a voting machine system on the ground that it is not proper, safe, or secure.

name: Provides that for any legal challenge to the constitutionality of a provision of the election law, venue shall be brought in the following designated court in the judicial department within which at least one plaintiff is located: first judicial department: New York county; second judicial department: Westchester county; third judicial department: Albany county; and fourth judicial department: Erie county.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Designates certain courts for proceedings or actions related to challenges of election provisions, based upon where one plaintiff is located.
  • Provides that a challenge to the constitutionality of a provision means a challenge in any form and that the claim may be raised by any party.

name: Modifies the order in which candidates appear on the ballot; requires that offices shall be listed on the ballot in descending order based on the size of the electorate and requires certain federal offices to be listed before state, county or local offices.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the order candidates must appear on the ballot.

name: Allows voters age sixty-five or older to request an absentee ballot.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits person 65 years or older to request an absentee ballot.

name: Requires voters voting by affidavit ballot to produce an identification document to verify residency in the election district; requires absentee ballots to be received by election day, or be post-marked by the first day of early voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires voters voting by affidavit ballot to produce an ID document to verify residency in the district. This bill also requires absentee ballots to be received by election day or be post-marked by the first day of early voting.

name: Permits boards of elections to change the date of a primary election within fourteen days of an election if such election date conflicts with a religious holiday.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows the primary election date can be changed by a board of elections within fourteen days of the primary if the election date conflicts with a religious holiday.

name: Requires a candidate for office to file additional information about the candidate's educational background, military service history, and employment history and provides penalties for violations.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a candidate to file additional personal information about their educational background, military service history, and employment history and creates a misdemeanor offense for violations.

name: Provides that in 2022, the statement of party positions to be filled at a primary election shall be filed by February 28, 2022; provides for the repeal of such provisions upon the expiration thereof.
summary: • Specifies that the statement of party positions for 2022 primary elections must be filed by February 28, 2022.

name: Relates to the time election day workers must be at poll sites to prepare for the opening of polls; one hour instead of one-half hour.
summary:
• Changes the time the inspectors of election and clerks will meet at the polls before opening from one-half an hour before opening to one hour before opening.
  • Requires the keys to the ballot scanner and ballot marking device to be delivered one hour before the opening of the poll, instead of one-half hour before.

name: Requires the state board of elections to develop a program to be administered by all boards of elections to notify voters of certain information where their area has been redistricted.
summary: • Requires the state board to create a program to notify voters about changes due to redistricting, and provides specific notification requirements.

name: Enacts the voter registration integrity act; requires a birth certificate, passport, certificate of naturalization or citizenship, evidence of New York state residency, or any other documentation that the board of elections determines establishes United States citizenship.
summary: • Requires those registering to vote for the first time to provide documentation of state residency, as well as certain documentation establishing citizenship.

name: Provides that school districts may hold elections in any building owned or leased by the district, in addition to any district schoolhouse.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a school district to use any building used or lease by the district as a polling place.

name: Exempts income earned working at the polls from the definition of income.
most_recent_action: reported referred to ways and means
summary: As introduced, this bill exempts income earned by election inspectors, poll clerks, and election coordinators working on elections from the definition of "income" related to gross income for federal income tax purposes.

name: Requires that subpoenas issued relating to election matters be served with a separate informational sheet that summarizes why the subpoena has been issued.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires subpoenas issued relating to election matters be served with a separate informational sheet that summarizes why the subpoena has been issued specifying that the action is related to the upcoming election of a relevant office and the consequences of not following the subpoena.

name: Requires a valid government issued photo identification card be presented when casting a ballot; provides for persons eligible for Medicaid to receive identification cards.
summary:
• Removes utility bills, banks statements, government check, paycheck, and other governmental documents from the list of acceptable forms of voter identification.
  • Requires voter identification to be a government issued photo ID.
  • Lists acceptable forms of government issued photo ID.
  • Requires an individual casting a fail-safe ballot to show the local board of elections a valid identification within three days of casting the ballot.
  • Establishes that adults who qualify for Medicaid are not required to pay a fee for a photo identification.

name: Enacts the voter registration integrity act; requires a birth certificate, passport, certificate of naturalization or citizenship, evidence of New York state residency, or any other documentation that the board of elections determines establishes United States citizenship.
summary: • Provides that each person registering for the first time in the state must provide documentation of residency, and either a birth certification, passport, naturalization certificate, or other documentation establishing citizenship.

name: Authorizes electronic submission of absentee ballots.
Excludes indebtedness for the construction of sewage facilities contracted prior to 2034 in determining current local debt limitation.
most_recent_action: Senate Judiciary Committee Hearing (10:00:00 10:00:00 Room 124 CAP)

name: A Joint Resolution proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, further providing for courts to be open and suits against the Commonwealth.
summary:
• Requires the state board of elections to provide a secure website for online voter registration.
  • Specifies procedures and requirements.
  • Clarifies that voter data must remain private.
  • Requires the annual report to include the number of voter registration applicants using online systems to register.

name: Establishes compulsory voting, with some exceptions, for general elections held in this state.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires all qualified voters to cast a vote in an election, other than a primary or school board election, or face a fine.

name: Provides that a voter may register to vote at any residence to which the voter maintains a continuous connection with an intent to remain, including a second home or a vacation home or a home where a student lives while attending a college or university.
summary: As introduced, this bill provides that a voter may reigister to vote using any address with which the voter maintains a continuous connection and to which they have an intent to return.

name: Provides that whenever a contiguous property of a college or university contains three hundred or more registrants, the polling place designated for such election district shall be on such contiguous property or at a location approved by the college or university.
summary: As introduced, this bill provides that when there is a property contiguous to a college or university, with 300 or more voters registered at the property, the college or university will approve a designated early voting polling location on the site.

name: Relates to the authority of the state board of elections to issue subpoenas; directs the board of elections to issue rules and regulations.
categories: Oversight and accountability,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary: As introduced, this bill specifies that quorum requirements for board votes regarding received complaints are met if two board members and the chief enforcement counsel are present at the vote. This bill also clarifies that the chief enforcement counsel may administer oaths or affirmations, and subpoena witnesses.

name: Requires electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidate who were nominated by the political party that nominated the presidential elector.
summary: • Requires each elector of the Electoral College in the state to cast their vote for the candidates nominated by the party, with administration guidelines and penalties and procedures if they do not do so.

name: Requires the county seat in Delaware county (Delhi) to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill designates at least one early voting polling place in Delaware County, on a public transportation route, if possible.

name: Relates to an electronically submitted absentee ballot application.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Special election procedures,Military/UOCAVA voting
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires the board of elections to accept absentee ballot delivery, military ballot applications, and special federal ballot applications by fax machine, as an email attachment, through an online filing system.
  • Requires the online filing system to be created by the state board of elections.
  • Requires the website for each board of elections to advertise the email address, website address, and fax number to return absentee ballots.
  • Specifies that applications received outside of normal business hours will be deemed as received the next day.
  • Allows for electronic signature on the absentee ballots.
  • Specifies that military ballot applications and special federal ballot applications sent by fax, email, and the online portal are considered the original application and the original copy does not need to also be mailed.

name: Requires funeral directors to ensure that death certificates are delivered to the state health department and the department of health of the city of New York who shall in turn deliver certain certificates to the state board of elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires all funeral directors to deliver death certificates to the state health department and for each county board of elections to ensure that any deceased voter is promptly removed from the voter registration list. This bill also makes conforming changes.

name: Provides that the police commissioner of the city of New York and all other cities with a population of one hundred thousand or more shall be an elected office with a four-year term; provides that such office shall be subject to term limits of two terms.
categories: Municipal election procedures,Special election procedures,Vacancy procedures
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Establishes that the police commissioner will be elected in every city with a population greater than 100,000 but less than a million people.
  • Provides that the police commissioner will be elected at the general election in 2024, and every fourth year after.
  • Provides that the term of office is four years, starting on January 1 after the election, and that there is a two term limit.
  • Furnishes that the suspension and removal rules for mayor also apply to police commissioner.
  • Outlines vacancy procedures, notifications, timelines, appointments, and primaries.
  • Provides the term of office when filling a vacancy.
  • Provides that special elections to fill a vacancy will be held the first Tuesday at least 80 days after the occurrence of the vacancy, unless the vacancy occurs after August 17 in an election year, and outlines scheduling procedures, with authority given to the mayor.
  • Outlines election scheduling procedures if the vacancy occurs after August 17 of an election year.
  • Outlines procedures for nominating petitions to fill a vacancy for police commissioner.
  • Provides that a person who wins the vacancy election will take office immediately upon qualification and serve until December 31 of the year of the unexpired term.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Provides voters an opportunity to cure deficiencies regarding affidavit ballots in order to have their votes counted.
summary: As introduced, this bill provides an affidavit voter who has an incomplete or defective ballot the chance to cure their ballot and the steps to complete the process.

name: Relates to the notification of county boards of elections of an individual's death and the subsequent removal of such voter's name from the applicable registration roll.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Modifies the deadline for receiving names of all those for whom a death certificate has been issued from at least monthly, to within seven days.
  • Requires the state board of elections to provide the information to relevant counties within seven days.
  • Directs that, upon receiving a death certificate, a voter's registration must be canceled and removed from the registration roll.

name: Relates to the number of signatures needed on certain designating petitions and independent nominations for town council districts.
summary: As introduced, this bill specifies that to run in town council district races, 500 signature or 5% of the total number of votes cast for governor in the last election, excluding blank or void votes, are needed for a nomination.

name: Permits party enrollment and change of party enrollment within 10 days of a primary, general, or special election.
most_recent_action: Senate Floor SB714 (3-07-23) (BULLARD) FS FA1 - SB714 (3-07-23) (BULLARD) FS FA1
summary:
• Provides that if a voter registers with a party at least 10 days before the election, the may vote in that party's primary.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Authorizes the governing body or agency of a public school building to reject a designation as a polling place or an early polling place.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a board or agency which controls a school building that has been designated a polling place to reject the designation.

name: Authorizes boards of elections to establish absentee ballot drop-off locations.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 07, 2023 H.J. 499
summary:
• Authorizes each board of elections to establish one or more absentee ballot drop-off locations, and includes notification requirements.
  • Requires the state board of elections to create rules for implementation of absentee ballot drop-off locations.
  • Specifies procedures and deadlines for receiving absentee ballots.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Changes the early voting period for general, primary, run-off primary and special elections for public office or party position; maintains the current early voting period for general elections in a year in which electors of president and vice president of the United States are to be elected.
summary: As introduced, this bill modifies the starting day of early voting for general, primary, run-off, and special elections, stating that early voting will be held 10, 7, 5, 3, and 2 days before an election, except general elections where there is a presidential and vice presidential candidate will remain 10 days before the election.

name: Authorizes electronic submission of absentee ballots.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Absentee/mail-in voter assistance,Military/UOCAVA voting,Digital/electronic voting
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires the state board of elections to establish and maintain an electronic absentee ballot submission system where completed absentee ballots may be returned electronically or by Email.
  • Requires the state board of elections to deliver the ballots to the appropriate board of elections for processing and verification.
  • Provides that each board of elections will maintain a system capable of receiving and processing this information, including digital and typed signatures.
  • Furnishes that the ballots should be considered as submitted on the date it was initially transmitted by the voter.
  • Establishes that this system will only be available for those eligible voters residing outside of the United States, military voters, and voters needing accommodations due to disability.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Requires voters to take and submit the oath electronically.
  • Requires the system to meet certain Web Content Accessibility guidelines.

name: Revise the process for nominating candidates for lieutenant governor and to make related technical changes.
most_recent_action: Senate Failed to concur, no committee appointed, Passed, YEAS 29, NAYS 4. S.J. 446
summary: This bill provides that school districts may hold elections in any building owned or leased by the district, in addition to any district schoolhouse, so long as they retain the building's accessibility features for disabled voters.

name: Improves transparency regarding boards of elections; improves voter centricity; includes boards of elections in open meetings requirements; requires certain notices be given regarding elections; requires additional transparency during the tabulation of votes.
categories: Voting equipment,Administrative deadlines,Audits,Poll observers,Transparency,Cure provisions,Language accommodations,Ballot design,Counting and canvassing procedures,In-person voting and polling places,Voter registration,Testing and certification,Chain of custody,Video surveillance
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Deems boards of elections must hold open meetings, subject to open meeting laws, as public bodies.
  • Requires designations of polling sites be proposed publicly at least 30 days before an election, with an opportunity for an advisory public comment.
  • Authorizes boards of elections to change poll sites without public comment if deemed necessary, as long as five days notice is provided, and provides that in addition to other methods, notice should be provided via email and text for voters whose contact information is available.
  • Provides a list of notification requirements by the county board of elections 30 days before a primary election.
  • Specifies where notices must be published, the duration of publication of the notices, and that they should be in all major languages spoken in the county.
  • Provides that 25 days before a primary election, through the date of the primary, the state board of elections will use certain media to notify voters of the election and direct voters to relevant online information.
  • Requires boards to prominently display voter registration instructions on their websites.
  • Changes the deadline for displaying the date, time, location, related deadlines, sample ballot, and other related items about an election from two weeks before to 30 days before, and adds social media channels to the display locations, and directs that the notice appear in all major languages of the jurisdiction.
  • Provides that notice of a constitutional amendment should include online notice and not be limited to two newspapers within the county.
  • Changes "appropriate ballot marking device" to a specified pencil, and includes maintenance and service requirements.
  • Requires decisions about the form and content of ballots and envelopes to be proposed publicly at least 30 days before adoption, with an opportunity for public comment.
  • Supplies that a registered voter may vote in any polling place within a county, with related requirements.
  • Requires the state board of elections to create rules ensuring that auditing of votes is simple, affordable, and secure, with related requirements.
  • Provides that the committee on open government may appoint as many watchers as the committee deems appropriate, with certain limits and stipulations.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Requires each county to have accessible polling places.
  • Provides that voters are entitled to a verifiable ballot and includes related provisions and definitions.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Requires ballot scanners be tested and that if ballot marking devices are a tabulating machine, their function too should be tested.
  • Requires instructions for how to cure a rejected absentee ballot.
  • Changes the number of pill watchers for party committees and bodies whose candidates are on the ballot from three per district to four per polling place.
  • Creates a process for the committee on open government to choose watchers when there are more watchers than spots.
  • Specifies that poll results should be posted publicly.
  • Provides that inspectors must print extra copies of the results tape for those who request a copy and post them publicly and announce the results.
  • Provides that candidates or watchers may be given a copy of the poll tape with certain requirements. 
  • Outlines other information available to watchers.
  • Increases to at least two police officers for delivering election devices, and two inspectors to receive them.
  • Designates two inspectors to receive the returns of the canvass and other records, with certain other stipulations regarding delivery and storage.
  • Provides that results will be released within 24 hours of the close of polls with certain related rules, including for certified results.
  • Requires hearing allowing for feedback of the process to be held within two weeks after certification of statements from the canvass board and adds certain transperencey requirements.

name: Relates to the accessibility of congressional, senatorial, assembly and election district maps in downloadable digital file formats compatible with geographic information (GIS) software.
summary: • Specifies that election district maps on websites must be available in a specific downloadable digital format.

name: Permits electronic correspondence with regard to determinations on objections to designating petitions, independent nominating petitions, certificates of nomination or ballot access documents upon the consent of the objector.
summary:
• Provides that notice regarding the sufficiency of a petition may be given electronically instead of by overnight mail, with the consent of the objector or candidate.
