  • Outlines how a candidate or objector may consent to electronic notice.

name: Elections; modifying requirements for participation in multistate voter list maintenance organizations. Effective date.
most_recent_action: Coauthored by Representative Roberts (principal House author)
summary: • Provides that the notice for optional party enrollment to vote in a primary must be in bold type and provides the wording.

name: Requires the county seat in Steuben county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
categories: Early voting administration,In-person voting and polling places
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the county seat of Steuben County to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.

name: Requires the county seat in Fulton county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
categories: Early voting administration,In-person voting and polling places
summary: As introduced, this bill exempts Fulton County from being required to have an early voting polling place in the largest city in the county but still be required to have one somewhere in the county.

name: Relates to certain deadlines for voter registration; changes the amount of time required with respect to certain deadlines for voter registration procedures.
categories: Voter participation deadlines,Voter registration,Automatic voter registration
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Changes the deadline for updating a voter registration address from 20 to 15 days before an election with specified notice.
  • Specifies that a voter registration applicant is entitled to have his or her vote canvassed in the election in which he or she is registered to vote.
  • Specifies that a board of elections receiving a voter registration application for a voter not registered in their district should electronically forward applications to the proper board of elections that same day the application is received.
  • Changes the deadline to receive a voter registration form from 25 to 10 days before an election, and requires that relevant instructions be updated.
  • Specifies that a mailed registration must be postmarked at least 15 days before the election.
  • Changes the deadline for the county board of elections to verify the identity of a voter registration applicant from 21 days after receipt to seven days after receipt.
  • Changes the deadline for notifying a voter of a rejected application from 10 days before the day of the first primary or election to seven days before.
  • Modifies the deadline for transmitting voter registration applications received 12-20 days before an election (instead of 13-25 days) to require them to be transmitted by the tenth day before the election.
  • Changes the deadline for a voter to request to be restored to active status before an election from 20 days before the election to 10 days before the election.
  • Modifies the deadline for a voter to correct his or her enrollment from 25 days before the election to nine days before.
  • Modifies the timeline for the board of elections to publish a a list of registered voters from six days before the election to five days before.
  • Adapts language in existing code to be gender neutral.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Permits electronic correspondence with regard to determinations on objections to designating petitions, independent nominating petitions, certificates of nomination or ballot access documents upon the consent of the objector.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that notification regarding candidate objection petitions or certificates may be given electronically, in lieu of overnight mail, with the consent of the objector or candidate.
  • Requires the officer or board to provide the objector and candidate an opportunity to be hears as to the validity of each objection.
  • Furnishes that a candidate or objector will be deemed to have consented to electronic correspondence if after advisement that the process is voluntary, they affirmitively choose to receive notices only by electronic corresponance.

name: Implements driving privilege licenses for applicants with alternative forms of identification; requires a social security number to register to vote on an application for a motor vehicle driver's license.
categories: In-person voter ID,Voter ID for registration
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits the use of driving privilege licenses and learners permits from being used as official form of state issued identification. This bill also requires voter registration applicants to provide a social security number on their application submitted through a driver's license application.

name: Enables constitutionally-qualified electors to register to vote and to cast a ballot on the same day at a polling location.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Defines "conditional voter registration."
  • Supplies that a qualified voter may complete a conditional voter registration and cast an affidavit ballot at an early voting or election day polling location.
  • Specifies that a conditional voter registration is deemed effective if the board of elections is able to determine the registrant is eligible, and has registered using accurate information matching information contained in the database, before or during the canvass period.
  • Specifies procedures for if the information provided by the registrant cannot be verified based on database information, but where the board of elections is able to determine the registrant is eligible to vote.
  • Requires the board to provide conditional voter registration and voting at all early voting and election day polling locations.
  • Specifies the information that must be given to a potential conditional voter registrant.
  • Requires the board of elections to conduct the receipt and handling of each conditional voter registration and conduct the process in a manner the protects the secrecy of the ballot and allows specified administrative processing procedures.
  • Requires the ballot to be included in the official canvass if the registration is deemed effective.

name: Requires that all candidates for elected local, state or federal office shall be required to caption any video advertisement which is viewed by the general public.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires candidates to ensure any video advertisement or promotion in which the candidate appears include clear, conspicuous captions that are either auto generated or added by the candidate.

name: Establishes a nonpartisan poll monitoring program.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Defines which groups constitute a "civic organization" and defines "ballot issue committee."
  • Establishes that up to two nonpartisan poll monitors per polling place may be appointed by a civic organization or ballot issue committee.
  • Requires the groups to file a statement of intention to appoint nonpartisan poll monitors with the state board of elections 30-45 days before an election.
  • Specifies content that must be included in the statement and who must sign and swear to the information provided.
  • Stipulates that the board of elections may deny an appointment if the group fails to furnish satisfactory evidence that the group is devoted to the enumerated purposes or if the group has not maintained an office and public phone number in the state for at least one year.
  • Sets a timeline of two business days for the state board of elections to approve or deny a group's request.
  • Specifies reasons for denials and also procedures if the request is denied.
  • Requires the state board of elections to send a list of approved organizations appointing poll monitors to county boards at least 15 days before the election.
  • Directs that monitors must wear a specified badge with certain credential information and establishes the process for the creation of the credential badges.
  • Requires poll monitors to be registered to vote in the district of the polling place.
  • Lists which individuals are not qualified to be poll monitors.
  • Outlines acceptable activities for nonpartisan poll monitors and lists which part of the voting process may be monitored.
  • Directs monitors to present their credentials when entering a polling place and specifies the format of the credentials.
  • Outlines procedures for handling credentials after the election.
  • Enumerates the rights of credentialed poll monitors.
  • Authorizes substituting poll monitors, with certain guidelines and procedures.
  • Prohibits more than two nonpartisan poll monitors from a committee or organization being in a polling place at the same time, and establishes related procedures.

name: Requires the county seat in Herkimer county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill adds Herkimer county to existing election law requiring at least one polling place designated for early voting, on a public transportation route, if possible.

name: Relates to the notification of county boards of elections of an individual's death and the subsequent removal of such voter's name from the applicable registration roll.
summary:
As amended, this bill:

  • Changes the deadline for delivery of records of all voting age individuals for whom death certificates have been issued from a monthly delivery, to immediate delivery, but no later than seven business days.
  • Requires the state board of elections to provide relevant information to any affected county board of elections immediately but no later than seven business days.
  • Directs that when notification of a voter's death is received, a voter's registration be cancelled and immediately removed from the registration roll.

name: Requires the county seat in Herkimer county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
categories: Early voting administration,In-person voting and polling places
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the county seat in Herkimer County to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.

name: Extends provisions relating to electronic absentee ballot applications until April 1, 2022; bumps the effectiveness to April 1, 2022.
summary: • Changes the effective date of an election law related to electronic applications for absentee ballots from December 31, 2021 to April 1, 2022.

name: Extends provisions relating to electronic absentee ballot applications until April 1, 2022; bumps the effectiveness to April 1, 2022.
summary: • Changes the effective date of an election law related to electronic applications for absentee ballots from December 31, 2021 to April 1, 2022.

name: Requires audits by hand recount of voter verifiable audit records.
summary: • Provides that audits of voter verifiable audit records must be performed by a hand recount.

name: Requires audits by hand recount of voter verifiable audit records.
summary: • Provides that audits of voter verifiable audit records must be performed by a hand recount.

name: Requires audits by hand recount of voter verifiable audit records.
summary: • Provides that audits of voter verifiable audit records must be performed by a hand recount.

name: Requires audits by hand recount of voter verifiable audit records.
summary: • Provides that audits of voter verifiable audit records must be performed by a hand recount.

name: Eliminates the ability of judicial candidates for office who are enrolled in a particular party to automatically be allowed to run as a candidate in another party's primary election.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Primary systems
summary: • Eliminates judges from candidates who may run in another party's primary election.

name: Prevents municipalities from abridging the election law.
summary: • Provides that anyone who does not have the right to vote, or the right to register to vote, by the state constitution, also does not have the right to vote, or register to vote, locally.

name: Permits voting by absentee ballot where there is a risk of contracting or spreading a disease that may cause illness to the voter or to other members of the public.
summary:
• Defines "illness" in absentee voting.
  • Changes the expiration date of the code to December 31, 2022 from January 1, 2022.

name: Extends provisions relating to electronic absentee ballot applications until April 1, 2022; bumps the effectiveness to April 1, 2022.
summary: • Changes the effective date of an election law related to electronic applications for absentee ballots from December 31, 2021 to April 1, 2022.

name: Extends provisions relating to electronic absentee ballot applications until April 1, 2022; bumps the effectiveness to April 1, 2022.
summary: • Changes the effective date of an election law related to electronic applications for absentee ballots from December 31, 2021 to April 1, 2022.

name: Requires the board of elections to send an absentee ballot application to all voters who filed an absentee ballot application for the prior election; provides for a permanent absentee ballot application list.
summary:
• Requires the board of elections to send an absentee ballot application to all voters who filed an absentee ballot application for village, primary, special, and general elections.
  • Requires the board of elections to establish a permanent absentee voter list.
  • Lists requirements for the permanent absentee voter list.

name: Requires a commissioner to meet certain qualifications before his or her appointment which shall include, but not be limited to, the qualifications prescribed by section three of the public officers law, and demonstrated experience in election administration or other management, operations, or administrative experience in the public, non-profit, or private sector as deemed sufficient by the board.
summary: This bill requires all commissioners of boards of elections in each county and the city of New York to meet certain qualifications before his or her appointment, including, but not be limited to, the qualifications prescribed by existing public officers law, and demonstrated experience in election administration or other management, operations, or administrative experience in the public, non-profit, or private sector as deemed sufficient by the board. These qualifications apply to appointments made beginning thirty days after promulgation of such qualifications and shall thereafter be reviewed by such board at least every two years and updated as necessary. Such qualifications shall be prescribed by the board only after consideration of the skills and knowledge necessary or useful for the exercise of the duties and responsibilities of such commissioners, as well as the ability to recruit a sufficient number of candidates to be commissioners.

name: Relates to special elections to fill vacancies in the state senate and assembly and certain deadlines with regard to such special elections.
categories: Administrative deadlines,Special election procedures,Vacancy procedures,Ballot access deadlines
summary:
• Creates separate guidelines for filling a vacancy for state senate or assembly.
  • Adds deadlines for determining nominations, certificate of party nomination, certificate of acceptance, and authorizing certificates for special elections.
  • Outlines procedures and timelines for objections to certificate of nomination or other specified certificates in a special election.
  • Provides that early voting places must operate 30 days before a special election.
  • Provides timelines for ballots for military voters in a special election.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Prohibits the at large election of any member of the governing or legislative body of a town or village by electors of such town or village; requires the election of such members by wards; repeals certain provisions related thereto.
summary:
• Provides that the board of trustees of eery village must provide for the election of trustees by ward or alter ward boundaries.
  • Removes provisions allowing for the abolition of the ward system in certain circumstances.
  • Removes the possibility to reduces the number of councilmen.
  • Removes certain guidelines regarding increasing the number of councilmen.
  • Provides that no member of a town or village legislative body will be elected at large.
  • Outlines how a ward system should be set up by the board of elections for a county.
  • Provides reapportionment guidelines for the ward system.
  • Provides exemptions and procedures related to exemptions.
  • Provides timelines for completion.
  • Provides reporting requirements.

name: Requires a new party to file a certificate following the election at which the party obtains party status.
summary: • Requires a new party to file a first certificate by the last day of February after the election where the party gained party status.

name: Authorizes the Westchester county board of elections to merge any election district with 50 or fewer registered voters into an existing election district.
summary: As introduced, this bill authorizes the board of elections in the county of Westchester to merge an election district with 50 registered voters or fewer into another existing election district, with certain requirements and limitations.

name: Prohibits election commissioners and deputy election commissioners from holding a publicly elected office or from being the respective chair of the county democratic or republican committees.
summary: This bill prohibits election commissioners from holding any other public office or chairing democratic or republican parties.

name: Requires the county seat in Steuben county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
summary: • Adds Steuben county to the list of locales that must have at least one polling place for early voting.

name: Provides for the appointment and removal for cause of commissioners of election; provides for removal for cause by the board of elections and/or the governor.
summary:
• Changes election commissioners' terms of office from two to four years beginning February 15, instead of January 1, and removes provisions allowing county legislative bodies to do otherwise.
  • Allows county committees to recommend at least two additional people for appointment for commissioner of elections when there is a vacancy and the legislative body failed to appoint someone.
  • Provides instructions for removal of election commissioners and filling vacancies.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Authorizes voting by proxy at a judicial district convention due to novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
summary: • Establishes that a delegate to a convention who cannot attend due to state of emergency due to coronavirus, the delegate is entitled to vote by proxy.

name: Relates to electronic applications for absentee ballots; provides for the repeal of such provisions upon the expiration thereof.
summary: • Allows for absentee ballot applications to be submitted electronically through a web portal or by email.

name: Requires the county seat in Delaware county (Delhi) to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires that Delaware county have at least one polling place designated for early voting, situated along public transportation routes, if possible.

name: Increases the term of office of an election commissioner from two to four years beginning January first of each odd numbered year.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the term of office for an election commissioner from two years to four years, and removes exceptions for New York city and Schenectady.

name: Authorizes a change of location of early voting polling places for certain special, primary and run-off primary elections when no voters of the municipality with the highest population within the county are eligible to vote.
categories: Special election procedures,In-person voting and polling places
summary: • Provides that the board of elections may have an early voting polling place in the municipality with the highest population in the county where eligible voters will vote in the election.

name: Requires the county seat in Fulton county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the county seat in Fulton county to have at least one early voting polling place.

name: Relates to the mailing and receipt of absentee ballots; provides for the repeal of such provisions upon the expiration thereof.
summary:
• Removes an exception for canvassing absentee ballots without certain verifications when canvassing all other ballots.
  • Changes the deadline for witness signature on various types of absentee ballots to Election Day, instead of the day before the election.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Requires the legislative body responsible for appointing election commissioners to hold a public hearing prior to appointing a person recommended by a party; requires an appointment within sixty days after the filing of a certificate of recommendation.
summary: This bill requires the legislative body responsible for appointing election commissioners to hold a public hearing prior to appointing a person recommended by a party. The bill requires an appointment within thirty days after the public hearing and sixty days after the filing of a certificate of recommendation.

name: Increases the dollar value of items that may legally be given or provided to any person, other than persons who are official representatives of the board of elections or political parties and committees and persons who are engaged as watchers, in a polling place without any identification of the person or entity supplying such provisions.
summary: • Stipulates that drink or refreshment worth less than five dollars (instead of one dollar) may be legally given to to voters at the polls.

name: Authorizes United States citizens currently residing outside the United States whose last residence in the United States was in the state of New York to vote in certain federal elections.
summary: • Removes "territory" and "possession of the United States" from Election Code listing possible places a voter may be registered.

name: Relates to furnishing money or entertainment to induce attendance at polls.
summary: This bill prohibits offering money, entertainment, or a nominal value such as snacks, water, soft drinks, or other refreshments to induce attendance at polls.

name: Establishes an electronic absentee ballot application transmittal system through which voters may apply for and submit an absentee ballot online.
summary:
• Adds an electronic absentee ballot application transmittal system to the options for a voter to order an absentee ballot.
  • Provides submission deadlines.
  • Provides that the state board of elections must establish and maintain an electronic absentee ballot application transmittal system.
  • Outlines procedures for transmitting information to local boards.
  • Outlines guidelines for submitting an electronic request for an absentee ballot.
  • Outlines required procedures for completing and processing an electronic request.
  • Outlines procedures for if a signature is missing on the request.

name: Requires voters voting by affidavit ballot to produce an identification document to verify residency in the election district; requires absentee ballots to be received by election day, or be post-marked by the first day of early voting.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots
summary:
• Provides that a voter voting by affidavit ballot is required to produce specific identification, and provides related requirements.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Adds a starting date of the first day of early voting to the time period for receiving absentee ballots.
  • Changes the last permissible day for receiving an absentee ballot to an office timestamp on the day of the election (instead of the day after the election).

name: Requires every board of elections to employ a minimum of four full time employees in addition to the appointed commissioners and two additional employees for every twenty thousand active registered voters beyond forty thousand active registered voters.
summary: This bill requires every board of elections to employ a minimum of four full-time employees, and two additional employees for every twenty thousand active registered voters beyond forty thousand active registered voters.

name: Provides that all local, village, town, county and city elections outside of New York City shall be in an even-numbered year.
categories: Election dates,Alignment of elections,Ballot design,Municipal election procedures
summary: This bill provides that all local, village, town, county and city elections outside of New York City shall be in an even-numbered year. Further, this bill specifies that elections be held on the Tuesday next succeeding the first Monday in November in an even-numbered year except in any village that elects its officers on a date not in November. In the event a village elects its officers on a date not in November, the primary election shall be held forty-nine days prior to the date of the village election. The bill also requires offices appearing on all ballots to be listed in the order of precedence, as applicable to the offices up for election in any given year, as follows: electors for president and vice president of the United States, governor and lieutenant governor, New York state comptroller, New York state attorney general, United States senator, member of the house of representatives, New York state senator, member of the New York state assembly. Any office which is not listed in the bill is not to appear on the ballot in a position before or ahead of an office which is listed. Additionally, all other offices are to be placed upon the ballot in the customary order; provided, further, that partisan offices regardless of the size of the constituency are to be listed before or ahead of nonpartisan offices and all candidates for judicial offices shall follow all other partisan offices.

name: Requires the state board of elections to develop a program to be administered by all boards of elections to notify voters of certain information where their area has been redistricted.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the state board of elections to develop a program notifying voters that their districts may have changed due to redistricting, and specifies that the program must include, but not be limited to, mailings, online resources, telephone resources to assist voters in determining their district.

name: Prevents municipalities from abridging the election law.
summary: As introduced, this bill clarifies that someone who does not have the right to register to vote according to state law also may not vote in county, city, town, or village elections through any action, nor may they register to vote for those local elections.

name: Requires local boards of elections to verify the number of enrolled members of a party in an election district and reject all petitions where there are no enrolled members of a party in such district.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires local boards of elections to verify the number of enrolled members of a party in an election district and reject all petitions where there are no enrolled members of a party in the district.

name: Requires the board of elections to send an absentee ballot application to all voters who filed an absentee ballot application for the prior election; provides for a permanent absentee ballot application list.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires the board of elections to send an absentee ballot application to all voters who filed an absentee ballot application for the previous election.
  • Requires the board of elections to establish a permanent absentee ballot application list.
  • Provides that a voter may request to be placed on the list at any time by completing an application electronically or by mail.
  • Authorizes a voter to request to be removed from the permanent absentee ballot list.

name: Permits New York city voters to sign designating petitions for multiple candidates for the same New York City municipal public office or party position.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a New York city voter to sign petitions for a greater number of candidates for a city municipal public office, or party position with the counties of New York city, than the number of people to be elected, with no limit.

name: Relates to promoting inmate voter registration and voting by incarcerated people; requires the department of corrections and community supervision to distribute a voter information guide and hold voter information and registration clinics for incarcerated people every other year.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Clarifies that an incarcerated person registering and voting should be considered a resident of their last address prior to incarceration.
  • Prohibits a voter's registration from being canceled while he or she is incarcerated in a state or local facility and prevents municipalities from enacting a conflicting ordinance.
  • Requires the department to establish a program promoting voter registration and voting by incarcerated people and lists items to be included, including a guide, registration clinics, voter registration drives, resources, voter information, and more.

name: Relates to the appointment of commissioners of elections; provides that once a party recommends a person for commissioner of elections the local legislative body shall automatically approve the appointment of such person.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a local legislative body to automatically approve any recommendations for commissioners of elections by a party.

name: Makes provisions relating to the joint nomination of candidates for the offices of governor and lieutenant governor; provides candidates be designated jointly either by the state committee or by petition; provides said petition will be valid only if it jointly designates both candidates.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary: As introduced, this bill requires candidates for governor and lieutenant governor be designated jointly by a single vote by committee, and members of the party may make other designations by petition for members of the same party. A petition designating a candidate governor or lieutenant governor can be valid only if the petition designates both jointly.

name: Requires absentee ballots to be provided to all qualified voters; relates to the delivery of absentee ballots.
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes no excuse absentee voting and directs local eleciton officials to provide all qualified voters within their jurisdiction an absentee ballot and a prepaid return envelope for all eligible elections.

name: Establishes a ranked choice voting method to be implemented by local governments for use in general elections, special elections and primaries within the state.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Authorizes the state board of elections to mandate all county boards of elections to conduct state elections to used the ranked choice voting method, starting in 2025.
  • Specifies that the ranked choice voting provision applied when there are three or more candidates.
  • Outlines procedures for the local governing body to implement a resolution regarding ranked choice voting.
  • Outlines election procedures for use of ranked choice voting including ballot specifications, instructions, administration of tabulation, determination of a winner.
  • Requires certain voter education measures where local governments pass a resolution authorizing ranked choice voting.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Requires the board of elections in the city of New York to release data on how voters ranked all candidates in a ranked choice election, even if a single candidate received a majority of highest rank votes and the tabulation process was not triggered.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the city of New York to release data on how voters ranked all candidates in all ranked-choice elections.

name: Requires a valid government issued photo identification card be presented when casting a ballot; provides for persons eligible for Medicaid to receive identification cards.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires valid identification to cast a ballot in-person. The bill also waives any fee associate with obtaining a government identification for any adult citizen whose income qualifies him or her for Medicaid.

name: Clarifies the qualification to receive an absentee ballot; clarifies the process for delivery of an absentee ballot.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Allows a person to receive a ballot at their registered or temporary address.
  • Prohibits a person being designated to receive more than 2 ballots in an election and a candidate from being designated to receive the ballots.
  • Requires the local board of elections to have an absentee ballot receiver fill out a form with their address and certify they are following the rules laid out to receive their ballot(s).

name: Designates campuses which are operated by the state university of New York or the city university of New York as early voting sites and polling sites.
most_recent_action: House Rules Public Hearing (13:00:00 13:00:00 HR C)
summary: This bill designates campuses which are operated by the state university of New York or the city university of New York as early voting sites and polling sites. The bill mandates a polling place designated for registrants on such campus shall be at a location approved by such college or university and that any university that has an on campus dormitory must have an early voting site on campus.

name: Removes the ability to petition for opportunity to ballot for public office or party position.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary: As introduced, this bill repeals the option to petition for opportunity to ballot for a public office or party position.

name: Includes attempting to register as an elector knowing that he or she is not qualified due to lack of U.S. citizenship.
summary: As introduced, this bill defines as a felony act attempting to register as an elector while knowing that he or she is not qualified due to lack of U.S. citizenship

name: Provides that certain local elections outside of New York City shall be in an even-numbered year.
summary: As introduced, this bill moves biennial town elections to even-numbered years, provides for one-year terms for certain officials elected in odd-numbered years, and specifies the order in which offices should appear on the ballot in certain elections.

name: Exempts public school buildings from being designated as early polling locations.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits the designation of public school buildings as early voting locations.

name: Requires voters voting by affidavit ballot to produce an identification document to verify residency in the election district; requires absentee ballots to be received by election day, or be post-marked by the first day of early voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires voters voting by affidavit to have a valid identification. This bill also requires absentee ballots be received by election day or postmarked by the first day of early voting to be canvassed.

name: Removes the requirement of a sworn statement administered by a notary public for purposes of petitions; requires the notary public to inquire whether the person is the same listed on the address.
summary: As introduced, this bill removes the requirement for a notary public to have a voter swear as to their identity, and instead requires the notary public to ask whether the person is the same person whose information is listed on the form, and makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to absentee voting by residents of nursing homes and other long-term care facilities; provides that inspectors of the board of elections shall not physically deliver ballots to residents of such facilities.
summary:
• Prohibits inspectors of the board from visiting certain facilities, or delivering ballots to residents of facilities for elections held before December 1, 2021.
  • Requires boards of elections to mail or deliver absentee ballots to voters in facilities in the same way they deliver absentee ballots to other absentee voters.

name: Provides all registered voters on the day of the general election and the primary election in every even numbered year a full work day off without the loss of pay; provides a tax credit to small businesses who provide a paid day off to employees on general election day.
summary: This bill provides that all registered voters on the day of the general election and the primary election in every even numbered year receive a full work day off without the loss of pay and provides a tax credit to small businesses who provide a paid day off to employees on general election day.

name: Permits voting at any polling place within the same county or, within the city of New York, polling place within the city of New York as a voter is registered.
categories: Early voting administration,In-person voting and polling places
summary: As introduced, this bill allows any registered voter to vote, including during early voting, in any polling place in the county they reside outside of New York City or in any polling place in New York City if they are a resident. Each polling place will be equipped to print ballots on demand.

name: Requires the boards of trustees of SUNY and CUNY to adopt policies requiring institutions thereof to grant course credit to students who serve as election inspectors, poll clerks, or election coordinators.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires state university trustees to adopt a policy requiring state universities to grant course credit to each student who serves as an election inspector, poll clerk, or election coordinator, and requires institutions to coordinate with the appropriate board of elections to verify work.

name: Provides that if a school building is designated as a polling place, the board or body which controls such building shall provide a space that is not easily accessible to areas of the building where instructional activities are taking place, and if such a space cannot be provided that meets such criteria, the board or agency which controls such building shall cancel in-person instructional activities during the operating hours of such poll site.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a public school building being used for elections have a space that is not easily accessible to areas where instruction is taking place, and if this is not possible, in-person instruction must be canceled during the operation of the polling site.

name: Requires the board of elections to post sample ballots online at least twelve days prior to the first day of early voting; requires such ballots to be posted in a searchable database.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the board of elections to post a sample ballot, in searchable format, in each district on the board's website for a minimum of 12 days before the first day of early voting, and requires use of security tools to prevent tampering.

name: Allows voters age sixty-five or older to request an absentee ballot.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows voters who are 65 or older to vote by absentee ballot.

name: Requires the board of elections to provide Russian interpreters at certain polling locations in cities having a population in excess of one million people.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires that a county whose population is made up of at least five percent of people whose first language is Russian and within a city whose population is greater than one million people to provide Russian interpreters at polling locations in the election districts in such county with a population comprised of five percent or more people whose first language is Russian.

name: Relates to the appointment of commissioners of elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill clarifies that when a county legislative body or city council fails to appoint a party nomination for election commissioner within a set period of time, that the nominee will nevertheless be appointed in certain circumstances.

name: Authorizes the state board of elections to reject the use of voting machines or systems on the grounds that such machines or systems are not proper, safe, or secure.
summary: As introduced, this bill authorizes the state board of elections to reject the use of voting machines or equipment that are deemed not proper, safe, or secure.

name: Provides that absentee ballots shall not be mailed or delivered to a voter unless such voter has specifically requested to receive an absentee ballot.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits election officials from mailing voters abesentee ballots unless the voter has specifically requested such a ballot.

name: Allows photographs of one's self and one's own ballot while voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits voters to capture and post on social media photos of themselves and their ballots at any stage of the voting process. The bill also creates a new misdemeanor offense for anyone who forces another voter to photograph their ballot or post such a photo on social media.

name: Provides voters an opportunity to cure deficiencies regarding affidavit ballots in order to have their votes counted.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Outlines cure procedures for the board of elections if an affidavit ballot envelope is incomplete.
  • Outlines how a voter may cure the defects on the ballot envelope and administrative procedures for the board.
  • Provides deadlines for curing the envelope.
  • Outlines what to do if the board is split as to the sufficiency of the cure affirmation.
  • Requires a voter be notified within three days if the board invalidates an affidavit ballot.

name: Relates to construction of voting machines and systems.
categories: Ballot design,In-person voting and polling places,In-person voter assistance
summary: As introduced, this bill makes changes to the physical requirements of ballots and provides for the use of non-tabulating ballot marking devices for any voter to use at in-person polling locations.

name: Adjusts the effective date of the John R. Lewis Voting Rights Act of New York to July 1, 2023.
categories: Administrative deadlines,Legal causes of action,In-person voter assistance,Absentee/mail-in voter assistance
summary: • Changes the deadline for enactment of the John R Lewis Voting Rights Act to July 1, 2023.

name: Relates to authorizing voting by incarcerated individuals in correctional facilities; requires the department of corrections and community supervision, in collaboration with the state and county boards of election, to establish a program to facilitate incarcerated individuals voter registration and voting.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Furnishes that an incarcerated person voting while in a correctional facility will be considered a resident of the locale where he or she resided prior to incarceration.
  • Prohibits a voter's registration from being canceled while he or she is incarcerated in a state or local correctional facility.
  • Requires the department, with the state and county boards of elections, to establish a program facilitating voter registration and voting for incarcerated people, including access and assistance and absentee voting.

name: Relates to requiring boards of elections to include the number of registration forms distributed to and returned by each agency assisting with voter registration in their annual reports; provides personally identifiable information about the registrants shall not be collected or included in the report.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires each state public agency assisting with voter registration to report the number of registration forms distributed to and returned in the annual report. Personally identifiable information cannot be collected.

name: Relates to split shifts for election inspectors or poll clerks.
most_recent_action: Local Government Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 9, NAYS 4.
summary: This bill allows poll clerks to work split shifts in addition to election inspectors.

name: Amends the constitution to delete the requirement that registration for purposes of voting be completed at least ten days before election day and provides that laws be made to adequately safeguard against deception in the exercise of the right of suffrage.
summary: • Removes the requirement that registration must be completed ten days before each election from the Constitution.

name: Requires the state board of elections to develop a program to be administered by all boards of elections to notify voters of certain information where their area has been redistricted.
summary:
• Requires the state board of elections to develop a program to notify voters the their district may have changed due to redistricting.
  • Provides guidance on what should be included in the program.

name: Requires the board of elections to establish an electronic system allowing absentee voters to monitor the status of their ballot and to correct an unaccepted ballot.
summary:
• Requires the board of elections to provide confirmation of receipt of an absentee ballot and information on its acceptance.
  • Requires the board to provide documentation when a ballot is not accepted including the reason it was not accepted.

name: Makes the following participating agencies for purposes of agency assisted voter registration: public libraries, local housing authorities, and public high schools; directs the state board of elections to promulgate rules and regulations for implementation.
summary: • Designates public libraries, local housing authorities, and public high schools as agencies providing voter registration programs.

name: Relates to authorizing voting by inmates in correctional facilities; requires the department of corrections and community supervision, in collaboration with the state and county boards of election, to establish a program to facilitate inmate voter registration and voting.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:
• Provides that an incarcerated voter will be considered a resident of the locale where he or she resided before incarceration.
  • Establishes that a voter's registration will not be canceled while he or she is incarcerated.
  • Requires establishment of a program to facilitate inmate voter registration and voting, and includes requirements.

name: Requires the board of elections or a bipartisan committee appointed by such board to conduct a risk-limiting audit of voter verifiable audit records from voting machines or systems within the jurisdiction of such board.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires the state board of elections to create rules for implementing a risk limiting audit, including the number of records to be selected, with a minimum of 3% of votes cast.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Requires the board of elections to conduct a risk limiting audit, including "hand to eye" review of at least 3% of paper records.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to the appointment of election inspectors and poll clerks; requires the board of elections of each county to make appointments by April 15 of each year; provides that a person listed on an original or supplemental list of eligible persons to serve as election inspectors or poll clerks for three consecutive years must submit a written affirmation of willingness and availability to serve.
summary: • Provides that if someone on the political party list for election inspector, poll clerk, or election coordinator has not served in three years, the party must obtain a written statement affirming that the person is still willing to serve.

name: Prohibits the use of campaign funds to pay any settlement fees, fines or penalties for sexual harassment civil or criminal actions.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits payment with campaign funds of any settlement fees, or fines related to criminal or civil action, or investigation, or prosecution related to sexual harassment allegations.

name: Requires the preparation of reports on assignments of election inspectors and poll clerks.
summary: • Provides that county boards of elections, and the city of New York, must prepare a report detailing assignments of election inspectors and poll clerks and include vacancies that exist at poll sites.

name: Relates to split shifts for election inspectors or poll clerks.
summary: • Adds poll clerks to rules governing election inspectors working split shifts.

name: Authorizes, under certain circumstances, full-time college and university students to act as election inspectors and poll clerks in the election district where their college or university is located.
summary:
• Provides that a full time college student may act as an election inspector or poll clerk in the county of the location of the college, with exceptions for New York City.
  • Provides guidelines on questions the student must answer to be certified.
  • Defines "full time."

name: Makes provisions relating to the joint nomination of candidates for the offices of governor and lieutenant governor; provides candidates be designated jointly either by the state committee or by petition; provides said petition will be valid only if it jointly designates both candidates.
summary: • Provides that candidates for governor and lieutenant governor will be designated jointly on a petition and on a ballot.

name: Relates to proceedings with respect to designating and nominating petitions.
summary: • Provides the option to hold a proceeding regarding a timely invalidation petition within three business days after the proper service of pleadings.

name: Allows a U.S. citizen, who is seventeen years of age, to vote in a primary election, including presidential, if he or she will turn eighteen by the date of the corresponding general election.
summary: • Provides that qualified voters who are 17 years old at the time of a primary, but will be 18 years old by the general election may vote in the primary.

name: Defines the term "party" as any political organization which at the last preceding election for governor polled at least fifty thousand votes for its candidate for governor.
summary: This bill defines the term "party" as any political organization which at the last preceding election for governor polled at least fifty thousand votes for its candidate for governor.

name: Sets out the procedures and requirements for special elections; implements a timetable for the special primary and special election, including the number of signatures required for the petition.
summary:
• Requires party nominations for special elections to be held during a special primary, where the candidate receiving the most votes wins.
  • Outlines timelines and requirements for the nomination process for the special primary, and specifies when the primary should be held.
  • Adds state senators and state assembly members to existing rules governing vacancies.
  • Requires the Governor to make a proclamation within ten days of a vacancy for a special election.
  • Specifies when vacancy elections should be held.

name: Relates to the registration status of voters; establishes additional requirements for the cancellation of a voter's registration; allows voters who have an inactive status to have their registration returned to active status and to have their vote counted for the election in which they vote.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Adds a violation for election officers canceling a voter's registration illegally, or refusing to allow someone to vote due to inactive status.
  • Removes a provision canceling a voter's registration if the voter did not vote during a specific time period.
  • Requires the inactive poll ledger be distributed to each election district in a county.
  • Requires inactive voter lists be compiled by the board of elections in each district.
  • Allows a voter to casting an affidavit envelope vote, who meets all the requirements, to be restored to active status.

name: Instructs the state board of elections to create and distribute voting guides to voters containing information about the candidates; mandates that voters receive postcards to notify them of upcoming elections and that television and radio stations also notify their audience of upcoming elections.
summary:
• Provides that a candidate may file a sworn statement with specific information for a voter guide created by the state board of elections.
  • Outlines procedures and timelines for the state board of elections in creating the candidate guide.
  • Outlines procedures for distributing the candidate guide and maintaining a website with the information.
  • Requires the board to notify the public by television and radio of the existence of the guide, with specific requirements.

name: Provides voting materials in French and Creole; requires translators in French and Creole in the city of New York at polling places in subdivisions where more than five percent of the citizens of voting age speak the language of French and/or Creole and are limited-English proficient.
summary:
• Requires boards of elections in cities with over one million people to provide voter information in French and Creole.
  • Requires New York City officials to provide ballots and voter support in French and Creole if 5% or more of voting age citizens in the district are limited-English proficient and speak one of the two languages.

name: Reduces the time for mailing and receipt of registration application to constitutional minimum.
most_recent_action: Assigned to s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee
summary: This bill reduces the time for mailing and receipt of registration application to constitutional minimum of fifteenth day before the next primary, general or special election, and received no later than the tenth day before such election

name: Provides that certain cities and towns shall have early voting poll sites within their boundaries and, where practicable, that such sites shall be situated along public transportation routes.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires at least one early voting polling place in cities or towns with a population between 50,000-100,000.

name: Permits voter registration and party enrollment, and change of party enrollment within 10 days of a primary, general, or special election.
summary:
• Changes deadlines for party enrollment application submittal to 10 days before the election (from 25), to be received at least five days before the election (from 20).
  • Removes a provision for military personnel honorably discharged before the election.
  • Changes deadlines for voter registration form submittal to 10 days before the election (from 25), to be received at least five days before the election (from 20).
  • Changes transmission and receipt deadlines of related forms for the Department of Motor Vehicles.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Requires absentee ballots to be provided to all qualified voters and relates to the delivery of absentee ballots.
summary:
• Requires county board of elections to mail an absentee ballot with a return postage envelope to every qualified voter in the district. 
  • Provides instruction on the administration of the mailing, timeline, and exceptions.
  • Provides instruction on return of the ballot.

name: Relates to petitions for election to the party position of member of the county committee; provides that candidates shall not be required to provide their zip code if they have clearly stated their town or city on their petition.
summary: • Clarifies that candidates for member of the party county committee are not required to provide a zip code if they stated their town or city on the petition.

name: Relates to empowering the commissioner of a board of elections to order a voting machine audit upon a finding of discrepancies.
most_recent_action: Second Reading referred to Aeronautics and Transportation
summary: • Provides that a commissioner of a board of elections is empowered to order an audit when a discrepancy in the tally exists.

name: Provides that casting and canvassing of absentee, military, special presidential, special federal and other special ballots shall occur as such ballots are received by the board of elections.
most_recent_action: Second Reading referred to Education Committee then to Appropriations Committee
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Special election procedures,Counting and canvassing procedures,Military/UOCAVA voting
summary:
• Allows the board of elections to establish a procedure providing for casting and canvassing ballots, and eliminates specific time deadlines.
  • Requires the board of elections to notify a voter whose absentee ballot was rejected or challenged and give the person an opportunity to correct an error prior to the election.
  • Specifies that if a voters name shows that the voter already voted before Election Day, the voter may only vote by affidavit ballot on Election Day.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Relates to annual reports of the boards of elections; requires such reports be made available on the boards' websites; requires that the reports include specific performance metrics.
summary:
• Requires the board of elections annual reports to be made public on a website by five days after the report is delivered.
  • Outlines a list of metrics required in the annual report.

name: Relates to the appointment of election inspectors and poll clerks; provides that each board of elections submit a report detailing assignments of election inspectors and poll clerks; provides that each board of elections be required to fill vacancies by appointing individuals that appear on the additional inspector list.
summary:
• Requires county board of elections to prepare and file a report with assignments of election inspectors and poll clerks, with specific assigned polling sites.
  • Requires boards of elections to appoint election inspectors, poll clerks, and election coordinators from the additional inspector list for vacancies, with specific guidelines.
  • Provides guidelines for additional vacancies when the list is exhausted.

name: Relates to designating every government entity which issues licenses to carry, possess, repair and dispose of firearms as participating agencies for voter registration form distribution and assistance.
most_recent_action: Assigned to s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee
summary: • Adds every court and law enforcement agency issuing licenses to carry firearms to the listed of agencies designated to do voter registration.

name: Relates to the confidentiality of registration records for victims of domestic violence; requires victims of domestic violence wishing to make their registration records confidential to deliver a signed written statement swearing or affirming that they are victims of domestic violence and due to the threat of physical or emotional harm they wish to keep their registration record confidential.
summary:
• Establishes that a registered domestic violence victim may request to keep their voter registration record confidential. 
  • Provides that a new application must be made every four years.

name: Relates to the text of proposed constitutional amendments and questions.
summary:
• Requires the state board of elections to publish the text of each amendment, proposition, and question.
  • Requires the state board of elections to include a relevant form on their website.
  • Requires the Attorney General to prepare and deliver an abstract of the proposed amendment, proposition, or question at least four months before the election.

name: Relates to authorizing voting by inmates in correctional facilities; requires the department of corrections and community supervision, in collaboration with the state and county boards of election, to establish a program to facilitate inmate voter registration and voting.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance
summary:
• Requires that an inmate voting while incarcerated will be considered a resident of the municipality in which he or she resided before the election.
  • Stipulates that a voter's registration cannot be canceled while he or she is incarcerated.
  • Requires the department to establish a voter registration and voting information program with certain requirements.

name: Relates to authorizing voting by inmates in correctional facilities; requires the department of corrections and community supervision, in collaboration with the state and county boards of election, to establish a program to facilitate inmate voter registration and voting.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance
summary:
• Requires that an inmate voting while incarcerated will be considered a resident of the municipality in which he or she resided before the election.
  • Stipulates that a voter's registration cannot be canceled while he or she is incarcerated.
  • Requires the department to establish a voter registration and voting information program with certain requirements.

name: Requires the board of elections to provide Russian interpreters at certain polling locations in cities having a population in excess of one million people.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate Education Committee
categories: Language accommodations,In-person voting and polling places
summary: • Requires Russian interpreters at polling locations in cities with a population over one million whose county has 5% or more of residents who speak Russian as a first language.

name: Relates to the number of affidavit ballots to be supplied at polling sites.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary: • Requires each county board of election to supply county affidavit ballots to polling sites and provides required quantities.

name: Relates to mandatory training curriculum for poll workers; requires the state board of elections to develop and provide to each county materials for a model poll worker training program which the counties may use to train individuals to serve as poll workers in state and county elections.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary: This bill provides mandatory training curriculum for election commissioners and key staff of boards of elections and to model poll worker training programs. The bill also requires the state board of elections to develop and provide to each county materials for a model poll worker training program, which the counties may use to train individuals to serve as poll workers in state and county elections.

name: Relates to authorizing voting by inmates in correctional facilities; requires the department of corrections and community supervision, in collaboration with the state and county boards of election, to establish a program to facilitate inmate voter registration and voting.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance
summary:
• Requires that an inmate voting while incarcerated will be considered a resident of the municipality in which he or she resided before the election.
  • Stipulates that a voter's registration cannot be canceled while he or she is incarcerated.
  • Requires the department to establish a voter registration and voting information program with certain requirements.

name: Relates to authorizing voting by inmates in correctional facilities; requires the department of corrections and community supervision, in collaboration with the state and county boards of election, to establish a program to facilitate inmate voter registration and voting.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance
summary:
• Requires that an inmate voting while incarcerated will be considered a resident of the municipality in which he or she resided before the election.
  • Stipulates that a voter's registration cannot be canceled while he or she is incarcerated.
  • Requires the department to establish a voter registration and voting information program with certain requirements.

name: Prohibits political candidates from being nominated by more than one party for any public office.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits a person from being nominated for public office if the person has already been nominated by another political party for a political office.

name: Creates a pilot program to provide for an instant runoff voting method to be used in up to ten local governments, selected by the state board of elections, in election years 2026 and 2027; requires report to state legislature.
summary: As introduced, this bill creates a pilot program trial of instant runoff elections in up to ten local governnmennts to be selected by the state board of elections and taking place in the elections years of 2026 and 2027.

name: Requires a government photo identification card to be presented when casting a ballot; provides for a method to receive a government photo identification card at no charge.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the use of photo identification when casting a ballot and provides for a means of acquiring valid government identification at no cost.

name: Relates to creating the "modernized voter registration act of New York"; modernizes voter registration; promotes access to voting for individuals with disabilities; protects the ability of individuals to exercise the right to vote in elections for local and state office and makes an appropriation therefor.
categories: Voting equipment,Administrative deadlines,Audits,Oversight and accountability,Transparency,Signature matching,Ballot design,Reporting,Voter participation deadlines,Enforcement against officials,Enforcement against non-officials,Election workers/volunteers,Election officials,Legislative authority,Challenges,Noncitizen voting,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance,In-person voter assistance,Absentee/mail-in voter assistance,Military/UOCAVA voting,Same-day/Election Day registration,Automatic voter registration,Testing and certification,Digital/electronic voting,Physical security,Cybersecurity
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Establishes that all qualified individuals will be automatically registered to vote with their consent.
  • Provides that anyone applying for a new drivers license, renewing their license, applying for a non-driver identification card, applying for a pre-licensing course certificate, learners permit, or a certification of supervised driving with the department of motor vehicles will have the opportunity to automatically register to vote, or anyone changing his or her name or address with the Department of Motor Vehicles.
  • Lists all of the state application processes where one may be automatically registering to vote.
  • Defines "source agency."
  • Requires the state board of elections and source agencies to enter into agreements to ensure electronic transmission of voter registration information in the appropriate format, and includes information that must be provided.
  • Furnishes that a transmission missing a signature is not disqualified if otherwise eligible and provides procedures for obtaining a signature.
  • Requires source agencies to provide information about citizenship status.
  • Directs the state board of elections to prepare and distribute instructions for implementation of this program, and to train employees of source agencies, and includes training requirements and prohibitions.
  • Details what must be included in the agreements between source agencies and the state board of elections.
  • Requires source agencies to enter into an agreement with the state board of elections by September 1, 2025, and that each agency be prepared to comply with the requirements by January 1, 2026.
  • Outlines instructions for the state board of elections upon receiving information from a source agency about an automatic voter registration.
  • Prohibits use of voter registration information to determine someone citizenship status for immigration enforcement, criminal law enforcement, or other purposes other than voter registration and elections, nor may the information be disclosed to the public for such purposes.
  • Requires that an online registration option be available on the website of every election district, with specified requirements, and requires counties and municipalities to accept each qualified online voter registration application.
  • Outlines procedures for election officials to process applications, send confirmations and notifications.
  • Outlines signature procedures on the electronic form.
  • Requires voter registration services be provided in a nonpartisan manner and that voter information be secure through appropriate technological means.
  • Requires the state board of elections to create an automated telephone based system to be in addition to making services available online.
  • Provides that election officials must ensure that a registered voter on a computerized list may update their voter registration information through the website and that the voter must attest to the contents of the updates and outlines procedures for election administrators to process and update the information, including notifications.
  • Outlines voter list maintenance procedures and privacy and security measures for the website, records, data transmission, access, and registration lists, and requires the state board of elections to establish the standards.
  • Outlines privacy standards related to automatic voter registration and requires the state board of elections to establish related standards and procedures.
  • Defines "personal information."
  • Outlines procedures and privacy standards for those who decline to register to vote.
  • Outlines voter data transmission timelines, deadlines, notifications, and security requirements for automatic voter registration source agencies.
  • Provides that an election official may send related notifications by email if he or she has the voter's email address, and provides associated procedures.
  • Establishes that counties will allow same day registration.
  • Outlines which information must be provided to accept a voter registration application.
  • Stipulates that those who registered online will be treated the same way as those who registered by mail and that all potential voters must be treated without discrimination (including a list of certain individuals).
  • Prohibits communicating by email with a potential voter, except to fulfill established, official duties.
  • Outlines penalties for violation of list maintenance, security, and privacy rules.
  • Requires the voter registration application to include a space for an applicants email address, which is optional, and includes certain information to be included.
  • Outlines required reports from the board of elections to the state legislature and governor and includes detailed requirements and timelines.
  • Requires local boards of elections to establish procedures for absentee voter registration for people with disabilities.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Prohibits election officials from preventing someone registering to vote or from challenging their voter registration status on the basis of certain documents, lists, errors, or omissions and outlines penalties.
  • Outlines penalties for depriving or defrauding someone of their right to vote, with certain requirements.
  • Requires use of certain types of paper ballots that may be verified, and that may be counted by hand or by a scanner, with certain additional requirements and outlines requirements for ballot preservation.
  • Requires the state board of elections to determines best practices in paper ballot voting, verification, and casting mechanisms, and includes certain requirements.
  • Establishes that the state board of elections will administer audits of election results and outlines requirements and procedures, including how many ballots are to be counted in an audit.
  • Outlines procedures for the auditing entity to follow in conducting the audit.
  • Provides that the random selection of entities to be audited will be conducted in public.
  • Outlines requirements, timelines, and procedures for publishing the results of the audit.
  • Prohibits an election official from taking an active part in political management or campaigning in any election where the official has supervisory authority, with exceptions, and definition of terms.
  • Requires the state board of elections to establish a hotline to respond to questions and complaints, with certain requirements.
  • Outlines prohibitions against spouses, partners and others losing their active voter registration status due to being absent because of military or naval orders, or for several other listed reasons.
  • Outlines reporting requirements and timelines before an election by the state board of elections regarding election preparations and ballot transmissions for overseas and absent uniformed voters.
  • Provides that an employee of a state agency my leave for up to six days to provide election administration assistance, with detailed guidelines.
  • Requires the state board of elections to create a model poll worker training program with detailed requirements.
  • Requires boards of elections to submit changes in administration, regulation, policies, practices in majority minority districts for approval to the civil rights bureau, with certain requirements.

name: Relates to allowing pre-registered voters to apply for an absentee ballot.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows a person who is pre-registered to vote and qualified to vote in the next election to be eligible to receive an absentee ballot.

name: Prevents municipalities from abridging the election law.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits local governments from preventing or granting people the right to vote as permitted under state law.

name: Relates to poll watchers for special, town or village elections being held for the sole purpose of a ballot proposal.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits county board of elections to appoint watchers in a manner that ensures balanced representation for those advocating for the passage or defeat of the ballot proposal when a special, town or village election is being held for the sole purpose of a ballot proposal.

name: Restricts electioneering activities within six hundred feet of a polling place or the entire property where a polling place is located.
summary: As introduced, this bill restricts electioneering activities within 600 feet of a polling place entrance, inside the polling place, or stairwells leading to the polling place if there are multiple stories. If there will be electioneering restrictions, they must be made public prior to 24 hours of voting on the county election website.

name: Permits New York city voters to sign designating petitions for multiple candidates for the same New York City municipal public office or party position.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows New York City voters to designate on a ballot petition multiple candidates for a municipal public office or party position with no limit to the number of candidates.

name: Requires the board of elections to provide Russian interpreters at certain polling locations in cities having a population in excess of one million people.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the board of elections in New York City to provide Russian language interpreters at polling locations in a county that has more than five percent first language Russian speakers.

name: Requires the state board of elections to develop a program to be administered by all boards of elections to notify voters of certain information where their area has been redistricted.
summary: As introduced, this bill develops a program to be administered by all boards of elections to notify voters that their districts may have changed due redistricting and uses mailings, telephone, online and other resources to reach voters prior to elections.

name: Permits enrollment in the address confidentiality program for election officers.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows election officers to take part in the address confidentiality program. County board of elections will assist in enrolling election officers into the program.

name: Requires the county seat in Seneca county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
categories: Early voting administration,In-person voting and polling places
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the county seat in Seneca county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.

name: Relates to town elections and permissive referendums.
most_recent_action: P2C, caption bill, held on desk - pending amdt.
categories: Ballot measures (initiative and referendum),Municipal election procedures
summary:
• Provides guidance regarding at which town election a submitted referendum petition or proposition should appear.
  • Changes the election at which a proposition for abolishing a ward system may appear to the next general election, instead of any special or biennial town election.

name: Prohibits election commissioners and deputy election commissioners from holding a publicly elected office or from being the respective chair of the county democratic or republican committees.
summary: As introduced, this bill adds a prohibition on deputy election commissioners from holding public office, and both election commissioners and deputy election commissioners being a chair of the county Democratic or Republican parties.

name: Relates to the number of signatures for independent nominating petitions; decreases the number of signatures and votes to 15,000 signatures for statewide candidates and 50,000 votes to maintain party ballot status; changes the petition period to 12 weeks and the petitioning time to May-August.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary: As introduced, this bill decreases the number of signatures and votes required for independent nominating petitions to 15,000 signatures for statewide candidates and 50,000 votes to maintain party ballot status. The bill also establishes a twelve week petition period from May to August.
