name: Relates to the crimes of fraud in connection with a primary election, caucus or convention, and criminal impersonation in the first degree where a person pretends to be an elected official or candidate for an elected office and acts by impersonating such an elected official, or candidate or campaign for such an elected office, by communication by internet website or electronic means, with intent to obtain a benefit or injure or defraud another; requires social media companies to establish practi
most_recent_action: Assigned to s/c Criminal Justice Subcommittee
summary:
• Adds impersonating an election office, candidate, or campaign to the list of crimes of fraud.
  • Lists what is considered fraud in connection with a primary election, caucus, or convention and establishes that the state board of elections has the authority to impose civil penalties on these violations.
  • Furnishes the state board of elections with the authority to seek injunctive relief, and investigative authority including subpoena powers, in cases of impersonation of an election official and other fraud.
  • Requires social media companies to close accounts within 24 hours where they receive complaints alleging first degree criminal impersonation or fraud.

name: Relates to town elections and permissive referendums.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that if petitions for certain town propositions or referendums are submitted 75 days or less before a general election, they should be submitted for the general election the following year.
  • Provides that if petitions for certain town propositions or referendums call for a special election, then the special election must be held 60 to 75 days after the petition is filed. 
  • Allows the county board of elections to apportion costs.

name: Relates to pre-clearance of voting-related regulations and policies.
summary: As introduced, this bill creates a pre-clearance requirement for any change made to voting or elections procedures in certain counties. The bill requires any changes made by the state or local board of elections effecting these counties be submitted to the attorney general in advance.

name: Authorizes the city of New York to establish and maintain an electronic voter registration transmittal system for New York city residents.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows agencies of the city of New York to establish voter registration systems. The bill is to be repealed 90 days after a forthcoming statewide voter registration transmittal system is operational.

name: Provides that certain local elections outside of New York City shall be in an even-numbered year.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the date of election for biennial town elections and elections for county elected from odd-numbered years to even-numbered years, with some exceptions. The bill also standardizes the order in which offices appear on the ballot.

name: Removes provisions requiring election inspectors, poll clerks, and election coordinators to be appointed in a bipartisan manner.
summary: This bill removes the requirement that poll workers and other elections inspectors be equally divided between the two major political parties and replaces it with a requirement that these groups be divided between the parties as practicably as possible.

name: Provides voters with a warning about New York's closed primary system on voter registration forms.
summary: As introduced, this bill provides voters with notice of New York's closed primary system at the time of voter registration and informs them that, though not required, they must enroll in a political party in order to vote in party primaries.

name: Relates to the representation of newly formed political parties; relates to the placement of candidates of newly formed political parties on ballots, the representation of such parties within the state and the transmission of the official canvass of votes cast for presidential electors.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Changes the determination for the order of candidates on a ballot from a descending order by how party's candidate polled for governor in the last election, to a descending order by how a party's candidate polled for governor, or how how a party's candidates polled for a slate of presidential electors, in the general election in even numbered years.
  • Provides that if a party formed at a presidential election, the number of delegates, the state committee, and the county committee, will be based on the party's vote for presidential electors in the second year after the presidential election, and then based on gubernatorial votes thereafter.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Eliminates the signature requirement for designating petitions for certain candidates for office in the city of New York.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures
summary: • Provides that there will be no signature requirement for a candidate receiving public matching funds in the city of New York.

name: Amends the constitution to delete the requirement that registration for purposes of voting be completed at least ten days before election day; provides that laws be made to adequately safeguard against deception in the exercise of the right of suffrage.
categories: Legal causes of action,Automatic voter registration
summary: As introduced on January 4, 2023, this bill deletes the requirement that registration be completed at least 10 days before the election. It also requires laws be made to safeguard against fraud in voting.

name: Establishes a nonpartisan poll monitoring program.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary:
• Allows certain groups to appoint up to two nonpartisan poll monitors per polling place.
  • Outlines procedures and timelines for designating nonpartisan poll monitors, including authorizations, denials, and appeals.
  • Outlines polling place procedures for nonpartisan poll monitors.
  • Outlines the qualifications needed to be appointed a nonpartisan poll monitor.
  • Provides the job responsibilities of the nonpartisan poll monitor.
  • Provides for credentials for the nonpartisan poll monitor.
  • Specifies that there will be no more than two nonpartisan poll monitors from any organization at a polling place at the same time and procedures for if there is more than one organization at the polling place.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Allows photographs of one's self and one's own ballot while voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits voters to capture and post on social media photos of themselves and their ballots at any stage of the voting process. The bill also creates a new misdemeanor offense for anyone who forces another voter to photograph their ballot or post such a photo on social media.

name: Authorizes, under certain circumstances, full-time college and university students to act as election inspectors and poll clerks in the election district where their college or university is located.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary: This bill authorizes full-time college and university students to act as election inspectors and poll clerks in the election district where their college or university is located provided he or she: (1) is registered to vote; (2) holds no elective office; (3) is not a candidate for any public office to be voted for by the voters of the district in which he or she is to serve, and is not the spouse, parent or child of such a candidate; and (4) is able to speak and read the English language and write it legibly. The bill defines "full-time" as any matriculated student enrolled in at least twelve credit hours per semester at a New York college or university.

name: Changes the time period for the annual national change of address system check for registered voters to January.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the month in which local boards of election must obtain the forwarding address of registered voters from the National Change of Address System.

name: Requires the county seat in Wayne county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the county seat of Wayne County to establish at least one early voting location for eligible elections.

name: Relates to proceedings with respect to designating and nominating petitions.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows for petition proceedings to take place within three business days after the proper service of pleadings for a timely invalidation proceeding.

name: Requires persons administering challenge oaths to voter applicants to attest that the challenge is being made in good faith and to provide certain identifying information; requires challenge oaths to be presented to a challenged voter applicant in writing.
summary: As introduced, this bill adds requirements to the process by which a voter may be challenged as to his or her right to vote, including requiring the challenger to complete an oath that the challenge is being made and good faith and requiring that the challenger complete a form with his or her name and address.

name: Authorizes United States citizens currently residing outside the United States whose last residence in the United States was in the state of New York to vote in certain federal elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill removes a provision forbidding qualified voters living outside the United States whose last domicile was in New York from voting inn certain elections if they maintain a domicile in a territory or possession of the United States.

name: Eliminates the requirements for publication of detailed election notices within the city of New York.
summary: As introduced, this bill eliminates certain requirements of public notice preceding elections in New York City.

name: Provides for voter requests for an absentee ballot from the board of elections by telephone.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows voters to request absentee ballots by telephone.

name: Increases the minimum compensation to be paid to election day workers to three hundred dollars and election coordinators to four hundred dollars within the city of New York.
summary: As introduced, this bill increases compensation for election inspectors and election coordinators in New York City.

name: Extends the right to vote in school district elections to qualified persons who are sixteen years of age.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits qualified voters who are sixteen years of age to vote in school district elections.

name: Makes the following participating agencies for purposes of agency assisted voter registration: public libraries, local housing authorities, and public high schools; directs the state board of elections to promulgate rules and regulations for implementation.
summary: As introduced, this bill designates the following as participating agencies to administer a program of distribution of voter registration: public libraries, local housing authorities, and public high schools.

name: Relates to absentee voting in nursing homes and senior citizen residences; requires board of inspectors to deliver and help complete applications for absentee ballots to residents of such facilities.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in voter assistance
summary: As introduced, this bill requires board of inspectors to deliver absentee ballot applications to resident in nursing homes, assist in completing these applications, and deliver absentee ballots once the application has been submitted.

name: Requires the board of elections or a bipartisan committee appointed by such board to conduct a risk-limiting audit of voter verifiable audit records from voting machines or systems within the jurisdiction of such board.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes a requirement that local boards of elections, or a bipartisan committee appointed by a board, conduct a risk-limiting audit of at least three percent of the records of voting machines or systems within their jurisdiction to be completed within thirteen days of each election. The bill directs the state board of elections to establish the procedures and regulations for such audits.

name: Requires the state board of elections to fit registration forms to 8.5 x 11 inches standard paper size.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires that voter registration forms must be sized to standard 8.5 x 11 inches paper.

name: Provides protections against illegal voter purging.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires anyone other than an election official sending mail to a registered voter or voter registration applicant, knowing that it may be used to challenge the qualification of a voter, must file a duplicate copy of the mailing with the state board within two days of the mailing, and provides certain requirements.
  • Specifies that failure to comply will create the presumption that the mailing will not be used to challenge the qualification of a voter.
  • Provides that anyone other than an inspector or clerk may challenge the qualifications of a voter by completing a qualifying challenge affidavit.
  • Directs the state board of elections to create a challenge affidavit form, and specifies content, and clarifies that each affidavit will only challenge the qualifications of one voter.
  • Requires forms to be available to all voters.
  • Specifies the questions to be asked by the inspector to the voter who was challenged.
  • Prohibits retention of citizenship information used to determine voting rights, except as required by law, and clarifies how to treat failure to certify citizenship.
  • Adds reporting requirements for the board of inspectors regarding challenges, requiring information such as the name and address of the challenger, and the like.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Relates to the representation of newly formed political parties; relates to the placement of candidates of newly formed political parties on ballots, the representation of such parties within the state and the transmission of the official canvass of votes cast for presidential electors.
Relates to Eastchester fire district elections; follows provisions of election law instead of town law for elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill modifies election procedures for the Eastchester fire district including changing the election date, as well as nominating petition and vacancy procedures.

name: Increases compensation of election inspectors to $300 and coordinators to $350 in New York city.
summary: As introduced, this bill increases the compensation of election inspectors and coordinators in New York City from $300 to $350.

name: Allows a judicial district convention to be conducted in whole or in part via video conference upon a minimum of seventy-two hours notice to the members of the respective committee by mail, an appropriately titled email, text or telephone call at an address or number expressly provided in writing for the purpose of receiving such notices.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a judicial district convention to be conducted via video conference with a minimum notice of seventy-two hours  provided by mail, an email, text or telephone and instructions on how to log-in to the conference.

name: Requires the county seat in Allegany county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the county seat of Allegany County to have at least one early voting location.

name: Establishes a nonpartisan poll monitoring program.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes a role of nonpartisan poll monitor, defines how citizens and organizations may apply to be recognized as qualified nonpartisan poll monitors, an defines the responnsibilities and scope of the poll monitors job.

name: Requires at least one form of electronic means to verify voter registration at every polling place.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires that at least one type of electronic verification of voter registration to be used at certain elections.

name: Requires the board of elections to provide email notifications to voters whenever they change the location of a polling place.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a board of elections to notify a voter of a change in polling locations by email if the voter has provided an email.

name: Requires the county seat in Warren county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires that there be at least one early voting location in the county seat of Warren County.

name: Relates to an electronically submitted absentee ballot application and absentee ballot.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration
summary: As introduced, this bill provides for the ability to request and submit absentee ballot application by electronic means. The bill also provides for the possibility for voters to submit absentee ballots via email.

name: Relates to certain absentee ballots received by a board of elections that do not bear or display a dated postmark.
summary: As introduced, this bill adds a unique barcode to absentee ballots to determine the date by which the ballot is submitted to the United States or foreign postal system. If a ballot is received with no postage date and the United States or foreign postal system is unable to determine the date on which the ballot is submitted, it shall be considered timely cast and canvassed so long as it is received by the appropriate board of elections no later than the seventh day after the general election and the ballot is signed and dated no late than the general election date.

name: Relates to the time election day workers must be at poll sites to prepare for the opening of polls; one hour instead of one-half hour.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the time at which inspectors of election and clerks must arrive at polling places before voting begins from one-half to one hour.

name: Exempts public school buildings with instructional space from being designated as early polling locations; allows school districts to decline school building designations as early polling locations.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits public school buildings with instructional space from being designated an early polling location and allows the superintindent of a school district to decline the designation of other buildings as early polling locations.

name: Relates to designating every government entity which issues licenses to carry, possess, repair and dispose of firearms as participating agencies for voter registration form distribution and assistance.
summary: • Adds courts and law enforcement agencies issuing firearm licenses to the list of designated voter registration offices.

name: Establishes provisions requiring absentee ballots that do not have postmarked dates that are received in the mail by the board of elections within three days following the day of election to be cast and counted.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary: • Establishes that an absentee ballot without postmark should be counted if received within three days of the election.

name: Sets out the procedures and requirements for special elections; implements a timetable for the special primary and special election, including the number of signatures required for the petition.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Primary systems,Special election procedures,Vacancy procedures,Ballot access deadlines
summary:
• Provides that special primary elections will take place on the first Tuesday that is 30-36 days before a special election.
  • Outlines procedures for designating signatures in a special election.
  • Establishes that the candidate receiving the most votes will be the party nominee in a special primary election.
  • Establishes vacancy procedures for certain officials when the vacancy occurs 90-180 days before a primary election.
  • Adds state senate and house members to existing vacancy procedures for the governor.

name: Authorizes additional days of voting as a result of emergencies; includes state of emergency.
summary:
• Empowers a county or state board of elections to determine the ability to convene a party caucus in the case of emergency and lists possible emergencies.
  • Outlines procedures for if a caucus is delayed.

name: Relates to the number of affidavit ballots to be supplied at polling sites.
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Provisional ballots
summary: • Requires county boards of election to supply each polling site a certain number of affidavit ballots.

name: Enacts the "Modernized voter registration act of New York."
categories: Oversight and accountability,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,Voter ID for registration,Signature matching,Noncitizen voting,Voter registration,Same-day/Election Day registration,Automatic voter registration,Cybersecurity
summary:
• Outlines requirements for automatic voter registration.
  • Defines and identifies "source agencies."
  • Outlines agreements and processes for becoming a source agency, as well as information the agency is required to transmit.
  • Outlines procedures for when a signature is missing on automatic voter registration information, and for obtaining citizenship information.
  • Establishes procedures between the state board of elections and source agencies.
  • Sets implementation deadlines.
  • Allows same day voter registration and outlines procedures.
  • Outlines procedures for updating voter information.
  • Requires voters registering to vote are given the option to receive information by email or electronically.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Includes within the class D felony of assault in the second degree, the intentional causing of physical injury to an election officer while such person is performing their assigned duties; amends aggravated harassment and obstruction of governmental administration to include election officers.
categories: Enforcement against non-officials,Legal causes of action
summary: • Adds harassment, obstruction, and injury of election officers to existing penal law.

name: Requires electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidates in a manner representing the plurality of votes in each congressional district.
summary:
• Establishes that two electoral votes will be given to the statewide winner of a presidential election.
  • Establishes that one electoral vote will be given in a presidential election to each congressional district winner, based on plurality vote.

name: Establishes an electronic military ballot application and military ballot transmittal system through which applicants may apply for a military ballot and return a marked military ballot, online.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes an electronic military ballot application and military ballot transmittal system which applicants may fill-out and submit online. The state board of elections must electronically transmit these applications and marked ballots to the applicable board of elections of each county or New York City for filing, processing, and verification.

name: Enables constitutionally-qualified electors to register to vote and to cast a ballot on the same day at a polling location.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows otherwise qualified voters to conditionally register to vote on election day and cast an affidavit ballot in that election.

name: Requires persons administering challenge oaths to voter applicants to attest that the challenge is being made in good faith and to provide certain identifying information; requires challenge oaths to be presented to a challenged voter applicant in writing.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a person challenging a voter’s right to vote to take an oral oath they are acting in good faith and document in writing the challenger’s name and address and the challenged voter.  A challenged voter must respond to the challenge by taking a challenge oath in written form or orally if needed.

name: Ensures that voting systems testing requirements do not make it impractical to provide each polling place for early voting all of the election district ballots.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the state board of elections to create rules to ensure that voting systems testing requirements do not make it impractical to provide each polling place for early voting all of the district’s ballots.

name: Relates to construction of voting machines and systems.

Provides all registered voters on the day of the general election and the primary election in every even numbered year a full work day off without the loss of pay; provides a tax credit to small businesses who provide a paid day off to employees on general election day.
summary: As introduced, this bill grants all registered voters a full paid day to vote on the general election and the primary election dates in even numbered year and provides tax credits for small businesses with less than 100 employees who are given the day off to vote in a general election.

name: Requires a proposed amendment to the constitution or other question provided by law to be submitted to a statewide vote be submitted to the people for their approval in plain language which is deemed to be no higher than an eighth grade reading level.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a proposed constitutional amendment or ballot question to be submitted to voters in plain English including the proposal text and the associated abstract and provides for the content requirements of the proposal form to be submitted to the voters, public comments, and public display requirements online.

name: Changes the primary election date from the fourth Tuesday in June to the second Tuesday in August; moves the presidential primary to the fourth Tuesday in April.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the date of the statewide primary election from the fourth Tuesday in June to the second Tuesday in August, and the date of the presidential primary from the first Tuesday to the fourth Tuesday in February.

name: Adds a voter's e-mail address and telephone number to the information contained on a voter registration application that is not available for public inspection.
summary: As introduced, this bill adds e-mail addresses and telephone numbers to the list of voter registration information that is not made available to the public.

name: Permits county committees to amend their rules to permit committee members whose terms are expiring in 2021 to remain in their office for an additional one-year term.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary: This bill permits county committees to amend their rules to permit committee members whose terms are expiring in 2021 to remain in their office for an additional one-year term.

name: Relates to requests for proposals for voting machines and contracts for the purchase of voting machines or systems.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows a commissioner of the state board of elections to solicit requests for proposals for voting machines or systems to be certified. All requests for proposals must contain a provision stating any entity submitting a proposal must pay to the board a fee equal to the cost of examining the voting machine or system. All contracts require 10 years of vendor assistance for the upkeep of the voting machines or systems and the machines or systems to be in good working order for 10 years.

name: Relates to the creation, consolidation, division, and alteration of election districts by the board of elections in the city of New York.
summary: As introduced, this bill modifies the parameters for election districts in New York City and specifies that each district shall contain not more than four thousand active registrants.

name: Relates to making electronic ballot images and cast vote records public records of the board of elections upon request.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires local boards of election to make a copy of each electronic image of each cast and counted ballot and to keep these as public records available upon request.

name: Relates to empowering the commissioner of a board of elections to order a voting machine audit upon a finding of discrepancies.
summary: As introduced, this bill enables a commissioner of a board of elections to order an audit of voting machines be conducted whenever a discrepancy exists between audit tallies and the voting machine or system tallies.

name: Removes the requirement that party emblems be included in ballot design.
summary: As introduced, this bill removes the requirement that party emblems be included on ballots.

name: Instructs the state board of elections to create and distribute voting guides to voters containing information about the candidates; mandates that voters receive postcards to notify them of upcoming elections and that television and radio stations also notify their audience of upcoming elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the state board of elections to create and distribute voter guides and requires voters be notified of upcoming elections and candidates through a variety of mediums.

name: Improves the issuing of absentee ballots.
summary: As introduced, this bill extends the period in which a voter may submit a request for an absentee ballot up to the day before the election.

name: Includes a statement on the envelopes of ballots for absentee voters and special presidential voters for signature affirmation.
summary: This bill, as introduced on January 18, 2023, requires ballot envelopes for absentee voters and special presidential voters to contain a statement reminding voters that they must sign the affirmation on the envelope.

name: Relates to prohibiting boards of elections from entering into contracts for certain services related to the conduct of elections with entities that have made any political campaign donations of any amount in the last ten years.
summary: • Prohibits state board of election officials from entering into any contract agreement for a list of election related services with anyone, or any entity, that has made campaign contributions in the last 10 years.

name: Relates to furnishing money or entertainment to induce attendance at polls.
summary: • Allows distribution of snacks, water, soft drinks, or other refreshments of nominal value at a polling place or for those in line to vote.

name: Relates to the procedure for filling a vacancy in the office of state senator or in the office of member of assembly occurring in a district consisting of parts of more than one county in a city with a population of one million or more; allows for independent nominating petitions to be presented and provides for a special election to be held forty-five days from the date of the governor making a proclamation for a special election.
categories: Election dates,Ballot access for candidates,Special election procedures,Vacancy procedures
summary: • Outlines election procedures for filling a vacancy in the office of state senator or state house member spanning more than one county and establishes that the winner of the election will take office immediately and serve for the remainder of the term.

name: Relates to the time period during which absentee ballots shall be mailed or delivered after an application for such ballot is received by the board of elections.
summary: • Implements timelines for mailing and receiving absentee ballots.

name: Requires every board of elections to employ a minimum of four full time employees in addition to the appointed commissioners and two additional employees for every twenty thousand active registered voters beyond forty thousand active registered voters.
summary:
• Requires every board of elections to employ at least four full time employees in addition to appointed commissioners.
  • Requires each board to employ two additional employees for every 20,000 active registered voters beyond 40,000.

name: Provides that school districts may hold elections in any building owned or leased by the district, in addition to any district schoolhouse.
summary: • Requires school district building used for elections to comply with established accessibility provisions.

name: Establishes an electronic military ballot application and military ballot transmittal system through which applicants may apply for a military ballot and return a marked military ballot, online.
summary:
• Requires the state board of elections to establish and maintain an online military ballot application and transmittal system.
  • Outlines requirements and procedures for the system.
  • Defines "digital signature."
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Establishes a deadline for changing the location of a polling place for early voting by requiring that no location change may occur within forty-eight hours of the commencement of an early voting period.
summary:
• Outlines procedures for if an early voting polling place location changes within certain time periods.
  • Clarifies that the location may not change within 48 hours of the start of early voting.

name: Includes attempting to register as an elector knowing that he or she is not qualified due to lack of U.S. citizenship.
categories: Legal causes of action,Noncitizen voting,Voter registration
summary: This bill prohibits attempting to registering or attempting to register if the person is not qualified due to lack of U.S. citizenship.

name: Relates to establishing a secure website and mobile application that allows voters who have submitted an application for an absentee ballot to view the current status of their application and absentee ballot.
summary: This bill requires the Board of Elections establish a website and mobile application to allow voters the ability to view the current status of their absentee application and absentee ballot. The website and mobile application must indicate for each such voter whether the board of elections has received such voter's request for an absentee ballot; approved or rejected that request; if rejected, a brief statement of the reason for rejection; mailed or delivered an absentee ballot to the voter; received a voter's completed absentee ballot; and a determination that a voter's completed absentee ballot valid or invalid, with a brief statement of the reason for an invalid finding.

name: Relates to specification of objections to designating petitions, independent nominating petitions, certificates of nomination or ballot access documents; standardizes requirements for specification of objections by removing authority of local boards of election to make their own rules.
summary: This bill standardizes the objection process for designating petitions at the state level so that local boards of elections' objection processes are the same.

name: Prohibits conflicts of interest among board of elections employees; prevents a board of elections employee from remaining on the board of elections payroll while also a candidate for an office who has an election overseen by the board at which they are employed; allows for a member to remain on the board until 90 days before the general election if there is no primary for such office.
summary: This bill will prohibit board of election employee to be involved with business that might generate a conflict of interest, including financial interest in companies providing services to candidates filing with that office or those providing voting equipment. Board members cannot be active while also being a candidate for office for a position whose election is managed by that board. If a member wants to run for office, they can enter a “leave without pay” status for the duration of their run.

name: Requires every board of elections to employ a minimum of four full time employees in addition to the appointed commissioners and two additional employees for every twenty thousand active registered voters beyond forty thousand active registered voters.
summary: This bill will require board of elections to have a minimum of four full time employees and two more employee for every 20,000 registered voters the area has over a base of 40,000 voters.

name: Requires every board of elections to employ a minimum of four full time employees in addition to the appointed commissioners and two additional employees for every twenty thousand active registered voters beyond forty thousand active registered voters.
summary: This bill will require board of elections to have a minimum of four full time employees and two more employee for every 20,000 registered voters the area has over a base of 40,000 voters.

name: Relates to prohibiting boards of elections from entering into contracts for certain services related to the conduct of elections with entities that have made any political campaign donations of any amount in the last ten years.
summary: This bill will prohibit the state board of elections from signing any contract related to ballot, petition, affidavit, application, or election materials production with an individual or entity vendor that made political contributions within ten years.

name: Relates to prohibiting boards of elections from entering into contracts for certain services related to the conduct of elections with entities that have made any political campaign donations of any amount in the last ten years.
summary: This bill will prohibit the state board of elections from signing any contract related to ballot, petition, affidavit, application, or election materials production with an individual or entity vendor that made political contributions within ten years.

name: Relates to obtaining written acceptance from candidates for certain county committees; requires written acceptance, duly acknowledged, from such candidates to be so designated to be filed within ten days of designating petitions for certain county committee candidates.
summary: • Requires a candidate's written acceptance within ten days of the filing of a designating petition for a party position for county committee in a city with more than one million residents.

name: Relates to obtaining written acceptance from candidates for certain county committees; requires written acceptance, duly acknowledged, from such candidates to be so designated to be filed within ten days of designating petitions for certain county committee candidates.
summary: • Requires a candidate's written acceptance within ten days of the filing of a designating petition for a party position for county committee in a city with more than one million residents.

name: Relates to ballots submitted in envelopes that are sealed with tape, paste or any other binding agent or device and have no indication of tampering.
summary: This bill will include sealed ballots (like with tape or paste) with no indication of tampering as part of the list of ballot envelopes that are valid.

name: Requires that subpoenas issued relating to election matters be served with a separate informational sheet that summarizes why the subpoena has been issued.
summary: This bill will require subpoena related to election law will be served with an additional informational sheet. This sheet will explain why the subpoena was served, that it is not criminal action related, and that the individual is not facing related criminal charges, specify the election it is in reference to, and any consequences.

name: Allows delivery of an application for an absentee ballot to the board of elections through and on the day of the election.
summary: This bill will allow applications for absentee ballots given out at the board of elections to be submitted all the way until and including the day of the election.

name: Relates to requests for proposals for voting machines and contracts for the purchase of voting machines or systems.
summary: This bill will allow commissioners from the state board of election to solicit proposal requests for voting machines and systems to be certified by the board. The proposals must include confirmation that the person requesting the certification will pay for the cost. The bill also changes the number of years voting machine or system vendors must provide assistance and guarantees from five to ten years.

name: Subtracts from the federal adjusted gross income any income earned by election inspectors, poll clerks, or election coordinators earned while working in relation to a general, primary, run-off primary, or special election to the extent includable in gross income for federal tax purposes; exempts such income from being included in the calculation of the amount of benefits under public assistance programs.
summary: This bill will exclude income from election inspector, poll clerk, or election coordinator jobs from being included in gross income for federal taxes.

name: Moves the date of the presidential primary to the same date as the state primaries.
categories: Election dates,Alignment of elections,Presidential elections,Primary systems
summary: This bill will move presidential primary election to also be held on the fourth Tuesday in June (same day as the state office primaries).

name: Increases from 9 to 11 the number of members on the board of education for the city school district of Buffalo; provides for appointment of two members by the Mayor of the city of Buffalo.
summary: This bill will change the number of members of the school district for Buffalo from nine to eleven. Each of these new members will be appointed to represent the district at large, one by the mayor and one by the common council. If a vacancy in one of these two offices occurs, the mayor will appoint a replacement within 30 days.

name: Requires that candidates for certain offices be residents and registered voters in the district containing the public office or party position sought at certain times during the electoral process.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access deadlines
summary: This bill will require that candidates for office be residents and registered voters for the district of the state public or party office they are declaring for at the time they file.

name: Relates to obtaining written acceptance from candidates for certain county committees; requires written acceptance, duly acknowledged, from such candidates to be so designated to be filed within ten days of designating petitions for certain county committee candidates.
summary: • Requires a candidate's written acceptance within ten days of the filing of a designating petition for a party position for county committee in a city with more than one million residents.

name: Relates to obtaining written acceptance from candidates for certain county committees; requires written acceptance, duly acknowledged, from such candidates to be so designated to be filed within ten days of designating petitions for certain county committee candidates.
summary: • Requires a candidate's written acceptance within ten days of the filing of a designating petition for a party position for county committee in a city with more than one million residents.

name: Provides that recounts of ballots conducted by the board of elections or a bipartisan committee appointed by the board can be either done manually or via the use of any automated tool authorized for such use by the board of elections, which is independent from the voting system it is being used to recount, of all ballots for a particular contest where the margin of victory is less than or equal to 0.5% but greater than 0.25%; allows for losing candidates to deny a recount before any recount is c
summary: This bill will change the two of the three separate threshold triggers for recounts from twenty to ten vote margin and 0.5% to 0.25% margin. The board of elections or bipartisan committee assigned may utilize automated tools to complete the recount for margin of victory between 0.25% and 0.5%. It also allows a losing candidate to concede to their opponent and reject a recount.

name: Relates to prohibiting boards of elections from entering into contracts for certain services related to the conduct of elections with entities that have made any political campaign donations of any amount in the last ten years.
summary: This bill will prohibit the state board of elections from signing any contract related to ballot, petition, affidavit, application, or election materials production with an individual or entity vendor that made political contributions within ten years.

name: Relates to prohibiting boards of elections from entering into contracts for certain services related to the conduct of elections with entities that have made any political campaign donations of any amount in the last ten years.
summary: This bill will prohibit the state board of elections from signing any contract related to ballot, petition, affidavit, application, or election materials production with an individual or entity vendor that made political contributions within ten years.

name: Provides for a separate line at polling places for persons with disabilities.
categories: In-person voting and polling places,In-person voter assistance
summary: This bill will require voting polling places to have a separate entry line for persons with disabilities. There will be access to seating in this line. For entry, the poll worker will alternate between the “general admission” voter line and the line for persons with disabilities.

name: Relates to the rejection by voting machines of ballots that contain a vote for a candidate who previously withdrew from an election.
summary: This bill will require that ballots for candidates that withdrew from the election be rejected by the voting machine. The voting machine will reject and provide notice to the voter as they are submitting the ballot and instruct the voter to fill out and submit a new ballot.

name: Eliminates the ability of judicial candidates for office who are enrolled in a particular party to automatically be allowed to run as a candidate in another party's primary election.
summary: This bill would prohibit judicial candidates registered in a party from being automatically allowed to be a candidate in another party’s primary election.

name: Provides for the appointment and removal for cause of commissioners of election; provides for removal for cause by the board of elections and/or the governor; repeals provisions relating to the removal of election commissioners.
summary: This bill will change the election commissioner term from two to four years, and change the term start date to February 15th. For appointing commissioners, if the legislature fails to appoint someone recommended from a political party and there are no members of that party in the legislature, then the county committee must recommend at least people for the legislature to choose from. For commissioner removal, the bill add a process by which the sate board of elections will have the power to remove a commissioner for “any willful violation or neglect of duty…or willfully disobeying any law, decision, order, settlement, rule or regulation of the state board of elections.” The governor may also remove a commissioner from office.

name: Authorizes, under certain circumstances, full-time college and university students to act as election inspectors and poll clerks in the election district where their college or university is located.
summary: This bill will allow full-time college or university students to be election inspectors or poll clerks as long as it is in the county where the school is and is a registered voter, not in office, not a candidate for office or closely related to one, and fluent in English.

name: Relates to annual reports of the boards of elections; requires such reports be made available on the boards' websites; requires that the reports include specific performance metrics.
summary: This bill will require that board of election annual reports be accessible by the public via its website within five days of the report’s delivery. The bill also requires eleven performance metrics be included in the report.

name: Requires every board of elections to employ a minimum of four full time employees in addition to the appointed commissioners and two additional employees for every twenty thousand active registered voters beyond forty thousand active registered voters.
summary: This bill will require board of elections to have a minimum of four full time employees and two more employee for every 20,000 registered voters the area has over a base of 40,000 voters.

name: Requires every board of elections to employ a minimum of four full time employees in addition to the appointed commissioners and two additional employees for every twenty thousand active registered voters beyond forty thousand active registered voters.
summary: This bill will require board of elections to have a minimum of four full time employees and two more employee for every 20,000 registered voters the area has over a base of 40,000 voters.

name: Prohibits candidates from authorizing more than one political committee for any one election.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits candidates from authorizing more than one political committee per election from working in behalf of their election.

name: Provides that the text to be used in a proposed amendment, proposition or question to be submitted to the people for approval shall be in the legislation proposing such amendment, proposition or question and shall not be altered without approval by the legislature.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the text for a proposed amendment, proposition or ballot question must be in the legislation proposing the proposed amendment, proposition or ballot question and cannot be altered without approval by the legislature.

name: Requires at-large electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidate who received the highest number of votes in the state; requires congressional electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidates who received the highest number of votes in each congressional district; removes and replaces electors who fail to vote in such manner.

Makes the following participating agencies for purposes of agency assisted voter registration: public libraries, local housing authorities, and public high schools; directs the state board of elections to promulgate rules and regulations for implementation.
summary: As introduced, this bill designates the following as participating agencies to administer a program of distribution of voter registration: public libraries, local housing authorities, and public high schools.

name: Makes provisions relating to the joint nomination of candidates for the offices of governor and lieutenant governor; provides candidates be designated jointly either by the state committee or by petition; provides said petition will be valid only if it jointly designates both candidates.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires candidates for governor and lieutenant governor be designated jointly by a single vote by committee, and members of the party may make other designations by petition for members of the same party. A petition designating a candidate governor or lieutenant governor is valid only if it designates both jointly.

name: Relates to the time period during which absentee ballots shall be mailed or delivered after an application for such ballot is received by the board of elections.
summary:
Ads introduced, this bill establishes time frames within which absentee ballots must be mailed or delivered base upon when the absentee ballot application is received. These are:

  • If the application is received more than 60 days before the election, then the ballot must be mailed or delivered by the 46th day before the election.
  • If the application is received between 60 and 46 days before the election, then the ballot must be mailed or delivered by the 42nd day before the election.
  • If the application is received between 46 and 30 days before the election, then the ballot must be mailed or delivered within four days of receiving the application.
  • If the application is received between 30 and 15 days before the election, then the ballot must be mailed or delivered within three days of receiving the application.
  • If the application is received between 15 and 7 days before the election, then the ballot must be mailed or delivered within two days of receiving the application.
  • If the application is received less 7 days before the election, then the ballot must be mailed or delivered by the day before the election.

name: Prohibits level two or three sex offenders from voting at a school or facility for children; authorizes absentee voting for such offenders.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits level 2 or level 3 sex offenders from voting at a school or other facility for children.

name: Relates to petitions for election to the party position of member of the county committee; provides that candidates shall not be required to provide their zip code if they have clearly stated their town or city on their petition.
summary: As introduced, this bill provides candidates for party positions of members of the county committee do not need to provide their zip code on petitions for election if they have stated their town or city.

name: Allows a U.S. citizen, who is seventeen years of age, to vote in a primary election, including presidential, if he or she will turn eighteen by the date of the corresponding general election.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows otherwise qualified voters who are 17 years of voter to vote in primary elections if they will be 18 years old at the time of the next general election.

name: Makes commissioners full time employees of the board.
summary: As introduced, this bill makes the position of election commissioner a full time employee of local boards of election.

name: Allows for limited three-day expansion of the statute of limitations where a proceeding to invalidate a designating or nominating petition has been commenced.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits the deadline for invalidation proceedings of a designating petition to be extended 3 business days after the proceedings have started.

name: Relates to empowering the commissioner of a board of elections to order a voting machine audit upon a finding of discrepancies.
summary: As introduced, this bill authorizes the board of elections commissioner to order a voting machine audit upon a finding of tally discrepancies.

name: Requires a proposed amendment to the constitution or other question provided by law to be submitted to a statewide vote be submitted to the people for their approval in plain language which is deemed to be no higher than an eighth grade reading level.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires proposed amendments to the state constitution submitted to the voters at statewide election to be written in plain language at no higher than an eight grade reading level.

name: Allows a U.S. citizen, who is seventeen years of age, to vote in a primary election, including presidential, if he or she will turn eighteen by the date of the corresponding general election.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows otherwise qualified voters who are 17 years of age to vote in a primary election if they will be 18 by the time of the subsequennt geenral election.

name: Permits party enrollment and change of party enrollment within 10 days of a primary, general, or special election.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows voters to enroll or change their party affiliation up to no later than the 10th day for the next primary election.

name: Allows poll workers to be from any political party.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows poll workers to be from any political party.

name: Directs the state board of elections to create a plan to permit voting by mail in the event of a natural disaster or state of emergency.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the state board of elections to create a plan for the establishment of vote-by-mail elections in the case of natural disaster of state of emergency.

name: Prohibits sex offenders who are on parole and in civil confinement from voting in certain elections.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits certain voters previously convicted of a certain class offense who have been discharged from imprisonment but are committed to civil imprisonment in a hospital or institution from voting in certain elections.

name: Requires electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidate who were nominated by the political party that nominated the presidential elector.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires electors to the elector college to cast their ballot for the presidential and vice-preisdential candidates nominated by the political party that nominated the elector.

name: Relates to the postmark date for change of enrollment.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the date by which a change of enrollment submitted to an elections board will take automatic effect.

name: Modifies the order in which candidates appear on the ballot; requires that offices shall be listed on the ballot in descending order based on the size of the electorate and requires certain federal offices to be listed before state, county or local offices.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes the order in which candidates appear on the ballot.

name: Relates to the exercise of powers and duties of the board of elections of the city of New York and its executive management.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Modifies the number of commissioners of election appointed by the city from ten to two, and provides that no two commissioners may be residents of the same county or registered voters of the same party.
  • Provides that party recommendations for election commissioner in New York City, or to fill such a vacancy, will be made by the county committee, or other relevant committee, by majority vote when there is quorum.
  • Requires each party to file a certificate of recommendation within 60 days, with specific requirements.
  • Requires the city council to hold a public hearing and confirmation within 30 days on the recommendation.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Outlines duties of the executive director of the board of elections in New York City and provides for his or her appointment and removal, and outlines vacancy procedures.
  • Defines "appointing authorities."
  • Specifies timelines, party roles, qualifications, and deadlines for appointment of the executive director.
  • Specifies reasons for removing an executive director from office.
  • Outlines powers and duties of the executive director, including appointment of other election officials.
  • Outlines board duties related to elections and reporting.

name: Authorizes any registered voter to vote by absentee ballot and to elect to permanently vote by absentee ballot.
summary: As introduced, this bill creates no excuse absentee voting and allows voters to elect to permanently vote by absentee ballot.

name: Requires that county committees meet no earlier than one day after the June primary is certified.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes that county committees shall meet no earlier than the first day after the June primary is certified.

name: Subtracts from the federal adjusted gross income any income earned by election inspectors, poll clerks, or election coordinators earned while working in relation to a general, primary, run-off primary, or special election to the extent includable in gross income for federal tax purposes; exempts such income from being included in the calculation of the amount of benefits under public assistance programs.
summary: • Provides that income earned while working an election is taxable income.

name: Relates to mandatory training curriculum for poll workers; requires the state board of elections to develop and provide to each county materials for a model poll worker training program which the counties may use to train individuals to serve as poll workers in state and county elections.
summary:
• Requires training be offered for election inspectors on at least a quarterly basis.
  • Directs the state Board of Elections to establish, develop, and host a statewide training program to certify poll worker trainers, and includes specific requirements for the program.
  • Directs county boards to send certain minimum numbers of people to the training.

name: Relates to the removal of an election commissioner by the governor or by affirmative vote of a majority of duly confirmed commissioners of the state board of elections for incompetence, misconduct, or other good cause, provided that prior to removal, such election commissioner shall be given a written copy of the charges against them and have an opportunity to be heard in their defense.
summary:
• Provides that an election commissioner may be removed from office by a majority of state board of elections commissioners.
  • Requires the election commissioner by given a written copy of charges and have an opportunity for defense.
  • Lists possible reasons for removal.

name: Relates to the exercise of powers and duties of the board of elections of the city of New York and its executive management.
categories: Voting equipment,Ballot access for candidates,Vacancy procedures,Election officials
summary:
• Adds a provision that no two election commissioners may be registered voters of the same party.

  • Outlines the process and timeline of parties recommending someone for election commissioner.
  • Provides guidelines and processes for if the board of elections of New York city is likely to exceed their budget.
  • Requires equal major party representation by election officials who qualify voters, distribute ballots, or count votes.
  • Outlines guidelines for appointing and removing the executive director in the city of New York.
  • Outlines duties and powers of the executive director and duties and powers of the board.
  • Codifies that purchase contracts for goods, services, and technology by the city of New York related to elections may be procured by the purchasing department or agency of the city.

name: Relates to designating early polling places.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits public school buildings from being designated early polling locations and proscribes the types of buildings to be used as an early voting locations.

name: Prohibits election commissioners and deputy election commissioners from holding a publicly elected office or from being the respective chair of the county democratic or republican committees.
summary:
• Prohibits a deputy election commissioner from holding office in a county where they do not reside or when they are not a member of the party who put forth his or her nomination.
  • Prohibits a deputy election commissioner from holding office if they chair the Democratic or Republican committee in the county.
  • Prohibits a deputy election commissioner from holding office if they are an elected village officer, or city or town justice.
  • Applies the above rules to those who are not currently holding office.

name: Authorizes boards of elections to establish absentee ballot drop-off locations.
summary:
• Defines "absentee ballot drop box" and "absentee ballot drop off location."
  • Authorizes each board of elections to establish one or more ballot drop off locations with certain notification requirements.
  • Provides that a ballot is deemed received if it is placed in a drop box by the close of polls on election day.
  • Instructs election workers regarding closing drop boxes after closing time.

name: Relates to furnishing money or entertainment to induce attendance at polls.
summary: • Allows certain goods (snacks, water, soft drinks, other refreshments) to be distributed at a polling place.

name: Relates to proceedings with respect to the canvass of absentee, military and special ballots and ballots cast by voters with registration records missing on days of election or voters who have not had their identity previously verified or who have moved after registering.
categories: Counting and canvassing procedures,Provisional ballots,Military/UOCAVA voting
summary: • Clarifies that if a qualified voter votes in the incorrect polling place or district, the board must canvass the portions of the ballot that correspond to the voter's election district.

name: Relates to split shifts for election inspectors or poll clerks.
summary: • Adds poll clerks to those who may be employed by a board of elections to work split shifts.

name: Increases compensation of election inspectors to $300 and coordinators to $350 in New York city.
summary:
• Codifies that election inspectors and other certain election workers will earn no less than $300.
  • Codifies that election coordinators will earn no less than $350.
  • Codifies that election inspectors and poll clerks who attend required training will earn no less than $50 (from $25).

name: Provides that for any legal challenge to the constitutionality of a provision of the election law, venue shall be brought in the following designated court in the judicial department within which at least one plaintiff is located: first judicial department: New York county; second judicial department: Westchester county; third judicial department: Albany county; and fourth judicial department: Erie county.
summary:
• Requires that a challenge regarding the constitutionality of an election law be heard in certain courts where at least one plaintiff is located.
  • Defines which challenges are included.

name: Makes the suppression of voters a civil violation.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes voter suppression as a defined misdemeanor offense and specifies that any person subject to voter suppression may bring civil action against the offender. The bill also makes repeated intances of voter supressionn a felony act.

name: Establishes portable polling locations for early voting; provides that a county board of elections may establish one or more portable polling locations.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits the use of portable polling locations and specifies that each county may establish one or more such polling locations.

name: Requires electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidates in a manner representing the plurality of votes in each congressional district.
summary: As introduced, this bill apportions two electoral votes for president and vice president to the statewide winner and one to each congressional district winner.

name: Relates to restricting election day duties of board of elections employees in the city of New York running for elected party positions; provides that no board of elections employee in the city of New York shall engage in any election day operations or management within any assembly district in which he or she is also a candidate for an elected party position.
summary: As introduced, this bill restricts a board of elections employee in New York City to engage in any election day operations or management within any assembly district in which they are also a candidate for an elected party position.

name: Relates to obtaining written acceptance from candidates for certain county committees; requires written acceptance, duly acknowledged, from such candidates to be so designated to be filed within ten days of designating petitions for certain county committee candidates.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a candidate to a party position of a member of a county committee’s written acceptance of a designating petition must be delivered to the board of elections within ten days of the filing of the petition.

name: Provides that an attorney licensed to practice in the state may serve as a poll watcher in any city or county in the state.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows attorneys licensed to practice in the state of New York to serve as a poll watcher in any county or municipality in the state.

name: Relates to the procedure for filling a vacancy in the office of state senator or in the office of member of assembly; allows for independent nominating petitions to be presented and provides for a special election to be held forty-five days from the date of the governor making a proclamation for a special election.
Prohibits the at large election of any member of the governing or legislative body of a town or village by electors of such town or village; requires the election of such members by wards.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires members of the legislative or governing body of a town or village to be elected by districts.

name: Prohibits a court from bifurcating the primary elections for members of the state and county committees and assembly district leaders and associate district leaders and all other party positions to be elected and all nominations for public office required to be made at a primary election in such year.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits a court from bifurcating political party primary elections for certain offices and positions held on the same primary date into separate dates.

name: Relates to the accessibility of congressional, senatorial, assembly and election district maps in downloadable digital file formats compatible with geographic information (GIS) software.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires each board of elections to make representational district and election maps available in downloadable digital file formats compatible with geographic information system (GIS) software.

name: Establishes a ranked choice voting method for nonpartisan primary elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes ranked-choice voting for all non-partisan primary elections, except the presidential primaries and provides provisions for the procedures for voting, ballots to be used, and voter education.

name: Provides that recounts of ballots conducted by the board of elections or a bipartisan committee appointed by the board can be either done manually or via the use of any automated tool authorized for such use by the board of elections, which is independent from the voting system it is being used to recount, of all ballots for a particular contest where the margin of victory is less than or equal to 0.5% but greater than 0.25%; allows for losing candidates to deny a recount before any recount is c
summary: As introduced, this bill provides that a manual recount occurs when the margin of victory is ten votes or less or 0.25% or less.  The board of elections or a bipartisan committee appointed by the board must conduct a full recount, manually or using an authorized automated tool, of all ballots for an election where the margin of victory is between .25 - .5%. A candidate who is losing before the recount can reject the count and concede prior to a recount.

name: Defines the term "party" as any political organization which at the last preceding election for governor polled at least fifty thousand votes for its candidate for governor.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the definition of a "party" to any political organization whose candidate received at least 50,000 votes in the preceding gubernatorial election.

name: Limits a candidate for public office to one authorized committee per election; defines the term "multi-candidate committee" and provides that such a committee may not be authorized by a candidate.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits candidates from authorizing more than one political committee to take part in their nomincation or election, except by making monetary contirbutions.

name: Relates to designating every government entity which issues licenses to carry, possess, repair and dispose of firearms as participating agencies for voter registration form distribution and assistance.
summary: • Establishes that every court and law enforcement agency issuing licenses to possess firearms is a participating agency to distribute voter registration forms.

name: Lowers the voting age to 16 years; requires that students receive education in civics and be given the opportunity to register to vote in the classroom.
summary:
• Lowers the voting age to 16, with specific guidelines.
  • Requires all students starting in ninth grade to receive civic education with certain specifications.
  • Requires voter registration forms and voter registration opt-out forms to be distributed to high school students with certain guidelines.

name: Establishes no polling place shall be located on the premises of any public or private elementary or secondary school or a school for preschool children.
summary: • Prohibits placement of a polling location on the premises of a preschool, elementary, or secondary school.

name: Increases the dollar value of items that may legally be given or provided to any person, other than persons who are official representatives of the board of elections or political parties and committees and persons who are engaged as watchers, in a polling place without any identification of the person or entity supplying such provisions.
summary: • Increases the value of items that may be provided to certain people in a polling location from $1 to $5.

name: Relates to the text of proposed constitutional amendments and questions; requires the state board of elections to publish the text of any proposed constitutional amendment, proposition or question; requires that the language of the proposed amendment, proposition or question be unbiased; requires that the language be prepared by the attorney general.
summary:
• Requires a copy of the text of a proposed amendment, question, or proposition be displayed on the state board of elections website until the day after the general election.
  • Requires the attorney general to prepare and deliver an abstract of a submission to the state board of elections at least four months before the election.

name: Allows voters to take photographs of themselves and their ballot, or absentee ballot, while in a privacy booth, and to share and disseminate such photographs on social media.
summary:
• Allows voters to photograph themselves and their ballot in a voting booth, and to share the photo on social media.
  • Defines social media.
  • Directs that those interfering with this right are committing a misdemeanor.

name: Relates to providing translators at certain polling place locations if fifteen percent of the number of voting age citizens who speak the same language other than English at home reside in the district where such polling place is located.
summary:
• Provides that if 15% of voters in a district speak the same language, other than English, ballots must be provided in the language and a poll worker speaking the language must be at each polling place.
  • Establishes that a voter may request translation services by the poll worker who speaks the language.

name: Prohibits the at large election of any member of the governing or legislative body of a town or village by electors of such town or village; requires the election of such members by wards.
summary:
• Requires election of trustees by wards.
  • Removes provisions allowing for different systems of election for trustees.
  • Outlines procedures for implementing election of trustees by wards.

name: Relates to the number of signatures needed for designating petitions in counties with a population of two hundred fifty thousand or fewer.
summary:
• Provides that in counties with 250,000 or fewer people, standard signature requirements will be reduced by 25%.
  • Provides that in counties with 250,000 or fewer people, the petitions must be signed by no less than 3.75% of registered voters of the party, except for certain offices.

name: Authorizes United States citizens currently residing outside the United States whose last residence in the United States was in the state of New York to vote in certain federal elections.
summary: • Removes "territory or possession of the United States" from Code regarding proving domicile in voting when residing outside the United States.

name: Relates to mandatory training curriculum for poll workers; requires the state board of elections to develop and provide to each county materials for a model poll worker training program which the counties may use to train individuals to serve as poll workers in state and county elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the state board of elections to develop a poll worker training program, including a train-the-trainer program to train county officials to prepare poll workers and volunteers for election work.

name: Lowers the voting age to 16 years; requires that students receive education in civics and be given the opportunity to register to vote in the classroom.
summary: As introduced, this bill lowers the voting age to 16 years old, requires mandatory civics education for high school pupils, and directs the state board to make voter registration information and forms available to students 16 years of age or who will turn 16 that year.

name: Provides protections against illegal voter purging.
summary:
• Requires anyone other than an election official who mails something to a registered voter or voter registration applicant to file the file the mail with the state board of elections, with specific requirements.
  • Provides that anyone other than an inspector or clerk may challenge the qualifications of a voter by executing a challenge affidavit.
  • Outlines administration guidelines and the oath for a challenge affidavit.
  • Provides that citizenship information shall not be retained.
  • Outlines certain requirement for challenge affidavits.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Provides that qualified persons who have never previously registered to vote in this state may apply personally for registration by appearing at the appropriate polling place for the election district in which such person resides on the day such polling place is open for voting; requires establishment of a procedure to enable such registrants to cast their votes at the appropriate polling places.
summary: • Establishes that a qualified person, not previously registered in New York, may apply for voter registration on Election Day and outlines requirements and administration.

name: Allows voters to take photographs of themselves and their ballot, or absentee ballot, while in a privacy booth, and to share and disseminate such photographs on social media.
summary:
• Permits voters to photograph themselves, and their own ballot, while in a privacy booth, and share the photo.
  • Defines "social media."
  • Provides that no one may solicit a voter to shoe his or her ballot after voting.

name: Orders the names on ballots for special elections in the same manner as ordered for general and primary elections.
summary: • Specifies that current Election Code regarding ballot order applies to general, primary, and special elections.
