name: Requires the fair campaign code to require campaign literature and other mass media identify the person, political party or committee authorizing such material.
summary: • Requires all campaign literature, media, advertisements, speeches, press releases, and other writing to identify the person or entity authorizing the material.

name: Provides for the re-enfranchisement of voters with felony convictions by repealing certain provisions in the election law.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: As introduced, this bill repeals a law that cancelled a voter's voter registration if he or she was convicted of a felony.

name: Designates campuses which are operated by the state university of New York or the city university of New York as early voting sites and polling sites.
summary: • Requires that when a state- or city-run college campus has a dormitory as an election day or early voting polling place, it must be approved by the university.

name: Provides for the state board of elections to undertake a study of the feasibility for voting by mail, telephone and/or the internet; authorizes a pilot program for such voting during the study; requires a report to the governor and legislature.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the state board of elections to conduct a study on mail voting, and voting by telephone or internet. The bill authorizes a pilot program for such voting, and directs the state board to deliver a report of their findings to the governor and the legislature.

name: Moves the date of the presidential primary to the same date as the state primaries.
summary: • Moves the presidential primary election from the first Tuesday in February to the fourth Tuesday in June.

name: Improves transparency regarding boards of elections; improves voter centricity; includes boards of elections in open meetings requirements; requires certain notices be given regarding elections; requires additional transparency during the tabulation of votes.
summary:
• Deems boards of elections public bodies subject to public meeting laws.
  • Requires designation of poll sites to be proposed at least 30 days before an election publicly with time for public comment, and outlines how the board may choose to make changes to site locations.
  • Requires boards to publish certain election information 30 days before an election on certain platforms and in all major languages spoken within the county. Specifies how the board must publish reminders before the election.
  • Requires voter registration instructions be displayed prominently in voter registration sites.
  • Specifies the type of ballot marking device to be used and administration of the devices.
  • Requires form and content of ballots and ballot envelopes to be proposed publicly at least 30 days before an election with time for public comment and revision.
  • Provides that every registered voter is entitled to vote in a polling place in their county and outlines related administration requirements.
  • Provides that a committee on open government may designate as many watchers as the committee deems appropriate and outlines related procedures.
  • Provides that paper ballots must be identical in an election district and specifies the type of paper to be used and how it should be counted.
  • Requires testing of tabulating machines.
  • Requires qualified rejected absentee ballots include instructions on how to cure the ballot.
  • Provides that up to four watchers from a political or independent committee may be on one polling place at a time and provides related instructions.
  • Requires results from a polling station to be posted publicly and given to candidates and watchers upon request and provides additional guidelines for sharing results.
  • Requires at least two police officers to deliver devices and to accept of deposit boxes, envelopes and containers, delivered by at least two inspectors.
  • Outlines security measures regarding the canvass and ballot security.
  • Outlines guidelines and timelines for publicly releasing information about results.
  • Requires a hearing within two weeks of certifying an election to allow individuals to offer feedback on the election process.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Requires absentee ballots to be provided to all qualified voters and relates to the delivery of absentee ballots.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration
summary:
• Requires an absentee ballot with return postage be sent to every qualified voter living in the city or county and outlines related administration.
  • Provides that any voter may complete an application to have the absentee ballot sent to a different address where he or she will be residing.

name: Prohibits a state party from using the word "Independent" or "Independence" in its name.
summary: This bill prohibits a state party from using the word "Independent," "Independence," "Independents," "Independence," or any abbreviations of the same, in its name.

name: Requires the counting of an affidavit ballot of an eligible voter if such voter appeared at a polling place in the correct county but in the incorrect election district; provides that such vote shall not be cast and canvassed for such contests for which the person was not entitled to vote at such election.
summary: This bill allows casting of affidavit ballots from the wrong polling place but the correct county, as long as that voter was not prohibited from voting in said election.

name: Requires congressional, senatorial, assembly and election district maps be made available on applicable board of elections' websites and in a downloadable Shapefile format.
summary: This bill requires copies of congressional, senatorial, assembly, and election district maps to be posted on the board of elections’ website in a downloadable format.

name: Relates to authorizing registration records of victims of sexual violence to be kept confidential in certain cases.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary: This bill allows confidential voting registration records for victims of sex offenses and crimes under article one hundred thirty of the penal law.

name: Relates to construction of voting machines and systems.
categories: Voting equipment,Ballot design,Counting and canvassing procedures,In-person voting and polling places,Cybersecurity
summary:
As amended, this bill:

  • Requires a ballot to be marked or printed on durable paper and defines "durable paper."
  • Requires voters have an opportunity to mark and verify votes on an individual, voter verifiable paper ballot, including allowing the voter a new paper ballot as many times as allowed to correct an error.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Requires paper ballots be retained and processed to protect voter privacy.
  • Requires voting equipment be constructed so that it can never print votes onto the ballot.
  • Prohibits voting equipment that contains ballot marking and ballot tabulation in the same device, with other associated prohibitions.
  • Prohibits voting equipment that encodes votes on a ballot.
  • Directs local boards to purchase equipment conforming to requirements.
  • Directs local board to provide every voter to hand mark a paper ballot or to use a nontabulating ballot marking device and requires all ballots to be printed and scannable, and to include all races.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to filing of papers; when received by a board of elections.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that when a county board of elections adopts a resolution, the election commissioners, outside of New York City, must provide that all required related certificates, petitions, and objections be received by the county board of elections by the last day to file such petitions, certificates, or objections.
  • Directs the office receiving the certificates, petitions, and objections to remain open until midnight on the last day to file.
  • Stipulates that failure of the post office or any individual to deliver the documents by the deadline is disqualifying.
  • Provides that the resolution must be adopted by March 1 of its effective year.
  • Directs that the adopted resolution be prominently displayed in the offices of the board of elections and on the website, and that a local board may use any media source available to publish the resolution.
  • Directs that the resolution be filed with the state board of elections with five days of adoption and that the state board must post it on its website.
  • Directs that the chairpersons of all party committees in the county be given written notice of the resolution within five days of adoption.
  • Provides that in order to discontinue the practice of a board of elections accepting filings until midnight on the last filing day, a resolution by the county board of elections must be passed by March 1 of the effective year and published and posted in the required manner.

name: Repeals certain provisions relating to absentee voting in primary elections for certain party positions.
summary: • Repeals certain provisions related to absentee voting in primary elections.

name: Provides that recounts of ballots conducted by the board of elections or a bipartisan committee appointed by the board can be either done manually or via the use of any automated tool authorized for such use by the board of elections, which is independent from the voting system it is being used to recount, of all ballots for a particular contest where the margin of victory is less than or equal to 0.5% but greater than 0.25%.
summary:
• Changes thresholds for when to conduct a full manual recount to when the margin of victory is ten votes or less (from twenty) or where the margin of victory is 0.25% (from 0.5%).
  • Establishes that the board of elections or a bipartisan committee will conduct the recount, and establishes procedures.
  • Allows a candidate who is determined to have lost an election within the new threshold to reject the recount and concede the election.

name: Provides that recounts of ballots conducted by the board of elections or a bipartisan committee appointed by the board can be either done manually or via the use of any automated tool authorized for such use by the board of elections, which is independent from the voting system it is being used to recount of all ballots for a particular contest where the margin of victory is less than or equal to 0.5% but greater than 0.25%.
summary: This bill provides that recounts of ballots conducted by the Board of Elections or a bipartisan committee appointed by the Board can be either done manually or with the use of any automated tool authorized for such use by the Board, so long as it is independent from the voting system it is being used to recount. This applies to all ballots for a particular contest where the margin of victory is less than or equal to 0.5% but greater than 0.25%. The bill also allows losing candidates the ability to refuse a recount before it is conducted.

name: Relates to pre-clearance of voting-related regulations and policies.
categories: Oversight and accountability,Legal causes of action
summary: This bill requires certain voting-related regulations and policies be subject to pre-clearance by the attorney general. Before the state board of elections or any local board of elections enacts or implements any changes in voting qualification, prerequisites to voting, administration, regulations, policies, practices or procedures with respect to voting affecting: 1. A county with a population comprised, in the aggregate, of at least ten percent of members of a protected class over the preceding decade, as determined by the five year estimates of the United States Census American Community Survey; 2. A county which has been subject to a court order or government enforcement action based upon a finding of a discriminatory practice, denial or abridgment of the right to vote of a member of the protected class within the past ten years; or 3. A county that was previously subject to pre-clearance under Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and has not been granted a decree granting exemption from such pre-clearance requirements, must submit such changes to the state attorney general for approval. The attorney general must then indicate objections or approval of such changes, in writing, within sixty days following the receipt of submission. The bill defines "protected class" as a class of voters who are members of a race, color, or language minority group, as defined in the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

name: Allows qualified voters who are primary caregivers of one or more individuals to vote by absentee ballot regardless of whether the individuals cared for are ill or physically disabled.
summary:
• Removes illness or disability when caring for another person for being unable to appear personally at a polling place.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Extends the right to vote in school district elections to qualified persons who are sixteen years of age.
summary:
• Provides that 16-year-olds are eligible to register and vote in school district elections.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Outlines preregistration guidelines based on the new age.

name: Includes individuals who do not identify exclusively as a binary gender in eligibility for party positions.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary: This bill provides for representation of individuals who do not exclusively identify as a binary gender to run for party positions.

name: Relates to ballots where the express intent of the voter is unambiguous.
summary: • Provides that in cases where a voters intent is unambiguous, stray marks on a ballot should not be a basis for voiding it.

name: Relates to the John R. Lewis Voting Rights Act of New York; establishes rights of actions for denying or abridging the right of any member of a protected class to vote; provides assistance to language-minority groups; provides for preclearance of certain voting policies; makes related provisions.
categories: Oversight and accountability,Transparency,Language accommodations,Voting materials,In-person voting and polling places,Legal causes of action,Legislative authority,Redistricting criteria/requirements,Voter registration
summary:
As amended, this bill:

  • Outlines a statement of purpose for the John R. Lewis Voting Rights Act of New York including encouraging maximum participation by all eligible voting groups, regardless of color, race, and language.
  • Provides that all rules related to elective franchise should be construed liberally in favor of protecting rights of voters, and ensuring minority voting rights.
  • Specifies that policies and practices limiting voting rights must be "narrowly tailored" and supported by evidence.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Prohibits enactment of a voting rule denying or abridging the right to vote by a protected class and specifies violations.
  • Prohibits using a method of election that dilutes the ability of a protected class to elect candidates of their choice and lists specific violations based upon districting and voting methods used, as well as specifying evidence in demonstrating a violation.
  • Lists what must be considered in determining whether a violation has occurred, such as the history of discrimination of a political subdivision, the extent that members of the protected class have been elected to office, and the like.
  • Provides that any aggrieved person, certain organizations, or the attorney general may file a related action in the Supreme Court of the county.
  • Lists possible remedies open to the court to ensure voters of every race, color, and language group have equitable access to fully participate in the electoral process and requires the court to consider proposed remedies, and empowers the court to require a political subdivision to implement remedies.
  • Outlines specific steps for implementing new or revised districting or redistricting plans, including holding public hearings, publishing drafts, providing for staggered terms of office, and more.
  • Outlines steps for a prospective plaintiff to provide written notice to a political subdivision that a judicial action against them is starting, and outlines a timeline and possible responses by the political subdivision, including enacting a remedy, such as an "NYVRA resolution."
  • Outlines steps and timelines for the governing body if the governing body cannot or fails to implement a remedy, including approving a proposed remedy and submitting it to the civil rights bureau, and included possible steps with an approval or denial. 
  • Provides that a political subdivision that passed a remedy ("NYVRA resolution") may enter into an agreement with the prospective plaintiff provided that the prospective plaintiff does not commence a court action for an additional 90 days, and includes agreement requirements.
  • Outlines a reimbursement process for the prospective plaintiff when a political subdivision enacts a remedy, including limitations, timelines, and rights.
  • Outlines how and when a prospective plaintiff may commence a judicial action when an imminent election is scheduled, and associated requirements.
  • Permits coalition claims demonstrating voting preferences of multiple protected classes.
  • Requires political subdivisions to provide language assistance to language-minority groups in voting and elections if they make up a certain, specified part of the electorate, and specifies what materials are to be translated, including accommodations for oral or unwritten languages.
  • Provides for filing an action against the state by a board of elections or other subdivision subject to the requirements, seeking to provide English only materials.
  • Provides that any aggrieved person, members of a protected class, certain organizations, or the attorney general may file an action.
  • Furnishes an exception for the language minority requirements for special districts.
  • Establishes that preclearance is required in the enactment or implementation of a covered policy by a covered entity by the civil rights bureau or by a designated court and lists covered policies and defines covered entity.
  • Provides that a covered entity may obtain preclearance for a covered policy from the attorney general and outlines the process, including powers, timelines, requirements, and appeals.
  • Provides that a covered entity may obtain preclearance for a covered policy from a designated court and outlines the process, including specifying courts, powers, timelines, requirements, and appeals.
  • Outlines procedures and violations for if a covered entity fails to obtain or seek preclearance.
  • Empowers the civil rights bureau to put forth rules and regulations necessary to implement its stated goals.
  • Outlines prohibitions on voter intimidation, deception or obstruction, and specifies how to establish a violation.
  • Provides that any aggrieved person, specific organizations, or the attorney general may file an action.
  • Outlines possible remedies for the courts.
  • Empowers the attorney general to issue subpoenas related to any action or investigation.
  • Provides circumstances for expedited judicial proceedings and for provision of relief.
  • Provides that these provisions apply to all elections within the state.
  • Provides that if any part of the law, or its application, are found to be invalid, it does not invalidate the entire provision or its application.

name: Relates to the John R. Lewis Voting Rights Act of New York; establishes rights of actions for denying or abridging the right of any member of a protected class to vote; provides assistance to language-minority groups; provides for preclearance of certain voting policies; makes related provisions.
summary:
• Changes the title for election code from "Violations of Elective Franchise" to "Protecting the Elective Franchise."
  • Establishes the John R Lewis Voting Rights Act of New York and provides reasons for its establishment.
  • Provides that all New York election laws be construed liberally in favor of equal protections.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Prohibits against voter suppression and vote dilution and provides for violations.
  • Provides guidelines on how to establish standing for alleged violations.
  • Provides that courts shall implement remedies and outlines the scope of violations.
  • Outlines procedures for implementing or revising districting and redistricting plans.
  • Outlines notification requirements and safe harbor for judicial actions.
  • Permits coalition claims and provides associated guidelines.
  • Provides guidelines for attorney's fees.

name: Reduces the time for mailing and receipt of registration application to constitutional minimum.
summary: This bill reduces the time for mailing of registration applications to constitutional minimum of fifteenth day before the next primary, general or special election, with receipt no later than the tenth day before such election.

name: Subtracts from the federal adjusted gross income any income earned by election inspectors, poll clerks, or election coordinators earned while working in relation to a general, primary, run-off primary, or special election to the extent includable in gross income for federal tax purposes; exempts such income from being included in the calculation of the amount of benefits under public assistance programs.
summary:
• Provides that income earned while working an election may be subtracted from gross income on federal income tax forms.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to designating early polling places.
summary:
• Provides that a board can designate any public building as a polling place, except public schools may not be designated as early polling places.
  • Establishes that if additional polling places are needed a building owned by an entity receiving more than $1,000,000 in annual state grant funds may be designated, with certain exceptions.
  • Removes the provision that no polling place may be on the premises of a building licensed to sell alcohol.

name: Provides that all local, village, town, county and city elections outside of New York City shall be in an even-numbered year.
categories: Election dates,Alignment of elections,Ballot design,Municipal election procedures
summary: This bill provides that all local, village, town, county and city elections outside of New York City shall be in an even-numbered year. Further, this bill specifies that elections be held on the Tuesday next succeeding the first Monday in November in an even-numbered year except in any village that elects its officers on a date not in November. In the event a village elects its officers on a date not in November, the primary election shall be held forty-nine days prior to the date of the village election. The bill also requires offices appearing on all ballots to be listed in the order of precedence, as applicable to the offices up for election in any given year, as follows: electors for president and vice president of the United States, governor and lieutenant governor, New York state comptroller, New York state attorney general, United States senator, member of the house of representatives, New York state senator, member of the New York state assembly. Any office which is not listed in the bill is not to appear on the ballot in a position before or ahead of an office which is listed. Additionally, all other offices are to be placed upon the ballot in the customary order; provided, further, that partisan offices regardless of the size of the constituency are to be listed before or ahead of nonpartisan offices and all candidates for judicial offices shall follow all other partisan offices.

name: Relates to construction of voting machines and systems.
summary:
• Requires ballots to be printed on "durable paper."
  • Defines "durable paper."
  • Codifies that a voter must be offered to vote by paper ballot and if the voter makes an error, offer a new paper ballot, as allowed by statute.
  • Defines "individual voter verifiable paper ballot," "non tabulating ballot marking device," and "ballot marking device."
  • Prohibits voting machines where a cast ballot passes under a printer.
  • Prohibits voting machines that both allow ballot marking and tabulating, and other related prohibitions. 
  • Requires local boards of elections to provide every voter the option to hand mark a ballot and to use a nontabulting ballot marking device.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Makes the suppression of voters a civil violation.
summary:
• Defines "deceptive practices" as they relate to communicating with voters and provides that they are a misdemeanor.
  • Defines "election."
  • Provides civil action and other relief mechanisms for victims of deceptive practices.
  • Prohibits suppression of voters.
  • Defines suppression of voters and provides that they are a misdemeanor.
  • Furnishes the attorney general with concurrent jurisdiction with any district attorney for prosecution of related cases.

name: Authorizes the state board of elections to reject the use of voting machines or systems on the grounds that such machines or systems are not proper, safe, or secure.
summary: • Provides that the state board may reject the use of a machine or system if they deem it to not be proper, safe, or secure.

name: Subtracts from the federal adjusted gross income any income earned by election inspectors, poll clerks, or election coordinators earned while working in relation to a general, primary, run-off primary, or special election to the extent includable in gross income for federal tax purposes; exempts such income from being included in the calculation of the amount of benefits under public assistance programs.
summary: This bill exempts income earned by election workers working in relation to elections from federal tax purposes and public assistance program benefits.

name: Prohibits a state party from using the word "Independent" or "Independence" in its name.
summary: This bill prohibits a state party from using the word "Independent," "Independence," "Independents," "Independences," or any abbreviations of the same, in its name.

name: Requires congressional, senatorial, assembly and election district maps be made available on applicable board of elections' websites and in a downloadable Shapefile format.
summary: This bill requires congressional, senatorial, assembly, and election district maps be made available on applicable board of elections' websites in a downloadable Shapefile format. A Shapefile is a vector data storage format for storing the location, shape, and attributes of geographic features.

name: Repeals certain provisions relating to absentee voting in primary elections for certain party positions.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Ballot access for parties
summary: This bill adds party position of ward, town, city, or county committee to absentee ballots for primary elections.

name: Relates to specification of objections to designating petitions, independent nominating petitions, certificates of nomination or ballot access documents; standardizes requirements for specification of objections by removing authority of local boards of election to make their own rules.
summary:
• Adds certificates to existing Code related to receiving petitions for office.
  • Outlines procedures for filing objections to designating petitions, nominating petitions, certificates of nomination, or ballot access documents.
  • Provides that the rules also apply to ballot access documents filed with the state board of elections, however some processes differ.
  • Outlines procedures for when determinations are made about the sufficiency of objections.

name: Improves transparency regarding boards of elections; improves voter centricity; includes boards of elections in open meetings requirements; requires certain notices be given regarding elections; requires additional transparency during the tabulation of votes.
summary:
• Provides that boards of elections are public bodies for the purpose of open meeting laws.
  • Stipulates guidelines for making public decisions about polling sites and allowing for public comment.
  • Outlines requirements for public notification about primary elections.
  • Requires that voter registration instructions be prominently displayed on each authorized body's website. 
  • Outlines and changes some guidelines for notification about elections, including the time period for notification, what must be included in the notification, and the platforms for notification. 
  • Specifies the marking device at the polling booth and how it must be tested and implemented.
  • Provides that the public must be notified, and have an opportunity for comment, regarding any changes proposed to the form and content of ballots and envelopes.
  • Provides that a qualified voter may vote at any polling station in the county and provides related guidelines.
  • Establishes that the committee on open government may appoint as many watchers as the committee deems appropriate, subject to space considerations, and outlines related guidelines.
  • Requires each county to provide accessible polling places.
  • Provides that each voter is entitled to use a voter verifiable private ballot that they can correct in the case of making an error.
  • Stipulates that all ballots of the same kind for the same election district must be identical.
  • Provides that any party committee on the ballot may have four watchers at each polling place (up from three at each election district), and provides further related instructions.
  • Codifies where to place the results tape after the election and requires extra copies for those present who request it.
  • Provides for poll tapes being copied for candidates or accredited watchers with associated instructions.
  • Requires at least two police officers (up from one) in New York City to deliver keys for the voting machine and the voting machines.
  • Increases the number of inspectors and police officers (to two, from one) for delivery of election related equipment, ballots, records, returns, and supplies.
  • Provides that results will be broken down by certain categories when made public and provides for times and days they will be released.
  • Adds government entities to those entitled to appoint watchers.
  • Requires the board of elections to hold a public hearing to allow feedback on the election process within two weeks of transmission of certified results, and provides related guidelines.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Authorizes additional days of voting as a result of emergencies; includes state of emergency.
summary:
• Adds states of emergency to the list of possible disasters on Election Day the may require an additional day for voting.
  • Provides that a county board of elections or the state board of elections will determine dates for additional voting days.
  • Establishes notification guidelines.
  • Provides guidelines for a party caucus scheduled during a disaster period.

name: Requires that subpoenas issued relating to election matters be served with a separate informational sheet that summarizes why the subpoena has been issued.
summary: This bill requires a written summary for each election subpoena explaining why the subpoena has been issued.

name: Relates to the removal of an election commissioner by the governor or by affirmative vote of a majority of duly confirmed commissioners of the state board of elections for incompetence, misconduct, or other good cause, provided that prior to removal, such election commissioner shall be given a written copy of the charges against them and have an opportunity to be heard in their defense.
summary: This bill provides for the removal of an election commissioner by the governor or by affirmative vote of a majority of duly confirmed commissioners of the state board of elections for incompetence, misconduct, or other good cause, provided that prior to removal, such election commissioner shall be given a written copy of the charges against them and have an opportunity to be heard in their defense.

name: Elections; modifying requirements for administration of precincts and sub precincts. Effective date.
summary: This bill requires the counting of an affidavit ballot of an eligible voter if such voter appeared at a polling place in the correct county but in the incorrect election district. The bill provides that such a vote shall not be cast and canvassed for contests the person was not entitled to vote at such election.

name: Makes commissioners full time employees of the board.
summary: This bill makes election commissioners full-time employees of the board.

name: Prohibits conflicts of interest among board of elections employees; prevents a board of elections employee from remaining on the board of elections payroll while also a candidate for an office who has an election overseen by the board at which they are employed; allows for a member to remain on the board until 90 days before the general election if there is no primary for such office.
summary: This bill prohibits conflicts of interest among board of elections employees, prevents a board of elections employee from remaining on the board of elections payroll while also a candidate for an office who has an election overseen by the board at which they are employed, and allows for a member to remain on the board until 90 days before the general election if there is no primary for such office.

name: Requires choices of a question or proposal printed on a ballot include a brief phrase stating the effect of such choice should such choice win such question or proposal.
summary: • Provides language for a question or proposal being included on the ballot.

name: Improves transparency regarding boards of elections; improves voter centricity; includes boards of elections in open meetings requirements; requires certain notices be given regarding elections; requires additional transparency during the tabulation of votes.
summary:
• Subjects board of elections to open meeting requirements as public bodies.
  • Requires decisions regarding poll sites be made publicly, with public comment and certain other requirements, at least 30 days before an election and provides exceptions.
  • Provides notification requirements for a primary election.
  • Requires voter registration instructions be prominently displayed on websites of bodies authorized to register people to vote.
  • Changes the deadline for publication of election- or registration-related notifications from at least two weeks before the deadline, to 30 days before the deadline, and specifies requirements for the notification.
  • Outlines rules for the ballot marking device.
  • Outlines notification and decision-making requirements regarding ballots and ballot envelopes.
  • Provides that a qualified voter is entitled to vote at any polling place in the county, with related requirements.
  • Eliminates certain early voting polling site exceptions.
  • Provides that the committee on open government may appoint as many watchers as the committee deems appropriate and provides related requirements.
  • Provides for voters being entitled to review their completed ballot and make any changes or corrections before it is cast and counted and provides related instructions.
  • Adds that ballot scanners and marking devices need to be tested, in addition to being inspected.
  • Provides that party committees and related organizations may appoint four watchers to a polling place (from three), with related instructions.
  • Specifies rules for posting the results tape outside a polling place.
  • Requires inspectors to print extra copies of the tabulated results tape and give them to accredited watchers, or anyone present requesting a copy.
  • Outlines what a poll watcher may access at a canvass.
  • Specifies that in New York City two police officers or peace officers must deliver voting devices.
  • Changes the number of officials delivering ballots and stubs, filing records and supplies, and other associated tasks from one to two.
  • Specifies that returns, records, and registration lists filed by the chairman must also be accompanied by an inspector from a different party.
  • Outlines other ballot and canvass security procedures.
  • Specifies what must be included in results posted by an election district.
  • Outlines rules and timelines for releasing election results.
  • Requires the board of elections to hold a public hearing within two weeks of certifying the results to get feedback about the election process.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Includes within the class D felony of assault in the second degree, the intentional causing of physical injury to an election officer while such person is performing their assigned duties; amends aggravated harassment and obstruction of governmental administration to include election officers.
summary:
• Adds election officers to existing code prohibiting physical injury to certain government workers and penalties.
  • Specifies the code refers to harassing, annoying, threatening, alarming, and having physically contact with an election official while he or she tries to perform his or her duties.

name: Requires electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidates in a manner representing the plurality of votes in each congressional district.
most_recent_action: held for consideration in election law
summary: • Provides that two electoral votes will be given to the statewide election winner and one will be given to each congressional district winner, based on a plurality of votes.

name: Requires a government photo identification card to be presented when casting a ballot; provides for a method to receive a government photo identification card at no charge.
most_recent_action: held for consideration in election law
summary:
• Lists which IDs count as "government issued photo identification."
  • Establishes when and how a person my obtain a non-driver identification.
  • Provides language for an affidavit for obtaining a non-driver government issued ID.
  • Details what must be included in the application for the non-driver identification.
  • Specifies that individuals obtaining a non-driver ID for the purpose of voting should not pay a fee and outlines procedures.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Restricts electioneering activities within six hundred feet of a polling place or the entire property where a polling place is located.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary:
• Provides that electioneering is not allowed near a polling place and provides specific details about distances of the prohibition based upon the type of building.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Requires at-large electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidate who received the highest number of votes in the state; requires congressional electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidates who received the highest number of votes in each congressional district; removes and replaces electors who fail to vote in such manner.
most_recent_action: held for consideration in election law
summary:
• Specifies that two electoral votes will be given to the statewide winner of the electoral college vote for president and vice president.
  • Specifies that one electoral college vote will be given to each Congressional district.
  • Outlines a presidential elector oath.
  • Specifies actions for an elector who refuses to take the pledge.

name: Requires funeral directors to ensure that death certificates are delivered to the state health department and the department of health of the city of New York who shall in turn deliver certain certificates to the state board of elections.
most_recent_action: held for consideration in election law
summary: This bill requires funeral directors to ensure that death certificates are delivered to the state health department and the department of health of the city of New York who shall in turn deliver certain certificates to the state board of elections. The bill then requires each county board of elections to subsequently ensure that any decedent registered to vote shall promptly be removed from enrollment.

name: Establishes no polling place shall be located on the premises of any public or private elementary or secondary school or a school for preschool children.
most_recent_action: held for consideration in election law
summary: • Prohibits a polling place from being located at a public or private preschool, elementary or secondary school.

name: Enacts the voter registration integrity act; requires a birth certificate, passport, certificate of naturalization or citizenship, evidence of New York state residency, or any other documentation that the board of elections determines establishes United States citizenship.
most_recent_action: held for consideration in election law
summary: • Provides that the board of elections will require first time registrants to include a document establishing their citizenship, with a list of acceptable documents.

name: Requires the boards of trustees of SUNY and CUNY to adopt policies requiring institutions thereof to grant course credit to students who serve as election inspectors, poll clerks, or election coordinators.
summary:
• Requires state university employees to adopt guidelines requiring a state university to grant course credit to students serving as election inspector, poll clerk, or election coordinator.
  • Stipulates related requirements.

name: Relates to making electronic ballot images and cast vote records public records of the board of elections upon request.
summary:
• Directs that an electronic image of each cast ballot and the cast vote record be copied by the board of elections within one week of the election.
  • Provides that the images and records will be public records available upon request.
  • Adds memory cards to the possible devices for information storage.

name: Relates to ballots submitted in envelopes that are sealed with tape, paste or any other binding agent or device and have no indication of tampering.
summary: • Codifies that a ballot envelope that is sealed using a binding agent, such as tape, and does not indicate tampering, does not require a cure.

name: Relates to ballots where the express intent of the voter is unambiguous.
summary:
• Provides that when the intent of a voter is clear, stray markings will not be the basis for voiding a ballot.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Provides for the declination of a designation as a candidate or nomination for a party position where the person so nominated or designated has been arrested or charged with one or more state or federal misdemeanors or felonies, or convicted of a crime after designation.
summary: This bill provides for the declination of a designation as a candidate or nomination for a party position where the person so nominated or designated has been arrested or charged with one or more state or federal misdemeanors or felonies, or convicted of a crime after designation.

name: Provides for the declination of a designation as a candidate or nomination for a party position where the person so nominated or designated has been arrested or charged with one or more state or federal misdemeanors or felonies, or convicted of a crime after designation.
summary: • Provides circumstances under which someone may decline a nomination.

name: Requires the board of elections to mail notice of ensuing primary and general elections, registration status, polling place location and other information to active voters between the third Tuesday in April and the second Friday in May each year.
summary: • Changes the date for the board of elections to mail notification of elections from 65-70 days before the primary to between the third Tuesday in April and the second Friday in May.

name: Requires a valid government issued photo identification card be presented when casting a ballot; provides for persons eligible for Medicaid to receive identification cards.
most_recent_action: held for consideration in election law
categories: Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,In-person voter ID,Voter ID for low-income voters
summary: This bill requires a valid government issued photo identification card to be presented when casting a ballot. This bill stipulates the following as valid forms of identification: a New York state driver's license or non-driver ID; a United States passport; an identification card issued by a United States educational institution; a United States military identification card; a government issued medical card or any identification card issued by the United States or the state of New York. Further, this bill mandates that any adult citizen whose income qualifies him or her for Medicaid, as verified in writing by the county's department of social services, is not required to pay any fee for a state-issued identification card.

name: Provides that absentee ballots shall not be mailed or delivered to a voter unless such voter has specifically requested to receive an absentee ballot.
most_recent_action: held for consideration in election law
summary:
• Requires a voter to specifically request an absentee ballot for one to be delivered to the person.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Relates to mandatory training curriculum for election commissioners and key staff of boards of elections and to model poll worker training programs; requires the state board of elections to develop and provide to each county materials for a model poll worker training program which the counties may use to train individuals to serve as poll workers in state and county elections.
most_recent_action: reported referred to ways and means
summary:
• Provides that training of election workers must be offered at least on a quarterly basis.
  • Establishes that the state board of elections will create and host a training institute that will serve as a train the trainers program and includes specific instructions on its implementation.

name: Relates to providing translators at certain polling place locations.
categories: Language accommodations,In-person voting and polling places
summary: This bill provides translators at polling place locations if 15% of the number of voting age citizens who speak the same language other than English at home reside in the district where the polling place is located.

name: Relates to designating every government entity which issues licenses to carry, possess, repair and dispose of firearms as participating agencies for voter registration form distribution and assistance.
most_recent_action: held for consideration in election law
summary: This bill designates every government entity which issues licenses to carry, possess, repair, or dispose of firearms as participating agencies for voter registration form distribution and assistance.

name: Enacts the voter registration integrity act; requires a birth certificate, passport, certificate of naturalization or citizenship, evidence of New York state residency, or any other documentation that the board of elections determines establishes United States citizenship.
summary: • Provides that people registering for the first time must provide specific documents certifying US citizenship.

name: Prohibits level two or three sex offenders from voting at a school or facility for children; authorizes absentee voting for such offenders.
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,In-person voting and polling places
summary:
• Prohibits level two and level three sex offenders from entering or remaining in a school to vote.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Provides penalty guidelines.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Requires the board of elections to compile a list of level two and three sex offenders entitled to receive an absentee ballot 60 days before the election and send the ballots.
  • Provides that no poll worker is civilly liable for refusing admittance to a level two or three sex offender and provides related guidelines.

name: Relates to providing translators at certain polling place locations.
summary:
• Requires that for existing election districts, and in redistricting, the board of elections ensure that identified language minority groups have at least one poll worker speaking their language at the relevant polls.
  • Requires the poll worker to assist the language minority voter upon his or her request.

name: Relates to ballots submitted in envelopes that are partially sealed or sealed with tape, paste, or any other binding agent or device.
summary: • Specifies that ballot envelopes are not invalid if they are sealed with tape, paste, or other binding and there is no evidence of tampering.

name: Allows a candidate for nomination or for party position, or nominated for an office to decline such designation or nomination after they are arrested, indicted or convicted of a crime no later than four days after such arrest, indictment or conviction.
summary:
• Requires a nominated candidate who is arrested, indicted, or convicted of a crime to decline the designation no later than four days after the event.
  • Makes exceptions based on the effective date.

name: Relates to prohibiting boards of elections from entering into contracts for certain services related to the conduct of elections with entities that have made any political campaign donations of any amount in the last ten years.
summary: • Prohibits the state board of elections from entering into agreements with anyone who has made any political campaign contributions in the past ten years.

name: Relates to the number of signatures for independent nominating petitions; decreases the number of signatures and votes to 15,000 signatures for statewide candidates and 50,000 votes to maintain party ballot status; changes the petition period to 12 weeks and the petitioning time to May-August.
summary:
• Decreases the number of signatures required for an independent nomination petition from 45,000 voters to 15,000 voters.
  • Decreases the number of those voters who must be in at least half of the congressional districts from 500 to 100.
  • Decreases the minimum number of votes for a party to have received in the last election from 130,000 to 50,000 or two percent of total votes for governor, whichever is less (rather than whichever is greater).
  • Provides that signatures will be collected during a 12 week period, and provides specific dates.
  • Changes the time range when the nominating petition is to be filed from 23-24 weeks before the election to 6-23 weeks before the election.
  • Changes the time for a certification of nomination to be made from thirty days after the June primary to seven weeks before the general election.

name: Relates to the number of signatures for independent nominating petitions; decreases the number of signatures and votes to 15,000 signatures for statewide candidates and 50,000 votes to maintain party ballot status; changes the petition period to 12 weeks and the petitioning time to May-August.
summary:
• Decreases the number of voters required to sign an independent nominating petition for state-level candidates from 45,000 to 15,000, and decreases the number of those signees who must live in half of the congressional districts from 500 to 100.
  • Decreases the number of required votes required to create a party from 130,000 at the last election for governor to 50,000, or two percent, whichever is less (a change from whichever is greater, which was the previous Code).
  • Stipulates that signatures for an independent petition for a general election will be collected for a 12-week period from the Monday before Memorial Day to the third Monday of August.
  • Changes the timeline for filing a petition for independent nomination from 23-24 weeks before the election to 6-23 weeks before the election.
  • Changes the deadline for filing a certificate of party nomination not made at a primary to seven weeks before the general election, rather than 30 days after the June primary.

name: Provides that the police commissioner of the city of New York and all other cities with a population of one hundred thousand or more shall be an elected office with a four-year term; provides that such office shall be subject to term limits of two terms.
summary:
• Provides that the office of police commissioner will be elected in every city with a population greater than 100,000, but less than one million.
  • Provides that the term of office will be four years and provides for dates of election.
  • Provides that the police commissioner may be removed or suspended the same way as the mayor.
  • Establishes rules for filling a vacancy in office for police commissioner, for scheduling related elections, and for the newly chosen police commissioner taking office.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Requires the board of elections to mail notice of ensuing primary and general elections, registration status, polling place location and other information to active voters between the third Tuesday in April and the second Friday in May each year.
summary: • Change the timeline for mailing notification of polling hours 65-70 days before a primary election to between the third Tuesday in April and the second Friday in May.

name: Makes commissioners full time employees of the board.
summary: • Provides that election commissioners will be full time employees of the board.

name: Authorizes United States citizens currently residing outside the United States whose last residence in the United States was in the state of New York to vote in certain federal elections.
summary: • Removes US territories from the list of locations where a citizen may be registered to vote.

name: Relates to the representation of newly formed political parties; relates to the placement of candidates of newly formed political parties on ballots, the representation of such parties within the state and the transmission of the official canvass of votes cast for presidential electors.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Presidential elections,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary:
• Adds presidential elections, in addition to existing gubernatorial elections, to ballot format guidelines regarding which party will be in column A or one.
  • Provides that for judicial district conventions the number of delegates for a new party will be based on the party's vote for presidential electors, and thereafter be based on the party's vote for Governor.
  • Adds the office of president of the United States to the list of office where someone running for an office may appear as many times as they are nominated.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Makes the suppression of voters a civil violation.
summary: Makes deceptive practices and voter suppression of voters a civil violation. Deceptive practices is defined as knowingly communicating or knowingly causing to be communicated deceptive information, such as election information known to be false, and thus preventing or deterring another person from exercising the right to vote in any election. Suppression is defined as the use force, authority or an abuse of power to prevent, restrain, inhibit or compel another from acting in his or her own interests or intentions.

name: Requires county committees to meet for the purposes of organization after the certification of the June primary at which the members of such committee are elected but no later than October sixth following the June primary.
categories: Ballot access for parties,Ballot access deadlines
summary: • Requires every county committee to meet no earlier than one day after the June primary is certified, instead of by September 17.

name: Relates to furnishing money or entertainment to induce attendance at polls.
summary: • Prohibits distributing anything with a nominal value at a polling place or in the line to vote.

name: Relates to objections to designating and nominating petitions; outlines requirements for officers, boards and judges making determinations as to the sufficiency of a designating or nominating petition.
summary:
• Specifies that an officer or board should construe election laws liberally when ruling on objections to designating and nominating petitions.
  • Outlines required considerations for the officer or board in making a determination about the sufficiency of a petition.

name: Requires voters to provide a current and valid social security number when casting a ballot to vote.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary:
• Requires the voter to provide his or her social security number when registering to vote.
  • Provides that a copy of a voter's social security card allows the applicant to apply for an absentee ballot.

name: Requires that county committees meet no earlier than one day after the June primary is certified.
summary: • Changes the date for county committees to meet from September 17 to one day after the June primary is certified.

name: Requires a new party to file a certificate following the election at which the party obtains party status.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary: • Requires new parties to file a first certificate by the last day of February after the election where the party obtained party status.

name: Requires absentee ballots for fire district elections, including, but not limited to, all projects or mandatory, permissive or special referendums which require a vote by qualified residents of such fire district; provides that a qualified voter may vote as an absentee voter under certain circumstances and lays out such criteria; requires that an application must be received by the district clerk no earlier than the thirtieth day before the election for which an absentee ballot is sought; makes
summary:
• Requires boards of fire commissioners to provide for absentee ballots for elections.
  • Provides guidelines and timelines for absentee ballots.
  • Outlines timelines and procedures for mailing the absentee ballots.

name: Prohibits municipal employees appointed by the chief executive officer of a municipality or the governing body of a municipality, who are not members of a collective bargaining unit, from serving as political party officers in any capacity; exempts municipal employees appointed by a school district or fire district.
summary:
• Prohibits municipal employees who are not part of a collecting bargaining unit from serving as political party officers, with certain exceptions.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Relates to the time period during which absentee ballots shall be mailed or delivered after an application for such ballot is received by the board of elections.
summary:
• Provides timelines for mailing or delivering absentee ballots based on when the application was received.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Provides that a voter may register to vote at any residence to which the voter maintains a continuous connection with an intent to return, including a second home or a vacation home.
summary: • Allows voters to register and vote from a second or vacation home.

name: Provides that a voter may register to vote at any residence to which the voter maintains a continuous connection with an intent to return, including a second home or a vacation home.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary: • Allows someone to vote from a second or vacation home if they are registered at the residence and maintain a continuous connection with the intent to return.

name: Removes provisions requiring election inspectors, poll clerks, and election coordinators to be appointed in a bipartisan manner.
summary:
• Removes the requirement, and instead makes it recommended, that election inspectors and poll clerks are to be equally divided between the two major political parties at each polling place.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Provides that an attorney licensed to practice in the state may serve as a poll watcher in any city or county in the state.
summary: • Specifies that existing election watcher code does not prohibit a licensed attorney who is a New York resident from visiting a polling place.

name: Includes within the class D felony of assault in the second degree, the intentional causing of physical injury to an election officer while such person is performing their assigned duties; amends aggravated harassment and obstruction of governmental administration to include election officers.
summary:
• Adds election officers to existing code prohibiting physical injury to certain government workers and penalties.
  • Specifies the code refers to harassing, annoying, threatening, alarming, and having physically contact with an election official while he or she tries to perform his or her duties.

name: Authorizes party designations and nominations for elections to be made via video conference upon notice to the members of the respective committee; allows certificates of designation or nomination to be executed in separate acts by the signatories.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary: This bill authorizes party designations and nominations for elections to be made via video conference upon notice to the members of the respective committee. The bill allows certificates of designation or nomination to be executed in separate acts by the signatories.

name: Prohibits an election district to be created, consolidated, divided or altered by the board of elections in 2021 in certain counties that made temporary amendments to its rules regarding the election of county committee members.
summary: • Prohibits creation, consolidation, division, or alteration of a county election district in 2021 if the county executive committee filed a temporary amendment to its rules related to election of county committee members.

name: Requires that all candidates obtain the written, express permission of any person identified in campaign literature.
summary: • Requires any campaign literature, advertisements, media broadcasts, public speeches, and other campaign writing identifying anyone other than the candidate, obtain the written permission of the person being identified.

name: Authorizes voting by proxy at a judicial district convention due to novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
summary: This bill permits voting by proxy at a judicial district convention due to novel coronavirus, COVID-19.

name: Relates to special elections to fill vacancies in the state senate and assembly and certain deadlines with regard to such special elections.
summary:
• Separates the state senate and assembly from other entities for rules related to calling a special election due to a vacancy.
  • Specifies that the governor may set the same date for a vacancy election in the state senate or assembly with another existing special election, with certain requirements.
  • Adds a deadline of 24 days before special elections for the state legislature for certifying candidates.
  • Provides a deadline for special elections for the state legislature related to party certificates of nomination of candidates.
  • Provides rules for filing an objection to a certificate of party nomination, or other certificates, for a special election to the state legislature.
  • Provides deadlines for acceptance of a certificate of nomination for special elections to the state legislature, and provides deadlines for other certificates related to the nomination process.
  • Provides a timeline for early voting locations for a special election to the state legislature.
  • Provides a timeline for military voting in a special election to the state legislature.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Changes the effective date of bills numbers S.1027-A and A.7931 to April 1, 2022.
summary: • Changes the effective date of this act regarding canvassing absentee, military, and special ballots from January to April 1, 2022.

name: Relates to the number of early voting poll sites in certain cities and towns; requires, where practicable, that such sites shall be situated along public transportation routes.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
categories: Municipal election procedures,In-person voting and polling places
summary: • Provides that there must be at least one early voting polling place in cities and towns with a population between 100,000 and one million, and that there should be additional polling places for every 50,000 additional people, not to exceed 11 polling places.

name: Extends provisions relating to electronic absentee ballot applications until April 1, 2022; bumps the effectiveness to April 1, 2022.
summary:
• Changes the effective date of codes related to electronic applications for absentee ballots from January 1, 2022 to April 1, 2022.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Permits voting by absentee ballot where there is a risk of contracting or spreading a disease that may cause illness to the voter or to other members of the public.
summary:
• Defines illness in absentee voting to include someone who is at risk of contracting or spreading a disease.
  • Changes the expiration date from January 1, 2022 to December 31, 2022.

name: Relates to the order in which candidates appear on the ballot; requires that offices shall be listed on the ballot in descending order based on the size of the electorate and requires certain federal offices to be listed before state, county or local offices.
summary:
• Requires that offices on a ballot be listed in order of precedence and lists the order of precedence for offices.
  • Provides that office other than those listed should appear in the customary order.
  • Requires partisan offices to appear on the ballot after nonpartisan offices.
  • Requires judicial offices to follow other partisan offices on the ballot.

name: Provides that whenever a contiguous property of a college or university contains three hundred or more registrants, the polling place designated for such election district shall be on such contiguous property or at a location approved by the college or university.
summary:
• Provides that if a property contiguous to a university has more than 300 active registered voters, those voters may vote at an address on the property, or at a location approved by the university.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Allows a judicial district convention to be conducted in whole or in part via video conference upon a minimum of seventy-two hours notice to the members of the respective committee by mail, an appropriately titled email, text or telephone call at an address or number expressly provided in writing for the purpose of receiving such notices.
summary:
• Authorizes a judicial district convention to be held via video conference with 72 hours notice.
  • Provides specific requirements for the notification.
  • Requires that the video conference portion afford the same opportunity to listen and to be heard as an in-person meeting.

name: Eliminates the requirements for publication of detailed election notices within the city of New York.
summary: • Makes an exception for the city of New York regarding publishing specific notifications with information about primary elections and publishing the names of candidates running for office.

name: Increases the minimum compensation to be paid to election day workers to three hundred dollars and election coordinators to four hundred dollars within the city of New York.
summary: This bill increases the minimum compensation to be paid to election day workers to three hundred dollars and election coordinators to four hundred dollars within the city of New York.

name: Orders the names on ballots for special elections in the same manner as ordered for general and primary elections.
summary: This bill orders the names on ballots for special elections to be in the same manner as ordered for general and primary elections.

name: Restricts electioneering on the polling place property.
summary: • Adds the electioneering may not be done on the polling place property while the polls are open.

name: Relates to the creation, consolidation, division, and alteration of election districts by the board of elections in the city of New York.
summary: This bill mandates that election districts in the city of New York  not contain more than four thousand registrants, excluding registrants in inactive status.

name: Exempts public school buildings with instructional space from being designated as early polling locations; allows school districts to decline school building designations as early polling locations.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary: • Prohibits public school buildings with instructional space from being designated as an early voting location, with an additional provision for school buildings without instructional space.

name: Requires the board of elections to provide a return postage guaranteed envelope with absentee ballots.
summary: • Requires a return postage guaranteed envelope be mailed with an absentee ballot.

name: Relates to the postmark date for change of enrollment.
summary: This bill allows for a change of enrollment to be received by the Board of Elections showing a dated cancellation mark of the United States Post Office or contained in an envelope showing such a dated cancellation mark which is not later than February fourteenth.

name: Provides that the language used in a proposed amendment, proposition or question to be submitted to the people for approval shall be in the legislation authorizing such submission.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary: • Requires that the submission form of a proposed amendment, proposition, or question be set forth through legislation to the people for approval.

name: Requires persons administering challenge oaths to voter applicants to attest that the challenge is being made in good faith and to provide certain identifying information; requires challenge oaths to be presented to a challenged voter applicant in writing.
summary:
• Provides instructions for challenging a voter's right to vote.
  • Provides clarifying edits.

name: Provides for voter requests for an absentee ballot from the board of elections by telephone.
summary:
• Adds an option to request an absentee ballot by phone.
  • Specifies that voters requesting an absentee ballot by phone are not required to fill out the application before receiving the ballot.
  • Requires the board of elections to keep a written record of phone requests and allows them to complete the absentee ballot application on behalf of the voter.

name: Instructs the state board of elections to create and distribute voting guides to voters containing information about the candidates; mandates that voters receive postcards to notify them of upcoming elections and that television and radio stations also notify their audience of upcoming elections.
summary:
• Provides that candidates may provide information for a voter guide, and lists specific information to provide.
  • Clarifies what the state board must do with the information to create, distribute, and publicize the voting guide.

name: Requires the county seat in Wayne county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
summary: • Adds Wayne county to the requirement that each municipality have at least one early voting polling place.

name: Establishes portable polling locations for early voting; provides that a county board of elections may establish one or more portable polling locations.
summary: This bill establishes portable polling locations for early voting and provides that a county board of elections may establish one or more portable polling locations. The bill requires that designation and location of any portable polling place be made no later than fourteen days before an election. Locations for portable polling locations must take into consideration population density, travel time to the polling place, proximity to other early voting poll sites, public transportation routes, commuter traffic patterns and such other factors the board of elections deems appropriate. Locations for portable polling locations for early voting shall be operational for no fewer than three consecutive days. No portable polling location for early voting established by this subdivision shall replace or otherwise decrease the number of polling places for early voting required by subdivision two of this section.

name: Provides that an attorney licensed to practice in the state may serve as a poll watcher in any city or county in the state.
summary: • Provides that a licensed attorney who is a New York resident may visit a polling place.

name: Requires the county seat in Seneca county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
categories: Municipal election procedures,In-person voting and polling places
summary: • Provides that the county seat in Seneca county will have at least one polling place designated for early voting.

name: Relates to the use of voting systems by municipalities; provides for the determination of actual expenses of the board.
summary:
• Changes the phrase voting machine to voting system.
  • Requires the board of elections to share voting systems, when possible, with localities and only charge for actual expenses.

name: Provides that the text to be used in a proposed amendment, proposition or question to be submitted to the people for approval shall be in the legislation proposing such amendment, proposition or question and shall not be altered without approval by the legislature.
summary: This bill mandates that text of an amendment, proposition, or question to be submitted to the people for their approval must be included in the text of the legislation proposing such amendment, proposition, or question. The text of a proposed amendment, proposition, or question to be submitted to the people for their approval must not be altered without the approval of the legislature.

name: Provides protections against illegal voter purging.
categories: Legal causes of action,Voter list maintenance
summary:
• Provides mailing procedures and other procedures for those seeking to challenge the qualifications of a voter.
  • Provides procedures and language related to the challenge affidavit.
  • Provides questions for an applicant taking a preliminary oath.
  • Establishes that information related to citizenship status will not be retained or shared for any other purposes.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Requires counties with a population of one million or more to have at least one polling place in each town and city of such counties.
categories: Municipal election procedures,In-person voting and polling places
summary: • Provides that in counties with a population of one million or more, outside of cities with a population of one million or more, that each town and city will have at least one polling place.

name: Elections; modifying date for certain elections; modifying filing period for declarations of candidacy. Emergency.
summary:
• Directs the state board of elections to create a plan for voting by mail when there is a natural disaster or state of emergency. 
  • Defines "voting by mail."
  • Requires the plan be completed by September 1, 2021, or 30 days after passage of the act.

name: Establishes the crime of voter intimidation or harassment and prohibits persons who have been convicted of such crime from registering for or voting at an election.
summary:
• Defines voter intimidation and harassment.
  • Provides that voter intimidation and harassment are class A misdemeanors.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to proceedings with respect to designating and nominating petitions.
summary: • Adds a third option for when proceedings with respect to a petition should be instituted.

name: Relates to poll watchers for special, town or village elections being held for the sole purpose of a ballot proposal.
most_recent_action: Taken off notice for cal in s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee of Local Government Committee
summary:
• Adds special, town, or village ballot proposal elections to existing legislation for when watchers may be appointed.
  • Allows watchers also to be appointed by the board of elections, upon request, for special, town, or village ballot proposal elections, and furnishes rules for the board to do this.

name: Relates to the use of voting systems by municipalities; provides for the determination of actual expenses of the board.
summary:
• Changes the term voting machine to the term voting system.
  • Requires, when possible for certain local and special districts to use the board of election's voting system for elections and prohibits to board to charge more than the actual expense.

name: Increases compensation payable to election inspectors, poll clerks, election coordinators, and qualified voters appointed to act in place of an absent inspector, clerk, or coordinator, who have or will have been employed in any of such capacities for four or more years, by twenty-five percent of the amount otherwise payable.
summary: • Increases the pay by 25% for election inspectors, poll clerks, election coordinators, and appointed substitutes who have been employed four or more years.

name: Requires the board of elections to provide email notifications to voters whenever they change the location of a polling place.
summary:
• Adds email notifications to existing mail notifications for when a board of elections changes a polling place.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Requires the board of elections or a bipartisan committee appointed by such board to conduct a risk-limiting audit of voter verifiable audit records from voting machines or systems within the jurisdiction of such board.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary:
• Requires a risk limiting audit after an election that includes a hand review of at least 3% of paper records.
  • Requires the board of elections to audit 3% of voting machine records.
  • Requires the state board of elections to create rules to implement risk limiting audit procedures.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Relates to making electronic ballot images and cast vote records public records of the board of elections upon request.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary:
• Requires an electronic image of each cast ballot and each vote record be copied from the memory card no later than one week after the election.
  • Provides that these images are public records.

name: Requires electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidate who were nominated by the political party that nominated the presidential elector.
summary: • Requires electoral college members to cast a ballot for the candidates nominated by the political party and outlines consequences for refusing to do so.
