name: Requires persons administering challenge oaths to voter applicants to attest that the challenge is being made in good faith and to provide certain identifying information; requires challenge oaths to be presented to a challenged voter applicant in writing.
summary: This bill requires persons administering challenge oaths to voter applicants attest that the challenge is being made in good faith and to provide identifying information. The bill requires challenge oaths to be presented to a challenged voter applicant in writing.

name: Requires that elections for municipal office in the city of New York shall use an "instant run-off" or "ranked choice" voting system.
summary:
• Provides the the city of New York will use instant run-off elections or a ranked choice voting system in elections for municipal office.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to pre-recorded political messages; prohibits automatic dialing-announcing devices unless a live operator provides certain information in the first thirty seconds; requires registration; authorizes attorney general to investigate violations.
summary: This bill prohibits any person or political committee from delivering or knowingly causing to be delivered via automatic dialing-announcing device a pre-recorded political message unless a live operator provides, within the first thirty seconds of the message the name of the candidate or of any organization or organizations the person is calling on behalf of and the name of the person or organization paying for the delivery of the message and the name of the treasurer of any such committee. The bill requires a copy of all scripts and schedules of such calls to be filed with the New York state board of elections  within twenty-four hours of such calls being made. Any person or political committee operating an automatic dialing-announcing device or placing any consumer telephone calls or pre-recorded political messages must register with the secretary of state as well as the New York state board of elections. The bill empowers the attorney general with the power to investigate violations of the bill, including the ability to subpoena records in furtherance of any investigation. Violations of this bill are punishable by a civil fine not to exceed two thousand dollars per occurrence.

name: Relates to voting rights expansion, voter registration on election day, expansion of the use of and requirements for absentee voting, creation of a real-time statewide voter registration database, special ballots for election employees, and voter affidavits.
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in voter assistance,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
• Provides that a qualified individual is entitled to register to vote at the polling place on Election Day.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Provides procedures for registering voters on Election Day.
  • Provides that qualified voters may vote absentee for all elections and enumerates the required process.
  • Outlines the process for requesting and administering absentee ballot applications.
  • Requires an absentee ballot to be sent to a voter's permanent address.
  • Provides for a computerized statewide voter registration list with associated requirements.
  • Provides that special ballots for board of election employees should be presumed valid and cast when there is no proof of fraud.
  • Provides clarifying edits.

name: Provides that qualified persons who have never previously registered to vote in this state may apply personally for registration by appearing at the appropriate polling place for the election district in which such person resides on the day such polling place is open for voting; requires establishment of a procedure to enable such registrants to cast their votes at the appropriate polling places.
summary: This bill provides that qualified persons who have never previously registered to vote may apply for registration by appearing at the appropriate polling place for the election district in which they reside on the day that polling place is open for voting.

name: Allows election commissioners flexibility to designate how many election inspectors are needed at poll sites.
most_recent_action: Taken off notice for cal in s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee of Local Government Committee
summary: • Changes the required number of election inspectors per district with fewer than 150 registered voters from four to two.

name: Requires the canvass of absentee ballots as they are received.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary:
• Requires officials designated by the board to canvass absentee ballots as they are received.
  • Removes a deadline for notifying candidates and parties entitled to have watchers at the polls, and requires it be sent "prior to" receiving ballots.

name: Requires audits by hand recount of voter verifiable audit records.
summary: This bill requires that audits be completed by hand recount.

name: Relates to the time period during which absentee ballots shall be mailed or delivered after an application for such ballot is received by the board of elections.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration
summary: • Provides timelines for mailing absentee ballots based on when an application was received.

name: Removes the requirement that party emblems be included in ballot design.
summary: • Removes reference to an emblem on existing election code regarding ballots, political parties, and nominating petitions.

name: Requires that elections for municipal office in the city of New York shall use an "instant run-off" or "ranked choice" voting system.
summary: • Requires that elections for municipal office in New York City be "instant run-off" or "ranked choice" voting systems.

name: Establishes provisions requiring absentee ballots that do not have postmarked dates that are received in the mail by the board of elections within three days following the day of election to be cast and counted.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary: • Requires an absentee ballot without any date markings indicating when it was mailed to be counted if it arrives to the board of elections by three days after the election.

name: Establishes an electronic military ballot application and military ballot transmittal system through which applicants may apply for a military ballot and return a marked military ballot, online.
summary: This bill establishes a military ballot transmittal system through which applicants may apply for a military ballot and return a marked military ballot online. The bill requires each board of elections maintain a system capable of receiving and processing military ballot applications and marked military ballot information, including digital signatures, from the electronic voter registration transmittal system established by the state board of elections. The bill defines "digital signature" as a certificate-based digital identification code issued to qualified personnel by the United States department of defense as part of the common access card or its successor.

name: Provides that certain cities and towns shall have early voting poll sites within their boundaries and, where practicable, that such sites shall be situated along public transportation routes.
summary: • Requires locales with a population between 50,000-100,000 to have at least one early voting polling place situated along public transportation routes if possible.

name: Prohibits judicial candidates from enrolling voters in minor parties; disqualifies an individual from holding judicial office for a violation thereof; defines "minor party".
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary: This bill prohibits judicial candidates from enrolling voters in minor parties and disqualifies an individual from holding judicial office for doing so. The bill defines "minor party" means a party that, excluding blank and void ballots, received less than ten percent of the total votes cast for its candidate for governor in the year in which a governor is elected, and less than ten percent of the total votes cast for its candidate for president in a year when a president is elected

name: Provides that a candidate who files a certificate of acceptance for an office for which there have been filed certificates or petitions designating more than one candidate for the nomination of any party, may thereafter file a certificate of declination not later than the seventh day after the primary election.
summary: This bill provides that a candidate who files a certificate of acceptance for an office for which there have been filed certificates or petitions designating more than one candidate for the nomination of any party, may thereafter file a certificate of declination not later than the seventh day after the primary election.

name: Prevents municipalities from abridging the election law.
summary: • Prohibits a county, city, town, or village from amending a municipal charter, or passing a local law, to allow or to prohibit someone from registering to vote.

name: Includes a statement on the envelopes of ballots for absentee voters and special presidential voters for signature affirmation.
most_recent_action: Failed in s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee of Local Government Committee
summary: This bill inserts a statement on the envelopes of ballots for absentee voters and special presidential voters for signature affirmation. The bill requires the following added to the envelope: IMPORTANT TO ABSENTEE VOTER: YOU MUST SIGN THE AFFIRMATION ON THIS ENVELOPE and IMPORTANT TO SPECIAL PRESIDENTIAL VOTER: YOU MUST SIGN THE AFFIRMATION ON THIS ENVELOPE.

name: Requires electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidates in a manner representing the plurality of votes in each congressional district.
summary: • Provides that two electoral votes will be given to the statewide election winner and one will be given to each congressional district winner, based on a plurality of votes.

name: Relates to the order in which candidates appear on the ballot; requires that offices shall be listed on the ballot in descending order based on the size of the electorate and requires certain federal offices to be listed before state, county or local offices.
summary: This bill orders candidates on the ballot by precedence: electors for president and vice-president, governor and lieutenant governor, state comptroller, state attorney general, United States senator, house representatives, state senator, member of state assembly.

name: Relates to the procedure for the recanvass of vote in election districts.
summary:
• Specifies the term manual recount to be a hand recount.
  • Redefines "margin of victory."
  • Requires the margin of victory of 0.5%, or less, be calculated by a certain method.
  • Outlines rules for if the contest appeared on ballots in two or more counties, or one county plus New York City.

name: Relates to the registration status of voters; establishes additional requirements for the cancellation of a voter's registration and allows voters who have an inactive status to have their registration returned to active status and to have their vote counted for the election in which they vote.
summary:
• Classifies as misconduct an election official canceling a voter's registration in violation of existing code, or refusing to allow a voter with inactive status to vote.
  • Requires the board of elections to verify a voter's registration before canceling it.
  • Provides procedures for distributing the inactive poll ledger.
  • Provides that if a voter casts a ballot in an affidavit envelope meeting all requirements, the voter is restored to active status.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to requests for proposals for voting machines and contracts for the purchase of voting machines or systems.
summary: This bill provides that any commissioner of the state board of elections may examine voter machines and systems and may solicit requests for proposals for voting machines or systems to be certified by such board for use in New York state. All such requests for proposals shall contain a provision stating that any person or entity submitting a proposal shall pay to the board a fee equal to the cost of such examination.

name: Relates to prohibiting boards of elections from entering into contracts for certain services related to the conduct of elections with entities that have made any political campaign donations of any amount in the last ten years.
summary: This bill prohibits boards of elections from entering into contracts with any person, firm, corporation, or other entity, that has made any political campaign donations of any amount in the last ten years, for the preparation, design, printing, mailing, distribution, delivery, processing, or counting of ballots, affidavits, petitions, applications, or other papers and materials involved in the conduct of elections or the canvass of results.

name: Relates to the procedure for filling a vacancy in the office of state senator or in the office of member of assembly occurring in a district consisting of parts of more than one county in a city with a population of one million or more; allows for independent nominating petitions to be presented and provides for a special election to be held forty-five days from the date of the governor making a proclamation for a special election.
summary: This bill provides that in a city with a population of one million or more, a vacancy in the office of state senator or in the office of member of assembly occurring in a district consisting of parts of more than one county and required to be filled at the next general election shall be filled by popular election. Within three days of the occurrence of such a vacancy, the governor shall make proclamation of a special non-partisan election to fill the office, specifying the district and/or counties in which the election is to be held, and held forty-five days from the date of the proclamation. (b) All nominations for elections to fill vacancies held pursuant to this bill are to be by independent nominating petition, which are required to contain a designated number of signatures the lesser of five percent of votes cast in the last preceding gubernatorial election or one thousand five hundred signatures per petition for the office of state senator and seven hundred fifty signatures per petition for the office of member of assembly and filed within fifteen days after the date of the governor's proclamation. A person elected to fill such a vacancy shall take office immediately upon qualification and serve for the remainder of the unexpired term.

name: Exempts public school buildings with instructional space from being designated as early polling locations; allows school districts to decline school building designations as early polling locations.
summary:
• Prohibits a public school building with instructional space from being used as an early polling location.
  • Allows a public school building with no instructional space to be designated as an early polling location, but gives the superintendent a right to decline the designation.

name: Requires at least one form of electronic means to verify voter registration at every polling place.
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Voter registration
summary: This bill requires at least one form of electronic means to verify voter registration at every polling place.

name: Revise certain provisions pertaining to poll watchers.
summary: This bill requires any county board of elections appointing election coordinators and, in the city of New York, the board of elections of the city of New York, must prepare a report detailing assignments of election inspectors and poll clerks, and specifically enumerate the poll sites for which election inspectors or poll clerks have not yet been assigned while detailing the efforts made to date to fill those assignments. These reports must be filed with the state board of elections no later than one month prior to the election at which election coordinators, election inspectors, and poll clerks are to be assigned.

name: Requires the disclosure of the applicant's social security number when registering to vote on an application for a motor vehicle driver's license.
summary:
• Requires a voter registration applicant to provide his or her social security number.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Relates to voting rights expansion, voter registration on election day, expansion of the use of and requirements for absentee voting, creation of a real-time statewide voter registration database, special ballots for election employees, and voter affidavits.
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Voter registration,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary:
• Allows qualified individuals to register to vote on Election Day and provides related guidelines.
  • Allows any voter to vote absentee and provides related guidelines.
  • Allows voters to have their absentee ballot mailed to an address other than their permanent address and provides related guidelines.
  • Allows hospitalized veterans to receive their absentee ballot at the address where they are registered to vote.
  • Provides that the board of inspectors will deliver absentee ballots to residents of certain facilities.
  • Requires the state board of elections to create a single official computerized statewide voter registration database within one year and provides associated guidelines and requirements.
  • Provides that absent proof of fraud, special ballots will be presumed valid and will be cast.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Requires a valid government issued photo identification card be presented when casting a ballot; provides for persons eligible for Medicaid to receive identification cards.
summary: This bill requires a valid government issued photo identification card to be presented when casting a ballot. This bill stipulates the following as valid forms of identification: a New York state driver's license or non-driver ID; a United States passport; an identification card issued by a United States educational institution; a United States military identification card; a government issued medical card or any identification card issued by the United States or the state of New York. Further, this bill mandates that any adult citizen whose income qualifies him or her for Medicaid, as verified in writing by the county's department of social services, is not required to pay any fee for a state-issued identification card.

name: Enacts the "Modernized voter registration act of New York."
summary:
• Establishes automatic voter registration for qualified individuals who do not decline the option.
  • Establishes the automatic voter registration procedure.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Lists agencies to be included in automatic voter registration.
  • Allows the state board of elections to designate additional agencies to serve as voter registration sites and provides guidance for the process.
  • Requires the state board of elections to develop certain procedures related to automatic voter registration.
  • Provides guidance regarding seeking citizenship.
  • Requires the state board of elections to issue program implementation instructions and training, with certain requirements.
  • Requires the board of elections to offer certain voter registration services on their website and by phone, and provides related procedures.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Eliminates the ability of judicial candidates for office who are enrolled in a particular party to automatically be allowed to run as a candidate in another party's primary election.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary: • Removes candidates for judicial office from existing rules regarding running in a party primary.

name: Relates to requests for proposals for voting machines and contracts for the purchase of voting machines or systems.
summary:
• Provides that any commissioner from the state board of elections may solicit requests for proposals for voting systems to be certified for use in New York.
  • Provides requirements for the request for proposals.
  • Lengthens the amount of time the vendor must provide assistance in training and operating the equipment from five to ten years.
  • Lengthens the amount of time the vendor must keep the machines in good working order from five to ten years.

name: Requires the board of elections or a bipartisan committee appointed by such board to conduct a risk-limiting audit of voter verifiable audit records from voting machines or systems within the jurisdiction of such board.
most_recent_action: Taken off notice for cal in s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee of Local Government Committee
summary:
• Provides that the board of elections or a committee will conduct a risk limiting audit including hand review of at least 3% of paper records.
  • Provides that 3% of voter verifiable records from voting machine systems will be audited.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Requires the election of fire district commissioners to take place on the same date and at the same location as elections of school board members.
summary:
• Provides that election of fire district members will occur on the same date, and at the same location, as election of school board members in the municipality.
  • Requires that the Secretary of State of the fire district get approval of the board of elections to prepare ballots for the fire district elections.
  • Changes the opening hour for poll openings for the fire district elections from 6:00PM to 6:00AM.
  • Provides that all electoral procedures related to the fire district election will follow the same procedures as the school board elections.
  • Provides that costs for the election will be borne by the fire district.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Requires the county seat in Allegany county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
summary: • Requires the county seat of Allegany county to have at least one polling place.

name: Relates to an electronically submitted absentee ballot application and absentee ballot.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Cybersecurity
summary:
• Lists how a board of elections will accept requests for a mail ballot.
  • Provides instructions for submitting an absentee ballot by email.
  • Requires the state board of elections to establish and maintain a system for returning a marked absentee ballot by electronic mail and outlines related procedures and requirements.

name: Authorizes absentee ballots in an election to incorporate a village.
summary:
• Establishes that absentee ballots should be as similar as possible to ballots used on Election Day, but with the words "Absentee Ballot" written on them.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Relates to prohibiting election commissioners from being chairs of political parties.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary: This bill prohibits a person from being appointed as Election Commissioner or continue to hold office who is the chair of a political organization in the county.

name: Decreases the number of signatures needed for designating petitions and independent nominations by one-third for political subdivisions, wholly or in part, within a county in which one or more residents have been confirmed to be diagnosed with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) for year two thousand twenty-one.
summary: • Provides that the number of signatures required on designating petitions and independent nominations for those diagnosed with COVID-19 will be reduced by one-third.

name: Relates to empowering the commissioner of a board of elections to order a voting machine audit upon a finding of discrepancies.
summary: This bill empowers the commissioner of a board of elections to order a voting machine audit upon a finding of discrepancies.

name: Allows voters to take photographs of themselves and their ballot, or absentee ballot, while in a privacy booth, and to share and disseminate such photographs on social media.
summary: This bill allows voters to take photographs of themselves and their ballot, or absentee ballot, while in a privacy booth, and to share and disseminate such photographs on social media or through electronic message. Any person who interferes with a voter's photograph is guilty of a misdemeanor.

name: Relates to the appointment of commissioners of elections.
summary:
• Establishes rules regarding appointment of a commissioner when action is not forthcoming from the legislative body, or the legislative body rejects the appointment.
  • Outlines rules for if the legislative body fails to appoint someone in a second certificate of recommendation.

name: Increases the number of days permitted for early voting; permits early voting beginning on the seventeenth day prior to any general, primary, run-off primary or special election.
summary: • Increases the early voting timeline from 2-10 days before the election to 2-17 days before the election.

name: Relates to obtaining written acceptance from candidates for certain county committees; requires written acceptance, duly acknowledged, from such candidates to be so designated to be filed within ten days of designating petitions for certain county committee candidates.
summary: This bill provides that in the case of a designating petition for election to the party position of member of a county committee located within a city having a population of one million or more, a candidate's written acceptance to be so designated, duly acknowledged, must be delivered to the board of elections within ten days of the filing of such designating petition.

name: Reduces the number of signatures for designating and nominating petitions to twenty-five percent of the number required by law, but not numbers in the New York city charter.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures
summary: This bill reduces the numbers of signatures for designating and nominating petitions.

name: Relates to absentee voting in nursing homes and senior citizen residences; requires board of inspectors to deliver and help complete applications for absentee ballots to residents of such facilities.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in voter assistance
summary:
• Adds absentee voting supplies the board of elections should deliver to the board of inspectors.
  • Provides that the board of inspectors should deliver an application for absentee ballot to any resident of a facility requesting one.
  • Provides that the board of inspectors will assist residents with the application and outlines procedures when receiving the application.

name: Designates certain university and community college campuses as polling places for early voting.
summary: This bill designates college campuses which are operated by the state  as early voting sites and polling sites. The bill mandates a polling place designated for registrants on such campus shall be at a location approved by such college or university and that any university that has an on campus dormitory must have an early voting site on campus.

name: Requires the county seat in Seneca county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
summary: This bill requires the county seat in Seneca county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.

name: Requires the board of elections to provide a return postage guaranteed envelope with absentee ballots.
summary: • Requires a postage paid envelope for absentee ballots to be returned.

name: Removes party lines from ballots and has candidates' names appearing only once on a ballot for an office for all elections that are not presidential or gubernatorial.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary:
• Applies certain ballot specifications and voting machine procedures regarding party names and titles in presidential and gubernatorial races.
  • Specifies that the names of all candidates should appear only once per office, except for presidential and gubernatorial races.
  • Specifies an order for the candidate names on the ballot.
  • Makes clarifications to rules regarding establishment of election districts and judicial district conventions.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Career and technology education; directing a district with certain number of electors to be divided into board zones. Effective date.
summary: • Establishes that when a property contiguous to a university with 300 or more active registered voters will have a polling place on the property or at a location approved by the university.

name: Relates to allowing photographs of one's self and one's own ballot while voting, provided that such photographs do not contain any other voter or reveal the contents of any other voter's ballot.
categories: In-person voting and polling places,Legal causes of action
summary:
• Permits voter to photograph and post only themselves voting, or their own ballot, on social media.
  • Prohibits anyone from soliciting a voter to show their ballot or forcing a voter to photograph and/or post their ballot or themselves voting on social media.

name: Enacts the "Modernized voter registration act of New York."
summary:
• Establishes that all qualified individuals will be automatically registered to vote.
  • Lists when a person will be automatically registered to vote.
  • Includes a list of which agencies are "source agencies" and provides criteria for the state board of elections designating additional source agencies.
  • Outlines procedures and requirements for making agreements with source agencies.
  • Outlines procedures for incomplete applications.
  • Outlines procedures for agencies handing and transmitting voter registration information.
  • Provides that the state board of elections will prepare and distribute instructions about program implementation and provides requirements for training.
  • Outlines procedures, guidelines, and requirements for carrying out automatic voter registration.
  • Provides deadlines for creating a format and content of electronic transmissions.
  • Provides that eligible individuals are permitted to register on the day of the election as well as being permitted to register to vote online.
  • Requires the board to make certain information available on the website related to voter registration.
  • Provides procedures and timelines for transmission of online voter registration applications.
  • Requires counties and municipalities to make online services also available through an automated telephone system.
  • Provides guidelines for updating voter registration information online.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to the text of proposed constitutional amendments and questions.
summary:
• Requires the state board of elections to publish a copy of the text of a proposed amendment to the Constitution, with specific requirements.
  • Requires the Attorney General to prepare and deliver an abstract and submission form for the state board of elections at least four months before the election in which the amendment, proposition, or question will be submitted to voters.

name: Makes provisions relating to the joint nomination of candidates for the offices of governor and lieutenant governor; provides candidates be designated jointly either by the state committee or by petition; provides said petition will be valid only if it jointly designates both candidates.
summary: This bill requires joint designation by single vote by the state committee for candidates for the offices of governor and lieutenant governor.

name: Provides that certain cities and towns shall have early voting poll sites within their boundaries and, where practicable, that such sites shall be situated along public transportation routes.
categories: Municipal election procedures,In-person voting and polling places
summary: This bill provides that cities and towns with a population of more than fifty thousand but less than one hundred thousand must have early voting poll sites within their boundaries and, where practicable, those sites be situated along public transportation routes.

name: Establishes no polling place shall be located on the premises of any public or private elementary or secondary school or a school for preschool children.
most_recent_action: Failed in s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee of Local Government Committee
summary: • Codifies that no polling place will be located at a public or private elementary, preschool, or secondary school.

name: Requires boards of elections and bipartisan committees to hand count ballots during recanvass of any ballots cast in election for a position where the difference between the candidates is 10 or less votes, or .5% of the ballots cast for such position, whichever shall be greater.
summary: • Provides that if there is a difference of ten or less votes, or 0.5%, of ballots cast in an election, the recount of all ballots must be conducted by hand.

name: Relates to the opportunity to ballot; removes ability to petition for opportunity to ballot for public office or party position.
summary: • Removes the petition for opportunity to ballot for public office from existing Electoral Code related to nominating petitions.

name: Provides for virtual witnessing of designating and nominating petitions.
summary:
• Provides that witness petitions may be witnessed virtually and provides guidelines.
  • Provides a statement for a virtual witness to fill in and sign.

name: Requires the board of elections to provide Russian interpreters at certain polling locations in cities having a population in excess of one million people.
categories: Language accommodations,In-person voting and polling places
summary: • Requires Russian language interpreters at polling stations in cities with over one million residents where within the county there are 5% or more of people who are first language Russian speakers.

name: Relates to the confidentiality of certain voter registration records.
summary: • Clarifies a voter's email address and telephone number are confidential.

name: Relates to poll watchers for special, town or village elections being held for the sole purpose of a ballot proposal.
summary:
• Adds watchers to ballot proposal elections.
  • Provides that the board of elections may appoint the watchers upon request for ballot proposal elections, and establishes requirements.

name: Relates to election inspectors at poll sites; requires at least one inspector of each major political party to be present at all times polls are open; does not require the same inspectors to be there the entire time.
summary: • Provides clarifying language regarding parties having inspectors at the polls at all times while the polls are open.

name: Provides that school districts may hold elections in any building owned or leased by the district, in addition to any district schoolhouse.
categories: Municipal election procedures,In-person voting and polling places
summary: • Includes building owned or leased by the district existing election code regarding the time of annual school district election meetings.

name: Requires the board of elections in the city of New York to release data on how voters ranked all candidates in a ranked choice election, even if a single candidate received a majority of highest rank votes and the tabulation process was not triggered.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary: • Requires the board of election in New York City to release data on how voters ranked all candidates when using ranked choice voting.

name: Relates to recounts of election votes.
summary:
• Lists circumstances under which to conduct an additional recount before certifying an election.
  • Outlines procedures for the additional recount.
  • Lists who should pay for the recount under different scenarios.
  • Lists who may request a recount, under what circumstances, and what the process should be.
  • Outlines timelines, notification requirements, participation requirements.

name: Relates to certain absentee ballots received by a board of elections that do not bear or display a dated postmark.
summary:
• Requires the board of elections to include a bar code with absentee ballot envelopes calling the absentee ballot to be tracked through the post office.
  • Specifies that absentee ballots with no cancellation mark to indicate when they were mailed should be counted if it is received by the seventh day after election day.

name: Permits voter registration within 10 days of a primary, general, or special election.
summary:
• Changes the deadline for a postmark on an absentee ballot application from 25 days before the election to the 10th day before the election, and the receipt deadline from the 20th day before the election to the 5th day before the election.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to an electronically submitted absentee ballot application.
summary:
• Provides that in person delivery of ballots must official no later than the day before the election.
  • Furnishes a list of ways a board of elections must accept an absentee ballot application and provides publicity guidelines.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to establishing a secure website and mobile application that allows voters who have submitted an application for an absentee ballot to view the current status of their application and absentee ballot.
summary:
• Requires the state board of elections to establish an electronic tool to allow registered voters to view the status of absentee ballot applications.
  • Specifies requirements for the electronic tool.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Allows election commissioners flexibility to designate how many election inspectors are needed at poll sites.
summary: This bill provides election commissioners flexibility to designate how many election inspectors are needed at poll sites. Nevertheless, each poll site must have a minimum of four election inspectors unless a poll site is located in a district with fewer than one hundred fifty registered voters, in which case there may be a minimum of two election inspectors.

name: Relates to absentee ballots; provides an electronic application to request an absentee ballot.
summary: This bill provides for an electronic application to request an absentee ballot.

name: Includes a statement on the envelopes of ballots for absentee voters and special presidential voters for signature affirmation.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary:
• Adds a sentence reminding absentee voters to sign the affirmation envelope.
  • Adds a sentence reminding special presidential voters to sign the affirmation envelope.

name: Authorizes any registered voter to vote by absentee ballot and to elect to permanently vote by absentee ballot.
summary: This bill authorizes any registered voter to vote by absentee ballot and to elect to permanently vote by absentee ballot.

name: Prohibits the at large election of any member of the governing or legislative body of a town or village by electors of such town or village; requires the election of such members by wards; repeals certain provisions related thereto.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary:
• Requires the board of trustees of villages to provide for the election of trustees by ward or alter ward boundaries.
  • Prohibits members of town or village governing or legislative bodies from being elected on an at-large system.
  • Requires the county board of elections to divide each town or village into wards, with specifications about the number and the procedure.
  • Requires all wards to be reapportioned at the same time as congressional, assembly, and senate districts are reapportioned.
  • Outlines procedures in case of delay in setting up the ward system.
  • Directs the attorney general to submit reports to the governor and legislature about towns and villages granted exemptions on April 1, 2024, 2025 and 2026, with specific information requirements.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Moves the date of the presidential primary to the same date as the state primaries.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary: Specifies that in years when a presidential and vice-presidential candidate will be elected, an additional primary election will be held on the fourth Tuesday in June (a change from the first Tuesday in February).

name: Requires counties with a population of one million or more to have at least one polling place in each town and city of such counties.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary: • Requires that in counties with a population of one million or more there be a polling place in each town and city.

name: Increases the term of office of an election commissioner from two to four years beginning January first of each odd numbered year.
summary: • Extends the term of office for an election commissioner from two years to four years and removes exceptions.

name: Enacts the Disaster Voting Relief Act; provides for temporary voting procedures in a state of emergency.
summary:
• Provides that the governor may delay an election in a municipality if there is a state of emergency or federal disaster declaration.
  • Provides guidelines for resuming voting.
  • Provides that a voter in an affected area may vote absentee.
  • Outlines guidelines for administering voting and a canvass in such circumstances.

name: Relates to the appointment of commissioners of elections; provides that once a party recommends a person for commissioner of elections the local legislative body shall automatically approve the appointment of such person.
summary:
• Provides that the legislature must automatically approve commissioners of elections recommended by a party.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Requires that subpoenas issued relating to election matters be served with a separate informational sheet that summarizes why the subpoena has been issued.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary:
• Requires a subpoena being issued in relation to election matters be served with a separate informational sheet with certain information.
  • Specifies how the informational sheet should be formatted affixed to the subpoena.

name: Provides voters an opportunity to cure deficiencies regarding affidavit ballots.
summary: This bill stipulates that once a board of elections determines, at or before canvassing, that an affidavit ballot envelope is incomplete or is in any other manner defective, the board must, within one day, send to the affidavit ballot voter's address, a notice explaining the reason for such rejection and the procedure to cure the rejection. The board must also contact the voter by either electronic mail or telephone, if that contact information is available to the board. The voter may then cure the aforesaid defects by filing a duly signed affirmation attesting to the same information required by the affirmation envelope and attesting that the signer of the affirmation is the same person who submitted such affidavit ballot. The board must include a form of such affirmation with the notice to the voter. A cure affirmation shall be filed with the board no later than seven business days after the board's mailing of such curable rejection notice. Provided the board determines that such affirmation addresses the curable defect, the rejected ballot shall be reinstated and duly canvassed. If the board of elections is split as to the sufficiency of the cure affirmation, the envelope must be set aside for three days and then canvassed unless the board is directed otherwise by a court order. When the board of elections invalidates an affidavit ballot and the defect is not curable, the voter must be notified by mail sent within three business days of such rejection.

name: Creates a pilot program to provide for an instant runoff voting method to be used in up to ten local governments, selected by the state board of elections, in election years 2024 and 2025; requires report to state legislature.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary:
• Proposes a pilot program using ranked choice voting in 2024 and 2025 in certain local government elections.
  • Defines ranked choice voting and local government.
  • Provides that the state board of elections will choose 10 pilot locations each year.
  • Requires specific rules for the format of the ballot in ranked choice voting. 
  • Outlines rules for determining a winner in ranked choice voting.
  • Requires the board of elections to conduct a voter education campaign in selected areas about ranked choice voting.
  • Subjects all ranked choice voting elections to existing election laws.

name: Lowers the voting age to 16 years and requires that students receive education in civics and be given the opportunity to register to vote in the classroom.
summary:
• Lowers the voting age to 16 for any election.
  • Provides that a voter registration applicant must be 16 by December 31 of the year they register.
  • Requires all ninth and higher grades to have civic education with certain guidelines.
  • Provides instructions for registering high school students to vote at school.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Allows for a voter to apply for an absentee ballot for any reason.
summary:
• Provides that a voter may request an absentee ballot for any reason.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Establishes an electronic military ballot application and military ballot transmittal system through which applicants may apply for a military ballot and return a marked military ballot, online.
summary:
• Directs the state board of elections to establish and maintain an electronic military ballot application and transmittal system and provides detailed instructions.
  • Requires each county election board to be able to receive these electronic ballots and applications.
  • Establishes that the electronic filing date will be the date the application or ballot should be considered filed.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes complying changes.

name: Requires the board of elections to provide email notifications to voters whenever they change the location of a polling place.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary: • Adds a requirement to email notifications to voters when there is a changed polling place location.

name: Lowers the voting age to 16 years and requires that students receive education in civics and be given the opportunity to register to vote in the classroom.
summary: This bill lowers the voting age to 16 years and requires that students receive education in civics and be given the opportunity to register to vote in the classroom.

name: Voting Districts And Officials -- Polling Place Cap
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary:
• Allows a board controlling a public school building to file a request for cancellation of designating the building as a polling place.
  • Requires the appropriate body to cancel the designation.
  • Allows trustees or a board of eduction to designate a location within district boundaries, that is not a school building, a location to conduct the annual meeting and election.

name: Relates to voting rights including voter protection, voter's bill of rights, illegal voter suppression and intimidation, vote dilution, and preclearance.
summary:
• Provides that a person is guilty of voter intimidation under specific circumstances, listing the circumstances.
  • Requires a Voter's Bill of Rights be posted at each poling place and distributed with official sample ballots.
  • Furnishes the language for the Voter's Bill of Rights and requires it in other languages in certain circumstances.
  • Requires the Board to create a manual of uniform polling place procedures and for local election officials to implement it and ensure that it is available.
  • Includes information to be included in the manual.
  • Clarifies what illegal voter suppression includes and includes penalties.
  • Establishes what constitutes vote dilution.
  • Outlines when pre clearance is required and outlines procedures.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Provides for the re-enfranchisement of voters with felony convictions by repealing certain provisions in the election law.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Voter registration
summary:
• Removes the provision requiring a voter's registration be canceled if he or she was convicted of a felony.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Relates to pre-recorded political messages; prohibits automatic dialing-announcing devices unless a live operator provides certain information in the first thirty seconds; requires registration; authorizes attorney general to investigate violations.
most_recent_action: referred to consumer affairs and protection
summary:
• Requires parties to have a live operator on the line within 30 seconds of an automated political message.
  • Outlines what information the operator must provide, how automatic calling must be carried out, and attorney general powers.
  • Provides that violation is punishable by a civil fine.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Relates to the registration status of voters.
summary: This bill mandates that an election officer who willfully cancels a voter's registration in violation or refuses to allow an individual to vote due to their inactive status is guilty of a felony.

name: Requires the county seat in Allegany county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary: This bill requires the county seat in Allegany county to have at least one polling place designated for early voting.

name: Moves the date of the presidential primary to the same date as the state primaries.
summary: • Provides that in presidential election years an additional primary will be held on the fourth Tuesday in June (was the first Tuesday in February).

name: Provides protections against illegal voter purging.
summary:
• Establishes procedures for mailers potentially related to a challenge.
  • Authorizes any person, other than an election inspector or clerk, to challenge the qualifications of a voter.
  • Establishes procedures, including the affidavit, for submitting a challenge.
  • Furnishes questions to be asked of the applicant.
  • Specifies that information about citizenship will not be retained, and specifies procedures related to citizenship.
  • Adds oath-related, and other, reporting requirements in a challenge.

name: Makes the following participating agencies for purposes of agency assisted voter registration: public libraries, local housing authorities, and public high schools; directs the state board of elections to promulgate rules and regulations for implementation.
categories: Oversight and accountability,In-person voting and polling places
summary: • Requires all public libraries, local housing authorities, and public high schools to offer voter registration forms to all qualified individuals in their initial interactions, except high schools, where they should be offered when seniors graduate.

name: Allows a voter to request an absentee ballot where such person is concerned of contracting or spreading a disease that may cause illness to the voter or to other members of the public.
summary: This bill allows a voter to request an absentee ballot where such person is concerned with contracting or spreading a disease that may cause illness to the voter or to other members of the public.

name: Requires the board of elections to provide the public with free and timely access to updated unofficial election results.
summary:
• Specifies that the board of elections must post running totals of unofficial results for each election district.
  • Requires the board of elections to make absentee results available upon completing the canvass of absentee, military, and special ballots and post them in a public place and online.

name: Relates to instant run-off elections in the city of New York for any city-wide elections for the office of mayor, public advocate or comptroller.
summary: This bill requires that New York city-wide primary elections for the office of mayor, public advocate, or comptroller, in which more than two candidates appear on the ballot for the same office, be conducted by instant run-off voting. The bill defines "instant run-off voting" to mean an election in which voters may rank up to five candidates in order of preference, first, second and so on, and in which tabulation proceeds in up to two rounds as follows: If the candidate with the most votes receives a vote total less than fifty percent plus one vote, the two candidates with the most votes proceed to a second round of ballot counting. In the second round, each ballot is counted as a vote for whichever of the two advancing candidates is ranked higher by that voter. Any ballot that does not rank either of the two advancing candidates would not be counted in the second round. The candidate with the most votes in the second round is then declared the winner. The bill requires the portion of the ballot pertaining to elections conducted by instant run-off voting allow a voter to rank candidates in order of choice in a way that is clear and easy to understand and include the opportunity to rank no more than one write-in candidate. The bill also requires ballots be designed so that a voter may mark their first choice in the same manner as for offices not elected by instant run-off voting.

name: Relates to nominations for public office without designation.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary: • Clarifies that an existing code regarding people being nominated for public office at a primary election includes contested and uncontested primaries.

name: Requires voting machines or systems approved by the state board of elections to: permit a voter to review their marked paper ballot; retain such ballot for the purposes of a manual audit; and count only a voter's handmade mark except when certain accessibility exceptions apply.
summary: This bill requires voting machines or systems approved by the Board of Elections to permit a voter to review their marked paper ballot, retain ballots for the purposes of a manual audit, and count only a voter's handmade mark.

name: Requires that candidates for certain offices be residents and registered voters in the district containing the public office or party position sought at certain times during the electoral process.
summary:
• Outlines residency requirements for candidates, including allowing localities to enact stricter requirements.
  • Specifies that a candidate for county committee must only be a resident of the Assembly district containing the election district.
  • Specifies candidates must be residents in the district by the time of the party caucus.
  • Specifies that failure to meet residency requirements renders a nomination void.
  • Exempts candidates for Congress, state assembly, state senate or judicial candidates for the Supreme Court from the specified district residency requirements.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Provides for the appointment and removal for cause of commissioners of election; provides for removal for cause by the board of elections and/or the governor.
summary:
• Changes the term of election commissioner from two years to four years, to begin February 15 of the first alternate odd numbered year.
  • Eliminates permissions allowing the county legislative body to determine the length of an election commissioner's term.
  • Changes rules regarding appointment of an election commissioner when an appointment is not forthcoming from the legislative body.
  • Outlines rules for removing an election commissioner.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Makes special provisions for nominations and elections for county, town or village public offices and special elections for public office to be filled at any election to be held in the year 2021.
summary: This bill makes special provisions for nominations and elections for county, town, and village public offices and special elections for public office to be filled at any election to be held in the year 2021, including the allowance of remote and proxy voting, absentee ballots, and the processes for counting of the large number of absentee votes.

name: Relates to providing timely written notice of closed primary party rules to newly registered voters; defines the terms "newly registered voter" and "written notice" and sets out what information the board of elections is required to provide to newly registered voters about closed primaries.
summary: This bill provides to newly registered voters, in a timely manner, an explanation as to what a closed primary election is, how party affiliation is related to said closed primary, and the dates for which they need to enroll in a party, if necessary. The bill defines the term "newly registered voter" means any person in the state of New York who has registered to vote after the effective date of this subdivision. The bill also defines "written notice" as a statement from the commissioner of the state board of elections.

name: Requires local boards of elections to verify the number of enrolled members of a party in an election district and reject all petitions where there are no enrolled members of a party in such district.
summary: • Requires local boards to verify the number of enrolled party members in districts and reject petitions where there are no enrolled party members.

name: Provides for the state board of elections to prepare and distribute to each voter a ballot pamphlet for every general election; provides for contents thereof and makes numerous related provisions including the distribution of information relating to each ballot proposal that is submitted to a statewide vote at such general election; permits any person eligible to vote on any ballot proposal to institute a proceeding as to the factual accuracy of statements or constitutional amendments.
summary:
• Describes the purpose for creating a ballot pamphlet and requires the state board of elections to develop and prepare ballot pamphlets.
  • Outlines what must be included in the ballot pamphlet and timelines.
  • Outlines requirements for a committee that will develop materials for the ballot pamphlet.
  • Provides notification requirements.
  • Provides guidelines for the committee accepting and rejecting submissions.
  • Outlines state immunity with respect to the ballot pamphlet.
  • Outlines printing and distribution guidelines.
  • Outlines guidelines regarding proceedings as to the factual accuracy of information in the ballot pamphlet.
  • Adds five copies of each ballot pamphlet to the list of items the board of elections must provide each county.

name: Relates to the procedure for filling a vacancy in the office of state senator or in the office of member of assembly; allows for independent nominating petitions to be presented and provides for a special election to be held forty-five days from the date of the governor making a proclamation for a special election.
summary: • Outlines guidelines and timelines for filling a vacancy for state senator or member of the assembly through popular election.

name: Reduces the number of signatures required for designating and nominating petitions to one and one half per centum or thirty percent of the signature threshold numbers required by law.
summary: This bill reduces the number of signatures required for designating and nominating petitions to 1.5 per centum or 30% of the signature threshold, whichever is less.

name: Provides that a candidate who files a certificate of acceptance for an office for which there have been filed certificates or petitions designating more than one candidate for the nomination of any party, may thereafter file a certificate of declination not later than the seventh day after the primary election.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access deadlines
summary: • Provides that candidates whose party filed to designate more than one person for an office may file a certificate of acceptance or declination by the seventh day after the primary election (for all other candidates it is four days).

name: Decreases the number of signatures needed for designating petitions and independent nominations by one-third for political subdivisions, wholly or in part, within a county in which one or more residents have been confirmed to be diagnosed with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) for year two thousand twenty-one.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot measures (initiative and referendum),Municipal election procedures
summary: This bill decreases the number of signatures needed for designating petitions and independent nominations by one-third for political subdivisions, wholly or in part, within a county in which one or more residents have been confirmed to be diagnosed with COVID-19 for year 2021.

name: Relates to Eastchester fire district elections; follows provisions of election law instead of town law for elections.
summary:
• Provides that elections in the Eastchester Fire District will take place on the Tuesday following the first Monday in November.
  • Requires candidates for Eastchester Fire District to file with the Westchester County board of elections.
  • Provides rules for filling vacancies in the Eastchester Fire District.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to instant run-off elections in the city of New York for any city-wide elections for the office of mayor, public advocate or comptroller.
summary:
• Provides for instant run-off elections when there are more than two candidates for city primary elections for mayor, public advocate, or comptroller.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Provides rules for tabulation of the vote.
  • Provides ballot rules for instant run-off elections.
  • Provides for ballot counting and sorting methods.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to requiring boards of elections to include the number of registration forms distributed to and returned by each agency assisting with voter registration in their annual reports; personally identifiable information about the registrants shall not be collected or included in the report.
summary:
• Requires board of elections annual reports to include the number of registration forms distributed and returned.
  • Specifies that personal voter information must not be included in the report.

name: Relates to restricting election day duties of board of elections employees in the city of New York running for elected party positions; provides that no board of elections employee in the city of New York shall engage in any election day operations or management within any assembly district in which he or she is also a candidate for an elected party position.
summary: This bill restricts election day duties of board of elections employees in the city of New York running for elected party positions and provides that no board of elections employee in the city of New York shall engage in any election day operations or management within any assembly district in which he or she is also a candidate for an elected party position.

name: Relates to the acceptance of nominations for office or for a party position and the constitutional and statutory requirements for such office or position.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary: This bill requires that nominees for office affirm they are a citizen of the State of New York, eligible to be elected to the office or position they are nominated for, and, if elected will meet the constitutional or statutory qualifications thereof or, with respect to judicial office, will meet such qualifications within thirty days of the commencement of the term of such office.

name: Relates to an electronically submitted absentee ballot application.
summary:
• Furnishes a list of ways the board of elections will accept absentee ballot applications, and outlines related requirements.
  • Requires the board of elections website to include certain information about returning an application.
  • Provides that applications returned electronically will be considered an original application and do not need a paper submission.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Allows photographs of one's self and one's own ballot while voting.
summary:
• Allows voters to photograph only themselves while voting.
  • Provides a misdemeanor offense for someone who forces an individual to photograph and/or post their ballot, or themselves voting, on social media.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Establishes a nonpartisan poll monitoring program.
summary:
• Provides that nonpartisan election monitors may be appointed by a civic organization or ballot issue committee.
  • Allows for two monitors per polling place by each organization.
  • Provides rules for filing, including rules for the filing statement, and a filing deadline.
  • Clarifies when and how the board of elections may deny a request for nonpartisan election monitors.
  • Creates timelines and guidelines for processing such requests.
  • Outlines credential identification requirements for poll watchers and the content of the credential badge.
  • Outlines rules of who may be appointed a watcher and what watchers may do at the polls. 
  • Provides for substitution of poll monitors.
  • Outlines rules for the number of watchers at a polling place.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: Allows voters to take photographs of themselves and their ballot, or absentee ballot, while in a privacy booth, and to share and disseminate such photographs on social media.
summary: This bill allows voters to take photographs of themselves and their own ballot, or absentee ballot, while in a privacy booth. The bill allows voters to share and disseminate their photographs on social media. The bill also states that person who interferes with a voter's photograph is guilty of a misdemeanor.

name: Requires electors to vote for the presidential and vice presidential candidate who were nominated by the political party that nominated the presidential elector.
summary:
• Directs each electoral college elector to cast their vote for president and Vice President for candidates nominated by the political party that nominated the elector.
  • Establishes that refusal will constitute a resignation and the vote will not be recorded, and a replacement will be named.
  • Requires ballots used by the elector to bear their name.

name: Relates to promoting inmate voter registration and voting by incarcerated people; requires the department of corrections and community supervision to distribute a voter information guide and hold voter information and registration clinics for incarcerated people every other year.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Voter registration
summary:
• Establishes that incarcerated individuals in a state or local correctional facility are considered residents of the address they had prior to imprisonment.
  • Codifies that a voter's registration will not be canceled while he or she is incarcerated.
  • Requires the establishment of a program to promote voter registration and voting by incarcerated people and outlines what the program should include, and how it should be administered.

name: Provides for automatic voter registration; and establishes a task force to study and make recommendations on the implementation of such automatic voter registration.
summary:
• Establishes automatic voter registration for qualified individuals who do not decline the option.
  • Establishes the automatic voter registration procedure.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Lists agencies to be included in automatic voter registration.
  • Allows the state board of elections to designate additional agencies to serve as voter registration sites and provides guidance for the process.
  • Requires the state board of elections to develop certain procedures related to automatic voter registration.
  • Provides guidance regarding seeking citizenship.
  • Requires the state board of elections to issue program implementation instructions and training, with certain requirements.
  • Sets September 1, 2022 as the deadline for source agencies and the state board to enter into an agreement, and full compliance by January 1, 2023.
  • Makes certain exceptions.
  • Makes complying changes.
  • Lists certain requirements for colleges and universities in compliance with source agency rules.
  • Establishes that those affirming they registered with a source agency, but missing information on Election Day, are to be permitted to cast an affidavit ballot and outlines related procedures.
  • Specifies that specific transmitted data should not be considered public record.

name: Allows poll workers to be from any political party.
summary: • Provides that if a political party does not have enough applicants for election inspector or poll clerk, appointments may be made of individuals who are not associated with any major party.

name: Prohibits political candidates from being nominated by more than one party for any public office.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary: • Provides that a person cannot be nominated for public office or a party position if the person has already accepted another party's nomination for such position.

name: Prohibits election commissioners and deputy election commissioners from holding a publicly elected office or from being the respective chair of the county democratic or republican committees.
summary: This bill prohibits Election Commissioners and Deputy Election Commissioners from holding a publicly elected office or from being the respective Chair of the County Democratic or Republican Party or Committees unless the person is currently serving as Election Commissioner or Deputy Election Commissioner at the time the bill becomes law.

name: Authorizes boards of elections to establish absentee ballot drop-off locations.
summary:
• Defines terms related to absentee ballot drop boxes.
  • Authorizes each board of elections to establish absentee ballot drop box drop off locations, with specific requirements.
  • Authorizes the state board of elections to create rules and procedures for absentee ballot drop box implementation and security.
  • Allows voters to drop off absentee ballots in drop box in their city or county.
  • Establishes rules for drop off, collection, and counting deadlines.

name: Relates to designating early polling places.
summary:
• Removes the provision that polling places may not be locations that hold a license to see alcohol for consumption in the premises.
  • Prohibits public school buildings from being designated early polling locations.
  • Allows buildings receiving more than $1 million in annual state grant funding to be used as polling places, with some exceptions.

name: Exempts public school buildings from being designated as early polling locations.
summary: • Provides that no public school building will be designated an early polling place.

name: Authorizes any registered voter to vote by absentee ballot; establishes a voter's right to cast a final vote on election day to nullify an earlier or absentee vote.
summary:
• Provides that any qualified voter may vote by absentee ballot.
  • Removes required reasons for voting absentee.
  • Provides that any voter who voted absentee or early may vote on Election Day and have that vote be counted instead.

name: Requires absentee ballots to be provided to all qualified voters and relates to the delivery of absentee ballots.
summary:
• Requires the board of elections to mail an absentee ballot and return postage envelope to every qualified voter in the county or city.
  • Requires the ballots be mailed to the voter's registered address.
  • Provides specifications on deadlines.
  • Makes exceptions for uncontested elections.
  • Allows voters to request envelopes be mailed to a different address.

name: Extends the timeframe during which a proceeding with respect to a primary, convention, meeting of a party committee or caucus shall be instituted to twenty-five days after the holding of such primary or convention or the filing of the certificate of nominations made at such caucus or meeting of a party committee.
summary: • Amends the number of days after a primary, convention, meeting of a party committee, or caucus to hold a proceeding, from within ten days after the event to within 25 days after the event.

name: Allows a U.S. citizen, who is seventeen years of age, to vote in a primary election, including presidential, if he or she will turn eighteen by the date of the corresponding general election.
summary: • Codifies that seventeen-year-olds who will be eighteen at the time of the general election may vote in the associated primary election.

name: Relates to the procedure for filling a vacancy in the office of state senator or in the office of member of assembly; allows for independent nominating petitions to be presented and provides for a special election to be held forty-five days from the date of the governor making a proclamation for a special election.
summary:
• Outlines procedures for filling a vacancy through popular election for state senator or assembly member.
  • Establishes related candidate petition requirements, timelines, and procedures.
  • Requires a person winning the related vacancy election to take office immediately.

name: Improves the issuing of absentee ballots.
summary:
• Removes a deadline for voters to mail back an absentee ballot.
  • Broadens the ways a voter may request an absentee ballot to include "written instrument" with a voter's signature.
  • Changes procedural deadlines for mailing an absentee ballot.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relates to the crimes of fraud in connection with a primary election, caucus or convention, and criminal impersonation in the first degree where a person pretends to be an elected official or candidate for an elected office and acts by impersonating such an elected official, or candidate or campaign for such an elected office, by communication by internet website or electronic means, with intent to obtain a benefit or injure or defraud another; requires social media companies to establish practi
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
summary:
• Adds pretending to be an elected official or candidate with intent to benefit or injure, by communication through electronic means, to penal code.
  • Provides that anyone acting or attempting to act to affect the results of an election will be subject to civil penalty, giving the state board of elections the authority.
  • Provides the state board of election with authority to seek injunctive relief to require a social media company to address a complaint requiring investigation and cessation of criminal impersonation in connection with elections.
  • Provides that a social media company receiving a complaint of first degree criminal impersonation in connection to elections must close all fraudulent accounts within 24 hours of notification.

name: Authorizes persons in control of public school buildings to request the cancellation of the designation of such building as a polling place.
summary: • Removes public school buildings from being an exception in requirements for polling places in public buildings.

name: Allows delivery of an application for an absentee ballot to the board of elections through and on the day of the election.
summary: This bill allows the delivery of an application for an absentee ballot to the Board of Elections throughout the day of an election.

name: Relating to requests for absentee ballots.
summary: •  Changes the timespan for receiving absentee ballot applications from 7-30 days before the elections, to a simple deadline of 7 days before the election.

name: Provides for a separate line at polling places for persons with disabilities.
summary: This bill requires a separate line be provided for people with disabilities, with seating provided, for entrance to the polls.

name: Adds a voter's e-mail address and telephone number to the information contained on a voter registration application that is not available for public inspection.
summary: This bill adds a voter's e-mail address and telephone number to the information contained on a voter registration application that is not available for public inspection.

name: Relates to annual reports of the boards of elections; requires such reports be made available on the boards' websites; requires that the reports include specific performance metrics.
most_recent_action: Taken off notice for cal in s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee of Local Government Committee
summary: • Requires the state board of elections to make public their annual report with certain timelines and content requirements.

name: Prohibits conflicts of interest among board of elections employees; prevents a board of elections employee from remaining on the board of elections payroll while also a candidate for an office who has an election overseen by the board at which they are employed; allows for a member to remain on the board until 90 days before the general election if there is no primary for such office.
summary:
• Prohibits actions creating a conflict of interest for board of election employees including: investing in a company providing services to a candidate in that district, or investing in a company who is a vendor selling voting equipment.
  • Provides penalties.
  • Prohibits a board of elections employee from working for a candidate or being a candidate in the district holding the election.
  • Provides related "leave without pay" policies.
  • Provides that a candidate employed by the board of elections who is not running in a primary election may remain on the payroll for up to 90 days before the general election.

name: Relates to town elections and permissive referendums.
most_recent_action: Committee recommended measure be held for further study
categories: Ballot measures (initiative and referendum),Municipal election procedures
summary:
• Clarifies in which election a petition will be submitted; general, special, or biennial town election.
  • Establishes timelines clarifying to which election a petition will be submitted.

name: Provides that the determination of the board of elections to issue a voter an absentee, military or special ballot shall only be challenged by a judicial proceeding in supreme court and that the board of elections and the voter whose application is challenged shall be necessary parties.
summary:
