In addition, the bill also requires an initiated amendment petition to be filed a year before the next general election, and the signatures for an initiated amendment petition must be submitted by the second Tuesday in March of a general election year.

name: Authorize school boards to modify the length of terms for members to allow for holding joint elections.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 27, 2023 H.J. 547
summary:
As amended, this bill:

  • Provides that a school board may increase initial prescribed terms of office from three to four years or decrease them from three to two years, with certain procedural requirements.
  • Provides that a school board resolution to increase or decrease initial school board terms is subject to a referendum of 5% of registered voters, and outlines related timelines and procedures.
  • Outlines procedures for if a resolution changing initial school board terms is approved.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Provide for an electronic system to update voter registration information.
summary: This bill provides that those with a South Dakota nondriver identification card may submit changes to their voter registration form electronically through an electronic voter registration interface maintained by the Office of the Secretary of State in order to update changes of last name, residence address, mailing address, telephone number, email address, previous voter registration information, party affiliation, and willingness to serve as an election worker.

name: Revise the qualifications to be a member of a county recount board.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 09, 2023 H.J. 520
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the requirements for the composition and membership in a county recount board.

name: Enhance the penalty for petition circulation perjury.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 07, 2023 S.J. 442
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Legal causes of action
summary:
As amended, this bill:

  • Directs that before filing a petition initiating a constitutional amendment, each petition circulator must sign a verification attesting that the circulator personally circulated the petition; that the circulator is not attesting to any signature from another person; that the circulator is a state resident; that to the best of the circulator's knowledge, petition signers are qualified voters from the appropriate county; and that no state statute was knowingly violated.
  • Establishes that no one may sign a candidate nominating petition before Jan. 1 in the year of the election, as well as establishing additional rules for signing petitions.
  • Requires a formal declaration of the candidate before circulating petitions, and requires the signed candidate declaration to accompany the petition, including the original declaration upon filing of the petitions.
  • Prohibits the candidate from notarizing the petition verification.
  • Provides that a circulator who falsely attests to the verification is guilty of a felony.
  • Requires a nominating petition to be a self-contained sheet of paper.
  • Allows a person registered with a party affiliation to sign a nominating petition for an independent or nonpolitical candidate if the person has not previously signed a petition for that office.

name: Revise the process for nominating candidates for lieutenant governor and to make related technical changes.
most_recent_action: Senate Failed to concur, no committee appointed, Passed, YEAS 29, NAYS 4. S.J. 446
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties,Ballot access deadlines
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires a gubernatorial candidate to choose a lieutenant governor and certify it with the secretary of state by 5pm on the second Tuesday in August of the election year.
  • Requires the secretary of state to create appropriate related rules and forms.
  • Outlines procedures for withdrawal of the lieutenant governor candidate.
  • Lists which seats must be nominated at a party's state convention.
  • Provides that political party conventions may only occur in even numbered years.
  • Provides that a petition for a party's candidate for attorney general and secretary of state must be signed by at least one-half percent of voters who voted for that party's gubernatorial candidate in the last election.
  • Provides clarifying edits.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Proposing and submitting to the electors at the next general election an amendment to the Constitution of the State of South Dakota, updating references to certain officeholders and persons.
most_recent_action: Delivered to the Secretary of State S.J. 442
summary: As introduced, this bill proposes and submits to voters to add a constitutional amendment at the next general election updating language references for certain officeholders and people.

name: Modify provisions for a statewide runoff election.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 07, 2023 H.J. 499
summary: As amended, this bill changes provisions for runoff primary elections including changing the date to eight week after the first primary election and requires the election to be held in the same manner as the first election.

name: Revise certain provisions pertaining to poll watchers.
most_recent_action: House of Representatives Failed to concur, no committee appointed, Passed, YEAS 68, NAYS 2. H.J. 501
summary:
As amended, this bill:

  • Clarifies that the clerk of court must send names of those declared mentally incompetent, those who are imprisoned, and those who are publishing in an obituary to the county auditor.
  • Specifies that the secretary of state will match voter registration records against death records.
  • Adds the social security death index and the social security administration master death file to records the secretary of state must examine, and specifies that verification must be done monthly.
  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Require the continued maintenance of the official list of candidates prior to an election.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 07, 2023 S.J. 442
summary: • Requires the continued maintenance of the official list of candidates before an election.

name: Provide for the election of State Brand Board members.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Tabled, Passed, YEAS 9, NAYS 0.
categories: Oversight and accountability,Special election procedures,State appropriations
summary:
AS introduced, this bill:

  • Creates a "State Brand Board" for the purpose of tabulating votes, and creating and distributing nominating petitions, preparing and mailing ballots.
  • Provides that the board consists of five members and provides for nomination of individuals, timelines, eligibility, dissemination of information, and terms of office.
  • Outlines ballot, voting, and counting requirements. 
  • Provides all costs of a State Brand Board election are the responsibility of the Board.
  • Clarifies that the State Brand Board is attached to the Department of Agriculture and Natural Resources for reporting purposes.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Require a percentage of signatures on a petition to initiate a constitutional amendment to be obtained from each legislative district.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 8, NAYS 1.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a constitutional amendment proposed by initiative to be presented via petition signed by at least 10% of qualified voters equal to at least 10% of total votes cast for governor in the last election. The bill clarifies that no more than 1/35th of the number of required signatures may be counted from any one legislative district.

name: Revise certain provisions pertaining to the destruction of ballots and pollbooks after an election.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 9, NAYS 0.
summary: As introduced, this bill modifies ballot and pollbook destruction procedures including changing the retention date to 182 days after the election date. The ballots and pollbooks may not be destroyed if the any civil action has commenced or they are being used in litigative discovery.

name: Modify the requirements for eligibility to vote by absentee ballot.
most_recent_action: House of Representatives Reconsidered, Failed, YEAS 30, NAYS 39. H.J. 346
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Enforcement against non-officials
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that a voter is qualified to vote absentee if they expect to be absent outside the county on the day of the election; or are unable to cast a ballot at their designated polling place because of disability, illness, observance of religious holiday, attendance at school or university, or due to employment reasons; or if the voter is an absent uniformed services voter or an overseas voter.
  • Establishes that absentee voting begins 46 days before the election.
  • Prohibits a county auditor from establishing, placing, or allowing to be established or placed, an absentee ballot drop box within the county auditor's county.
  • Establishes that an absentee ballot may only be returned to the office of the individual in charge of elections by mail, in person, or through an authorized messenger.
  • Defines "absentee ballot drop box."
  • Provides that violations are a misdemeanor.

name: Authorize legislative intervention into certain cases pertaining to election law.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 7, NAYS 4. H.J. 4
summary: As amended, this bill permits the Executive Board of the Legislative Research Council, on behalf of the state legislature, to legally intervene when a state election law’s constitutionality or the construction of validity is brought into question and the legislature is not a party. The Executive Board may seek counsel other than the attorney general if the Board deems the attorney general cannot adequately represent it.

name: Require certain reviews and updating of voter registration records and data sharing.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 9, NAYS 0.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the names of persons who are mentally incompetent, deceased, or have been excused from jury duty due to moving, being deceased, or found not to be U.S. citizens be removed from state and county voter registration lists on a monthly basis.

name: Require postelection audits.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 11, NAYS 0.
categories: Voting equipment,Audits,Transparency,Enforcement against officials,Testing and certification
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Establishes that within ten days after each election a post election audit of ballots cast is required.
  • Arranges for the person in charge of the election to establish a date, time, and place, with the stipulation that the audit be held within five business days after the order for audit is made.
  • Requires the person in charge of the election to notify the secretary of state of the audit time, date, and place, which the secretary of state must post on the secretary's website.
  • Requires public notice be published of the post election audit by 48 hours before the audit begins in certain media and websites.
  • Establishes that all audits must be open to the public.
  • Requires the audit to be conducted in at least 25% of election precincts, or at least two precincts, whichever is greater, for jurisdictions using automatic tabulating or electronic balloting equipment.
  • Requires the audit to be conducted in at least 10% of precincts, or at least two precincts, whichever is greater, for jurisdictions not using automatic tabulating or electronic balloting equipment.
  • Outlines guidelines and instructions for conducting the audit and clarifies actions to take in the case of certain discrepancies.
  • Provides guidelines for when an order for a manual hand count of each paper ballot must be made.
  • Instructs that where automatic tabulating or electronic balloting systems are not used, the audit must be conducted via manual hand count of each ballot for all races and ballot issues in the selected precincts.
  • Specifies that a post election audit is complete when the audit conducted by comparison results in no discrepancies or differences, or when the manual hand count arrives at the same total twice.
  • Codifies that violations of these sections are a misdemeanor offense.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Specifies that automatic tabulating or electronic ballot marking systems capable of storing aggregate ballot level data must provide data consisting of a single record for each ballot tabulated showing the manner in which the tabulator or system interpreted and tabulated the markings.
  • Requires a test of voting equipment at least two days before a post election audit and provides that violations of testing guidelines are a misdemeanor violation.

name: Establish the legal standing of the Legislature to bring suit and be a necessary party in actions involving election law violations by public officials.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 10, NAYS 2.
summary:
• Establishes the legal authority for the Legislature to file a lawsuit in actions related to election law violations by government officials.
  • Establishes the legal authority for the Legislature to be a necessary party in actions related to election law violations by government officials.

name: Remove the option to register to vote by a signed statement.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 9, NAYS 0.
summary: As introduced, this bill strikes the option to register to vote via a signed statement verifying identity.

name: Update maintenance and verification requirements for voter registration files.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 9, NAYS 0.

name: Proposing and submitting to the electors at the next general election an amendment to Article III of the Constitution of the State of South Dakota, to limit terms of service for legislators to eight years.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 8, NAYS 1.
summary: As introduced, this bill limits terms of legislators to two years, with an eight year limit for senators and representatives, and exempts partial terms. This bill also sets mileage reimbursement at 5 cents per mile and establishes that the legislature should meet for no more than 40 legislative days, with an exception.

name: Clarify the convening of recount boards for primary elections.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on February 13, 2023 H.J. 280
summary: As introduced, this bill provides that the board appointed to preside over a recount will meet in the office of the county auditor at 9am on the second Monday following the filing of the petition, 9am on the second Tuesday if Monday is a holiday, or a date selected by the presiding judge to avoid conflict with the electoral process. This bill also requires that the date chosen by the judge must provide opportunity for recount witnesses to attend.

name: Permit the display of campaign signage in municipalities prior to the beginning of absentee voting.
most_recent_action: Local Government Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 9, NAYS 4.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits campaign signs less than 4 sq ft to be placed in residential zones and signs less than 32 sq ft to be placed in commercial/industrial zones next to public roads 45 days prior to an election. The municipality determines when the signs must be removed.

name: Modify provisions pertaining to poll watchers.
most_recent_action: Local Government Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 10, NAYS 1.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows poll watchers to be present at any polling place for the purpose of observing the voting and counting process. The poll worker may not be a candidate on the ballot and may stand between 4-5ft from the desk where voters announce themselves without any obstructions.

name: Permit the use of tribal identification cards when registering to vote.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 8, NAYS 1.
categories: Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,In-person voter ID,Voter ID for registration
summary: As introduced, this bill adds a tribal identification card to the approved valid state identification for registering to vote and for voting and defines "tribal identification card."

name: Proposing and submitting to the voters at the next general election an amendment to the Constitution of the State of South Dakota, limiting the amount of ad valorem tax on real property, and limiting the increase in the assessed value of real property.
summary: As introduced, this bill proposes and submits to voters to add a constitutional amendment at the next general election an amendment to the state constitution to limit the amount of ad valorem tax on real property and the increase in the assessed value of real property.

name: Facilitate the process of establishing election precincts and polling places by counties.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 5, NAYS 2.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Ensures the legislature respects the boundaries of counties, municipalities, and election precincts when consider redistricting measures;
  • Directs each board of county commissioners to review the boundaries of election precincts and location of polling places in its county after each legislative redistricting, consult with the county's auditor and any applicable municipal governing body when establishing election precinct boundaries and polling place locations, and establish its election precincts and polling places by resolution.

name: Revise provisions pertaining to absentee voting at nursing facilities, assisted living centers, or hospitals.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 12, NAYS 1.
summary: As introduced, this bill deletes the provision that election representatives will deliver ballots and assist voters at nursing facilities, and the like, only during general elections and requires voters at the facility to complete the absentee ballot application and return envelope.

name: Proposing and submitting to the electors at the next general election an amendment to the Constitution of the State of South Dakota, providing for the retention elections of circuit court judges.
most_recent_action: Withdrawn at the Request of the Prime Sponsor S.J. 148
summary: As introduced, this bill proposes a Constitutional amendment to submit to voters to determine if circuit court judges should be subject to retention elections.

name: Provide for the recall of school board members.
most_recent_action: Education Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 6, NAYS 1.

name: Proposing and submitting to the voters at the next general election an amendment to the Constitution of the State of South Dakota, requiring an intervening general election occur before an initiated constitutional amendment that is substantially similar to an initiated amendment that was previously voted on and rejected may be submitted to a vote of the electors.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 10, NAYS 2.
categories: Ballot measures (initiative and referendum),Ballot access deadlines
summary: • Stipulates that a general election take place before a constitutional amendment substantially similar to a previously proposed constitutional amendment, be proposed again.

name: Prohibit private funding of election costs except for gifts of a nominal and intrinsic value.
most_recent_action: Signed by the Governor on March 28, 2022
summary: This bill prohibits the private funding of election costs except for gifts of a nominal and intrinsic value.

name: Modify certain provisions related to elections for sparse school districts.
most_recent_action: House of Representatives Deferred to another day, Passed H.J. 487
categories: Municipal election procedures,In-person voting and polling places
summary: This bill mandates that a board of a sparsely populated and highly rural school district may not designate fewer polling places than the number designated by a county commission within the school district's boundaries.

name: Provide for certain permissible dates for municipal and school district elections.
most_recent_action: Senate Do Pass Amended, Failed, YEAS 16, NAYS 19. S.J. 408
categories: Election dates,Municipal election procedures,Ballot access deadlines
summary: This bill specifies that municipal officer and school board elections must be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in June or the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November of each year. Nominating petitions are due no later than the last Tuesday in March for a June election or the last Tuesday in August for a November election.

name: Absentee voting; unsolicited absentee ballot applications, required information, penalty.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 8, NAYS 0.
summary: This bill mandates the Board of Elections conduct a forensic audit of ballots, voting equipment, and voter verification processes, of every federal office on the ballot of a general election in which the offices of President and Vice President of the United States are on the ballot and the two candidates with the highest number of votes are separated by less than ten percent of the total votes cast. The audit must be completed by June 1 of the year following the election. The board may contract with a third party with experience in forensic audits of elections.

name: Modify the date for the state's presidential primary elections.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 9, NAYS 0.
summary: This bill sets the date of the primary election for the first Tuesday after the first Monday in June of every presidential election year and sets the deadline for ballot access as the last Tuesday in December prior to the primary.

name: Establish fees for information provided from the statewide voter registration file.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 8, NAYS 1.
summary: This bill establish fees for information provided from the statewide voter registration file.

name: Update maintenance requirements for voter registration files.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 9, NAYS 0.
summary: This bill mandates that the county auditor maintain a file of voters in computer format that contains the information of each person registered in each voting precinct within the county, including all information from each voter’s registration card, the date of the last election the voter voted in, and when the voter’s information was last updated. The file is required to be updated at least twice a year, including no less than sixty days prior to a general election, and if a voter is purged or unregistered that information must be kept for twenty-two months. The bill also empowers the county auditor to request confirmation that a person still resides at their registered address and remove the person from the file if they both fail to respond and fail to vote within a period of four years covering two general federal elections.

name: Provide for certain requirements in the absentee ballot application process.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 7, NAYS 2.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Ballot collection
summary: This bill specifies that no person may distribute an absentee ballot application to a voter that is prefilled with the voter's name and registration address but excludes any person authorized to request an absentee ballot for a voter, or a person assisting a voter who requires assistance by reason of blindness, physical disability, or inability to read or write. The bill also prohibits the distribution of an application for an absentee ballot that is not the official application provided for by the State Board of Elections.

name: Protect the integrity and accuracy of voter registration information.
most_recent_action: State Affairs Deferred to the 41st legislative day, Passed, YEAS 6, NAYS 3.
summary: This bill mandates that each county auditor provide a report to the Secretary of State and the State Board of Election that provides the number of voters removed from the voter registration list each year.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Section 2-3-102, relative to reviewing assignments of voters to precincts and districts.
summary:
As introduced on January 31, 2023, this bill:

  • Requires the state coordinator of elections to submit a list of registered voters to each county comptroller of the treasury after each decennial census.
  • Requires the comptroller to compare the list to GIS data in order to ensure voters are assigned to the appropriate districts for various elections, and to provide results to the state coordinator of elections and each county administrator.
  • Requires county administrators to review the results and make final determinations about districts.
  • Requires county administrators, within seven days of making final determinations, to notify the comptroller and state coordinator of determinations, including justifications.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to elections.
most_recent_action: House Finance, Ways, and Means Subcommittee Hearing (10:30:00 10:30:00 House Hearing Room III)
summary: As introduced on January 31, 2023, this bill reduces the minimum size of a farm that lies between two counties from 15 acres to 10 acres for residents to qualify to make a one-time decision to register to vote in either county.

name: A RESOLUTION to propose an amendment to Article VII, Section 5 of the Constitution of Tennessee, to change the date of elections for judicial and other civil officers.
most_recent_action: Placed on s/c cal Finance, Ways, and Means Subcommittee for 4/12/2023
summary:
• Proposes a constitutional amendment stating that elections for judicial and other civil offices should be moved from the first Thursday in August to the first Tuesday following the first Monday in November.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, Chapter 17 and Title 2, Chapter 8, relative to elections.
categories: Voter ID for registration,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Affirms that each candidate in an election has the right to have delivered certified copies of all poll lists, tally sheets, and list of voters who changed their address, upon request and payment of associated fees.
  • Specifies that fail safe affidavits and change of address forms may be used to comply with this request.
  • Requires a recount must include all ballots cast and include verification of any address changes.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to elections.
most_recent_action: Taken off notice for cal in s/c Finance, Ways, and Means Subcommittee of Finance, Ways, and Means Committee
summary: As introduced on January 25, 2023, this bill allows the commission to notify individuals filing petitions of a defect in documentation.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Section 2-3-102, relative to reviewing assignments of voters to precincts and districts.
summary:
As introduced on January 31, 2023, this bill:

  • Requires the state coordinator of election to submit a list of registered voters to the county comptroller of the treasury.
  • Requires the comptroller of the treasury to compare the list of registered voters to the GIS system data to ensure the voters has been assigned to correct districts for each election.
  • Requires the comptroller of the treasury to provide the results to the county administrator of elections and state coordinator of elections.
  • Requires the county administrator of elections to review the results and make determinations about correct assignments within seven days and notify the comptroller and the state coordinator of determinations, including justifications when there are deviations.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to polling places.
summary: As introduced on January 31, 2023, this bill requires a specific sign be placed in a prominent location at each polling place reminding voters that it is a crime to vote in a party primary when a voter is not a bona fide member of the party.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2 and Title 40, relative to voting rights.
most_recent_action: Taken off notice for cal in s/c Criminal Justice Subcommittee of Criminal Justice Committee
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary:
As introduced on January 25, 2023, this bill:

  • Provides that a voter is disqualified if he or she is currently imprisoned, on probation, or on parole for a judgement of infamy and instructs the state coordinator of elections and others to place the voter registration of the convicted individual on suspended status.
  • Requires the state coordinator of elections to maintain a list of individuals on suspended status.
  • Codifies that pardoned individuals may petition for restoration of full citizenship rights after the pardon, and outlines guidelines for those convicted of an infamous crime.
  • Requires a form be used for notifying county election commissions of someone whose voter registration is suspended due to the commission of a crime.
  • Provides that someone with a suspended registration due to committing an infamous crime may testify in any civil or criminal action.
  • Provides that those convicted of an infamous crime are ineligible to vote while imprisoned, on parole, or on probation, except certain specific circumstances.
  • Provides that upon completion of a sentence a person convicted of an infamous crime will be issued a certificate of voting rights restoration by certain parties and requires the issuing parties to explain the procedure to apply for a voter registration card.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to elections.
most_recent_action: Taken off notice for cal. in Local Government Committee
summary: As introduced on January 25, 2023, this bill requires election officials to meet at the polling place at least 45 minutes (instead of 30 minutes) before the start of voting.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to elections.
most_recent_action: Rec. for pass. if am., ref. to Calendar & Rules Committee
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access deadlines
summary: As introduced, this bill requires election officials to examine any document, petition, or paper filed before accepting it, to ensure information is filed properly and deadlines are met. This bill stipulates that if the document, petition, or paper are accepted, then it can be presumed that they met the requirements for filing.

name: AN ACT to amend Chapter 563 of the Acts of 1903; as amended by Chapter 64 of the Acts of 1907; Chapter 647 of the Private Acts of 1911; Chapter 158 of the Private Acts of 1915; Chapter 170 of the Private Acts of 1915; Chapter 3 of the Private Acts of 1917; Chapter 397 of the Private Acts of 1919; Chapter 23 of the Private Acts of 1919; Chapter 231 of the Private Acts of 1919; Chapter 764 of the Private Acts of 1927; Chapter 232 of the Private Acts of 1941; Chapter 669 of the Private Acts of 1947

summary: As introduced on January 25, 2023, this bill amends the number of days from 30 to 15 within which a party needs to submit a copy of their operating rules, after adoption, for the party to have nominees on the ballot or act in other party-related ways.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2 and Title 6, relative to local elections.
most_recent_action: Placed on Senate Regular Calendar for 4/6/2023
summary: As introduced, this bill eliminates election procedures that require a candidate to be nominated from a district but elected at-large.

name: AN ACT to amend Chapter 159 of the Private Acts of 2002; and any other acts amendatory thereto, relative to the charter for the Town of Chapel Hill.
most_recent_action: Rec. for pass. if am., ref. to Calendar & Rules Committee

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Section 2-2-102 and Title 40, Chapter 29, relative to voting rights.
most_recent_action: Taken off notice for cal in s/c Criminal Justice Subcommittee of Criminal Justice Committee
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Voter registration
summary:
As introduced on January 25, 2023, this bill:

  • Provides that a voter is disqualified if he or she is currently imprisoned, on probation, or on parole for a judgement of infamy.
  • Codifies that pardoned individuals may petition for restoration of full citizenship rights after the pardon, and outlines guidelines for those convicted of an infamous crime.
  • Provides that those convicted of an infamous crime are ineligible to vote while imprisoned, on parole, or on probation, except certain specific circumstances.

  • Provides that upon completion of a sentence a person convicted of an infamous crime will be issued a certificate of voting rights restoration by certain parties and requires the issuing parties to explain the procedure to apply for a voter registration card.
  • Outlines procedures for submitting the certificate of voting rights restoration to the coordinator of elections and outlines related administrative guidelines.
  • Requires the Department of Corrections to provide a list of newly eligible people to the Secretary of State twice per month, with certain information requirements.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Section 2-2-106 and Section 2-2-141, relative to election integrity.
most_recent_action: Action def. in Local Government Committee to 4/11/2023
summary: As introduced on January 30, 2023, this bill provides that the coordinator of elections must compare the statewide voter registration database with databases of other relevant state agencies and county records to ensure all those registered to vote are US citizens.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, Chapter 17 and Title 2, Chapter 8, relative to elections.
summary:
As introduced on January 30, 2023, this bill:

  • Provides that each candidate is authorized to obtain certified copies of poll lists, tally sheets, and a list of voters who changed their address in the election where the candidate ran, upon proper request and payment of fees.
  • Provides that copies of voters' fail safe affidavits or change of address forms may be used to comply with related parts of the request. 
  • Provides that a recount of ballots must include verification of any address changes by voters in the election.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to elections.
summary: As introduced on January 31, 2023, this bill reduces the minimum size of a farm that lies between two counties from 15 acres to 10 acres for residents to qualify to make a one-time decision to register to vote in either county.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2 and Title 17, relative to elections.
most_recent_action: Scheduled for executive session in the House Committee on Transportation at 4:00 PM
summary: This bill prohibits a political party from requiring a person to pay a fee as a requirement to run as a candidate for that political party.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to voter registration.
most_recent_action: Taken off notice for cal in s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee of Local Government Committee
summary: As introduced, this bill reduces the time period a person can no longer register to vote or alter their voter registration from 30 to 15 days before an election.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to voting machines.
most_recent_action: Passed to Rules Committee for second reading.
summary: This bill requires a county election commission purchasing or entering into a contract to obtain a voting system to ensure that the system produces a voter-verifiable paper audit trail. Under the bill, a commission may only enter into a contract to obtain a voting system that does not produce a voter-verifiable paper audit trail if the contractor is contemporaneously seeking approval of compliant technology from the United States Election Assistance Commission or the Secretary of State and the contract provides for the transition to technology that produces a voter-verifiable paper audit trail during the initial term of the contract at no additional cost to the county election commission. The bill defines "voter verifiable paper audit trail" as a paper ballot marked by hand or device that is made available for inspection and verification by the voter at the polling location or a record contemporaneously printed at the time a voter casts a ballot using a direct recording electronic system that is made available for inspection and verification by the voter at the polling location.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2 and Title 40, relative to voting rights.

summary: This bill provides that the revocation of a person's voting rights pursuant to a conviction for certain infamous crimes is only temporary for the period of confinement, probation, or parole, and automatically restores a person's voting rights upon release from confinement, probation, or parole.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to elections.

The bill directs county election commissions to conduct training programs for poll watchers prior to each federal primary election and directs the Division of Elections to create a program for the recruitment of poll watchers. The bill also directs county election commissions to maintain an online system to enable persons to verify the status of their voter registration application in real time.

summary: This bill prohibits a person from contributing, including in-kind contributions, donating, paying, or otherwise transferring money or equipment to the state election commission or the coordinator of elections for purposes of conducting state or local elections in this state. name: AN ACT to amend Chapter 563 of the Acts of 1903; as amended by Chapter 64 of the Acts of 1907; Chapter 647 of the Private Acts of 1911; Chapter 158 of the Private Acts of 1915; Chapter 170 of the Private Acts of 1915; Chapter 3 of the Private Acts of 1917; Chapter 397 of the Private Acts of 1919; Chapter 23 of the Private Acts of 1919; Chapter 231 of the Private Acts of 1919; Chapter 764 of the Private Acts of 1927; Chapter 232 of the Private Acts of 1941; Chapter 669 of the Private Acts of 1947
summary:
As introduced, this bill

  • Updates a charter for the Town of Greeneville, specifying 32 sections of code related to elections and other municipal matters.
  • Furnishes that the governing body will be a city council and specifies roles, terms, duties, and the like.
  • Outlines a voting system for the city council to elect a vice-mayor to fill the mayor's duties in the case of a vacancy.
  • Specifies that mayor and council member elections will be every four years with terms from September 1-August 31 and that the election will be in August.
  • Sets district boundaries.
  • Stipulates qualifications for voting for members of the general assembly.
  • Outlines powers of municipal authorities.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Section 2-2-102 and Title 40, Chapter 29, relative to voting rights.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate Judiciary Committee
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Voter registration
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Establishes that a person convicted of a felony is only ineligible to vote while imprisoned, on probation, or on parole for a felony conviction, unless the person is convicted of first-degree murder, aggravated rape, treason, or voter fraud, in which case the person is never eligible to vote.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Section 2-2-102 and Title 40, Chapter 29, relative to voting rights.
most_recent_action: Assigned to s/c Criminal Justice Subcommittee
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals,Voter registration
summary:
As introduced on January 26, 2023, this bill:

  • Provides that a US citizen who is a resident of the state and 18 years or older is a qualified voter unless the person is currently imprisoned, on probation, or on parole for a judgement of infamy.
  • Provides that those who are pardoned may petition for immediate restoration of the full rights of citizenship after the pardon.
  • Provides that a person convicted of an infamous crime may petition for full restoration of citizenship rights after the expiration of the prison sentence, probation, and parole, except for those individuals who are never eligible to vote again in the state.
  • Provides that voting rights may not be infringed due to inability to pay monetary obligations or penalties related to a conviction.
  • Provides that a person whose voting rights are restored must be issued a certificate of voting rights restoration by specified authorities, which may used to obtain a voter registration card, following the rules that apply to other voters.
  • Outlines procedures for verifying a certificate of voting rights and issuing a voter registration.
  • Lists infamous crimes.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, Chapter 20 and Title 2, Chapter 5, relative to elections.
summary:
• This bill requires that each November general election any County Election Commission utilizing a precinct-based optical scanner must conduct automatic mandatory audits of the voter-verified paper ballots cast for the President of the United States in a presidential election and the Governor in a gubernatorial election.
  • The Secretary of State must randomly select county election commissions that must conduct an audit after each August and November election.
  • The selection must occur on election day, and the Coordinator of Elections must notify the selected County Election Commissions.
  • County Election Commissions must provide public notice of the time and location of the audit at least 48 hours before the audit is conducted.
  • After each August election, the Secretary of State must select at least three counties to audit and after each November election, the Secretary of State must select at least six counties to audit.
  • The Secretary of State must select the audit methodology to be used in each selected county, from either a traditional tabulation audit, risk-limiting audit, or performance audit.
  • For an August election, the County Election Commission must conduct automatic mandatory audits for the highest race for county office.
  • The County Election Commission may select one or more additional races to be audited.
  • If all of the ballots in a race are counted as part of the manual hand count audit, the results of the hand count audit must be used as the official results to be certified by the County Election Commission.
  • Authorizes the Coordinator of Elections to define the method and type of watermark to be placed on an absentee ballot pursuant to present law, and authorizes the use of invisible ink or pre-printed opaque images to produce the watermark.

summary: This bill requires the Comptroller of the Treasury, the Director of the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation, and each District Attorney General to designate personnel in their respective departments as election crime specialists. name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to elections.
categories: Voting equipment,Poll observers,Ballot design,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary: This bill requires each county election commission to use ballot-marking devices or hand-marked ballots and tabulate the votes using an electronic tabulator or by a hand count, beginning with the 2024 election cycle. If a county election commission cannot acquire the necessary equipment to implement this requirement before the 2024 elections, the county election commission may request an extension to 2026 from the Secretary of State. The bill prohibits preventing a poll watcher from observing and documenting the counting and processing of ballots from a normal unaided visual length of sight, which is a distance of three feet or less, and requires the coordinator of elections to prescribe security features that must be used on paper ballots. The security features may include watermarks, fluorescence, digital holograms, or a unique ballot identifier that ensures no ballot can be duplicated or counted more than once. The Coordinator of Elections may change the ballot security features from election to election.

summary: This bill requires an employer to allow an employee who is a local elected official to leave work in order to perform the duties of the elected office during the employee's regular hours of employment without loss of pay, vacation time, sick leave, or earned overtime accumulation. If the employee is entitled to paid leave and the employee elects to use paid leave during the period of the employee's absence to perform duties as a local elected official, then the employer must permit the employee to use the paid leave for that purpose. This bill also authorizes the employer to require the employee to submit a written statement from a local elections official verifying that the employee is a local elected official. This bill defines "local elected official" as a person elected to a public office within a municipal, county, or metropolitan government, or a governmental entity that exercises authority on behalf of that government.

The bill prohibits a voter-verifiable paper audit trail from including the voter's identity.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to voting machines.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary: This bill requires any County Election Commission purchasing or entering into a contract to obtain a voting system to ensure that the system produces a voter-verifiable paper audit trail. For purposes of this bill, a voter-verifiable paper audit trail is a paper ballot marked by hand or marked by a device that is made available for inspection and verification by the voter at the polling location or a record contemporaneously printed at the time a voter casts a ballot using a direct recording electronic system that is made available for inspection and verification by the voter at the polling location. The bill prohibits a voter-verifiable paper audit trail from including the voter's identity.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 49, relative to the office of elected superintendent of schools.
summary: This bill creates a pilot program for the establishment of the office of elected Superintendent of Schools and requires the Department of Education to study the pilot program procedures for establishment of the office.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to elections.
summary: This bill prohibits the use of voting machines. The bill requires that elections be conducted using hand-marked paper ballots, authorizes pool watchers to record video at the polling place, and requires the Coordinator of Elections to prescribe certain security measures for paper ballots.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 57, relative to local option elections for alcohol sales.
categories: Ballot measures (initiative and referendum),Municipal election procedures
summary: This bill removes population requirements for a municipality to hold a referendum on the sale of alcoholic beverages and requires a municipality to maintain a police department or enter into an agreement for the provision of law enforcement during the hours of sale of alcoholic beverages to be eligible to hold a referendum on the sale of alcoholic beverages.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Section 2-7-114, relative to elections.
summary: This bill requires the state coordinator of elections to procure a vendor that produces paper ballots containing a unique voter identifier prior to the 2024 election cycle.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2 and Title 17, relative to elections.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary: This bill prohibits a political party from requiring a person to pay a fee as a requirement to run as a candidate for that political party.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2 and Title 67, Chapter 1, Part 5, relative to the compensation of administrators of elections.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary: This bill increases the minimum compensation for certified administrators of elections from 90 percent of the compensation of the county assessor of property to 100 percent of the compensation of the county assessor of property.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 49, relative to reestablishment of the office of elected school superintendent.
summary: This bill authorizes a county or municipality to vote to establish an elected superintendent of schools, instead of having a director of schools appointed by the board of education, upon two-thirds vote of the legislative body and approval of the voters in a referendum.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to elections.
most_recent_action: Assigned to s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee
categories: Early voting duration,In-person voting and polling places
summary: This bill extends the time from 4:00 p.m. until 6:00 p.m. in which a county election commission must keep its main office open on the days when the commission maintains routine office hours during a period of early voting and on the day of an election.

name: AN ACT relative to the Verify Our Tennessee Elections Act.
categories: Audits,Counting and canvassing procedures,Chain of custody
summary: This bill requires the Secretary of State, in collaboration with the county election commissions, to investigate the results of the 2020 general election results for President and U.S. Congress. Specifically, the bill requires a forensic audit of each ballot available for review from the 2020 general election, a complete canvassing of each ballot for purposes of confirming the vote tallies for each race, and a thorough review of the chain of custody for ballots, ballot boxes, and voting machines and equipment.

name: AN ACT relative to the Verify Our Tennessee Elections Act.
categories: Audits,Counting and canvassing procedures,Chain of custody
summary: This bill requires the Secretary of State, in collaboration with the State Election Commission, to investigate the results of the 2020 general election results for President and U.S. Congress. Specifically, the bill requires a forensic audit of each ballot available for review from the 2020 general election, a complete canvassing of each ballot for purposes of confirming the vote tallies for each race, and a thorough review of the chain of custody for ballots, ballot boxes, and voting machines and equipment.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 49, Chapter 2, relative to partisan elections for school board members.
summary: This bill authorizes partisan elections for school board members and states that candidates for school board may campaign as the nominee or representative of a political party if the applicable county primary board of a political party elects to conduct school board elections on a partisan basis.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 49, Chapter 2, relative to partisan elections for school board members.
summary: This bill authorizes partisan elections for school board members and states that candidates for school board may campaign as the nominee or representative of a political party if the applicable county primary board of a political party elects to conduct school board elections on a partisan basis.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 49, Chapter 2, relative to school board elections.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, held on desk.
summary: This bill expands to all counties the authority to recall a local board of education member and decreases from 66 percent to more than 50 percent the amount needed to recall a local board of education member.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to convenient voting centers.
summary: This bill prohibits the coordinator of elections from approving convenient voting centers for any county election commission that has not used at least one early satellite voting location throughout an early voting period in the most recent regular November election. The bill also extends authorization for counties that have an approved convenience voting pilot project plan to establish convenient voting centers within the county for federal, state, and local elections held in 2022.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to convenient voting centers.
summary: This bill prohibits the coordinator of elections from approving convenient voting centers for any county election commission that has not used at least one early satellite voting location throughout an early voting period in the most recent regular November election. The bill also extends authorization for counties that have an approved convenience voting pilot project plan to establish convenient voting centers within the county for federal, state, and local elections held in 2022.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to private funding for elections.
summary: This bill prohibits a person from contributing, including in-kind contributions, donating, paying, or otherwise transferring money or equipment to the state election commission or the coordinator of elections for purposes of conducting state or local elections in this state. The bill applies this same prohibition to such activity as it relates to a county election commission, local government, administrator, registrar, or other election official for purposes of conducting state or local elections in this state. The bill also requires that a taxpayer-funded audit of an election or election equipment must conform to the United States Government Accountability Office's generally accepted government auditing standards.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2; Title 3; Title 4; Title 8; Title 16 and Title 17, relative to the "Tennessee Election Integrity Act".
summary: This bill prohibits the various officials from accepting funding or contributions, including in kind-contributions for the purpose of conducting an election.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2; Title 3; Title 4; Title 8; Title 16 and Title 17, relative to the "Tennessee Election Integrity Act".
summary: This bill prohibits the various officials from accepting funding or contributions, including in kind-contributions for the purpose of conducting an election.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to voting machines.
most_recent_action: Assigned to General Subcommittee of Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary: This bill requires a county election commission purchasing or entering into a contract to obtain a voting system to ensure that the system produces a voter-verifiable paper audit trail. Under the bill, a commission may only enter into a contract to obtain a voting system that does not produce a voter-verifiable paper audit trail if the contractor is contemporaneously seeking approval of compliant technology from the United States Election Assistance Commission or the Secretary of State and the contract provides for the transition to technology that produces a voter-verifiable paper audit trail during the initial term of the contract at no additional cost to the county election commission. The bill defines "voter verifiable paper audit trail" as a paper ballot marked by hand or device that is made available for inspection and verification by the voter at the polling location or a record contemporaneously printed at the time a voter casts a ballot using a direct recording electronic system that is made available for inspection and verification by the voter at the polling location.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2; Title 3; Title 5; Title 6; Title 8; Title 10; Title 17; Title 39; Title 40; Title 49 and Title 54, relative to elections.
most_recent_action: Assigned to General Subcommittee of Senate State and Local Government Committee
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access deadlines
summary: This bill requires any person trying to receive a party nomination by write-in ballots to complete a notice requesting such person's ballots be counted in each county of the district no later than 12:00 noon, prevailing time, 25 days before a primary election.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to elections.
most_recent_action: Assigned to General Subcommittee of Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary: This bill requires new amendments or additions to political party rules to take effect 10 business days after being filed with the Secretary of State and the Coordinator of Elections.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 49, relative to reestablishment of the office of elected school superintendent.
most_recent_action: Def. to Summer Study in K-12 Subcommittee
summary: This bill authorizes a county or municipality to vote to establish an elected superintendent of schools, instead of having a director of schools appointed by the board of education, upon two-thirds vote of the legislative body and approval of the voters in a referendum.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to convenient voting centers.
most_recent_action: Assigned to General Subcommittee of Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary: This bill allows all counties to establish convenient voting centers for use on election day upon a super majority vote of the County Election Commission. The Commission must submit to the Coordinator of Elections a project plan for the convenient voting centers. The coordinator's approval is required prior to the County Election Commission implementing the plan.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to fingerprint identification of voters.
summary: This bill authorizes the State Election Commission and each County Election Commission to utilize technology to identify the fingerprints of voters for purposes of conducting elections in this state in collaboration with state agencies that maintain a database of fingerprints in this state. The bill requires state agencies with fingerprint databases to collaborate with Secretary of State to implement the bill.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to political parties.
most_recent_action: Failed in s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee of Local Government Committee
summary: This bill decreases the number of signatures required for a political party to become a recognized minor party and increases the number of votes a political party's candidate for a statewide office must receive during a gubernatorial election for the party to be a statewide political party

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2 and Title 3, relative to elections.
most_recent_action: Placed on cal. Local Government Committee for 3/14/2023
summary: This bill allows a hospital administrator or, in the hospital administrator's absence, a licensed physician attending a person, to serve as an emergency registrar.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2; Title 3, Chapter 1; Title 4, Chapter 16; Title 4, Chapter 29 and Title 8, Chapter 4, relative to redistricting.
most_recent_action: Assigned to s/c Public Service Subcommittee
summary: This bill establishes a nine-member independent redistricting commission.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to the Fair Elections Act.
most_recent_action: Assigned to s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee
summary:
• Revises various provisions regarding the state election commission, county election commission, and the duties of the secretary of state and coordinator of elections. 
  • Increases the state election commission from seven to nine members and increases from two to three the maximum number of commission members that may be from the same grand division.
  • Requires a composition of three members each of the majority and minority parties and three additional members to be elected, without regard to political affiliation, by the six members of the general assembly who serve on the state election commission. 
  • Reduces from five to four the number of commissioners for each county election commission that the state election commission will appoint, and requires that those four members of the county election commission appoint the fifth member.
  • Transfers the duty to appoint the coordinator of elections from the secretary of state to the state election commission.
  • Revises the rulemaking authority of the coordinator.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, Chapter 3, Part 1 and Title 2, Chapter 6, Part 1, relative to elections.
categories: Early voting administration,In-person voting and polling places
summary: This bill requires County Election Commissions to designate public institutions of higher education with 20,000 or more enrolled students as polling places during early voting in federal and state general elections and presidential primaries for a period of at least five days.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, Chapter 9, relative to records of votes.
most_recent_action: Taken off notice for cal in s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee of Local Government Committee
summary: This bill requires a county purchasing direct recording electronic voting systems to ensure that the systems have the capability to create a voter-verifiable paper audit trail for each ballot cast.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to voting.
summary: This bill abolishes early voting, prohibits the use of voting machines, and requires elections to be conducted with watermarked paper ballots that are hand-marked by the voter.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to fingerprint identification of voters.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary: This bill authorizes the State Election Commission and each County Election Commission to utilize technology to identify the fingerprints of voters for purposes of conducting elections in this state in collaboration with state agencies that maintain a database of fingerprints in this state and requires state agencies with fingerprint databases to collaborate with Secretary of State to implement the bill.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2 and Title 17, relative to elections for judges of courts of record.
most_recent_action: Executive session scheduled, but no action was taken in the House Committee on State Government & Tribal Relations at 1:30 PM.
summary: This bill requires nonpartisan elections for chancellors, circuit court judges, criminal court judges, and judges of any other state trial court and prohibits a political party from requiring a person to pay a fee in order to run as that political party's candidate for public office.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2; Title 3, Chapter 1; Title 4, Chapter 16; Title 4, Chapter 29 and Title 8, Chapter 4, relative to redistricting.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate Government Operations Committee
summary: This bill establishes a nine-member independent redistricting commission.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2; Title 5 and Title 6, relative to local elections.
categories: Election dates,Alignment of elections,Municipal election procedures
summary: This bill requires the legislative body of each municipality to change the date of municipal elections to coincide with the August primary and November general elections. An initial election of a municipality that is chartered after the date that this bill becomes a law must occur on the fourth Tuesday following the election in which a form of municipal government is adopted, but all subsequent elections must coincide with the August primary and November general elections. The bill also specifies that the changing of an election date to comply with this bill's requirements must not extend a term for more than two years beyond its regular expiration date.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2 and Title 49, relative to elections.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
categories: Absentee/mail-in voting eligibility,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,In-person voter ID
summary: This bill allows a voter to use a photo identification card issued by a public institution of higher education to verify the voter's identity when voting. The bill permits a voter to vote absentee for any reason after providing a certification as to the identity of the voter in the application for a ballot and requires an absentee ballot to be counted for the election in which the ballot is cast. Lastly, the bill deletes the requirement that a voter who registers by mail must vote the first time in-person.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to political parties.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary: This bill decreases the number of signatures required for a political party to become a recognized minor party and increases the number of votes a political party's candidate for a statewide office must receive during a gubernatorial election for the party to be a statewide political party

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2; Title 3; Title 5; Title 6; Title 8; Title 10; Title 17; Title 39; Title 40; Title 49 and Title 54, relative to elections.
most_recent_action: P2C, caption bill, held on desk - pending amdt.

most_recent_action: Assigned to s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee
summary: This bill allows a hospital administrator or, in the hospital administrator's absence, a licensed physician attending a person, to serve as an emergency registrar.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2; Title 5 and Title 6, relative to local elections.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
categories: Election dates,Alignment of elections,Municipal election procedures
summary: This bill requires municipal legislative bodies to change the dates of municipal elections to coincide with the August primary and November general elections.

name: A RESOLUTION to propose amendments to Article III of the Constitution of Tennessee, to provide for popular election of the secretary of state.
most_recent_action: Assigned to s/c Departments & Agencies Subcommittee
summary: This resolution proposes statewide popular election of the Secretary of State rather than appointment by joint vote of the General Assembly.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, Chapter 3, Part 1 and Title 2, Chapter 6, Part 1, relative to elections.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
categories: Early voting administration,In-person voting and polling places
summary: This bill requires county election commissions to designate public institutions of higher education with 20,000 or more enrolled students as polling places during early voting in federal and state general elections and presidential primaries for a period of at least five days.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to convenient voting centers.
most_recent_action: Assigned to s/c Elections & Campaign Finance Subcommittee
summary: This bill allows all counties to establish convenient voting centers for use on election day upon a super majority vote of the County Election Commission. The Commission must submit to the Coordinator of Elections a project plan for the convenient voting centers. The coordinator's approval is required prior to the County Election Commission implementing the plan.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to elections.
summary: This bill directs the Secretary of State to file a copy of the previous year's consolidated report on Help America Vote Act funds and Title II requirements and payments to the State and Local Government Committee of the Senate and the Local Government Committee of the House of Representatives.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to the Fair Elections Act.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary:
• Revises various provisions regarding the state election commission, county election commission, and the duties of the secretary of state and coordinator of elections.
  • Increases the state election commission from seven to nine members and increases from two to three the maximum number of commission members that may be from the same grand division.
  • Requires a composition of three members each of the majority and minority parties and three additional members to be elected, without regard to political affiliation, by the six members of the general assembly who serve on the state election commission.
  • Reduces from five to four the number of commissioners for each county election commission that the state election commission will appoint, and requires that those four members of the county election commission appoint the fifth member.
  • Transfers the duty to appoint the coordinator of elections from the secretary of state to the state election commission.
  • Revises the rulemaking authority of the coordinator.

name: AN ACT to amend Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 2, relative to elections.
most_recent_action: Passed on Second Consideration, refer to Senate State and Local Government Committee
summary: This bill directs the Secretary of State to file a copy of the previous year's consolidated report on Help America Vote Act funds and Title II requirements and payments to the State and Local Government Committee of the Senate and the Local Government Committee of the House of Representatives.

name: Relating to the interstate voter registration crosscheck program.
summary: As introduced, this bill adds conditions related to the state’s participation in the interstate voter registration crosscheck program.

name: Relating to elimination of the countywide polling place program.
most_recent_action: Not again placed on intent calendar
summary: As introduced, this bill eliminates the countywide polling place program.

name: Relating to increasing the criminal penalty for certain offenses related to elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill increases the penalties for certain election related offenses.

name: Relating to the combination of certain election precincts.
Relating to requiring notice to the attorney general in an action under the Election Code seeking a temporary restraining order.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a court that issues a temporary restraining order under the election code to submit a copy of that temporary restraining order to the attorney general.

name: Relating to a proposition to approve the issuance of bonds or other debt.
categories: Election dates,Alignment of elections,Ballot measures (initiative and referendum)
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a proposition for approval of the issuance of bonds or other debt to be submitted to the voters in an election held on the November uniform election date.

name: Relating to accepting an early voting ballot voted by mail; creating a criminal offense.
Relating to the election of board members of certain emergency services districts.
Relating to confirmation of a voter's residence by a voter registrar.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the registrar to confirm a voter’s current residence if the voter maintains a residence that does not correspond to a residence, there are discrepancies in a suspension list, or reason exists to believe the voter does not reside at their listed residence.

name: Relating to the failure of a voter registrar to comply with voter registration laws.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits the secretary of state to withhold funds administered and distributed to a registrar for failure of a registrar to comply with voter registration laws.

name: Relating to nominations by primary election by certain political parties.
Relating to helping ensure the timely enforcement of the Texas Election Code.
categories: Enforcement against officials,Enforcement against non-officials,Legal causes of action
summary: As introduced, this bill exempts a legal or enforcement action related to elections from certain legal proceedings.

name: Relating to processes to address election irregularities; providing a civil penalty.
Relating to preparing and delivering precinct election returns; increasing a criminal penalty.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits the secretary of state to supervise to complete the ballot count, prepare the precinct returns, and distribute the records if the precinct election records are not delivered by the deadline. If the precinct election records are impounded, the district judge must supervise to complete the count, prepare the precinct returns, and distribute the records. This bill increases penalties related to election returns.

name: Relating to access to certain election records under the public information law.
summary: As introduced this bill applies existing election code to election records available to the public for general, primary, and special elections.

name: Relating to the presidential electors of this state.
Relating to the use of an accessible absentee mail system by certain voters.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows a qualified absentee voter to cast a ballot using an accessible, electronic absentee mail system.

name: Relating to renewal of an appointment as a volunteer deputy registrar.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Directs the registrar, by November 30 of an even numbered year, to notify each volunteer deputy registrar that the term of appointment expires on December 30 of that year.
  • Requires the notification to include a renewal application and information about any relevant election law changes.
  • Requires the registrar to immediately appoint a volunteer deputy registrar for a new term beginning January 1, with certain procedural requirements.
  • Specifies that a volunteer deputy registrar is not required to attend training unless the person has failed to comply with requirements related to the role.

name: Relating to requirements for a trial in the contest of an election on a proposed constitutional amendment.
Relating to a study by the secretary of state on the feasibility of central counting stations complying with federal standards for facilities that contain sensitive information.
categories: Poll observers,Counting and canvassing procedures,Reporting,Legislative authority
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Directs the secretary of state to conduct a study regarding the feasibility of conforming each central counting station to the US government Sensitive Compartmented Information Facilities standards.
  • Requires the study to consider compliance with the standards, while allowing for poll watchers and other citizen involvement that is permitted under state law.
  • Furnishes that the secretary of state must submit a detailed report by September 1, 2024 summarizing findings to the state legislature.
  • Provides that this section expires on December 1, 2024.

name: Relating to the procedures for the issuance of a personal identification certificate to a person whose driver's license is surrendered.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a person to receive a voter registration form to update their registration information when surrendering their driver’s license for an ID card.

name: Relating to the procedures for the issuance of a personal identification certificate to a person whose driver's license is surrendered.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires individuals applying for a personal identification certificate to also be given a voter registration form, to include the new certificate identification number of the newly issued certificate.
  • Requires the completed voter registration form be submitted to the secretary of state or county clerk by the 30th day after the issue date of the certificate.

name: Relating to ineligibility to serve as a poll watcher.
summary: Establishes that a person is ineligible to be appointed as a poll watcher if he or she has been convicted of a first or second degree felony related to elections.

name: Relating to a pilot program for recording activity at a ballot counting station.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the secretary of state to establish a pilot program for counties to use a video recording device to record ballot counting activity in no less than 20 percent of precincts in the county.

name: Relating to authorizing certain political subdivisions to change the date on which the general election for officers is held.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a governing body of a political subdivision, other than a county or municipal utility district, that holds its general election for officers on the November general election date to change the date of its general election to the May general election date.

name: Relating to accommodating a voter unable to enter a polling place.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a parking space be available at each polling place for persons without the ability to enter the polling site and offer proper accommodations assist the person to vote.

name: Relating to meetings of a county election board.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a meeting of the county election board to held in person and open to the public. The county clerk shall post notice of the meeting on the county's website no later than 48 hours before each meeting.
