name: Relating to the compensation of an election judge or clerk.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits a judge or clerk from being paid for more than two hours of work before the polls open except for making changes to the list of registered voters at another polling place.

name: Relating to the secretary of state posting on the secretary of state's Internet website databases containing certain information about elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the secretary of state to post on its website a database containing election information and another with candidate and incumbent information. Counties, political parties, and political subdivisions are required to submit the proper information to each respective database.

name: Relating to the determination of a majority vote in certain elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a candidate to receive more than half of the votes in an election requiring a majority vote. A majority may not be determined by using a preferential voting system to reassign votes.

name: Relating to abolishing the county elections administrator position in certain counties.
summary: As introduced, this bill transfers all powers and duties of the county elections administrator of a county with than one million people to the county tax assessor-collector and county clerk. The county tax assessor-collector will serve as the voter registrar, and the county clerk will retain their duties carried out by the elections administrator previously. The commissioners court of a county with a population of one million or less may create the position of county elections administrator for the county.

name: Relating to release of an area from a municipality's extraterritorial jurisdiction by petition or election.
Relating to the manufacture of voting machines by certain foreign persons.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits a manufacturer of voting systems from entering into a contract for software development services with a company headquartered in China, Cuba, Iran, North Korea, or Russia or an individual based in one of those countries.

name: Relating to the enforcement of laws relating to elections.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Establishes a system of state election marshals and inspectors to investigate any allegations of election law violations.   
  • Allows the secretary of state or an election marshal to impound voting equipment in the investigation of an election.
  • Permits a candidate or political party affiliate that fears harm from violation of election law to seek injunctive relief.
  • Clarifies which judges can preside and are disqualified from presiding over injunctive relief cases and the process for emergency review of election activities.

name: Relating to the election date for the authorization of the issuance of bonds or a tax increase.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election for the issuance of bonds or other debt or a tax increase to be held on the November general election date.

name: Relating to death records maintained and provided by the vital statistics unit of the Department of State Health Services.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the department of state health services to implement a method to provide death information to the secretary of state to assist in maintaining the statewide voter registration list.

name: Relating to the persons authorized to administer an oath in this state.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows a retired justice of the peace to administer an oath.

name: Relating to the authority of the secretary of state to order a new election in certain counties.
categories: Oversight and accountability,Special election procedures,In-person voting and polling places,State appropriations
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Directs that the secretary of state may order a new election if, in a county of over one million people, the secretary has good cause to believe that at least 2% of polling places did not get supplemental ballots fro more than one hour after making the request.
  • Grants the secretary of state the same authority as is granted to a district court in establishing the procedures for the new election.
  • Specifies that expenses for the new election will be paid from the same fund and by the same authority as the previous election.

name: Relating to ballots voted by mail.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires an election officer to maintain a register of mail-in ballots returned at a polling place.
  • Permits a voter who voted by mail to correct any defects and provides the procedure for the early voting clerk to notify the voter and how to fix the defects.
  • Provides for signature matching verification on carrier envelopes for mail-in ballots.
  • Permits the early voting ballot board to notify a voter who voted by mail and has a defect on the ballot on the defect and how to fix the defects.

name: Relating to the application of statutes that classify political subdivisions according to population.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes population requirements for political subdivisions shaped by population.

name: Relating to the randomized audits of elections in certain counties.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the secretary of state to conduct an audit of the elections held on the uniform election date in four counties during the previous 2 year. This bill also permits the secretary of state to randomly select a county with a population of less than 300,000 to be audited if the mandatory audit requirements have been met for this county size category during a 2 year period.

name: Relating to the suspension of a county elections administrator.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits the secretary of state to enter a written order to suspend a county elections administrator at any time if a complaint is filed and the secretary has cause to believe there is a recurring pattern of election administration problems. A vacancy created by the suspension of a county elections administrator is filled by appointment of the secretary of state until the problem is rectified.

name: Relating to the systems used in a central counting station.
summary: As introduced, this bill modifies requirements for the purchase or use of ballot scanning equipment, requiring the ballot scanner to only use a data storage device (rather than disc) that is incapable of being modified without rendering the device unreadable.

name: Relating to an indication on a voter's voter registration certificate that a voter is a veteran.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes a "veteran" designation on a voter’s registration certificate.

name: Relating to the date of runoff elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the runoff election date to the sixth Saturday after the date of the main election.

name: Relating to the suspension of a county elections administrator.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Lists the reasons a secretary of state my submit a written order to suspend a county election administrator from employment.
  • Provides that a vacancy due to a suspension should be filled by the secretary of state.
  • Specifies that the newly appointed person is to serve until the the secretary of state determines that the problems with the election administration are rectified.

name: Relating to the hours during which early voting by personal appearance is conducted.
categories: Early voting administration,In-person voting and polling places
summary: As introduced, this bill repeals population requirements for certain hours of operation for early voting polling places with in-person voting.

name: Relating to the determination of a majority vote in certain elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill clarifies a candidate must receive more than half of the votes in an election requiring a majority vote. A majority may not be determined by using a preferential voting system to reassign votes.

name: Relating to the omission of a deceased candidate from the ballot in certain elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits an election authority responsible for preparing the ballot to omit the candidate from the ballot if a candidate dies before the ballots are printed.

name: Relating to the randomized audits of elections in certain counties.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits the secretary of state to randomly select a county with a population of less than 300,000 to be audited if the mandatory audit requirements have been met for this county size category during a 2 year period.

name: Relating to personal information entered on the carrier envelope of a ballot to be voted by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the secretary of state to include instructions on how to include personal information on the carrier envelope for vote by mail and provides for the design.

name: Relating to automatic recounts of certain elections.
Relating to the compensation of an election judge or clerk.
summary: As introduced, this bill increases the hours an election judge or clerk may be paid for work before the polls open to no more than two.

name: Relating to a person submitting proof of citizenship to verify eligibility to vote in Texas.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a voter to submit proof of citizenship when submitting a voter registration application.

name: Relating to the withdrawal of a candidate in a runoff primary election.
summary: As introduced, the bill mandates a candidate may not withdraw from a runoff primary election after 5 p.m. of the 21st day after the state canvass. If a runoff candidate withdraws from the election before the deadline, the candidate with the third highest number of votes in the primary will be on the runoff ballot. If a runoff candidate withdraws after the deadline, the remaining candidate is the nominee and the runoff election for that office is not held.

name: Relating to elections.
Relating to election practices and procedures in a county with a population over 3.5 million.
Relating to the applicability to election judges of a prohibition on the carrying of a handgun at a polling place.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits an election judge to carry a handgun in a polling place while carrying out their duties.

name: Relating to a ballot option to not vote for any candidate.
summary: As introduced, this bill provides the option for a voter not to vote for any candidate on the ballot.

name: Relating to the venue for the prosecution of an election offense.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows the prosecution of a felony or misdemeanor election related crime to take place in a judicial district next to where the crime occurred.

name: Relating to ballots voted by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits an official carrier envelope for an early voting ballot to be modified if the voter is provided a signature sheet that contains omitted required parts. For an early voting mail ballot to be counted, a voter must either include a completed signature sheet in the carrier envelope containing their ballot or complete the carrier envelope certificate.

name: Relating to standardized training for election officers.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the secretary of state to provide a standardized training program in election law and procedure for presiding or alternate election judges, election watchers, members of an early voting board, members of a signature verification committee, and members of a counting station.

name: Relating to accommodating voters with a disability.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires an election officer to accept a person with a disability before accepting others to vote at the polling place who arrived before the person and post notice of this accommodation at the entrance to each polling place and on the county clerk’s website.
  • Requires 2 parking spaces at a polling place to be reserved for persons with disabilities. The spaces must contain a sign with a number for election officials to assist.
  • Requires a county clerk and the secretary of state to post early voting and early voting by mail applications on its website to complete before printing.

name: Relating to unlawful altering of election procedures.
categories: Oversight and accountability,Enforcement against officials,Election officials
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the secretary of state to send notice to a public official who has been accused of an improper election procedure to correct the action. If corrective action is not taken, the secretary will send notice to the attorney general to take further action and apply potential penalties.

name: Relating to certain ballot access requirements.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the number of signatures required for a candidate’s names to appear on the ballot and the required filing fees for various offices.

name: Relating to repealing the ability to declare certain unopposed candidates for office as elected.
summary: As introduced, this bill makes nonsubstantive changes to the election code.

name: Relating to requirements for certain petitions requesting an election and ballot propositions.
categories: Ballot measures (initiative and referendum),Enforcement against officials,Legal causes of action
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires a proposition to use definitive, clear, and neutral language so that it does not mislead the voter.
  • Permits a voter to seek court action to compel the governing body of the city to comply with this language provision if a court order mandates it to do so. 
  • Permits a qualified voter to file a complaint with the secretary of state to determine if the wording provisions for definitive, clear, and neutral proposition language are being met. The secretary can make changes to the ballot proposition language and submit back to the home-rule city for use in the election.
  • Clarifies an illegible signature on a petition submitted to a home-rule city cannot be invalidated if certain requirements are met.
  • Permits a religious organization to circulate or submitting a petition in connection with a recall election.

name: Relating to authorizing certain cities to change the date on which their general election for officers is held.
summary: As introduced, this bill authorizes a city of certain size, a council-manager form of government, and that holds its general election for officers on a date other than the November uniform election date may change the date for its general election for officers to the November uniform election date.

name: Relating to the deadline for submitting certain recount petitions.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the deadlines for submission of recount petitions.

name: Relating to the amount of a filing fee for certain candidates.
summary: As introduced, this bill increases the state representative candidate filing fee to $1,250.

name: Relating to the process of applying for a place on a ballot.
most_recent_action: Senate State Affairs Committee Hearing (09:00:00 09:00:00 Senate Chamber)

name: Relating to the requirements to access the online tracker of an application for a ballot to be voted by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs a voter to provide their name, date of birth, and driver or ID number or the last 4 digits of their social security number to access their status information online in the mail-in ballot application system.

name: Relating to the procedure for closing a polling place.
categories: Counting and canvassing procedures,In-person voting and polling places
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the presiding election judge or alternate election judge to print the tape to show the number of votes cast for each candidate or ballot measure for each voting machine on the last day of in-person early voting.

name: Relating to the operation of political parties.
Relating to hours of service by an election watcher.
summary: As introduced, this bill removes the time commitments necessary for poll watchers to choose their own hours and a provision related to using cell phones while on duty.

name: Relating to election integrity and security, including by preventing fraud in the conduct of elections in this state; authorizing a penalty, increasing a penalty.
Relating to the interstate voter registration crosscheck program.
summary: As introduced, this bill adds conditions related to the state’s participation in the interstate voter registration crosscheck program.

name: Relating to elimination of the countywide polling place program.
summary: As introduced, this bill eliminates the countywide polling place program.

name: Relating to death records maintained and provided by the vital statistics unit of the Department of State Health Services.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the department of state health services to implement a method to provide death information to the secretary of state to assist in maintaining the statewide voter registration list.

name: Relating to accommodating a voter unable to enter a polling place.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires two election officers to provide assistance to mark a ballot to person who needs accommodations. Any person accompanying the voter shall exit the vehicle and remain outside of the vehicle unless the person is asked by the voter for assistance.

name: Relating to the availability of paper ballots for a person voting by personal appearance.
categories: Voting equipment,In-person voting and polling places
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election officer to provide a paper ballot to a voter who requests a paper ballot. Each polling place in a precinct is required to have a method of printing paper ballots unless they have the proper number of ballots procured.

name: Relating to release of an area from a municipality's extraterritorial jurisdiction by petition or election.
Relating to eligibility for early voting by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill creates an exception for a late mail-in ballot to be accepted for voters whose work requires frequent and unexpected travel and the voter will need to be absent from their county on election day and during the period for early voting in-person.

name: Relating to the disclosure of anonymous voted ballots under the public information law.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the general custodian of election record to provide public access to anonymous voted ballots, cast vote records, ballot images, authentication files, ballot reports and related records on the 61st day after an election.

name: Relating to counting certain voted ballots by hand; creating a criminal penalty.
Relating to the process for filling a vacancy on the board of trustees of an independent school district.
summary: As introduced, this bill provides that If a vacancy occurs on the board of trustees of a school district, the remaining trustees may not fill the vacancy by appointment. The board shall fill the vacancy at the district's next general election or through a special election process.

name: Relating to the authority of the secretary of state to order a new election in certain counties.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the secretary of state to order a new election in a county of more than 1 million people if the secretary believes that at least two percent of the total number of polling places in the county did not receive supplemental ballots for one or more hours after making the request.

name: Relating to an election to approve the issuance of bonds or other debt.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election to authorize the issuance of bonds or other debt to receive two-thirds of the voters on the proposition to pass.

name: Relating to centrally counted optical scan ballots.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election authority operating a central counting station to purchase and use a centrally counted optical ballot scan system. A system must use a data storage device that once written on is not capable of being modified or becomes unreadable if a person attempts to modify it.

name: Relating to acceptable forms of identification for voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill adds a Native American ID or tribal document with a photo, a higher education ID with a photo, and a state agency ID with a photo to the list of acceptable voter IDs.

name: Relating to the procedure for early voting.
categories: Counting and canvassing procedures,Early voting administration,In-person voting and polling places
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the presiding election judge or alternate election judge to print the tape to show the number of votes cast for each candidate or ballot measure for each voting machine after closing the polls for voting on election day and on the last day of in-person early voting. This bill also requires the same closing and securing of voting machines measures as required on election day.

name: Relating to establishing election marshals and enforcing violations of elections law.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes a system of appointed state election marshals to investigate any allegations of election law violations. The secretary of state must create a clearinghouse for allegations of election violations to be reported for election marshals to investigate and direct to the attorney general if probable cause is found.

name: Relating to nominations by primary election by all political parties.
Relating to practices and procedures for an early voting ballot voted by mail.
Relating to requiring public schools to designate certain uniform election dates as staff development days.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a school that serves as a polling place to designate election day as a staff development day. A waiver will be given for the minutes of instructional time suspended.

name: Relating to requirements for a trial in the contest of an election for an office.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a county clerk to be a party in a trial related to any contested election that alleges an election official engaged in improper conduct. The clerk cannot be paid or incur costs related to having to take part in the trial.

name: Relating to the confidentiality of certain home address information in certain documents.
Relating to the provision of information relating to certain election officials appointed by the commissioners court.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the county clerk to provide to the county chair of each political party a list of each presiding election judge and alternate presiding judge appointed by the commissioners court. If a county chair holding a primary requests it in writing, the county clerk must  provide a list of election officers, election judges, and additional details of each person listed.

name: Relating to the adoption of a climate policy in a municipal charter.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a municipality or charter commission to receive approval on a climate charter from the appropriate state agency to propose a climate charter for a municipality or an amendment to a municipality's climate charter.

name: Relating to the posting of an application for a place on the ballot in certain elections on an election authority's internet website.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a candidate’s application for a place on the ballot and accompanying petition must be made available and posted to the election authority's website not later than 5pm on the date that the application is received.

name: Relating to promoting voter registration and voting participation in rural counties.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows a voter registrar in a county with less than 250,000 to use state funds to promote voter registration and participation.

name: Relating to the presidential electors of this state.
Relating to authorizing certain cities to change the date on which their general election for officers is held.
summary: As introduced, this bill authorizes a city of certain size, a city-manager form of government, and that holds its general election for officers on a date other than the November uniform election date may change the date for its general election for officers to the November uniform election date.

name: Relating to the venue for the prosecution of an election offense.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a felony offense related to the election code to be prosecuted in a judicial district adjoining the judicial district in which the offense occurred. This bill also permits a misdemeanor offense related to the election code to be prosecuted in a county adjoining the county in which the offense occurred.

name: Relating to electioneering conducted near a polling place.
summary: As introduced, this bill creates an electioneering offense for a person who conducts exit polling within 100ft of a polling place.

name: Relating to the procedure for duplicating ballots for automatic counting.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows a ballot to be duplicated so that it can be automatically counted if an electronic system ballot is damaged so badly it cannot be automatically counted.

name: Relating to the powers and duties of the State Commission on Judicial Conduct.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows the State Commission on Judicial Conduct to accept complaints, conduct investigations, and take any other action as allowed in the Constitution for a judge candidate in the same manner as a judge.

name: Relating to ballots voted by mail and the prosecution of the offense of unlawful solicitation and distribution of an application to vote by mail.
Relating to the process of canvassing elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a canvassing authority to compare the precinct returns with the corresponding tally list.

name: Relating to the duty of the attorney general to prosecute certain criminal offenses.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the attorney general to prosecute criminal offenses related to the election code.

name: Relating to the procedure for closing a polling place.
categories: Counting and canvassing procedures,In-person voting and polling places
summary: As introduced, this bill permits any watcher present, but not more than three, to sing the tape printed to show the number of votes cast for each candidate or ballot measure for each voting machine.

name: Relating to the filing fee required for certain candidates.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the required candidate filing fees for various offices.

name: Relating to the disposition of certain election records.
Relating to the systems used in a central counting station.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits an authority operating a central counting station from purchase or using a ballot scanner unless the scanner can only use a data storage device that is incapable of being modified without rendering the device unreadable.

name: Relating to the security of election systems.
Relating to the public inspection of election records.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election record to be made available to the public no later than 10 days after the date the custodian receives a request for public inspection. The general custodian of election records must make available for public inspection election records no later than 60 days after an election.

name: Relating to the review of ballot proposition language for certain political subdivision elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a political subdivision to submit ballot language and a brief statement on the purposes to the attorney general for consistency with state law. The bill provides for what happens if the ballot language is not consistent and rejected or if the attorney general does not respond to the submission.

name: Relating to the distribution of an application for a ballot to be voted by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits any exemptions to distributing an application form for an early voting ballot to a person who did not request an application.

name: Relating to the procedure for duplicating ballots for automatic counting.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows a ballot to be duplicated so that it can be automatically counted if an electronic system ballot is damaged so badly it cannot be automatically counted.

name: Relating to the eligibility of political party candidates or officers and certain procedures of the county executive committee.
Relating to unlawful altering of election procedures.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the secretary of state to send notice to a public official who has been accused of an improper election procedure to correct the action. If corrective action is not taken, the secretary will send notice to the attorney general to take further action and apply potential penalties.

name: Relating to unlawful altering of election procedures.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the secretary of state to send notice to a public official who has been accused of an improper election procedure to correct the action. If corrective action is not taken, the secretary will send notice to the attorney general to take further action and apply potential penalties.

name: Relating to the authority to cancel an election on a measure.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits an election authority who ordered the election on a measure to cancel the measure on the ballot no earlier than 90 days before an election.

name: Relating to the use of paper ballots and certain electronic devices in conducting an election.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits signature rosters, poll lists, combination rosters, and ballot marking devices in electronic format from being used. If a voter requests a paper ballot, they must be provided one.

name: Relating to the audit of an election in certain counties.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows counties participating in the Countywide Polling Place program to conduct the manual count on one percent of the county's polling locations for both early voting in-person and election day in-person. In precinct-based election systems, theThe custodian of elections must select the precincts at random and begin the count no later than 72 hours after the polls close.

name: Relating to requiring notice regarding the potential eligibility to vote of certain persons convicted of a felony and the duties of a sheriff or jailer relating to elections.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a defendant placed on community supervision for a felony, a person pardoned by the governor for a felony offense, or an offender who has completed their sentence to be notified of their potential eligibility to register to vote. A sheriff or jailer are also required to provide notification to prisoners about their potential eligibility to vote, provide applications to vote by mail, and assist in voting by mail.

name: Relating to the members on a signature verification committee.
Relating to a tribunal declaring an election void.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits the tribunal hearing an election contest to declare an election void if the tribunal determines the number of illegal votes is equal to or greater than the number of votes necessary to change the outcome of an election.

name: Relating to a notice of the delivery of provisional ballots.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the presiding judge of an election precinct to prepare a notice of the number of provisional ballots delivered to the general custodian of elections records daily and deliver the notice to the central counting station, lower counting stations, or the early voting ballot board.

name: Relating to the suspension of the authority of a county election officer.
Relating to restrictions on candidacy in the general election.
summary: As introduced, this bill specifies that a candidate applying to be a replacement candidate who did not receive approval from the executive committee may not run as a write-in candidate for that office in the next general election.

name: Relating to authorizing certain election precincts to consolidate.
Relating to the procedure for closing a polling place.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits the presiding election judge or alternate election judge at a polling place from ordering the polls to stay open past the official closing time. A district judge, county court at law judge, or statutory county court judge may not issue an order extending the hours that polls are required to remain open at any polling place.

name: Relating to the procedure for duplicating ballots for automatic counting.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that the manager will designate teams of two election officers, of different political parties, with exceptions, to prepare duplicate ballots.
  • Outlines procedures for duplicate ballot creation by election officers.
  • Requires the manager of the central counting station to post the time that ballots will be duplicated to ensure poll watchers can observe the activity.

name: Relating to the members on an early voting ballot board.
Relating to requiring a general custodian of election records to adopt procedures for public inspection of voted ballots.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Directs a general custodian of election records to develop procedures and policy for providing access to voted ballots for public inspection.
  • Outlines minimum policy requirements, including redacting personally identifiable information, time period, logging names of those who accessed records, use of video technology to monitor record access,  security measures, procedures to remove other materials from the room.
  • Outlines general requirements regarding access to the ballot including requiring one member of the staff to be present; prohibition of writing devices, food, and beverages; prohibition of removal of records, permitting certain imaging devices, and storage in certain containers.
  • Specifies that the rules will also apply to electronic ballot records, where applicable.
  • Clarifies that a county may image of scan voted ballots before making them available for public inspection.

name: Relating to the residence address of an applicant for purposes of voter registration.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires that that a person must habitually sleep at a residence to use the residence on their voter registration application purposes. If the applicant has no residence, they must make a statement on their application about not having a residence.

name: Relating to the plan for the operation of a central counting station.
categories: Oversight and accountability,Counting and canvassing procedures
summary: As introduced, this bill provides for the requirements of an operating plan for a central counting location. This plan must be posted to the county’s website where election information is provided no later than 15 days before an election.

name: Relating to election precinct boundaries and the establishment of polling places.
Relating to vote harvesting; creating a civil penalty.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Clarifies that a person committing the offense of vote harvesting is liable to any candidate or party harmed by the services for damages and penalties.
  • Outlines what a person needs to demonstrate to prove that they were harmed by vote harvesting services.
  • Outlines what must be demonstrated to establish standing in the case.
  • Lists what a litigant who prevails may be able to recover in compensation and penalties.
  • Specifies penalties when a litigant who can demonstrate that the number of voters contacted by the vote harvesting service exceeds the number of votes by which he or she lost the election.
  • Provides that a person found liable for damages is jointly liable with any other defendant for the entire amount of damages.
  • Clarifies that a case may be brought in the county where any part of the vote harvesting services occurred.

name: Relating to the oversight of and reporting requirements for the county elections administrator.
Relating to election precinct boundaries and the establishment of polling places.
summary: Relating to election precinct boundaries and the establishment of polling places.

name: Relating to the use of a public school as a polling place.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits a polling place from being located on a public primary or secondary school campus.

name: Relating to notice requirements for a public test of logic and accuracy of a voting system.
summary: As introduced, this bill provides for the public notice requirements for the rescheduling of public tests of logic and accuracy for voting systems.

name: Relating to counting certain voted ballots by hand; creating a criminal penalty.
summary: Relating to counting certain voted ballots by hand; creating a criminal penalty.

name: Relating to storing data received from a centrally counted optical scan ballot.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election authority operating a central counting station to purchase and use a centrally counted optical ballot scan system that stores data on a computer with a data storage disc that is incapable of being overwritten during a system upgrade.

name: Relating to the form of a constitutional amendment on a ballot.
Relating to conduct constituting the criminal offense of illegal voting; increasing a criminal penalty.
categories: Enforcement against non-officials,Legal causes of action
summary: As introduced, this bill classifies certain offenses related to attempting to vote when a person knows that he or she is not eligible to vote as felonies, and makes clarifying edits.

name: Relating to the security of election systems.
Relating to voting a limited ballot following the change of the county of residence by a voter.
summary: As introduced, this bill specifies that a voter eligible to vote a limited ballot due to address change may do so at an early voting polling place, or on election day at a county-wide polling place, or at a polling place in their new precinct.This bill also modifies the title of "early voting clerk" to "election officer" in existing election code related to limited ballots.

name: Relating to the administration of a temporary restraining order under the Election Code.
Relating to the practices and procedures related to early voting by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the secretary of state to provide each early voting clerk with an electronic device used to time-stamp and provides for how to use it during processing of mail-in ballots.

name: Relating to the dissolution by election of certain urban area water control and improvement districts.
Relating to the concurrent jurisdiction of prosecuting attorneys in adjoining districts or counties to prosecute criminal offenses involving the election laws in this state.
Relating to permitting poll watchers to observe certain procedures of correcting a defect in an early voting ballot voted by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows poll watchers to observe certain aspects of correcting a defect in an early voting ballot voted by mail if they submit personal information to the signature verification committee. A defect in a ballot may not be corrected in person unless two members of the signature verification committee appointed are present and each of a different party.

name: Relating to number of races displayed on an electronic system ballot screen at a time.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an electronic system ballot to display no fewer than two or more than four races on a voting screen at a time.

name: Relating to the review of ballot proposition language for certain political subdivision elections.
Relating to cooperation with other states to maintain voter registration lists.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits participation in the interstate Electronic Registration Information Center program.

name: Relating to the composition of a county election board.
Relating to the use of electronic devices to accept voters.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the secretary of state to certify an electronic device to accept voters if it produces data for retention and transfer in an electronic format capable of updating in real time and compatible with the statewide voter registration list. The secretary may not certify a device that does not meet all requirements to accept voters.

name: Relating to the residence address of an applicant for purposes of voter registration.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a voter registration application to provide for a statement that an applicant does not have an address.

name: Relating to requiring counties to cooperate with the secretary of state in randomized election audits; providing an administrative penalty.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires counties to complete a randomized election audits if the secretary of state requests or face penalties. A county selected to be audited may not be required to pay the cost of performing an audit except for these randomized audits.

name: Relating to requiring voting systems to produce a paper receipt.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits a voting system from being used that does not produce a paper receipt for the voter with the information necessary to verify that the voter's participation in the election is recorded accurately in the voter information databases.

name: Relating to action by the early voting clerk on receipt of a ballot voted by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the early voting clerk to enter the time and date on the carrier envelope on receipt of a ballot voted by mail.

name: Relating to ensuring access to the right to vote by all eligible voters.
Relating to delivery of election records by an election clerk.
Relating to the provision of the reason for rejecting a voter registration application.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a county registrar to identify which section or sections of the voter registration application were rejected and specify if the section was incomplete, was improperly filled out, or contained information identifying the applicant as ineligible to vote.

name: Relating to the suspension or termination of a county elections administrator.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits the county elections administrator employment to be suspended or terminated on the three-fifths vote of the county election commission and approval by a majority vote of the commissioners court.

name: Relating to personal information entered on the carrier envelope of a ballot to be voted by mail.
Relating to the use of certain optical scan ballot technology by an election authority operating a central counting station.
Relating to a study by the secretary of state on the accuracy of the information contained in the statewide voter information database.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the secretary of state to conduct a study regarding the accuracy of the statewide computerized voter registration list and any related database.

name: Relating to abolishing the county elections administrator position in certain counties.
Relating to electronic voter registration.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the secretary of state to implement an online application system for voter registration and the process to occur once an application is submitted.

name: Relating to abolishing the county elections administrator position in certain counties.
summary: As introduced, this bill transfers all powers and duties of the county elections administrator of a county with than one million people to the county tax assessor-collector and county clerk. The county tax assessor-collector will serve as the voter registrar, and the county clerk will retain their duties carried out by the elections administrator previously. The commissioners court of a county with a population of one million or less may create the position of county elections administrator for the county.

name: Relating to the timing of state financing for voter registration.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes the timeframe for reimbursements to registrars for voter registration expenditures.

name: Relating to the concurrent jurisdiction of prosecuting attorneys in adjoining districts or counties to prosecute criminal offenses involving the election laws in this state.
Relating to the election date for the authorization of the issuance of bonds or a tax increase.
categories: Election dates,Alignment of elections,Ballot measures (initiative and referendum)
summary: As introduced this bill requires an election for issuance of bonds or tax increase to occur during a November election.

name: Relating to a procedure for applying for a place on a ballot as a candidate for precinct chair of a political party; providing an administrative penalty.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the secretary of state to adopt rules establishing a procedure for the filing of applications with the county chair for a place on the ballot as a candidate for precinct chair of a political party.

name: Relating to the public inspection of election records.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Specifies that election records that are public information must be made available no later than ten days after a request for public inspection is received.
  • Defines "election record" to include anything created by the government, in addition to anything distributed or received.
  • Requires that election records including original voter ballots, and images of voted ballots, be made available for public inspection by the 60th day after an election.
  • Requires the custodian of records to adopt procedures that remove personally identifiable information of the voter contained on a ballot that is made available for public inspection.

name: Relating to the eligibility of certain persons to vote early by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill removes the eligibility of persons based on age to vote early by mail.

name: Relating to penalties for the intimidation and harassment of election officials; creating criminal offenses.
summary: As introduced, this bill creates an offense for a person who intimidates or harasses an election worker on more than occasion.

name: Relating to the process of canvassing elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the canvassing authority to compare precinct returns with the corresponding tally list, rather than making it optional.

name: Relating to the qualifications necessary for a political party to have the names of its nominees placed on the ballot.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Ballot access for parties
summary: As introduced, this bill increases the percentage of votes in the previous statewide election required for a party's statewide candidate to be placed on the ballot from 5% to 10%.

name: Relating to a proposition to approve the issuance of bonds or other debt.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Proposes that issuance of bonds or other debt should be submitted to voters via proposition in November elections.
  • Grants that if a proposition requires submission to voters on a date not connected to a November election, the election authority may set an election date to comply with requirements.

name: Relating to ballots voted by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the general custodian of election records to keep an image of the voter's signature on the carrier envelope and early voting ballot application for at least 6 years and makes signature verification changes.

name: Relating to automatic voter registration on interaction with a voter registration agency.
summary: As introduced, this bill automatically registers a person to vote with the issuance or change to a driver’s license or ID card unless the applicant declines to register.

name: Relating to a candidate's application for a place on the ballot for a party's primary election.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits a candidate from filing an application for a place on the general primary election ballot with more than one political party in the same voting year and permits an election authority to void an application if one is received. A candidate whose application is voided under this section is ineligible for a place on the ballot for the succeeding general election for state and county officers.

name: Relating to county election precincts.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a county election precinct to contain between 500 and 10,000 registered voters. If the county populationis under 100,000, the maximum number of registered voters the precinct may contain is 5,000. No later than September 15 of each odd-numbered year, each commissioners court must determine if the county election precincts comply with certain requirements and may make boundary changes at any time if necessary.

name: Relating to the declaration of a candidate's ineligibility on the basis of failure to pay a filing fee or submit a petition in lieu of a filing fee.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a candidate to be declared ineligible if the candidate fails to pay the filing fee or submit a petition in lieu of a filing fee.

name: Relating to the disposition of certain election records.
categories: Administrative deadlines,Transparency,Ballot design,Counting and canvassing procedures,Provisional ballots,Chain of custody,Physical security
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Adds certain required information to the register, including the range of serial numbers of the ballots provided to voters, the range of serial numbers of ballots received for voting at a polling place, and serial numbers of spoiled ballots.
  • Directs that provisional ballots be placed in a separate envelope.
  • Directs that all provisional ballots at a precinct be placed in a ballot box.
  • Requires rejected early voting provisional ballots be placed in envelopes segregated and marked by precinct.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Changes the length of time to keep precinct election records from 22 months to 36 months.
  • Makes mandatory (instead of optional) procedures for handling ballots on the 61st day after an election, including keeping ballots segregated and marked by precinct, and creating and maintaining a public index of voted ballots and ballot numbers.
  • Prohibits a ballot box or other container containing voted ballots from being opened for the first 60 days of the preservation period.
  • Specifies that the ballot container must be sealed and the number logged to ensure a chain of custody.
  • Requires a ballot box opened during the preservation period to be resealed and a uniquely numbered, logged seal.
  • Requires the general custodian of election records to post ballot images, if they are imaged, with certain specifications, on the website no later than five days after the election.
  • Requires the opening of the box be witnessed by two witnesses, who must sign a specified sworn statement.
  • Specifies that the custodian of the key to ballot box no. 3 must keep the key in a secure, locked place.

name: Relating to the voter registration of naturalized United States citizens.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a county voter registrar to automatically register a resident of the county who is eligible to vote upon issuance of a certificate of naturalization.

name: Relating to the use of a public school as a polling place.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits a polling place from being located on a public primary or secondary school campus.

name: Relating to conduct constituting the criminal offense of illegal voting; increasing a criminal penalty.
summary: As introduced, this bill clarifies a person commits an offense if the person intentionally votes or attempts to vote in an election if the person knows of a particular circumstance that makes them not eligible to vote. The bill also increases the penalties for illegal voting to a felony of the second degree unless the person is convicted of an attempt which is a state jail felony.

name: Relating to requirements for counties posting election information on an Internet website.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a county to use the domain ".gov" or ".texas.gov" for a website used to post election information.

name: Relating to the elections and operations of certain hospital districts.
Relating to the required use of paper ballots in certain counties.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a county with a population of less than 75,000 to maintain a printer at each polling place for printing additional ballots and may only adopt voting systems that use paper ballots.

name: Relating to the use of preferential voting in an election of officers of a municipality.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a municipality to use a preferential voting system in the election of an officer of a municipality if the city charter authorizes it.

name: Relating to the office hours of an election authority during an election period.
summary: As introduced, this bill defines “regular business day" for an election authority to mean a day the main business office of the county, city, or otherpolitical subdivision is regularly open for business.

name: Relating to the interstate voter registration crosscheck program.
summary: As introduced, this bill adds conditions related to the state’s participation in the interstate voter registration crosscheck program.

name: Relating to the eligibility requirements to serve as an election watcher.
summary: As introduced, this bill removes eligibility requirements for election watchers other than being a qualified voter and to complete training.

name: Relating to the form, content, and delivery of a voter registration certificate.
Relating to maintaining certain voter registration information and reviewing ballots voted by mail; creating criminal offenses.
Relating to the procedure for closing a polling place.
Relating to voting by a voter unable to enter a polling place.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits an election officer to deliver a ballot to the voter at the polling place entrance or curb if the voter is physically unable to enter without assistance, has a child under 12 who requires supervisor, or is the primary caretaker of a person who is unable to care for themselves.

name: Relating to the availability on the Internet of reports of political contributions or expenditures filed in connection with certain offices.
Relating to the conduct and administration of elections; providing a civil penalty.
Relating to the authority of the legislature, governor, and certain political subdivisions with respect to disasters and emergencies.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits the governor to suspend a provision of the Election Code only during the first 30 days of a declared state of disaster and the legislature must respond to the suspensions if the disaster exceeds 30 days. The governor may not suspend a provision of the Election Code related to early voting by mail or accepting a voter during any voting period with certain exceptions. The governor is not prohibited from extending the voting period for early voting by mail to address the declared disaster.

name: Relating to matters affecting the powers and duties of the Texas Ethics Commission.
Relating to the ability of a volunteer deputy registrar to distribute and receive applications for a ballot to be voted by mail.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Enforcement against officials,Election workers/volunteers
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a volunteer deputy registrar to supply vote by mail applications to county voters and accept completed application for delivery to an early voting clerk. A volunteer deputy registrar commits an offense if they do not deliver the completed applications.

name: Relating to voting a limited ballot on election day following the change of the county of residence by a voter.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a statement to be submitted to an election officer at any early voting polling place where voters may submit a limited ballot if the person is voting in-person and recently changed their address on their voter registration.

name: Relating to the directors and administration of the Hidalgo County Water Improvement District No. 3; creating a criminal offense.
Relating to the selection of the chief appraiser of an appraisal district; authorizing a fee.
Relating to the reporting of direct campaign expenditures by certain persons and political committees.
Relating to the adoption and amendment of an annual budget by certain emergency services districts.
Relating to the selection of the chief appraiser of an appraisal district; authorizing a fee.
Relating to early voting by mail.
Relating to the use of electronic devices to accept voters.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the secretary of state to certify an electronic device to accept voters if it produces data for retention and transfer in an electronic format capable of updating in real time and compatible with the statewide voter registration list. The secretary may not certify a device that does not meet all requirements to accept voters.

name: Relating to processes to address election irregularities; providing a civil penalty.
Relating to the use of political contributions by a candidate or officeholder for child-care expenses.
Relating to postage for early voting ballots voted by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a mail-in ballot carrier envelope to be prepared so that it can be mailed free of postage.

name: Relating to requiring notice regarding the potential eligibility to vote of certain persons convicted of a felony.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a judge who discharges a defendant placed on community supervision for a felony to notify in writing the defendant that they may be eligible to register to vote. The department must notify in writing an offender who completes the offender's sentence that the offender may be eligible to register to vote.

name: Relating to certain procedures for voters to vote a limited ballot in a new county of residence.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a statement to be submitted to an election officer at any early voting polling place where voters may submit a limited ballot if the person is voting in-person and recently changed their address on their voter registration.

name: Relating to the voter registration powers of volunteer deputy registrars.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a volunteer deputy registrar to serve throughout the state regardless of the county the deputy was appointed. A volunteer deputy registrar may distribute a voter registration application throughout the state and receive a completed application in person regardless of the county in which the application was printed.

name: Relating to automatic voter registration of students enrolled in public institutions of higher education.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the voter registrar of each county to automatically register any county resident who is eligible to vote and is enrolled in an institution of higher education. The higher education applicant can decline to register to vote.

name: Relating to imposing a civil penalty for a violation of the Election Code.
summary: As introduced, this bill imposes civil penalties of no less than $100,000.for a person who commits an election law offense in the state

name: Relating to election integrity and security, including by preventing fraud in the conduct of elections in this state; authorizing a penalty, increasing a penalty.
categories: Voting equipment,Poll observers,Transparency,Signature matching,Ballot design,Counting and canvassing procedures,Certification,Reporting,Early voting administration,Early voting duration,In-person voting and polling places,Electioneering,Enforcement against officials,Enforcement against non-officials,Legal causes of action,Voter list maintenance,In-person voter assistance,Digital/electronic voting,Chain of custody,Video surveillance,Physical security,Cybersecurity
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that in-person voting may occur for a total of nine consecutive days, including election day.
  • Modifies the maximum number of registered voters in a county election precinct from 5,000 to 2,000.
  • Authorizes early voting polling places to be located in an adjoining precinct, allowing more than one precinct to vote at a polling place, if it meets certain requirements.
  • Stipulates that the room being used as a polling place may be used solely for the purpose when an election is being conducted, and requires that it be locked and secured from unauthorized access when an election judge is not present.
  • Provides penalties for certain election related offenses.
  • Prohibits a polling place being located at a business location of a candidate, or certain others with a relationship to the candidate.
  • Prohibits a polling place being located in a movable structure.
  • Makes clarifying edits.
  • Provides penalties certain election related offenses for election administrators and officials.
  • Changes some election related offenses from misdemeanors to felonies.
  • Requires ballot printing be done within the state.
  • Specifies ballot chain of custody procedures in printing and delivering ballots, and specifies penalties.
  • Outlines procedures in the case of a misprint or ballot error.
  • Outlines ballot security design requirements, including numbering ballots.
  • Requires specified ballot hand counting procedures during the canvass, and requires video recording, publicly posted, and possibly live-streamed.
  • Specifies which items must be in plain view for the video feed, including provisional ballots, ballot boxes, and more.
  • Outlines detailed procedures for counting ballots, including location, who does the counting, video recording, supervision, watchers, and reporting results.
  • Specifies how the public may access video recordings, and for what length of time.
  • Outlines reporting and follow up procedures for if a registered voter believes there was an error.
  • Outlines procedures for if the canvassing authority does not address an error, including recall procedures and court procedures.
  • Outlines ballot transport procedures and prohibitions in handling ballots.
  • Requires results of a hand count be posted publicly in certain ways and in certain locations.
  • Outlines procedures for if a judge suspects a security breach, including conduct of a full investigation and reporting.
  • Removes 5:30pm as the end time of voting and instead leaves the time unspecified.
  • Adds early voting to existing rules prohibiting revealing information about voting.
  • Makes clarifying edits to existing law.
  • Makes an exception for watchers in existing law prohibiting use of electronic devices at a polling place.
  • Requires a printed poll list of registered voters printed 30 days before election day be at each precinct.
  • Requires each voter to sign the poll list.
  • Outlines procedures for election officers to enter each voter's name on a separate voter roster, and outlines additional vote roster format requirements and entry requirements.
  • Outlines procedures for if the poll list indicates that someone requested a mail ballot.
  • Requires the poll book to have a spot for a voter to declare an impediment.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relating to establishing election marshals and enforcing violations of elections law.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes a system of appointed state election marshals to investigate any allegations of election law violations. The secretary of state must create a clearinghouse for allegations of election violations to be reported for election marshals to investigate and direct to the attorney general if probable cause is found.

name: Relating to the recall of a United States senator by the legislature.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows an elected U.S. senator to be subject to recall by a majority vote of each house of the legislature.

name: Relating to the text of ballot propositions that increase taxes.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires ballot propositions that increase taxes to include the statement “"THIS IS A TAX INCREASE.”

name: Relating to verifying the citizenship of an applicant for voter registration; creating a criminal offense.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a voter registration applicant’s citizenship to be verified with documentation. A criminal offense is created for voter registrars who fail to verify an applicant’s citizenship status, and the bill provides for penalties.

name: Relating to increasing the criminal penalty for election fraud.
categories: Enforcement against non-officials,Legal causes of action
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the criminal penalty for election fraud from a misdemeanor to a felony.

name: Relating to the deadline for submitting certain recount petitions.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes the deadlines for recount petitions to be submitted after canvasses.

name: Relating to the ability of voters with certain disabilities to cast a secret ballot.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the secretary of state to develop an online tool that allows a voter with certain disabilities to complete an application to vote by mail or vote online with the use of assistive technology. The online tool must allow the voter to complete an application or vote without personal assistance.

name: Relating to prohibiting the designation of polling place locations on the campuses of institutions of higher education.
Relating to a notice of the delivery of provisional ballots.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the presiding judge of an election precinct to prepare a daily notice of the number of provisional ballots delivered to the general custodian of elections records and deliver the notice to the central counting station, the counting station, or the early voting ballot board.

name: Relating to number of races displayed on an electronic system ballot screen at a time.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an electronic system ballot to display no fewer than two or more than four races on a voting screen at a time.

name: Relating to accommodating a voter unable to enter a polling place.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires two election officers to provide assistance to mark a ballot to person who needs accommodations. Any person accompanying the voter shall exit the vehicle and remain outside of the vehicle unless the person is asked by the voter for assistance.

name: Relating to increasing the criminal penalty for election fraud.
Relating to the declaration of a candidate's ineligibility and to the prohibition of the candidate's placement on the ballot.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election authority responsible for preparing ballots to omit a candidate from the ballot if the candidate is declared ineligible including for failing to pay a filing fee or submit a petition in place of the fee.

name: Relating to the appointment of election clerks.

Relating to certain agreements entered into with the Department of Public Safety for the issuance of renewal and duplicate driver's licenses and other identification certificate services, including voter registration services; increasing the amount of a fee.
summary: As introduced, this bill designated private vendors who provide driver license and ID services to the department of public safety as voter registration agencies and provides for the requirements they must comply with to provide services. No fees may be collected for voter registration services.

name: Relating to the authority of certain independent school districts to change the date of the general election for officers.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits an independent school district that holds its general election for officers on a date other than the November general election to change the date to the November general election. This applies to only counties along the Mexican border with a certain population.

name: Relating to a notice of the delivery of provisional ballots.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the presiding judge of an election precinct to prepare a notice of the number of provisional ballots delivered to the general custodian of elections records daily and deliver the notice to the central counting station, lower counting stations, or the early voting ballot board.

name: Relating to the withdrawal of a candidate in a runoff primary election.
Relating to the days and hours during which the polls are open for early voting by personal appearance.
Relating to the administration and conduct of elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes the order of offices to appear on a general election ballot.

name: Relating to annual applications for ballots to be voted by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill considers a vote by mail application submitted in the year the application was submitted and the following calendar year under certain conditions.

name: Relating to the designation of polling place locations on the campuses of certain institutions of higher education.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the commissioners court to designate main campuses of certain higher education institutes as polling places.

name: Relating to the use of certain devices by a person occupying a voting station.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a voter to use their mobile phone to access ballot or candidate information that was downloaded or created before the person entered the polling place.

name: Relating to the penalty for the offense of illegal voting; increasing a criminal penalty.
categories: Enforcement against non-officials,Legal causes of action
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the penalty for illegal voting from a misdemeanor to a felony.

name: Relating to the text of ballot propositions that increase taxes.
Relating to the signature required on an application for voter registration.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a voter registration application to be signed by the applicant using ink on paper. An electronic signature or photocopied signature is not permitted.

name: Relating to local option elections to legalize or prohibit the operation of eight-liners; imposing fees and issuing fee permits; creating criminal offenses; increasing criminal penalties.
Relating to the appointment of election clerks.
Relating to the use of preferential voting in certain elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires special elections to fill a vacancy requiring election by majority vote to use preferential voting.

name: Relating to the appointment of election clerks.
Relating to the enforcement of laws relating to elections.
Relating to vote harvesting; creating a civil penalty.
Relating to the time for ordering a special election to fill a vacancy in the state legislature or in congress.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the governor to order a special election to fill a vacancy in the legislature or in congress no later than 7 days after the vacancy occurs.

name: Relating to the appointment of election officers to serve during the early voting period.
Relating to the deadline for an early voting ballot board to determine whether to accept voters' ballots.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires an early voting ballot board to verify and count provisional ballots no later than the 10th day after an election.
  • Requires an early voting ballot board to determine whether to accept mail ballots no later than the 10th day after an election.
  • Requires the presiding judge of the early voting ballot board shall deliver written notice of the reason for the rejection of a ballot to the voter no later than the 10th day after the canvass.

name: Relating to the issuance and acceptance of a high school student identification card and certain other forms of identification as identification for voting.
categories: Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,In-person voter ID,Voter ID for registration
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a school district or open-enrollment charter school to issue to each high school student enrolled a student ID card with a photo. A high school student ID or any other form, ID, or document issued by the state with a photo can be used as a proof of identity for voting.

name: Relating to written communications brought to a polling place.
Relating to the May uniform election date.
Relating to electronic voter registration.
Relating to preferential voting in runoff elections for certain voters voting by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill establishes procedures for preferential voting in runoff elections for voters for early voting by mail.

name: Relating to electronic voter registration.
Relating to a poll watcher presenting proof of identification at the polling place.
Relating to the registration of voters at a polling place and related procedures.
Relating to electronic voter registration.
Relating to the reading and marking of a ballot by a person occupying a voting station or by the person's child.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the secretary of state to develop voter education materials for parents that allow a child under 14 years of age to read and mark the ballot while accompanying the child's parent to a voting station. A child under the age of 14 years may accompany their parent, read, or mark the ballot at the direction of the parent which does not constitute assisting a voter.

name: Relating to the method of returning a ballot to be voted by mail.
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,In-person voting and polling places
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a county to post notice on its website of the location of each polling place open on election day, for early voting, and available for ballots to be dropped. The county clerk may designate certain locations for delivering mail-in ballots in person during election day or the early voting period.

name: Relating to the use of certain devices by a person near a voting station; creating a criminal offense.
Relating to the procedure for closing a polling place.
categories: Counting and canvassing procedures,In-person voting and polling places
summary: As introduced, this bill permits up to three poll watchers—in addition to all present election judges or alternate election judges—to sign the tape printed by the presiding election judge that shows the number of votes cast on each machine for each candidate or measure.

name: Relating to automatic voter registration on issuance or change of a driver's license or identification card by the Department of Public Safety.
summary: As introduced, this bill automatically registers a person to vote with the issuance or change to a driver’s license or ID card unless the applicant declines to register.

name: Relating to the penalty for the offense of illegal voting; increasing a criminal penalty.
summary: As introduced, this bill increases the criminal penalty for the offense of illegal voting to a felony of the second degree unless the person is convicted of an attempt which is a state jail felony.

name: Relating to procedures for verification of a ballot voted by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires verification of a vote by mail ballot using a card with the voter’s thumbprint and signature.

name: Relating to the days and hours during which the polls are open for early voting by personal appearance.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits in-person early voting to be extended for any number of days before an election if authorization is ordered. The polls must be open 12 hours on a weekday or Saturday and 5 hours on Sunday.

name: Relating to the authority of the board of trustees of a school district to exclude the use of district buildings as polling places and to the designation of days a school district campus is used as a polling place as staff development days.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits the board of trustees of an independent school district to exclude a building owned or controlled by the district as a polling place.  If a school is selected for use as a polling place, the school district must designate the day the campus serves as a polling place as a staff development day.

name: Relating to allowing a person who will be 18 years of age on the date of the general election for state and county officers to vote in the preceding primary elections.
Relating to documentation of proof of identification for voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill classifies a Transportation Worker Identification Credential (TWIC) card issued by the Transportation Security Administration that has not expired or that expired no earlier than 4 years as acceptable proof of identity for voting purposes.

name: Relating to a requirement for certain entities to enter into a contract for election services.
Relating to the signature required on a carrier envelope for a ballot voted by mail; changing the elements of a criminal offense.
Relating to the early voting period.
summary: As introduced, this bill designates the period for early voting by personal appearance begins on the first day of business day after the last day a voter registration becomes effective for election day.

name: Relating to voter registration application forms in high schools.
summary: • Provides that the Secretary of State will consult with Texas Education Agency to provide the appropriate number of voter registration applications to each high school each fall and spring.

name: Relating to the methods of voter registration.
summary:
• Provides for automatic voter registration for certain qualified voters when being issued a driver's license or personal identity card and outlines implementation and application guidelines.
  • Adds the requirement that the Department of Public Safety send a voter registration application to anyone applying by mail or online for ID renewal, new ID or other ID related options.
  • Stipulates that a change of address with the Department of Public Safety is a change of address for voter ID.
  • Directs the Department of Public Safety to consider applications for ID also to be an application for voter registration.
  • Clarifies that the information should be transferred to the Secretary of State with associated guidelines.

name: Relating to registering to vote and voting while in custody at certain county jails and related procedures.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: As introduced, this bill requires certain county jails to serve as polling places for inmates who are eligible to vote, make voter registration applications available for inmates, and offer same-day registration for inmates.

name: Relating to electronic voter registration.
Relating to practices and procedures for an early voting ballot voted by mail.
Relating to eligibility requirements for public office for persons finally convicted of a felony.
