summary: As introduced, this bill requires a public office candidate to have not been convicted of a felony due to a release of conviction by a court of competent jurisdiction.

name: Relating to the voter identification required for submission of an early voting ballot by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill makes a technical correction in relation to the use of election identity certification cards for early voting by mail.

name: Relating to preferential voting in a primary election.
Relating to the form of a constitutional amendment on a ballot.
Relating to qualifications and registration of certain voters on parole or mandatory supervision.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: As introduced, this bill categorizes a convicted felon who has completed their incarceration or community supervision or a person who has been released on parole or mandatory supervision as a qualified voter.

name: Relating to confirmation of a voter's residence by a voter registrar.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the registrar to request confirmation of a voter’s current residence if they have a P.O. box that does not correspond to a residence, the voter’s name is not on suspend list and hasn’t voted in the last 25 months, or reason exists that the voter’s residence is different than the one recorded.

name: Relating to eligibility to be a candidate for, or elected or appointed to, a public elective office in this state.
Relating to voter registration, including electronic voter registration.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the secretary of state to implement a program to allow a person who has a valid state-issued driver's license or ID to complete a voter registration application over the Internet from an official state website. This bill also removes certain responsibilities for deputy registrars.

name: Relating to the early voting period.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the in-person early voting period from 1-8 days before election day.

name: Relating to the acceptance of identification for voters who identify as transgender.
summary:
• Requires training for election workers regarding accepting photo identification for transgender individuals.
  • Provides that written gender identification that does not align with gender expression or identity by someone seeking to vote does not invalidate the form of identification for voting purposes.

name: Relating to software installation in voting system hardware manufactured outside the United States.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows a voting system or equipment to be considered to be manufactured in the United States if any hardware used in the voting system, if manufactured outside the United States, is delivered to the United States without embedded software installed.

name: Relating to the use of public schools as polling place locations.
summary: As introduced, this bill prevents a district that owns a building selected as polling place may not designate the building as a polling place for a board of trustees or school district bond election if the district fails to make the polling place available for voting.

name: Relating to a requirement for certain entities to enter into a contract for election services.
Relating to the selection of the chief appraiser of an appraisal district; authorizing a fee.
summary: As introduced, this bill provides for the election of the chief appraiser in an appraisal district.

name: Relating to the selection of the board of directors of an appraisal district; authorizing a fee.
summary:
• Authorizes taxpayers to request an audit of the appraisal district.
  • Specifies that of the five directors on the appraisal district board of directors, four are election in precincts, while one is elected at-large.
  • Establishes terms for members of the board, as well as vacancy procedures.
  • Establishes rules for directors moving out of the precinct while on the board.
  • Establishes a filing fee for the appraisal district director election, based upon population size.
  • Provides clarifying language.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relating to automatic voter registration on issuance or change of a driver's license or identification card by the Department of Public Safety.
summary: As introduced, this bill automatically registers a person to vote with the issuance or change to a driver’s license or ID card unless the applicant declines to register.

name: Relating to the cancellation of a person's voter registration on notice that the person has acknowledged that the person is not a citizen.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs requires a person’s voter registration to be cancelled on notice from a government agency the person is not a U.S. citizen.

name: Relating to allowing straight-party voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits straight-party voting and sets forth the necessary election procedures.

name: Relating to authorizing certain political subdivisions to change the date on which their general election for officers is held.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits the governing body of political subdivisions, other than a county or municipal utility district, to change the general election date for officer elections no later than December 31, 2024.

name: Relating to the selection and administration of an appraisal review board; authorizing a fee.
summary:
• Changes the membership on an appraisal review board from three to five members with associated guidelines for election and terms of office.
  • Updates vacancy procedures for the appraisal review board.
  • Provides that a member of the appraisal review board may be removed for failing to complete a required course.
  • Limits appraisal review board members to four terms.
  • Outlines guidelines for appointing appraisal review board members.
  • Provides that the appraisal review board may select a chairman and secretary from the board's members.
  • Provides that certain guidelines are for populations of one million or more in an appraisal district, and other guidelines are for populations of 200,000 or more.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relating to the election date for the authorization of the issuance of bonds or a tax increase.
most_recent_action: Referred to Pensions, Investments & Financial Services
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election for a bond issuance or tax increase to be held on the November uniform election date.

name: Relating to the use of public schools as polling place locations.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a board of trustees to make a school unavailable to be a polling place during school hours if the board determines this use would conflict with the school’s security plan.

name: Relating to the timing of changes to county election precincts.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs each commissioners court determines whether the county election precincts comply with established boundary requirements during March or April of each even-numbered. A change in a county election precinct boundary takes effect on the first day of the first odd-numbered year following the year changes were made.

name: Relating to the eligibility of certain persons younger than 18 years of age to preregister to vote.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a person who is at least 17 years old to preregister to vote.

name: Relating to defense of certain actions brought against election judges and clerks.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a district attorney to defend an election judge or clerk against legal action which alleges the judge or clerk committed an election violation while acting in their official capacity.

name: Relating to the reapportionment of state legislative, congressional, and judicial districts and the functions and duties of the independent redistricting commission.
summary: As introduced, this bill creates an independent redistricting commission responsible for drafting preliminary and final redistricting plans after the decennial U.S. Census for all stat legislative, congressional, and judicial districts.

name: Relating to eligibility to be a candidate for, or elected or appointed to, a public elective office in this state.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires all candidates for public office to have paid off all child support or is in a payment system or the support is being contested.

name: Relating to electronic submission of an application for an early voting ballot by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the secretary of state to implement a program to allow a person to submit an early voting by mail application over the Internet from an official state website.

name: Relating to the conduct of primary elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires primary elections in a county to be conducted jointly at the regular polling places for the general election for state and county officers.

name: Relating to accommodating voters with a disability.
summary: As introduced, this bill creates election accommodations for persons with disabilities including notification of accommodation requirements, parking requirements at polling sites, posting of early voting ballots online, distribution of printable mail-in ballot forms with the ability to be electronically transmitted, and assistance for persons who cannot enter a polling site.

name: Relating to the appointment by the attorney general of a special prosecutor to prosecute certain election offenses that are committed in an adjacent county.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows the attorney general to appoint a special prosecutor to prosecute certain election offenses that are committed in an adjacent county to where the crime may have occurred.

name: Relating to a statement by the secretary of state regarding the furnishing of certain personal information on an application for a ballot to be voted by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires the secretary of state to provide a statement on the early voting application and online that says how a voter’s personal information will be used for early voting purposes.

name: Relating to the adoption of the Agreement Among the States to Elect the President by National Popular Vote.
summary: As introduced, this bill enters Texas into agreement with the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact.

name: Relating to the method of returning a ballot to be voted by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a voter to deliver their own marked mail-in ballot to the county’s early voting site or another designated site while the polls are open during election or during the early voting period. Each county must give notice on its website of the polling places open during election day, during early voting, and open to accepting marked mail-in ballots.

name: Relating to early voting by mail by any qualified voter and to the repeal of certain criminal offenses concerning the solicitation and distribution of an application to vote by mail.
summary:
As introduced, this bill: 

  • Provides any eligible voter is eligible for early voting by mail or in-person.
  • Provides that a person who participates in the attorney general’s confidentiality program is eligible for early voting by mail only if they submitted a registration application for personal delivery.
  • Specifies in more detail who is eligible to vote by mail under different circumstances such as those who reside in a hospital, in a jail, or are civilly confined.
  • Repeals provisions related to unlawful solicitation and distribution of vote by mail.

name: Relating to the designation of polling place locations on the campuses of certain general academic teaching institutions.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the commissioners court to designate the main campus of certain educational institutes as polling places for voting.

name: Relating to the required vote by a presidential elector and related procedures.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires state electors to swear under oath their willingness to confirm the elected candidates they were nominated to certify. If an elector fails to show or swear the oath, the secretary of state must choose a substitute elector.
  • Lays out the procedures for elector voting. 
  • Requires the presidential and vice presidential candidates to affirm their willingness and ableness to serve the position they were elected. The state electors must certify the elected candidates’ willingness and ableness to serve.

name: Relating to the Texas Redistricting Commission.
summary: As introduced, this bill proposes a Constitutional amendment establishing the Texas Redistricting Commission to make redistricting and procedural decisions related to redistricting to be approved by voters.

name: Relating to electronic voter registration.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the secretary of state to implement an online application system for voter registration, the requirements to complete an application, and the process to occur once an application is submitted.

name: Relating to the separation of federal elections from state and local elections, and to related practices and procedures.
categories: Election dates,Alignment of elections,Presidential elections,Primary systems,Voter registration,Military/UOCAVA voting
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Specifies that federal elections are separate elections from any other election in the state, and that the federal election ballot may not list a state or county election.
  • Furnishes that federal and state elections should be held "separately and concurrently" using the same polling places.
  • Authorizes the secretary of state to enact related rules, and stipulates that the rules should reduce voter disruption and confusion as much as possible.
  • Defines "military service voter."
  • Specifies requirements to be eligible to vote in a federal election.
  • Outlines voting and registration procedures if someone submits a voter registration application, but does not meet all the state requirements.
  • Specifies rules and procedures for preparation of separate federal and state ballots. 
  • Provides that to the extent possible voting, tabulation, and reporting procedures should be conducted to the extent possible under the existing election code, and when federal law conflicts, procedures should follow the applicable federal law.
  • Specifies that election of federal officers should be conducted on the first Tuesday following the first Monday in November of even numbered years, concurrently with general elections for state and county officers.
  • Specifies that primary elections of federal, state, and county officers should be held concurrently the first Tuesday in March of even numbered years and that any necessary runoff elections should be on the fourth Tuesday in May following the primary.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Clarifies the validity of a federal postcard application.
  • Defines related terms.

name: Relating to the procedures for voting after changing residence to another county.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Establishes the procedure for qualified voters who have changed residence to another county to cast a provisional ballot. This bill also establishes the conditions needed to be met for the provisional ballot to be accepted.
  • Classifies an election officer serving a polling place as a deputy voter registrar and has the same authority as a regular deputy registrar.

name: Relating to requiring a voter to be affiliated with a political party to vote in that party's primary election or otherwise participate in that party's affairs; creating a criminal offense.
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Primary systems,Voter registration
summary:
HB 239 - As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires voter registration forms to include a space for an eligible voter’s party affiliation.
  • Requires a person to be affiliated with a party to be able to vote in the party’s primary or become a candidate, a nominee, or a presidential elector. This bill prescribes the procedure for a person to become affiliated with a party.
  • Establishes the dates for a county registrar to release a voter registration renewal certificate.
  • Requires an independent candidate to attest to not being affiliated with a party before being added to a general election ballot.
  • Voids a vote in a primary election or a signature for a candidate petition if the person is not affiliated with that party.
  • Creates an offense for a person voting in a primary who is not affiliated with that party.
  • Requires a candidate to attest to being affiliated with the party when they file to become a candidate for elected office or party officer. A party may not require a filing fee for candidates of a county chair or precinct. The party shall be printed next to the candidate's name on a ballot.
  • Makes a candidate petition signer ineligible to affiliate with another political party during the voting year a primary election is held. A political party may allow voters who are not affiliated with any political party to be eligible to sign a petition.

name: Relating to early voting by mail by any qualified voter and to the repeal of certain criminal offenses concerning the solicitation and distribution of an application to vote by mail.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides any eligible voter is eligible for early voting by mail or in-person. 
  • Provides that a person who participates in the attorney general’s confidentiality program is eligible for early voting by mail only if they submitted a registration application for personal delivery.
  • Specifies in more detail who is eligible to vote by mail under different circumstances such as those who reside in a hospital, in a jail, or are civilly confined. 
  • Repeals provisions related to unlawful solicitation and distribution of vote by mail.

name: Relating to the use of public schools as polling place locations.
summary: As introduced, this bill prevents a school district from using one of its buildings as a polling place for a board of trustees or for a school district bond election until 5 years after the date in which the district did not allow their buildings to be used for other elections.

name: Relating to election fraud; increasing a penalty.
summary: As introduced, this bill increases the punishment for illegally voting from a misdemeanor to a felony.

name: Relating to the date of the primary election runoff.
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the runoff primary election to the second Tuesday in April following the general primary election. The runoff primary election date for a federal office is the fourth Tuesday in May following the general primary election.

name: Relating to an application for an early voting ballot by mail.
summary: As introduced, this bill provides a mail-in ballot application will serve as both an application for the general election and any run-off election. The applicant can choose not to receive a ballot for a resulting run-off election.

name: Relating to increasing the punishment of conduct constituting the offense of illegal voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill increases the punishment for illegally voting from a misdemeanor to a felony.

name: Relating to the electronic transmission of a ballot to a voter voting early by mail on the ground of absence from the county of residence.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows a voter who is voting by mail who is not in the county of residence to receive a mail-in ballot through electronic means including through email. The marked ballot may be returned through the mail or common carrier to the early voting clerk.

name: Relating to the ballot application requirements for the election of a precinct chair.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires that a ballot application for a precinct chair contain a place for their email address, telephone number, or both.

name: Relating to the registration of voters at a polling place and related procedures.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits individuals who are qualified to register to vote to be able to at a polling site.

name: Relating to acceptable forms of identification for voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows tribal IDs, higher education IDs, and state agency IDs with photos to be used as an acceptable forms of voter ID.

name: Relating to authorizing certain political subdivisions to change the date on which their general election for officers is held.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits the governing body of political subdivisions, other than a county or municipal utility district, to change the general election date for officer elections.

name: Relating to electronic voter registration.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the secretary of state to implement an electronic registration system so that a person can register to vote over the internet.

name: Relating to the enforcement of laws relating to elections.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Establishes a system of state election marshals and inspectors to investigate any allegations of election law violations.  
  • Allows the secretary of state or an election marshal to impound voting equipment in the investigation of an election.
  • Permits a candidate or political party affiliate that fears harm from violation of election law to seek injunctive relief.
  • Clarifies which judges can preside and are disqualified from presiding over injunctive relief cases and the process for emergency review of election activities.

name: Relating to participation in the countywide polling place program.
summary: As introduced, this bill repeals a provision limiting which type of counties may participate in the countywide polling place program.

name: Relating to identification of early voting ballots voted by mail by electronic code.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires each mail-in ballot to include a unique code readable by an electronic device to verify the authenticity of the ballot. The early voting ballot board must verify that the unique code included on each ballot matches the code on record. If the code does not match a recorded code, the early voting ballot board may not count the ballot.

name: Relating to voter registration application forms in high schools.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the secretary of state to provide each Texas high school with a proper number of voter application forms once each fall and spring semester.

name: Relating to early voting by mail by any qualified voter and to the repeal of certain criminal offenses concerning the solicitation and distribution of an application to vote by mail.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides any eligible voter is eligible for early voting by mail or in-person.
  • Provides that a person who participates in the attorney general’s confidentiality program is eligible for early voting by mail only if they submitted a registration application for personal delivery.
  • Specifies in more detail who is eligible to vote by mail under different circumstances such as those who reside in a hospital, in a jail, or are civilly confined.
  • Repeals provisions related to unlawful solicitation and distribution of vote by mail.

name: Relating to the registration of voters at a polling place and related procedures.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Permits an eligible voter to register to vote at a polling place and vote on the same day.
  • Classifies an election officer serving a polling place for in-person early voting as a deputy voter registrar.
  • Requires two voter registrars to be present at each polling place while the polls are open.
  • Changes dates for verification of provisional ballots and local canvasses.

name: Relating to increasing the punishment of conduct constituting the offense of illegal voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill increases the punishment for illegally voting from a misdemeanor to a felony.

name: Relating to the days and hours during which the polls are open for early voting by personal appearance.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits in-person early voting to be extended for any number of days before an election if authorization is ordered. The polls must be open 12 hours on a weekday or Saturday and 5 hours on Sunday.

name: Relating to a requirement that an election for a member of a board of trustees of an independent school district is partisan.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires elections for board of trustees for independent school districts to be partisan affairs necessitating a party primary and a change in election dates. This bill also changes the term lengths for elected board of trustees.

name: Relating to requirements for certain petitions requesting an election and ballot propositions and to related procedures and provisions.
categories: Ballot measures (initiative and referendum),Municipal election procedures
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Requires a city charter amendment or a ballot initiative or referendum to use the same language as on the ballot petition.
  • Permits a qualified voter to seek court action to compel the governing body of the city to comply with this language provision if a court order mandates it to do so. 
  • Permits a qualified voter to file a complaint with the secretary of state to determine if the wording provisions are being met. The secretary can make changes to the ballot proposition language and submit back to the home-rule city for use in the election.
  • Clarifies the form and content of a ballot petition. 
  • Directs the secretary of state to create a standard ballot petition form that petitioners can use.
  • Prescribes procedures for home-rule cities for ballot petitions. 
  • Repeals verifying by statistical samples and effect of city charter or ordinance verification provisions.

name: Relating to acceptable forms of identification for voting.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows high education ID with a photo to be used as an acceptable form of voter ID.

name: Relating to qualifications and registration of certain voters convicted of a felony.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the qualifications for persons to vote or register to vote to include persons who are not currently incarcerated for a convicted felony.

name: Relating to the penalty for the offense of illegal voting; increasing a criminal penalty.
summary: As introduced, this bill increases the punishment for illegally voting from a misdemeanor to a felony.

name: Relating to processes to address election irregularities; providing a civil penalty.
summary: As introduced, this bill outlines the process for a requestor to address election irregularities. A requestor must make a request to the county clerk for explanation of irregularities, and the secretary of state may conduct an audit if the explanation is not satisfied with the explanation. The secretary of state must present findings to the county clerk for remedy or face potential penalties.

name: Relating to the use of preferential voting in certain elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill allows municipalities or independent school districts to establish preferential, or ranked choice voting, in any nonpartisan elections in that district.

name: Relating to notification by the secretary of state when a person convicted of a felony may register to vote.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: As introduced, the bill directs the secretary of state to notify those with felony convictions who were ineligible to vote or register to vote when they become eligible to register.

name: Relating to the authority of certain entities and individuals to prevent individuals from accessing private property for the purpose of registering voters or communicating political messages.
summary: As introduced, this bill prevents political entities, homeowner's associations, or property managers from prohibiting individuals from accessing residences for the purposes of voter registration or campaigning.

name: Relating to the appointment of volunteer deputy voter registrars.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits a registrar from refusing to appoint a volunteer deputy registrar based on their sexual orientation, gender identity, or political affiliation.

name: Relating to the punishment for illegal voting; increasing criminal penalties.
summary: As introduced, this bill increases the punishment for illegally voting from a misdemeanor to a felony.

name: Relating to the use of preferential voting in certain elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a special election held to fill a vacancy in an office requiring election by majority vote to use preferential voting.

name: Relating to authorizing certain political subdivisions to change the date on which their general election for officers is held.
summary: As introduced, this bill removes the deadline a governing body of a political subdivision that holds its general election for officers on the November general election date may change the date of its general election to the May general election date.

name: Relating to the use of paper ballots and certain electronic devices in conducting an election.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits signature rosters, poll lists, combination rosters, and ballot marking devices in electronic format from being used. If a voter requests a paper ballot, they must be provided one.

name: Relating to the election of board members of certain emergency services districts.
Relating to voter registration application forms in high schools.
Relating to qualifications and registration of certain voters convicted of a felony.
Relating to the adoption of the Agreement Among the States to Elect the President by National Popular Vote.
summary: As introduced, this bill enters Texas into agreement with the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact.

name: Relating to penalties for intimidation and harassment of election officials and election interference; creating criminal offenses.
summary:
• Outlines what constitutes intimidation or harassment of election officials, election interference, dissemination of personal information, obstructing access, and conspiracy.
  • Establishes penalties for the offenses.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Relating to regulating the cultivation, manufacture, processing, distribution, sale, testing, transportation, delivery, transfer, possession, and use of cannabis and cannabis products; authorizing the imposition of fees; requiring occupational licenses; creating a criminal offense.
summary: This bill authorizes the commissioners court of a county to order an election to approve the sale and cultivation of cannabis and specifies the language of the proposition that appears on the ballot. The election must be held on the first authorized uniform election date allowing sufficient time for compliance with any established requirements.

name: Relating to early voting by mail by any qualified voter and to the repeal of certain criminal offenses concerning the solicitation and distribution of an application to vote by mail.
summary:
As introduced, this bill: 

  • Provides any eligible voter is eligible for early voting by mail or in-person.
  • Provides that a person who participates in the attorney general’s confidentiality program is eligible for early voting by mail only if they submitted a registration application for personal delivery.
  • Specifies in more detail who is eligible to vote by mail under different circumstances such as those who reside in a hospital, in a jail, or are civilly confined.
  • Repeals provisions related to unlawful solicitation and distribution of vote by mail.

name: Relating to participation in the countywide polling place program.
summary: As introduced, this bill repeals a provision limiting which type and number of counties may participate in the countywide polling place program.

name: Relating to the eligibility of certain persons younger than 18 years of age to preregister to vote.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a person who is at least 17 years old to preregister to vote.

name: Relating to the separation of federal elections from state and local elections, and to related practices and procedures.
Relating to the use of a public school as a polling place.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits a primary or secondary school from being used a polling place.

name: Relating to requiring a voter to present proof of identification.
summary: As introduced, this bill expands the list of acceptable photo IDs and proof(s) of identity with a signed statement acceptable for voter ID purposes for in-person voting.

name: Relating to the voter registration of naturalized United States citizens.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires a county registrar to register a person to vote who is eligible to do so once the county receives notification of the voter’s naturalized citizenship status.

name: Relating to the use of preferential voting in certain elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits the governing body of a municipality or independent school district to use of preferential voting for a nonpartisan election of an officer of the municipality or school district.

name: Relating to the availability of paper ballots for a person voting by personal appearance.
summary: As introduced, this bill requires an election officer to provide a paper ballot to a voter who requests a paper ballot. Each polling place in a precinct is required to have a method of printing paper ballots unless they have the proper number of ballots procured.

name: Relating to qualifications and registration of certain voters convicted of a felony.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: As introduced, this bill classifies a person convicted of a felony but is not currently incarcerated as a qualified voter.

name: Relating to the Texas Redistricting Commission.
summary: As introduced, this bill proposes a Constitutional amendment establishing the Texas Redistricting Commission to make redistricting and procedural decisions related to redistricting to be approved by voters.

name: Relating to allowing a person who will be 18 years of age on the date of the general election for state and county officers to vote in the preceding primary elections.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a voter who will be 18 years old and eligible to vote in the next general election in the preceding primary election.

name: Relating to cooperation with other states to maintain voter registration lists.
summary: As introduced, this bill prohibits participation in the interstate Electronic Registration Information Center program.

name: Relating to electronic voter registration.
summary: As introduced, this bill directs the secretary of state to implement an online application system for voter registration, the requirements to complete an application, and the process to occur once an application is submitted.

name: Relating to the registration of voters at a polling place and related procedures.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Permits an eligible voter to register to vote at a polling place and vote on the same day.
  • Classifies an election officer serving a polling place for in-person early voting as a deputy voter registrar.
  • Requires two voter registrars to be present at each polling place while the polls are open.
  • Changes dates for verification of provisional ballots and local canvasses.

name: Relating to the disclosure of a voted ballot under the public information law.
summary: • Establishes that voted ballots are confidential and not subject to disclosure until the end of the preservation period.

name: Relating to registration powers of volunteer deputy registrars.
summary: As introduced, this bill permits a volunteer deputy registrar to serve throughout the state regardless of the county the deputy was appointed. A volunteer deputy registrar may distribute a voter registration application throughout the state and receive a completed application in person regardless of the county in which the application was printed.

name: Relating to the prohibition on lobbying by certain elected officers.
Relating to the enforcement of certain election laws by district attorneys, criminal district attorneys, and county attorneys; providing a civil penalty.
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Defines "policy" and "prosecuting attorney."
  • Prohibits a prosecuting attorney from adopting or enforcing a policy, or acting such that it prohibits or limits enforcement of criminal offenses prescribed by election law.
  • Prohibits a prosecuting attorney from limiting a peace officer or attorney from enforcing any criminal offense prescribed by election laws.
  • Authorizes an attorney general to bring action in Travis County or in a district court in which the prosecuting attorney is located to issue an injunction in violation of the above prohibitions.
  • Directs that the attorney general may recover "reasonable expenses incurred" in obtaining relief and lists possible expenses to be included.
  • Provides that a prosecuting attorney who a court finds has intentionally violated the above prohibitions is subject to certain civil penalties, and specifies that each day of continuing violation constitutes a separate violation for the penalties imposed, giving power to the court that hears an action to determine the amount of the penalty.
  • Furnishes that the attorney general may sue to collect the penalty and to recover reasonable expenses incurred, with a list of potential expenses.
  • Waives and abolishes sovereign immunity of the state and governmental immunity of a county to the extent of a created liability.
  • Provides that a prosecuting attorney may forfeit their office if the prosecuting attorney violates the above prohibitions, and outlines a petition process for the attorney general to file under the Civil Practice and Remedies Code and requires the court in which the petition is filed to give precedence to such related proceedings, as well as enter a judgement removing the person from office if he or she is found guilty.

name: Public Notice Requirements
most_recent_action: Governor Signed in Lieutenant Governor's office for filing
summary:
• Requires notification of an election four weeks before election day.
  • Requires notification of an incorporation election at least three weeks before the day of the election.
  • Requires the county clerk to provide notice of a public hearing regarding determination of the number of council members and specifies who will pay the costs.
  • Requires notification of at least two weeks before an election of officers of a new municipality.
  • Outlines notification guidelines in future metro township elections.
  • Requires notice of local election at least three weeks before the election.
  • Requires local district board elections to provide notice at least ten days before the first day of filing of candidacy.
  • Requires notification of cancellation of local elections at least 15 days before the election.
  • Requires notification of testing tabulating equipment at least four weeks before the day of the test.
  • Requires notice of a general election in each voting precinct for seven days before the election and requires an election officer to provide certain information to voters at least five days before the election.
  • Requires notification of ballot drop box locations at least 19 days before the election.
  • Outlines notification guidelines for public hearings before initiative petitions are circulated.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Details requirements for certain types of notices.

name: Elections Record Amendments
most_recent_action: Governor Signed in Lieutenant Governor's office for filing
summary:
As introduced on January 27, 2023, this bill:

  • Requires county election clerks to provide written notice to voters whose registration record was classified as a private record before May 12, 2020 that beginning on January 1, 2024 the voter's record will no longer be classified as private and lists those elements that will remain classified, and requires the voter be provided with information regarding how to classify their record as private again.
  • Outlines deadlines, language, and processes for the notification requirement.
  • Requires county clerks to comply with the above code with specific mailings and deadlines.
  • Requires the lieutenant governor to coordinate the judicial branch and pertinent advocacy groups to disseminate information.
  • Provides that a record disclosing a particular voter's ballot has been rejected is protected record.
  • Makes conforming changes.

name: Election Changes
most_recent_action: Governor Signed in Lieutenant Governor's office for filing
categories: Voting equipment,Absentee/mail-in ballot return processes,Absentee/mail-in ballot administration,Audits,Oversight and accountability,Transparency,Cure provisions,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,Signature matching,Counting and canvassing procedures,Certification,Reporting,Voter participation deadlines,Provisional ballots,Enforcement against officials,Election workers/volunteers,Election officials,Legal causes of action,Voter registration,Voter list maintenance,In-person voter assistance,Absentee/mail-in voter assistance,Testing and certification,Chain of custody,Video surveillance,Physical security,Cybersecurity
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Establishes that the lieutenant governor is the chief election officer of the state, responsible for overseeing and supervising all election related functions in the state and ensuring that each election officer complies with legal requirements relating to elections.
  • Provides the lieutenant governor full access to documents, recordings and other information in control of election officers or boards of canvassers and allows the lieutenant governor to observe, examine and copy all records.
  • Specifies that the lieutenant governor has full access to facilities, storage areas, equipment, materials, staff, and audits in control of election officers and boards of canvassers.
  • Grants the lieutenant governor the right to attend any meeting and observe and examine work within the scope of authority or responsibility related to elections.
  • Requires election officers and staff to full assist and cooperate with the lieutenant governor and his or her staff in fulfilling requirements and obtaining access.
  • Establishes procedures for if the lieutenant governor determines an election officer is in violation of an election related law or rule.
  • Establishes content and procedures for a written order (having the force of law) if the lieutenant governor determines that the violation has continued after attempts to remedy the violation.
  • Directs an election officer to fully comply with the written order, unless the officer obtains a court order rescinding or modifying the order, with certain requirements.
  • Provides that the election officer filing an action has the burden of proof.
  • Empowers the lieutenant governor to bring legal action to compel an officer to comply with the law.
  • Defines "election administrator."
  • Requires the lieutenant governor to design and provide training to election officers and related government workers without charge.
  • Details that the training should be designed for election administrators and government workers, include five sessions with two courses in each session, may require live attendance, and relate to individual election processes.
  • Outlines a timeline for beginning and completion of the training.
  • Provides reasons a lieutenant governor may waive training requirements.

  • Stipulates that an election officer must ensure that an individual conducting ballot processing auditing procedures is not auditing his or her own work.
  • Directs the lieutenant governor to keep the Government Operations Interim Committee informed of technology advancements that the committee may want to study for implementation in state elections.
  • Lists technological advancements in post election audits the lieutenant governor should study.
  • Requires the lieutenant governor to attend the last 2023 meeting of the Committee and report on methods studied and recommendations.
  • Requires the Driver License Division work with the lieutenant governor to study options for improving the quality of signatures collected for signature verification purposes and to report options, needs, costs, and recommendations by the Committees last 2023 meeting.
  • Defines relevant terms.
  • Requires the lieutenant governor to operate, maintain, and regularly monitor a statewide voter registration system that is used to maintain the statewide voter registration database with timelines and specifications for updates from the Driver License Division and the Department of Corrections.
  • Requires the lieutenant governor to use matching criteria and security measures to identify duplicate or contradictory data in the database, or changes in data, and make related notifications to the county clerk.
  • Stipulates that the lieutenant governor must maintain a document, with deadlines, describing the utilities and tools the county clerk is required to run and related actions to take on the website.
  • Requires the document to indicate by county whether the county clerk has complied by the deadline and other related compliance and dates.
  • Directs each county clerk to run the system's voter identification verification tool when he or she enters a voter registration record, and regularly report related information to the lieutenant governor.
  • Directs the county clerk to monthly run a duplicate voter utility and take related actions, and in December each year to run an annual maintenance utility.
  • Adds a timeline of "within 14 days" for sending a voter a "voter registration address" form to a voter who does not vote in two consecutive general elections.
  • Adds a timeline of "within 31 days" of receiving information for a county clerk to change a voter's address who moved within the county.
  • Makes it mandatory for a county clerk to list a voter as inactive after sending notice, if the voter requests so in writing, or the voter died.
  • Establishes that the director of elections will make rules for county clerks regulating data entry and updates of the system; establishing duties and deadlines for updating and securing the database; reporting to the lieutenant governor; running utilities and tools, and taking related actions; and documenting and reporting compliance.
  • Establishes that the director of elections will establish requirements to ensure uniformity and security of return envelopes, for complying with signature comparison audit requirements, and to conduct and document the identity verification process.
  • Requires election officers to provide an accessible voting method to voters with disability who vote in person.
  • Requires election officers to include certain existing instructions on how a person with disability may vote on the officers website and with each mailed ballot.
  • Requires poll workers to verify that the signature on the affidavit of the return envelope is consistent with an individual's signature on record, or to verify by alternative means for voters who check the related box.
  • Requires poll workers to record when an envelope is rejected and to state the reason, and to notify the voter within two business days, with certain exceptions.
  • Requires the election officer to ensure certain information related to obtaining an affidavit is communicated.
  • Requires an election officer to notify an individual if their ballot is rejected within 30 days of the rejection.
  • Provides rules and procedures for when an election officer may county a rejected ballot and requires preservation of documentation for at least 22 months.
  • Requires the director of elections to establish criteria and processes for: verifying signatures, training and certification requirements for election employees, and alternative means for verifying signatures of individuals who have checked the appropriate box.
  • Directs an election officer to preserve the chain of custory of all ballots.
  • Directs the election officer to maintain a count of certain ballots.
  • Directs the election officer to ensure poll workers immediately count ballots received.
  • Lists all ballot handling and security items for which the election officer is responsible.
  • Requires election officers to keep recordings for at least 22 months.
  • Outlines certain stipulations of who may access recordings or photos and for what reasons they may be accessed.
  • Requires the director of elections to establish requirements and procedures to fulfill the chain of custody requirements, perform signature verification audits, and comply with reconciliation requirements.
  • Outlines signature audit requirements for election officers.
  • Changes the day for updating the audit data on the website from the Friday before the election to the Wednesday after the election.
  • Outlines requirements for the election officer to conduct ballot reconciliation.
  • Adds certain requirements to the election officer's report to the board of canvassers, including number of ballots counted, provisional ballots, the final ballot reconciliation report.

  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Petition Amendments
most_recent_action: Governor Signed in Lieutenant Governor's office for filing
categories: Oversight and accountability,Ballot access for candidates,Ballot measures (initiative and referendum),Ballot access deadlines
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Specifies the process for when a legislative body receives a petition for consolidating municipalities and consolidating counties, including timing of submission to the county clerk, and required actions by the county clerk.
  • Stipulates that a voter may have his or her signature removed from the petition for consolidating municipalities up to three business days after the day the county legislative body provides the petition to the county clerk by submitting a requesting statement via email or other electronic means, with certain requirements.
  • Stipulates that a voter may have his or her signature removed from the petition for consolidating counties up to three business days after the day the county legislative body provides the petition to the county clerk by submitting a requesting statement not via email or other electronic means, with certain other requirements.
  • Outlines required county clerk procedures to determine whether to remove the signature from the petition.
  • Outlines procedures for the county clerk when receiving a petition for disincorporation.
  • Stipulates that a voter may have his or her signature removed from the petition up to three business days after the petition is filed with the county clerk, by submitting a requesting statement via email or other electronic means, with certain requirements.
  • Outlines required county clerk procedures to determine whether to remove the signature from the petition.
  • Stipulates that a voter may have his or her signature removed from an incorporation petition up to three business days after the petition is filed with the county clerk, by submitting a requesting statement via email or other electronic means, with certain requirements.
  • Outlines required procedures for the lieutenant governor to determine whether to remove the signature from the petition, including determining if the signer is a registered voter.
  • Defines "legal voter."
  • Specifies the process for when a legislative body receives a petition for annexation of a portion of a county to an adjoining county, or for creation of a new county, or an initiating petition, including timing of submission to the county clerk, and required actions by the county clerk.
  • Stipulates that a voter may have his or her signature removed from the petition up to three business days after the day the county legislative body provides the petition to the county clerk by submitting a requesting statement not via email or other electronic means, with certain requirements.
  • Outlines required county clerk procedures to determine whether to remove the signature from the petition.
  • Specifies the process for when a legislative body receives a petition for registered voter adoption of an optional plan, or repeal of an optional plan, including required actions by the county clerk, including determining whether a signer is a registered voter.
  • Stipulates that a voter may have his or her signature removed from the petition up to three business days after the day the county legislative body provides the petition to the county clerk by submitting a requesting statement not via email or other electronic means, with certain requirements.
  • Outlines required county clerk procedures to determine whether to remove the signature from the petition.
  • Provides that a clerk of county, or municipal clerk, or recorder who receives a valid written withdrawal or reinstatement from a signer of a registered voter request or registered voter petition, will use outlined procedures to determine whether to remove or reinstate the individuals signature.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Defines "registered voter petition."
  • Provides that a county clerk receiving a registered voter petition shall assist a board of trustees or municipal clerk or recorder with determining whether a signer is a registered voter.
  • Stipulates that a voter may have his or her signature removed from the petition up to three business days after the day the county legislative body provides the petition to the county clerk by submitting a requesting statement not via email or other electronic means, with certain requirements.
  • Outlines required county clerk procedures to determine whether to assist a board of trustees, municipal clerk, or records to remove the signature from the petition.
  • Specifies related procedures for local building authority bonds.
  • Defines terms relevant to the manual initiative process and the manual referendum process.
  • Specifies who may sign a related petition and the signature process.
  • Requires sponsors or their agents to submit a signed and verified packet to the county clerk before 5pm and by certain specified deadlines for certain initiatives and for certain referendums.
  • Outlines guidelines and requirements for the submissions.
  • Specifies procedures and deadlines for the county clerk to determine whether a signer is a registered voter and their address.
  • Provides that a signer may have their signature removed from the petition and specifies procedures and deadlines.
  • Specifies procedures and deadlines for the county clerk to determine whether to remove a signature.
  • Prohibits anyone from retrieving a packet from the county clerk or making any alterations to a packet after it is submitted to the county clerk.
  • Makes conforming changes.
  • Provides that a municipal clerk will determine whether the required number of signatures of registered voters appear on a nomination petition, with the assistance of the county clerk.
  • Provides that a county clerk, city recorder, or town clerk will determine whether each petition signer is a registered voter, with the assistance of the county clerk.
  • Specifies signature removal procedures for nominating petitions for candidates for delegate to the ratification convention, and for initiative petitions for creation of new school districts, or consolidation of districts, or for transfer of a portion of a school district, and for entry into a privatization project.
  • Makes conforming changes.

summary:

  • Makes it a class A misdemeanor to tamper or interfere with election returns or the canvass.
  • Makes it a class A misdemeanor to interfere with election officials in their discharge of election duties.

summary:

name: Election Modifications
most_recent_action: Governor Signed in Lieutenant Governor's office for filing
summary:

  • Changes the official to which voters submit a voter registration form from the county clerk to the election officer
  • Changes the day on which a voter changing their party affiliation from one party to another takes effect from the day after the regular primary to the day after the statewide canvass for that year's regular primary
  • Modifies the procedure for an unaffiliated voter who wishes to affiliate with a party or an affiliated voter who wishes to become unaffiliated, provides that such a voter may submit a party affiliation form or a voter registration form to the county clerk or a poll worker, stipulates that any such form submitted between April 1 and the date of the regular primary election shall take effect on the day after the statewide canvass for the regular primary election 
  • Increases the required time of advanced  public notice that an election officer must give for the time and place of early voting and for the location of any ballot drop boxes from 19 to 28 days, and increases the advanced public notice that an election officer is required to give before testing automatic ballot tabulating equipment from 48 hours to 10 days
  • Increases the required time of notice that county clerks must give before any election from two to five days
  • Requires that ballots be prepared in the possession of election officers at least 7 days before the commencement of voting
  • Reduced the frequency of which voter registration audit reports must be delivered from biannually to biennially 
  • Removes certain ballot design requirements
  • Makes changes to the layout of physical ballots
  • Makes changes to how ballot initiatives and referendum petitions are presented and summarized on the ballot
  • Makes changes to the filing period for candidates of a qualified political party
  • Makes changes to the conflict of interest disclosure requirement

It would require that the outside of mail-in ballot envelopes include instructions for returning mail-in ballots (in the event that the individual to which a ballot was sent no longer lives at that address). name: President and Vice President; binding of electors, vacancies.

summary:

  • Stipulates that electors must vote for the required candidate.

  • Direct each political party to provide the State Board a list of qualified electors equaling the number of positions, along with the names of the party's candidates for President and Vice President for whom the electors must vote, by noon, 74 days before the election.
  • Applies timeline exceptions when a party's convention as after the 74th day before the election.
  • Outlines guidelines for appointing substitute electors in the case of a vacancy.
  • Provides that a group of qualified voters, who are not a political party, may nominate the appropriate number and geographic location of electors, to be printed on the official ballot, and specifies petition requirements and deadlines for the group.
  • Provides that if the group meets the petition and other requirements, their electors will be places on the official ballot and designated as "independent."
  • Provides vacancy rules for independent electors.
  • Outlines an appeal process for an elector who does not qualify through the petition process because of missing the minimum number of signatures.
  • Requires the State Board to develop a process for appeals.
  • Provides that voters will choose the electors every four years at the general election starting in 2024.
  • Outlines guidelines and timelines for convening electors and voting for President and Vice President, and provides for timeline exceptions if Congress changes dates.
  • Establishes that electors will be paid $50 per day.

name: Election officials, state and local; acceptance of certain gifts and funding prohibited.

summary: This bill prohibits state and local elections officials from soliciting, accepting, using, or disposing of any moneys, grants, property, or services given by a private individual or nongovernmental entity for the purpose of funding voter education and outreach programs, voter registration programs, or any other expense incurred in the conduct of elections. name: Elections; local electoral boards & general registrars to perform certain risk-limiting audits, etc.
most_recent_action: Governor: Acts of Assembly Chapter text (CHAP0443)
summary: This bill requires local electoral boards and general registrars to perform risk-limiting audits under the supervision of the Department of Elections and in accordance with the procedures prescribed by the State Board of Elections. The bill provides that localities are required to participate in such audits at least once every five years. The bill also provides that the Department shall submit a report on the results of such audits to the State Board. The provisions of the bill requiring that such audits be conducted for at least one randomly selected contested race for the General Assembly in the year of a general election for members of the General Assembly and for any other contested race that is necessary to ensure that each locality participates in a risk-limiting audit of an office within its jurisdiction at least once every five years or that the State Board finds appropriate have a delayed effective date of July 1, 2023. The provision of the bill requiring that such audits be conducted for at least one randomly selected contested race for an office that requires certification by the State Board in the year of general election for any local office has a delayed effective date of July 1, 2024. The bill also requires the Department to convene a work group to consider and propose a process and timeline for implementing risk-limiting audits of statewide contests

  • Requires the general registrars to use the information on the lists to carry out their duties.

  • Makes clarifying edits.

name: Voter registration; restoration of political rights upon release from incarceration.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: This bill provides that any person who loses his political rights as a result of a felony conviction shall be invested with those rights upon their release from incarceration and is entitled to register to vote. The bill directs the Department of Corrections and the State Board of Local and Regional Jails to transmit to the Department of Elections information for incarcerated persons with a pending date of release and requires the Department of Elections to process the information and make the necessary changes to the voter registration system to permit those persons to register to vote by the date of the person's scheduled date of release. On the date of an incarcerated person's release, the appropriate authority is required by the bill to provide a voter registration application, information on returning the form by mail or completing it by electronic means, and an official release document to serve as a safety net for voter registration. The bill amends the language regarding adjudications of mental incompetency for purposes of being qualified to vote; a person adjudicated to lack the capacity to understand the act of voting shall not be entitled to vote until that capacity has been reestablished.

name: Absentee voting; verification by social security number or unique identifier.

summary: This bill requires the State Board of Elections to promulgate regulations for providing a unique identifier to any qualified voter who lacks a social security number and provides that such unique identifier can be accepted in place of a social security number for the purposes of voting absentee. The bill makes optional the current absentee ballot witness signature requirement by giving the voter the option to provide the last four digits of the voter's social security number and the voter's date of birth in lieu of a witness signature. The bill clarifies that verification of the required voter affirmation on absentee ballots by the general registrar includes matching any date of birth and last four digits of the social security number or assigned unique identifier provided as part of the voter affirmation against the information in the voter's registration record.

Instead, the bill provides that such voter is entitled to cast a provisional ballot.

name: Absentee voting; unsolicited absentee ballot applications, required information.
most_recent_action: Passed by indefinitely in Privileges and Elections (9-Y 6-N)
summary: This bill requires any individual or organization sending an application for an absentee ballot to a registered voter that was not solicited or requested by the registered voter to include with the application instructions on completing the application and submitting it to the appropriate general registrar. The bill requires a statement that the application is not being sent by any state or local government official or agency on the envelope containing the application or on the first page of any enclosed materials. Such individuals and organizations are required to use the information provided in the list of registered voters acquired by such individual or organization from the Department of Elections pursuant to law, and a violation of this requirement is a Class 4 misdemeanor. The bill requires the Department of Elections to ensure, when providing the list of registered voters to such individual or organization for purposes of sending unsolicited absentee ballot applications, that no voter is included on the list provided if such voter has applied for an absentee ballot on or before the date the list is requested. The bill also provides that no absentee ballot sent to a registered voter that was not solicited or requested by the registered voter may be pre-populated with information the applicant is required to provide.

name: Elections; electronic return of voted military-overseas ballots.
summary: This bill directs the Commissioner of Elections to establish and supervise a pilot program by which an overseas voter who is a registered voter of a county or city participating in the pilot program may return his or her voted military-overseas ballot by electronic means. The Commissioner is required by the bill to produce standards and develop procedures for the secure transmission and return, storage, and processing of voted military-overseas ballots, including security measures, methods for verifying and authenticating a voter's identity, and encryption methods for the voted ballots. Counties and cities participating in the pilot program are required under the bill to participate in a security review after each election. In each year of the pilot program, the bill requires the Commissioner to conduct a security assessment and update the security measures for the pilot program. The bill also requires that voters eligible to return their military-overseas ballots by electronic means through the pilot program be permitted to sign the statement of voter and any other documents related to absentee voting using the digital signature associated with their respective Common Access Cards issued by the U.S. Department of Defense. The bill provides that the pilot program is in effect for elections held on and after January 1, 2023. The Commissioner is required by the bill to submit a report on or before December 1, 2027, on the outcomes of the pilot program and to include a recommendation on whether to implement the electronic return of voted military-overseas ballots on a permanent, statewide basis.

name: Voter registration; restoration of political rights upon release from incarceration.
categories: Voting by felons or incarcerated individuals
summary: This bill provides that any person who loses his or her political rights as a result of a felony conviction shall be invested with those rights upon release from incarceration and be entitled to register to vote. The bill directs the Department of Corrections and the State Board of Local and Regional Jails to transmit to the Department of Elections voter information for incarcerated persons with a pending date of release and requires the Department of Elections to process the information and make the necessary changes to the voter registration system to permit such persons to register to vote by the date of the person's scheduled date of release. On the date of an incarcerated person's release, the appropriate authority is required by the bill to provide a voter registration application, information on returning the form by mail or completing it by electronic means, and an official release document to serve as a safety net for voter registration.

name: School boards; method of selection, election required.
summary: This bill requires members of each school board in the Commonwealth be elected, rather than appointed.

name: Conduct of election; election results, post-election forensic audits.
most_recent_action: Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections Hearing (00:00 2/1/2022 SR 3/ Updated to include SJRs)
summary: This bill provides for the conduct of a forensic audit of an election in a county or city upon the request of certain officials or upon the petition of a group of residents of the locality in question. The bill provides that an audit includes a review of all materials, equipment, and procedures used during any part of the election, including ballots, pollbooks, voting machines, and routers. The bill requires that the audit be open to the public and states that the auditing process may include participation by residents. The results of the audit are to be presented to a jury of local residents who have to power to declare the election valid or invalid. The bill also gives the State Inspector General the power and duty to conduct an audit of the 2020 general election and requires him to produce a report of his finding.

name: Election officials, state and local; acceptance of certain gifts and funding prohibited.
most_recent_action: Subcommittee recommends laying on the table (8-Y 0-N)
summary: This bill prohibits state and local elections officials from soliciting, accepting, using, or disposing of any moneys, grants, property, or services given by a private individual or nongovernmental entity for the purpose of funding voter education and outreach programs, voter registration programs, or any other expense incurred in the conduct of elections. The bill specifically provides that the operation of a polling place or voter satellite office in a facility furnished by a private individual or nongovernmental entity is not a violation of this prohibition.

name: Voter identification; identification containing a photograph required.
categories: Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,In-person voter ID
summary: Requires presentation of a form of identification containing a photograph in order to vote. The bill repeals the provisions of law permitting a voter who does not have one of the required forms of identification to vote after signing a statement, subject to felony penalties for false statements, that he is the named registered voter he claims to be. Instead, the bill provides that such voter is entitled to cast a provisional ballot.

name: Voter identification; identification containing a photograph required.
categories: Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,In-person voter ID
summary: This bill requires presentation of a form of identification containing a photograph in order to vote. The bill repeals the provisions of law permitting a voter who does not have one of the required forms of identification to vote after signing a statement, subject to felony penalties for false statements, that he is the named registered voter he claims to be. Instead, the bill provides that such voter is entitled to cast a provisional ballot.

name: Absentee voting; reimbursement of costs to counties and cities for cost of conducting.
most_recent_action: Assigned App. sub: General Government and Capital Outlay
summary: This bill requires the General Assembly to establish in the general appropriation act a reimbursement plan to reimburse counties and cities, fully and annually, for the cost of conducting absentee voting in the locality.

name: Voter identification; identification containing a photograph required.
most_recent_action: Passed by indefinitely in Privileges and Elections (9-Y 6-N)

summary: Requires presentation of a form of identification containing a photograph in order to vote. The bill repeals the provisions of law permitting a voter who does not have one of the required forms of identification to vote after signing a statement, subject to felony penalties for false statements, that he is the named registered voter he claims to be. The bill repeals the provisions of law permitting a voter who does not have one of the required forms of identification to vote after signing a statement, subject to felony penalties for false statements, that he is the named registered voter he claims to be. name: Elections; removal of officers, recall elections, petition for recall.
most_recent_action: Referred to Committee on Privileges and Elections
summary: This bill provides for the removal of elected officers and officers appointed to elected offices by recall referendum. The bill requires a petition for recall be signed by 30 percent of the total number of votes cast at the last election for the office for which a recall is sought.

name: Elections; photo identification required, time for in-person absentee.
most_recent_action: Referred to Committee on Privileges and Elections
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Permanent lists,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,In-person voter ID,Early voting duration
summary: This bill requires the presentation of a form of identification containing a photograph in order to vote. The bill repeals the provisions of law permitting a voter who does not have one of the required forms of identification to vote after signing a statement, subject to felony penalties for false statements that he is the named registered voter he claims to be. Instead, the bill provides that such voter is entitled to cast a provisional ballot. The bill also limits absentee voting in person to the week immediately preceding an election. The bill repeals the provisions of law by which any registered voter may apply to receive absentee ballots for all elections in which he is eligible to vote and remains on the list until the voter requests in writing to be removed from the list, the voter’s registration is canceled or placed on inactive status pursuant to law, or the voter moves to a different address not in the same county or city of his registration. The bill also removes provisions allowing absentee ballots received after the close of polls to be counted.

name: Elections; voter identification containing photograph required, etc.
most_recent_action: Referred to Committee on Privileges and Elections
categories: Absentee/mail-in ballot deadlines,Absentee/mail-in ballot request processes,Drop-box availability,Voter ID for absentee/mail-in ballots,In-person voter ID,Witness or notary requirements,Early voting duration,Voter registration,Same-day/Election Day registration
summary: This bill requires the presentation of a form of identification containing a photograph in order to vote and provides that a voter who does not have one of the required forms of identification is entitled to cast a provisional ballot. The bill repeals a provision that would permit any person who is qualified to register to vote to do so in person up to and including the day of the election and limits the persons who are entitled to register to vote after the close of registration records to members of a uniformed service of the United States on active duty, persons who are residing temporarily outside of the United States, and their spouses and dependents. The bill limits the period during which absentee voting in person is available from 45 days to the 10 days immediately preceding the date of the election, including both Saturdays. The bill requires that absentee ballots returned by mail be returned to the office of the general registrar by the close of polls on election day and be postmarked on or before the Saturday preceding the date of the election. The bill eliminates the use of drop-off locations for the return of absentee ballots. The bill requires absentee ballot applications to contain the last four digits of the applicant's social security number and provides that the failure of an absentee ballot to include a witness signature is a material omission, rendering the ballot void.

name: An act relating to nominating petitions for a candidate for the office of a unified union school district board member
categories: Ballot access for candidates,Municipal election procedures
summary: As introduced, this bill changes the number of required valid petition signatures for a unified school board at-large candidate from 60 to 30 and adds the option to instead getting signatures from 1% of voters residing in the combined unified district, whichever is less. This bill also makes conforming changes.

name: An act relating to approval of amendments to the polling place provisions of the charter of the City of Burlington
most_recent_action: Read First Time and referred to the Committee on Government Operations and Military Affairs

name: An act relating to ranked-choice voting for presidential primary elections
most_recent_action: Read First Time and referred to the Committee on Government Operations and Military Affairs
summary:
As introduced, this bill:

  • Provides that a ranked choice ballot will be used in presidential primary elections.
  • Requires parties to confirm 150 days before the election which type of ranked choice voting they will use and explains the options.
  • Requires the secretary of state to notify the party at least 120 days before the election that the state is capable of implementing the party's preference.
  • Outlines rules for tabulating ballots in a ranked choice system, including the case of a tie.
  • Outlines rules for ranked choice voting results reporting.
  • Provides that the canvass committee must state the number of final round votes received by each candidate in their report.
  • Requires the secretary of state to provide voter information regarding ranked choice voting and to ensure design of appropriate tally and summary sheets, and returns.
  • Empower the secretary of state to adopt relevant rules.
  • Appropriates $2 million for implementation.
  • Defines relevant terms.

name: An act relating to approval of an amendment to the ranked choice voting provisions of the charter of the City of Burlington
most_recent_action: Read First Time and referred to the Committee on Government Operations and Military Affairs

name: An act relating to approval of amendments to the election boundary provisions of the charter of the City of Burlington
most_recent_action: Read First Time and referred to the Committee on Government Operations and Military Affairs

name: An act relating to approval of amendments to the voter qualification provisions of the charter of the City of Burlington
most_recent_action: Read First Time and referred to the Committee on Government Operations and Military Affairs

name: An act relating to miscellaneous changes to election laws
